review:
Yeah, it's somewhat of a paid demo and if you're only interested in the story this chunk provides you will be highly disappointed. 
On the other hand, if one is willing to dig deeper, Ground Zeroes has much to offer for its price. I adore it.

review:
As a MGS since the first Solid game (Played the older versions on a later date)  I can only as much recommend this game as any other, I have not played it as much but still love how awesome it feels to run, shoot, sneak and to choke someone.

Can't wait for Phantom Pain

All in all, 10/10 would be kept waiting again!

also "This will be the last Metal Gear" Kappa

review:
Is it a glorified tech demo? I would argue...no. It is not. This package stands on its own feet as the vanguard of MGS's rebirth on PC with the upcoming MGS V. I would define it as a limited open-world sandbox, a small slice of what to expect, as well as a prequel/setup of sorts for those of us MGS fans who have been waiting with bated breath for the next outing in the series. Of course, this made perfect business sense from Konami's perspective. I did not pay full price for this, getting it at the introductory sales time with approximately 40% off. I don't know if I would have gone for it at full whack.

So what do we get here? We get a solid impression of the new gameplay possibilities that will feature in MGS 5, superb enemy AI, solid backstory, and the tried-and-tested stealth 'em up mechanics we all know and love. What else? You get an intricately woven web of possibilities with a LOT of replay value and challenges for you to consider to retry and rediscover based on your play style and approach. There certainly *is* variety on offer here. 

Interesting to note that as the MGS series delves into its past, it proceeds to the most advanced ever technological and visual outing the series has seen so far. It is a paradox worthy of Kojima himself. The game looks gorgeous, with a multitude of graphics settings and customisation options. Audio is excellent. Gameplay-wise, the setting is immersive, challenging you to adapt as only the original stealth 'em up can. Of course, being an MGS fan is kind of a pre-requisite to getting your full play time's worth. The basic run took me about 4 hours, and I can see myself getting at least that much once again by completing side-ops and just dicking around in general. The only complaint I have as a spoilt PC gamer is that the checkpoint system means no saving on the fly.

Before I get to the review, here’s some personal backstory:

I was born in early 1992 and grew up with a PlayStation, but I have never played a Metal Gear game before this one. The last stealth game I played (not including the Elder Scrolls games, because their stealth mechanics don’t count) was Tom Clancy’s Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory on the Xbox, and that was released a decade ago (as of the writing of this review). I’ve heard a lot about the series, but it took a birthday gift from a close friend of mine to get Ground Zeroes (which I will abbreviate to GZ for the rest of this review).

I regret not buying this one release during the Steam Winter Sale; this game was awesome.

Unlike most AAA titles, GZ released on Steam with a $20 price tag (before the sale). This is because the game is essentially a tech demo to show off Hideo Kojima’s Fox Engine that will be used in The Phantom Pain (which I will abbreviate to TPP for the rest of this review). I never had any technical issues in the 27 hours running this game with my i5-4690K and my 280X, so it’s safe to say that this engine was incredibly well-made.

“Wait, you spent 27 hours in what you call a tech demo?”

There is only one story mission that will take even the newest of gamers no more than 2 hours to complete; it is a prologue to the events of TPP (not going to spoil anything). After you complete the story mission, you unlock a few “Side Ops” that have varying objectives. The open-world feel of GZ offers multiple ways for a mission to be complete (a quick search on YouTube would back me up on this). After you complete a mission, you’ll unlock the “Hard” difficulty for that mission as well as some gear to start with for that particular mission (granted you get a “C” Rank or better). Each mission also has a few optional objectives, most of them involving rescuing a prisoner or two.

The stealth mechanics, although not realistic, are definitely fun. Get too close in an enemy’s line of sight, and they’ll get suspicious and start searching the area for you. Stay in a camera’s lens for too long and the whole base knows exactly where you are. Sneak up too quickly behind a guy, and he’ll turn around and alert the base (which is the only map in the game, by the way; all missions have the same setting) unless you knock him out or kill him beforehand. Make sure you drag the bodies away, or their buddies will try to wake them up or alert the others if they find them. To assist in being sneaky, GZ allows you to “mark” an enemy, which essentially allows you to see them through obstructions granted you’re not moving or have the base on alert. You can also interrogate and disarm your foes to further help you in your missions. Explosives and even empty magazines can cause noise to divert your foes attention elsewhere while you sneak by.

Although you are aiming to avoid it, the combat in this game is well-done. There is CQC which allows you to knock out opponents in a cinematic way. Of course, there are also weapons such as a tranquilizer pistol, stun revolver, and your usual assortment of rifles and SMGs. You can toggle between third-person shooting and first-person shooting while aiming down the sights of your weapons. Certain weapons have attachments, such as silencers (which can break!) and lights to blind your foes.

What kept me playing this game were the collectibles and challenges, as well as a few hidden things. Completing a mission unlocks a challenge that you can do in the next play-through of that mission to unlock more challenges. These range from fastest marking of all enemies to fastest completion time and few other miscellaneous things. Steam keeps these records that you can look up and compare with your friends or with the rest of Steam.

I most certainly enjoyed my first Metal Gear experience, and this definitely won’t be the last. Now I remember why I liked Splinter Cell so much when I was younger and I think it’s time for me to be more invested in stealth games. I do want to go back and play the Metal Gear series from the beginning, but I have too much in my library to catch up on.

Also, I probably missed reviewing some parts of GZ. I’ll edit this as I figure that out.

9/10

Edit: Formatting and some wording.

review:
[h1] OMG, that is CRAP, really. It's a demo. [/h1] 
Playtime: 25-30 minutes, Playtime in stealth 45-60 minutes, Cutscences: 55 minutes. 
This is a one-level mission, you can finish it in about 1 hour and a half. 
After the first run, you unlock a bunch of sidequests, in the same level. 

[b]Stealth? WTF?![/b]
It's the worst stealth game I've ever played. I'd loved Deus Ex, Hitman: Absolution and DARK, but the stealth-part in the game isn't really stealth.

[b]Gameplay, GUI etc.[/b]
You cannot change keybindings and it's a crappy console-port with no story. I don't know if it's better on PS4, but I played the PC-Version. You have to Press 1 or 3 to go forward or back in the menu and you can't use the mouse in the menu either. In-Game the keys often doesn't work as they should, so you have to restart the checkpoints, because there is no option to save.

Steam-Overlay isn't working and so you didn't have the option to take screenshots, too.

[b]Yes or No?[/b]
Definitive: No. I had Phantom Pain on my whishlist and deleted it, after finishing the demo-mission for the first time. The content of the cut-scenes are horrible, the graphics are good, but the writing is really really bad. I face palmed so much or nodded my head or rolled with my eyes.
Waste of money, really - and time. 

I will not enjoy the next hours of replaying this boring Demo-Mission to get all 100%-achievements... ^^

EDIT:
So, after finishing all the achievements (almost 29 hours), I didn't changed my opinion and uninstalled it immediately. I will never play it again.

review:
Like all worthwhile love-letters, this game makes its point succinctly, and beautifully.  It doesn't tread its way through page after page with pointless nothings and needless filler, it takes up a little more than a paragraph or two of your time, and leaves you yearning for another verse.  Like all good love-letters, you'll find yourself wanting to read it through again and again, just to see the affection laced between every word.  

It's been a long seven years, Snake, and we've missed you so terribly.  Welcome back, old friend.

review:
Just moments ago I achieved 100% in Ground Zeroes. Having said this, I've still to complete all time trials, yet I've been enetertained for just shy of 35 hours. I dont regret a single second of that time.

As a veteran to the series, my first hour or so was spent aclimating to the new systems of stealth. Nothing short of a complete overhall. Gone are the days of simple CQC run bys ala MGS3 whereby enemies were obstacles in your path to the next zone. Now every enemy is a threat; And I love it.

If you enjoy the stealth genre you'll be in good hands with Ground Zeroes. If you enjoy Metal Gear, you better be reading this review with a copy in your steam library. Good luck getting 100%.

(PC version is wonderfully optimised too.)

9/10
+ Genuine Stealth Action.
+ Expressive game design. Take on missons how you see fit.
+ Chrom works for Skullface confirmed

- Unshakable lack of cardboard boxes
- "She surfife"

review:
May seem like a tech demo for MGS: 5 at first, but there is a lot of re-playability once you have completed the main mission. I haven't played many games in the MGS franchise, but Ground Zeroes holds true to the Kojima style of blending seriousness with humor in a perfect fashion. 
Know what you are buying before you purchase, try all the missions before giving up on the game as they all add new elements of gameplay the previous modes may not have had.

review:
Overall this is a pretty great game. Yes the "cannon" mission is pretty short but the side missions and multiple other objectives in the game definately make it a fair value in my opinion. It is definately just a taste of the full MGS V game and makes you really want the actual Phantom Pain to drop. 

Overall this is a decent PC port. Interacting with some of the menus is really janky if you are using a mouse and Keyboard, and the controls for these can't be set in the options menu. Overall I'd give the game a B. It is great getting you ready for MGS V: TPP, but if you are not interested in completeing the different achievements in the game there probably isn't enough value to justify the price-tag. 

TL:DR - Short, but a great game for metal gear fans and people who like challenging achievements.

review:
First off, this is a prologue not a demo! Just want to clear things up there.
This game is an important aspect if you are looking to play The Phantom Pain because it shows how Snake ended up where he does in the beginning of TPP. The amount of side missions makes up for the short but sweet story mission which in true Kojima style, is doubled in length by its beautiful cinematics.
Also the game plays amazingly smooth considering its level of graphical details and feels like it was almost made for PC only and didn't release on consoles first.
A definite buy.

review:
Metal Gear Appetizer.

Ground Zeroes is pretty much a demo that acts as a prologue for the upcoming title The Phantom Pain. The main mission is over quickly, but you're encouraged to re-deploy to the same base on side missions or to explore the area for secrets and collectables. 

Fans of the series will find a very bite-sized example of the open-ended gameplay coming in The Phantom Pain. You can bet there will be a huge map with several bases like this for Snake to infiltrate at his leisure.
a demo which is worthwhile

review:
Its a fun game and its great to be playing Snake again after playing Raiden for so long I was getting bored.
Ah well here is some information for everyone sense reviews go here.

-Does not play like MGS 1,2, & 3 (not sure on four haven't played it.)
-Controls for a PC 360 controls do not act like the classic controls so had to re-learn them
-Game is a pre-story for the Phantom pain coming out in September.
-Game is really short, seriously I think the world record is ten minutes now.
-Its not David voice acting Snake
-No seriously, It is a really freaking short game.

review:
I put over 18 hours into a  30 minute prologue just get it.

Essentially a sandbox showing off some of the new features in Metal Gear Solid V, the controls are tight and the replay value is almost endless even though the story mode of Ground Zeroes is only roughly half an hour long to the average player. As someone who's played a few of the MGS games (including MGS3, Portable Ops, Peace Walker, and MGS1 itself), I can definitely say this series has never been better. Get hyped for The Phantom Pain. Only a couple months now!

review:
I am biased as I am a massive fan of the entire series of Metal Gear and Metal Gear Solid. Been playing since MGS1, never missed a game - always played each at least three times.

So, when this came out and everyone comlained at the length, I didn't mind so much. The game itself is bloody great, yes the map is one small location, and there's one main mission and a few side missions. But there are so many ways you can approach each one, it gets tactical, stealthy, actiony, and great fun. Not to mention how mechanically sound it is and how beautiful it looks.

If you are new to the Metal Gear series, it may seem a little daunting as the story given is fairly minimal - but just playing this you can understand the story of this game and how it preludes MGSV The Phantom Pain - just, not it's standing in the wider lore which can be explained and discussed for days.

Overall, yeah, bloody great.

review:
God I love this game so fucking much

If you are a fan of Metal Gear, buy it right now

If you are not, either from disliking or lack of playing, this game might just change your mind

There is just so much damn detail in this game, from CQC to map design to secrets to bonus features to gunplay to replayability, you name it.

Also, calling all MGS1 fanboys, be sure to grab every XOF patch ;)

this is probably a late ass review its just that i get tired of hearing the phrase '20 dollar demo' to this very day :/

review:
If you're a REALLY BIG fan of the Metal Gear franchise and plan on getting The Phantom Pain - you should get this, too. Even though really lacking in content, gameplay-wise it's a very solid piece, and a great introduction to the story of why things happened the way they happened at the beginning of The Phantom Pain. You also get a little bonus in the "sequel" for playing this, such as Snake's costume and some of the prisoners you've exctracted as the staff of Mother Base.

Otherwise - do not waste your money. I, myself, enjoyed it dearly.

review:
Playing this game is like sex, depending on who you are.
You'd be hot and bothered, and aroused in some way, when you start, you'd do it on a table, and the experience is very enjoyable.
But when you're finished, you're either left wanting more (Phantom Pain), or you feel a bit bad, maybe a weird twisted mixup of both.
Always use protection when you're playing.

review:
On my old pc, i couldn't even run this game on the lowest setting, now with my new pc, nvidia graphics intel cpu, i can run this game no problem on the highest setting, 60fps.

Oh i forgot. this game is really good, 10/10 

buy it.

Worth playing but don't try to pay very much for it as it feels quite incomplete.  The mechanics are quite good, Kiefer Sutherland does a fine bit of work though I see no reason for the change, and the main mission and the Deja Vu mission are laden with Kojima's style.  My only complaint is that it feels like a handful of VR missions and a demo (the main mission stands out as the main mission, however it does that; just seems more effort was put into it).  All the missions are good.  The game is gorgeous as well, if you care about that type of thing.

My only complaints are the length of the main mission, the odd function that you're apparently invisible once you're crawling (I've crawled past guards' feet essentially as close as I could be without touching them and they didn't seem to mind), and that it doesn't feel like the 1970s with all that iDroid stuff.  The only proper complaint is the length however.

The story is intriguing and the main mission is art.  I can't wait for Phantom Pain.
A masterpiece. As pure a gameplay experience as you can find. Well, well worth the money.

review:
You can tell that a game is very polished when the audio cues, animation, control and gameplay mechanics generate a solid combination of immersion and fun. Learning the many ways of interacting with the game world and the story are how you should be playing this game to get the most out of it. Holding up guards, creating distractions and making the whole base fall asleep while you're at the edge of getting spotted all the time are just few of the ways you can get a godlike feeling.

It's also a canon MGS by Hideo Kojima. By that I mean you simply cannot get better quality spy drama, action, humor and stealth. That much you should already know when we're talking about Kojima. This is a strong prologue for a game that will most certainly contest the GOTY awards of many gaming critics.

Some get under an hour of gameplay out of this game since the main mission is that long, but I got 46 hours figuring out how to 100% the whole game and doing some challenges. Only finishing the first mission I believe gives you 8%. This game is worth it if you're into the world of MGS and would like to get something cool in MGS Phantom Pain when it releases.



Now that Phantom Pain has been released for quite a while and I ended up here again, I'm going to say Ground Zeroes was more entertaining as whole. The fact that the difficulty is balanced around your gear and thus there's no time spent grinding for materials you then would use for hundreds of statistical upgrades makes this a lot better game than PP.

Ground Zeroes is more like the older MGS (not Peacewalker) in the sense that you acquire new gear on site and have no need to return to base to do some tedious micromanaging. No interruptions, just pure gameplay and cinematics from start to finish. It's at least 10 times shorter, but it's also much more gamelike.

review:
Heed My WORDS!  DO NOT BUY THIS DEMO! ...It's not worth its current asking price of 20 bucks, wait for a discount or another price cut. This game should cost 10 dollars or less. (IT'S EARLY DLC for the Phantom Pain) Now, you will notice that I invested (more like, wasted) 200 plus hours playing this DEMO. That's because I am a fan of the MGS series, I never played it on consoles untill recently on PC and I get addicted to demos (or games) with superb gameplay! It's awesome, i will not deny that. However, not everyone will find this DEMO as enticing as i have and my reverence for the Metal Gear series does not prevents my inner responsible-consumer from talking. IT'S WAY TOO SHORT AND IT WILL LEAVE YOU CRAVING FOR MORE just like I am right now!!! Wait for the Phantom Pain to be released to play this Ground Zeroes fiasco along with it.

I need my MGSV fix... Hurry the heck up Kojima!!!

review:
This is a ripoff, the 'story' is finished in about 45 minutes, and that is INCLUDING watching the cut-scenes. Actual playing time maybe 30-35 minutes.

Adding to that, I have to say I'm somewhat disappointed with the 'stealth' gameplay as well. After triggering the first alarm, I went on and simply shot all the dudes coming at me instead of trying to get back to cover, and guess what... 5 minutes of searching, and then everyone forgot about the homicidal maniac running around their MILITARY BASE, and went on to business as usual.

Did this a few times, and after piling up 40 dead bodies, called in the extraction chopper, right in front of the C3 since I was too lazy to find a safe spot, in the freaking middle of the base.

Did the opponents care? Not really, they were like whatever dude, just a random unidentified chopper landing in our base, probably no connection whatsoever with that guy that just killed 40 of our guys minutes ago. He probably escaped anyway, no point in searching anymore, or securing the perimeter, or checking out what that chopper is doing...

Pretty weak for a title that supposedly provides good stealth action. Not going to buy the full game when it comes out, as the demo I just bought is maybe...

3/10

review:
This is my second review (i'm Bad English but this game is awesome) after 20+ hours played this game.
The Good:
- Impressed AI and environent.
- Excellent Gameplay, more comfortably and freely.
- Very good port.
- Great combination between Stealth action and "Semi-sandbox". You can choose the way to finish mission. More replayable.
- Very good Prologue. Cassettes make me chilling....
- Graphic likes Movie.
- Difficult enough to makes you crazy (if you choose CQC only way lol)
- Achievements

The Bad:
- Sometime AI has "super vision" can see us through the wall.... and AI has some stupid acts.
- Too short..... very short.....
- I have a nightmare when play this game because Sniper experience..... It's terrable......
- Quite easy to "mastering" mission (without shitty aiming)

Hoping Metal Gear Solid V The Phantom Pain.... and ready to RIP my wallet......

review: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is ,yes, a playable demo. But that doesn't mean you shouldn't buy it. It's a preivew of the upcoming open world Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, which is the TRUE MGSV. While I wouldn't recommend buying it at it's full price of $20.00, you should buy it during a sale. For MGS fans waiting patienly for the next game, I would say that this is a must buy to see what you're gonna be up against. For newcomers into the Metal Gear franchise, I wouldn't willingly reccomend this to you unless you've played previous games in the franchise (Peace Walker, Snake Eater, etc.)

review:
My body is ready for The Phantom Pain, just like it has been for all other Metal Gear games prior. This game is what you'd expect from a Metal Gear Solid game. Fun, nice mixture of action and stealth and the ability for the player to approach the situation as they see fit. It's really setting the foundation of the story for TPP and after being kept waiting for a long while, the legendary Snake is back and boy is my Snake Solid. 
I've got 100% on this game and it took me a fair while, you could play through the story once and complete all the side ops but I really think to get your money out of the game you should go for the full completion. Although it's not for everyone as it can be tricky getting everything on S, yet still, a challenge is entertaining.
This is only a taster of what TPP is going to be and I can say with confidence it's going to be orgasmic. If you're a fan of the Metal Gear Solid, get this, if you liked the games prior then you'll love this and it'll really feed your hype for TPP.

review:
Things have changed a lot from earlier Metal Gear Solid games. It's still quite dialogue and cutscene heavy, but it's not the excessive level of earlier games. It all quite clearly serves a purpose now, and gets back to the gameplay rather than mess about too much out of gameplay once it has actually started.

Gameplay has changed too, with the scale of undetected to caught being more progressive. There's no more binary states for these, and the level genuinely is huge and expansive. So not only do you have plenty of places to go to try to evade chasing guards, but any guards who come to help their friends will actually travel from their post elsewhere on the map to do so rather than just spawn in when it's convenient for them. Everything's more intuitive and eloquent simply because it all occurs organically.

And the big point everyone fixates on; length. It's short, but remember it's not full price. And the extra missions on the side will keep you busy with their twists and changes to the gameplay even if they're not canon. I magnified my time in the main mission in these side/extra ops several times over. And that's the whole point of Ground Zeroes being separate too; It's so we can see how MGS5 gameplay works in advance of the full game. And it's all there. We get a taste of how sneaking gameplay works, more combat oriented gameplay, vehicle sections, and it all works really well.

The PC version's very good too. It looks fantastic and runs great. Some people may be bothered by the 60fps cap, but it's not hard to reach it and it's enough for most people. PC controls are great to use and the mouse aiming's good, with acceleration available but disabled by default. The only problem I've personally had is it doesn't handle aspect ratios wider than 16:9.

Definitely one I recommend to people who like stealth games!

Definitely has me excited for the Phantom Pain. I got it on sale and i reccomend you do too though, as it definetly isn't a full game, more of a prologue for the full game.

review:
Too difficult, and very frustrating. They need an easy mode. If you blink an eye you are caught by the enemy or the cameras. In seven hours I have yet to complete the first mission. Blue wheel spins in the middle of the screen if you use a controlled on a PC. Lots of lag as well. Another disapointment is that they use the same map for every mission. How lazy! Games a waste of money.

UPDATE: After one completes four missions on normal, one has to go back and then complete them at HARD beforel you can unlock other missions. Very disappointing game.

review:
Favourite series of all time by my favourite developer. I am so grateful to them for releasing on PC. If they didn't, I would have to buy a PS4 for literally just two games; this and Phantom Pain.

Beautifully made game. Runs perfectly. This is a lesson in optimisation. Konami have come along and got top marks on THEIR FIRST TRY. How long have Ubisoft been doing a horrible job of porting their overated games? Too long. Look at the mess they made of Unity. They disgust me and I can only hope that they get what's coming to them.

This is a lesson in PC game porting. Please, PC community, let us reward this effort by purchasing Phantom Pain when it comes out.
Great demo! :)

review:
This game is a massive shift in tone compared to the other Metal Gear Solid games. 

I’m not commenting on the gameplay, I want to comment on the story. I’m also not commenting on whether the price justifies the amount of content. These have been covered in other reviews. My main topic here hasn’t.

This is not a combination of the serious and the silly that you usually see in a Metal Gear Solid game. This game is very violent. I had trouble watching some of the cut scenes. I also gave up on listening to the extra tapes you get as rewards for completing missions because of how devastating they were emotionally. I am a fan of the series. I have played 1 to 4 and Peacewalker and enjoyed each one for their gameplay and their ability to broach sensitive or important or esoteric topics with a large degree of skill. 

One of the great things about Metal Gear Solid is that characters have pasts. There have always been disturbing elements in MGS, but they have usually been related to you through a character. This means that, in some sense, the very act of the character telling you a story of a disturbing event in their past allow a character to demonstrate a degree of autonomy and decision making. When a character describes their past they demonstrate awareness of both the event and how it impacted their thoughts and actions.  In other words, the way in which an event is described reveals something about both the event, and a characters current motivations. This provides context to the event, and also serves to prevent a spectacle.

 This game gives you the spectacle by showing you an event and not having it mediated through the character that is experiencing it. In fact, this game seems to go out of its way to remove context and character autonomy by not even allowing characters to comment on the events or their own motivations. 

All you are left with is a horrifying spectacle devoid of context or purpose beyond its own enjoyment. 

So if you enjoy horrifying spectacles and extreme emotional reactions then this is the game you want to play. In this respect it is very well made. It would have taken a lot of skill to do this. Otherwise, if you want something with a story or tone that was in the vein of previous MGS games you may want to atleast be aware that it might be different to what you are expecting. I personally found it too extreme, which is why I don’t recommend it. 

P.S I realise I may be in a minority here. Nonetheless I include this review because there is bound to be someone out there who would like a metaphorical speed bump to prevent them from speeding headlong into this without some kind of warning.

review:
pretty fun. i haven't "gotten the feel" for the gameplay mechanics as well has i have 1/2/4... YET.

my only problem is that it took around 2 hours of fiddling just to even get it to run on Server 2008 R2 (and i've only played Ground Zeroes 3.4 hours). the only game worse than this is the X Series. just about every other game was fixable with about 4-5 files soon after OS install, save for Recettear. also, the game crashes just after the credits, so i have no idea if there's anything after that in the way of story.

review:
first off, i am, like so many others, not recommending this game due to its limited scope.  is it fun? yes. is it worth 20 bucks? not really.  i am not exactly disappointed, since i knew what to expect, but this game doesnt really tide me over while waiting for the phantom pain either.  metal gear solid 4 is one of my favorite games of all time by the way. 
   the stealth is challenging, with patience probably ones biggest virtue.  the environment is passably full of activity, though not as varied as i hoped. it is, after all, a single level. im likely to spend more time in this game, and it is likely to grow on me as i get better at it.  
   weapons are my biggest complaint. you get the (now seemingly standard) 4 weapon slots, having to put something down to pick up a new weapon. i hate that. i want mgs4 style weapon mongering, where i can keep any weapon i find and use whatever i want. i will be ok if you can only carry 4 weapons with you, so long as there are permanent upgrades and a cache to choose from between missions.  call of duty style weapon management (you get 4 weapons, trade one for something you find if you want it) sucks.  in order for a game to keep me playing, i must be able to accumulate weapons and upgrade them.  i really hope they didnt fuck this up...
    overall, splinter cell blacklist is a better game in many ways.  stealth is great, but options are best.  i hope the team keeps mostly the same formula as mgs4 (and takes some ques from blacklist) while developing the phantom pain. they could really fuck this up for me if they dont stick to the important parts of the formula. for now, i'll spend some more time in this glorified demo and keep my fingers crossed.

    overall, splinter cell blacklist is a better game in many ways.  stealth is great, but options are best.  i hope the team keeps mostly the same formula as mgs4 (and takes some ques from blacklist) while developing the phantom pain. they could really fuck this up for me if they dont stick to the important parts of the formula. for now, i'll spend some more time in this glorified demo and keep my fingers crossed.", "timestamp_created": 1424016492, "timestamp_updated": 1424016492, "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 1, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.44433295726776123", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: This is truly a must have game for anyone that loves the Metal Gear franchise. But it's also great for newcomers. The main story line may be short, but that doesn't mean that there isn't any replay value from it. If you go for the 100% completion like I did. You find yourself playing over 30 hours guaranteed! Shortly said. Ground Zeroes is a very polished game in itself. And it gives you a taste of what's to come on the massive MGSV: The Phantom Pain!

review:
Although it's quite short MGS:GZ is a ton of fun. There's a million ways to approach every mission, there's a good variety of stealth techniques to choose from, and there's a decent selection of weapons as well. Plus, it runs great, achieving a solid 60 FPS whilst still looking stunning. 

If this little teaser is anything to go by then MGS: The Phantom Pain looks set to be one of the best MGS games since MGS3: Snake Eater. I can't wait!

review:
I was initially very excited to play this game, Metal Gear Solid being one of my all-time favorite game series. I bought this game in folly without doing any research thinking there was no way a MGS title could disappoint and that I had gotten quite a deal with the price.

Wrong. The main story of this game offers 2 hours, maybe 2 and a half, of gameplay. That's assuming that like myself you play reserved and stealthy at all times. The game offers several "side-missions" which will all be played on the same limited map as the initial mission, the only difference being different objectives that are nearly as limited as the battleground.

This was, in my eyes, a blatant cash grab. If you enjoy short games with minimal main game content that will leave you feeling forced to play side missions in order to feel as if you haven't just been robbed, then this game is for you.

To be fair, this game was half of a "complete" title. Buying two games to feel as if I've played ONE is not my forte. Not that it would matter as this is the last MGS title I will purchase.

review:

This is the shortest game i have ever played, only one map, and you have to ask yourself: would i pay $20 for this game? My suggestion is wait till its dirt cheap, then purchase it if your a fan of the franchise.

review:
Ground Zeroes is the latest entry in the Metal Gear Solid saga. It's story takes place after the events of Metal Gear Solid 3, Metal Gear Solid Portable ops and Metal Gear solid Peace walker.  This game is the first in the series to make use of the Fox engine, a completely new game engine aimed at creating a new generation of games. Gameplay wise this definitely shows, movement feels more controlled and enemies seem to move around more realistically. This does seem to make the game a lot harder then previous Metal Gear games (especially with reflex mode turned off) which is something people interested in this game should take into account.

Now to cover the inevitable elephant in the room when talking about this game: It's pretty short. The game has around 6 missions all taking place in the same area. However only one of those missions really matters to the story and depending on your skill can be finished in about half an hour, with the rest being more like bonus missions with true Kojimaesque eastereggs. Some argue that this makes the game a paid demo. Now I wouldn't go as far as to claim that myself, but story wise the game definitely leaves it's players hungry for more.

Speaking of which, another major controversy surrounding this game would be it's macabre ending. Now I won't spoil it for anyone reading this review since they likely haven't played the game yet, but needless to say this game isn't for the faint of heart. Which isn't necessarily bad however. As it elavates the games plot to a more mature level not seen before in videogames.

So would I recommend Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes? Yes, but if players feel they might be getting too little bang for their buck I would recommend them to get this game on sale.

review:
i don't know I can't play the bloody thing.BS waste of money.just crashes upon loading I get a white arrow that goes clockwise and stops about 3 oclock.I have to restart my computer again! WTF

Credit where credits due - Thank you steam I have retracted my previous review and changed to "recommended"  as the game is now fixed with no issues. Thank you for sorting this out :-)
By the way the games awesome hit the "purchase" button NOW..

Incredibly small map (you can stand just about anywhere and see all the edges) and just one mission. The side missions are a joke. Having played proper games like the Call of Duty , Battlefield or even Sniper Elite franchises, I wonder how the developers of MGSV have the cheek to charge what they do. This MGSV GZ would rate as a cheap DLC anywhere else and can not be considered as a full game. Sure, it played well enough on PC but all those folks who raved about it must have extremely low expectations.
I hope the developers realise what a rip-off this is and at least make the next few installments free of charge to purchasers of Ground Zeroes. That might just redeem it.

review:
A fantastic beginning to what I expect to be an even more fantasic story. Looks incredible, plays amazingly, and filled with fanservice and easter eggs. Despite peoples complaints of it being too short, you can spend hours upon hours trying to S-rank all the missions and explore every nook and cranny. Even now, people are finding out new things about this game!

That being said, unless you REALLY want this game and/or you're a huge MGS fan, don't buy this game until it goes on sale. I hate to say it, but I'd say the ideal price for this should be $9.99-$14.99.

review:
This game was the first MGS game that I've ever played, but I was very interested in the game ever since I saw the first trailer video for Phantom Pain, so I read up on the story before Ground Zero came out(Bought it on PS4). I really like this game, true there isn't that much gameplay to the main mission, but lots of side missions to do. But what really captivated me was the story overall, after lots of hours researching the story. 

Graphics are great, superb animations, sounds/music, Ai. Like many in the other reviews keep saying, the Ai is amazing, how they react to certain situations is just astonishing.

If you haven't played any MGS before, and know nothing about the story, I'd say it doesn't really matter, I guess it just makes more sense if you know, but you get the gist from the dialogue in the game. Save the targets, save the day. 

SPOILER!!: When I was playing the game, I was really impressed by the dialogue of the characters, graphics, animations, everything was great. However I never really found anything special about the game, until I came to the tortured Paz. Nothing really special about it, torture in games happens often, however when I found these "Tapes" of the torture it just became SO MUCH more feeling to the whole thing. The sounds of Paz being tortured, raped and all kinds of sick stuff. Now that is something I wasn't used to see in games, a much darker side of the story, more detail. I really wanted to kill "Skull Face" or whatever his name is, after these tapes. It was really messed up, but gave so much more feeling to the game and if Phantom Pain has anything unexpected like this, I will be such an amazing game.

Overall I like the game, one of the best of 2014, even though it's short, unless you go for 100% completion, then it's quite a long game for the price. But it sure is better than most titels that came out in 2014.

review:
[h1] My Review of MGS V: Ground Zeroes[/h1]

[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=778Sr8ePnWc]Check out the Entire MGS Overarch Story - If you didn't know it already.[/url]

[olist]
    [*]Gameplay [9/10] - Probably the best Tactical Espionage game I have played until now. The Game Mechanics, The A.I, The openess in how you approach your Mission objectives. It's all top notch, I don't know about others but whoever did the porting of this game did a damn good job if you ask me. This is after all how a Port should be done and the fact that this game is just a preview of what Phantom Pain will be - I am just speechless (No literally I can't speak anymore, need to go to a doctor).

    [*]Story [8.5/10] - Now I wish I could have given 10 or at least a 9 here in this but that would be cheating, after all I am trying to give a genuine review of this game. This individual story is quite good, you have everything that you need to know provided in the back-story and casette tapes. The cutscene directions, the wonderful voice acting - all has been done near to perfection. However when you play this game for the first time (Like me) - All I knew about Metal Gear was Snake - I didn't knew who was who and all that stuff and honestly speaking - it's not quite easy to get hold of it either unless of course, you're a die hard fan which I wasn't - so what about us. Maybe someone else will provide you with a different solution but mine is simple, watch the video series (The Link I provided above - it will bring you up to speed on the entire MGS lore) and once again that video series if for people who don't know much about the MGS Story or they are confused in some parts. That will surely help them, it surely helped me - Now I know everything about MG ^_^ (Boo Yea).

    [*]Total Score [9.5/10] - This game for me is value for money, it provides hours and hours of gameplay - I am 12 hours in game and I still have to collect a few of the achievements that are left. So overall you get at least - 5 hours of gameplay if you're a player who likes to rush through things and over 20+ hours - if you're an achivement hunter and a completionist. This game sets a very good stage for what's in store for us - Phantom Pain (The name sends a shiver down my spine), that game will be epic. I don't know what others will do with this game but for me it surely will be one Hell of an Epic game, for me it will be one of the best games of 2015. 
[/olist]

Do I recommend it? - HELL YES, after all if I don't - Naked Snake aka Big Boss will come find me, which I don't want. *Psssst - I hear a helicopter, gosh I am too late in writing this review, Snake is here D:* *Runs around in circles and hides inside a box*

review:

I played it like a fiddle... because I'm pretty good.

review:
Even when it's a very short game during the main story, it has very addictive extras and you have to take in count that this game it's like a teaser for the MGSV The Phantom Pain.
Even when it's a PC port, I don't found glitches or technical problems of any kind, runs very smooth in my average notebook with a discrete "nVidia GT 740M" card with full HD resolution and Extreme configuration graphics.
I am a real fan of this series and the most I played this game I am more exited for the Phantom Pain!

I really cry at the end of this game, I was so immersed in the story (I am following The Big Boss story since the MGS Snake Eater) that I feel like it was happening to me... It's an amazing game with an awesome story... 
If you hasn't played MGS Snake Eater and MGS Peace Walker I recommend you to play them to understand the story correctly ;)

review:
Seven hours only in the campaign mission. Sent every soldier in the camp to sleep. Laughed when they started the alert states since no one was awake. Ran around like a moron for couple of hours. Then after I realized there were no threaten, finished the mission.

9/10    First game that made me feel Anger and vengeance. 

Next game is really got its name accurate (Phantom of Pain), I will definitely kill those Bitches for Mother Base.

This game can be short if thats just the way you want to see it. But there is MUCH more to this game than a lot of people give it credit for. 

The Fox Engine is clearly a great looking and optimized engine that works on all platforms. The level of detail possible is really something else. This is all done while the game runs extremely well, and hardly any hicups even when the Graphic settings are pushed to the max. 

The action feels tense and can have a great deal of difficulty. This all the more adds to the stealth of the game, trying to avoid conflicts, as they can be difficult to escape. This game has shown me that the Phantom Pain will be a damn good game, and I cant wait to get my paws on it.

review:
High quality stealth action videogame.

( plus )

Modern Stealth Gameplay
Fluid Character's Movements
Satisfying Difficulty (If played as a stealth purist)
Amazing "Sandbox-Style" map
Many different approaches to the same goals
AMAZING Graphics

( minus )
Only one (Even if very big and articulated) map
Needs too much patience to complete achievements (Some of which ask you to complete the same missions over and over and over again)
The game can be completed in a very short time, if played without chasing the ultimate stealth experience.
Makes the wait for the phantom Pain even harder than it used to be

review:
I'm a huge Metal Gear Solid fan but I was skeptical about the port to steam since, let's face it, many console ports haven't made a smooth transition to pc as of late but Kojima definitely ensured a quality port that actually ends up feeling like its native platform was pc to begin with.

Mouse and keyboard support is spot on! the keys are mapped in a very intuitive way, keys are also stream lined so that several keys share different functions rather than having to contort a finger reaching for some ridiclous punctuation key. Most console ports have been plagued with mouse smoothing (which can't be disabled in some cases) but right from the get-gp the mouse is precise and responsive, unfortunately there is no mouse support in the menus but meh, that's really a small nit pick.

Anyone complaining that Ground Zeroes doesn't pack a lot of content is sorely mistaken. The main campaign takes at least an hour for skilled players to complete on normal difficulty (far more if you try to accomplish challenges and play on hard difficulty) plus there is a slew of side missions. All in all this "demo" as people call it can easily run you 30 to 40 hours of gameplay, which isn't too shabby for the price.

Either way Ground Zeroes accomplishes what it sets out to do in the first place: It makes me want Metal Gear Solid 5 The Phantom Pain far more than I already did to begin with so hurry the **** up already Kojima! I want more!!

review:
If you invest over 24 hours into what is considered to be a 2 hour, 1 mission demo, is it still a demo?

Haha all joking aside Metal Gear Solid: Ground Zeroes is a prologue of sorts serving towards the upcoming highly anticipated Phantom Pain and this simply wet my appetite even more for the upcoming game and all the amazing potential it may have, if this one short "demo" had me addicted and invested until 100% completion imagine the main course?

Once again Mr Kojima has pulled it off with flying colors and while it may be simply be one medium sized map taking place on a Cuban blacksite it yearns to be replayed again in different variations of missions, collectables, and competitive rankings worldwide for who can do (the longes tranqualizer shot) best. 

Story: "!WARNING some minor spoilers below, skip this section if you wanna come in clean not knowing anything"

In the aftermath of the Peace Walker incident, Paz Ortega Andrade is missing and presumed to be dead. Under the direction of Kazuhira Miller and Huey, Militaires Sans Frontières turn their attention to an upcoming inspection by the UN amid suspicions that they possess a nuclear weapon, which MSF believe to be an attempt by the Cipher organization to stifle them. Their preparations are interrupted when MSF agents in Cuba investigate reports that Paz survived and has been detained at Camp Omega. The situation is complicated when Ricardo "Chico" Valenciano Libre attempts to rescue her and is similarly captured. Believing that both of them could compromise MSF, Snake is sent to infiltrate Camp Omega and extract them if they are alive, or confirm that they are dead and if so, determine what they revealed to their captors. Snake also recognizes the value in rescuing Paz, as he believes doing so will convince Cipher to stand down while Paz will be more willing to discuss Cipher's activities with MSF. 
Everything in this story is mature and handles it maturely nothing is out of place or put there merely for "shock value" if you have knowledge of "Peace Walker" on psp or simply listen to the audio codecs you'll know it happens for a reason. HIdeo is a master at clever writing with "double agents", malignant organizations, and controversial topics to move the game industry forward as a whole into a work of art. 
The character conversations are deeply engrossing and I slightly teared when Big Boss first finds Chico. This game solidly earns it's M+ rating and wouldn't recommend it to anyone under the age of 17 as there are depictions of extreme violence, torture, and gore.

Gameplay: The threat detection system is revamped, with the removal of the onscreen meter or gauge to indicate the player that they are in the 'alert/evasion/caution' state as in previous games, which have instead been replaced by visual and audio representations. Snake's binoculars have also been revamped; instead of selecting the binoculars as an item, the binoculars are hot keyed to a button. The player is able to mark enemies and be aware of their locations in the iDroid's holographic display. There are directional cues to help players when an enemy sees them from a distance and gets closer to them. A new "Reflex Mode" is activated when an enemy finds Snake and the player only has a short window of time (in slow motion) to take out the enemy before he fully sounds the alarm (a hissing audio cue can be heard if the player is detected by searchlight). Lights can be shot out to further aid the player's stealth efforts. 
Thats some of the new things that can be found in this latest iteration of the franchise, next up comes cqc and takedowns which for anyone who has played a mgs game in the past, more specifically "Metal Gear Solid 3" should be familiar with, although here it's expanded upon with guards being much more dynamic depending on the situation ahd the level of freedom to not being constrained to any one point in the base. Once you grab a guard in a chokehold there are a number of things you can do such as make them yell out for assistance to the nearest guard to take both of them out in one fell swoop, or perhaps interrogate him for information on locations with more weaponry? The number of ways to take on an obstacle deeply varied depending on your playstyle. Of course all the previously mentioned things such as "reflex mode" and third person shooting can be turned off for purists wanting the ultimate challenge.

Sound: The design, soundstage, voice-acting, original score, all work harmoniously this is top notch quality at work here the production value is through the roof for this game and they really have invested big into it to bring this game to life. From ambient sound such as the rain pitter patting down to the ground and changing when going indoors to a "clunk" on the metal roof. Or the plop of a boot walking through mud, it all puts you there in the moment for you to enjoy and completley immerse yourself into the experience. 

Guns sound top-notch more than likely recorded in a professional studio first hand; every bullet being fired off packs a punch into your ears and shells falling to the ground give off a distinctive sound, reloading a magazine sounds authentic snapping into place just right.
 
Now I know many of you have been complaining about the new voice actor Mr.Sutherland, while he may not be the original Snake voice we all know and love he gets the job done just fine, and rather adding some emotion into Big Boss's voice through sadness, shock, or humor all being translated well into the game. And subjectively speaking I rather like his new voice gives Big Boss some depth as opposed to the monotone and gruff voice that we use to have.

Graphics: Wow thats all I can say... wow, wow, wow. The best looks to performance ratio game I've played in years, the game is very well optimized and I regard it highly as one of the best running games I have ever played. I was able to crank everything up to it's maximum settings at 1080p with an older gtx 660ti while still running it at a smooth 45-60fps. Now thats what you call optimization, a large number of settings are there for you to tweak to your hearts content from lighting detail to ssao and special effects it's all there for the taking. Heck I was able to get this running on an old laptop at 720p and it still ran great at 30fps, looked really good too, so don't be afraid to buy this software for an older running machine.

The Fox Engine is really being utilized to it's full potential here, some-things in the game from research I've done has actually been laser-scanned into the game such as rocks and twigsto add on to the ground, cinematography effects as well, depth of field, bokeh, and yes the infamous lens flare are all used to great extent in this game giving it as always a signature kojima flair that adds to the mood of the game, very reminiscint of film effects. Facial expressions and character models are highly detailed with each wrinkle on snake's face telling a story of his past and expressing emotion depending on the situation. Animations are out of this world good, acting in realistic ways whenever shooting, falling, or choking someone out and motion capture quality I haven't seen since a little game called "The Last Of Us".

Conclusion: "Half as long, twice as bright". "Short but sweet". These are the words that come to mind when investing my hard earned money into this game and playing through it again and again, simply pumping me up and setting the  bar higher for other developers to topple, there is loads of content here, new easter eggs to discover and accomplishments to topple in a mission. Buy this game with peace in mind that you will enjoy it, I give it my personal recommendation to everyone and anyone who enjoys gaming! Although be forwarned this is a "tactical espionage" game take it nice and slow the less people alerted the better. 
I hope you enjoyed my review, and as always have a nice day. 
Final Score: 9/10

review:
Metal Gear Solid on PC... finally! So many memories of the franchise came back to me whilst playing this. Great to play as Snake in HD.. its been so long! The new fox engine is beautiful and it runs perfectly on max settings. 

Gameplay is excellent, felt really smooth and controls are straight away simple to pickup. I am a strong believer in quality over quantity, this game being a pure demonstration as to why. Everything has been well thought out, the story mode admittedly not long but provided great entertainment. I wasn't particularly excited about the idea of playing through just a prologue, but after completing it and seeing the story set up it just makes me want the full game now!

Side Ops and Extra Ops is a nice bonus, providing just that little bit more for us MGS lovers that wanted more before the final game is out. For people that have been worrying about the short storymode, check my hours for the game. Personally I feel it has great replayability and with more challenges and tasks to do you will be finding yourself eager to get stuck in and try to earn all the accomplishments - like me.

Overall I am very impressed and am looking forward to the full game. Finally... Snake is here. We've missed you!

review: Great game, worth the $20 in my opinion!  I bought this game because I love "slow paced" tactical games and I wanted to see what my new PC could handle.  The game is georgeus, the detail is amazing.  The controls (I use a controller) were solid.  I know people call this a "demo", but it's really not.  I might be a bit upset if I dropped $40 on it, but at $20 it's worth it.  I've got over 5.5 hours in and I haven't even done the side missions yet and I want to play it again to try different tactics.  The people that say this is a rip-off and are enraged about spending $19.99 on this are the same people that likely spend $10.50 to watch a 90 minute Transformers movie after getting a $4.00 coffee at Starbucks.   If you are a fan of MGS and you like stealthy combat games, I say drop the $20 and give it a go!  Can't wait for Phantom Pain!

review:
If you're looking for a realistic and entertaining stealth gameplay with amazing graphics and performance, this game is for you. Enemies in this game are smart and perceptive, they make conclutions about what has happened and inform others. Controls are precise and intuitive. Graphics are amazing, true next-gen. 

Surely the story mission is short, and for new players doesn't make much sense. But the focus is in the gameplay and environment. There are couple of side missions that have both normal and hard mode, which are different from each other.

For MGS fans, this will be an enjoyment, also a refreshing experience different from the previous ones (I'm a fan too).
Good way to get to know the controls and how everything works before the release of The Phantom Pain.

review:
Any game that can provide me with 30+ hours of gameplay (and I'm just over half-way finished with it at the time of writing) is worth a purchase at full price. This game came out with a default discount and will only get cheaper as time goes by. Excellent gunplay, solid stealth mechanics and a much darker tone when compared to any other game in the franchise. Not for those looking strictly for a story-centered cinematic experience. There's much more gameplay than there is story. 

Can you get to a 100%? 

9/10 - Wish there was more actual linear narrative!

First of all, I've never been such a great MGS/Kodjima fan, But I played previous games, know story - who is who and so on. Main problem in previous games was (in my opinion) too much cutscenes and very archaic gameplay - it was actually just 3d version of original 2d Metal Gear games from MSX and copies itself every time with minor changes with more and more cutscenes (I know Japanese like it).
So, this game was a COMPLETE SURPRISE for me!
1. Sandbox that was made right - it is actually something between Thief2 (with it's huge locations) and Deus Ex:HR with it's variability. This is HUGE level up for this game series gameplay-wise. Main mission shows very smart and tactic stealth gameplay. Additional missions demonstrate other types of gameplay - as I understand - to show us what to expect from Phantom Pain in a future. Each of this gameplay modes are made on a top level of coolness.))
2. Picture - one of the best picture in contemporarry games, esprcially characters. Therefore it is not very technological (if compare with something like RYSE) but due to excellent work of artists it looks even better. I also noticed that animation is very snooth and percise.
3. Story - of course it is mot much of it, bacause it is more demo than actual game but all what is presented by Kodjima now looks much more mature and stylish than before. Game says "Hello" to Emmanuel Lubezki with it's single shot cutscenes. Top notch directing.
4. PC version - another surprise - historically Japanese games have very poor PC ports with lots of problems, but this time it  is exeption. It even looks like it actually made for PC - good optimisation and comfortable controls - first time I REALLY enjoyed playin MGS game with keyboard and mouse!
So even it is just a "demo" it is definitely worth the money I spent on it. And if this just a "demo" I hardly imagine how huge and deep "game" itself will be.
After this Phantom Pain is one of most anticipated game of 2015 for me.

review:
First time in my live I payed for a DEMO, no jokes, this is a bloody DEMO. Under an hour for the main mission, and about 2 hours for the extra missions/challenges on the same map.

Pros:
Very good visuals
Different play through options
Well optimised controls
Well polished quality product/DEMO

Cons:
Upon closer inspection the Stealth component is not that good
AI is predictable
No story mode here, just a demo - prequel to Phantom Pain
$20 price tag (would only recommend buying for $5

review:
For $20, its essentially a fan service Demo for The Phantom Pain.
Excellent graphics, good controls, very clever and well organized AI and a graphics engine that will revolutionize how Metal Gear games work, should we be treated to more after the Phantom Pain. The cutscenes were very nostalgic in the Deja Vu mission and the Raiden Mission was pretty sweet, except now I want the Revengeance game as well. My one and only complaint here is that there is only one map, and only 5-6 missions to play. While does seem very skimpy of Mr. Kojima to sell a demo at full game price (by Steam standards), this demo is very good, with excellent replay value and how it pays a great deal of fan service to long standing fans of the series. I paid the full $20 for it and do not regret it one bit. Enough to tide me over till the release of The Phantom Pain. All in all, worth the money if your a fan. 

Oh, but watch out for that last cutscene in the Main Mission. gets a little gruesome with bomb disposal.

8.5/10 - Would play Hiding in a Cardboard Box again

review:
I would definitely recommend this game to fans new and old. This is the definitive best version to buy. If you already purchased MGSV: Ground Zeroes for console then here are the main differences to keep in mind:

   Pros:
     +60 fps and 1080p+ (not very demanding for a next gen game)
     +mods (Mr. Hideo Kojima is finally playable!)
     +dual language (for all you Kiefer Hayters)
   Cons:
     -no custom helicopter music (can be semi-fixed with mods)

It's worth the purchase if you haven't burned yourself out on the console version, because there isn't any new content added. If this doesn't apply to you because you have yet to play Ground Zeroes because you are waiting for the Phantom Pain, then I would say to go ahead and buy it. This a separate, but short, game that offers unique content and a good distraction until the Phantom Pain comes out. Also you will be able to carry over some unlockables to the full game.

review:
Well from what I've seen the game is amazing, it is short but that is because it's the prolauge for the full game The Phantom Pain, BUT this might just be a problm with me, but the game always freezes when it is first loading, so I cant get so far as the title screen (if there is one, I dont know)
Also it's not just taking a long time, I have let it sit there for 19 hours straight and it still did not get past the loading screen.

review:
Think of this as a fox engine tech and MGS5 demo with a price tag. Good game, buy it on sale price only.

The catch is do not hesitate to wait and buy this  game for the lowest price as you can (you can take better adventage from 3rd-party deals if you like). Main reason is this prologue of MGS5 give a good peek for potential of upcoming Phantom Pain could be. Good port is also a nice message from Hideo Kojima that he gonna take a decent care of PC players. But admit it , even MGS fans can taste a sign of bitterness from this price for such a short game.

Furthermore , For a people that used to play Ground Zero on console version like me. I can appreciate that PC control scheme is not a substitute of console control. I can feel that I played this game differnt than console version and with good experiance in total. They didn't make aiming control clunky like gamepad to make game harder on purpose.

Gameplay on the other hand , I can see that they still preserved some of stealth genre charming aspect. Ground Zero sneaking system still depended mostly on awareness of surrounding and like to take things slow. This can be described as annoying or time wasting, but personally I like stealth game that based on design philosophy of "Plan and Execute"
rather than dynamic sneaking layout. It might be lack of modernize system in some way but it worked out.

Bottom line , I love Ground Zero yet not recomended anyone to buy it in full price. This might be the better demo than Silent Hills (P.T) from Kojima. But Konami just have to slap a price tag on it. If you can find this game around $10 or cheaper it might worth some good time just to see how much effort they put into this.

review:
I paid for a demo.
It was pretty. I'm hoping for a discount when Phantom Pain comes out.
Let me be clear: everything is great, except that it's a demo. There's absolutely nothing 'open world' about it. 
"Open-world stealth game and prologue to Metal Gear Solid V"
"A deep, entertaining stealth sandbox with endless scope for mastery. You kept us waiting, Kojima, but it was worth it."
I don't know how PC Gamer gets away with printing blatant bollocks like this, or why it's the featured review. 
Definitely get Phantom Pain when it happens, but skip this.

review:
Best money I have ever spent on a demo! I'm guessing that PP will come out Jan 2016 for PC. man I can't wait that long . Im going to freeze myself in the ice cream section at the 7-11 until then. The Graphics are top notch and the controls fell good. I have dumped 16 hours into this game and Im still at 36% completion. Once you unlock weapons its just so satisfying going around blasting Marines with the shotgun or Sniper :D




-If you got the Simpsons/South Park reference then good for you.

review:
I love this game. People say its short, it is but has a S**T ton of replay value.
-Though i do think this could be even better with David Hayter as Snakes actor its still fun.

Another thing i dislike about this game is that...

-The game is a serious xbox port. if you goto the control options it refers everything with a Xbox Gamepad. Making the Button Mapping non existing.

And those are the only 2 downfalls i have on this game.

7/10

review:
Kojima did it again this game is absolute top-notch in the audio-visible department. One of the best looking and sounding games of 2014 and it still manages to run smooth even on not high-end hardware. Nice to see finally Big Boss on the PC. 

Even though this is only a prologue I can't wait for the Phantom Pain to come out as this teaser promises a lot of interesting game changes. Metal Gear Solid has come a long way since it first version back on PC and PSone. But the characters and story is still exciting as ever, gameplay has become more non-linear to the earlier installments. Kojima just knows how to make an action-sci-fi-thriller into a sound and fun to play game.

review: This is a level not a game, and a short level at that. Only two objectives. Not a very interesting scenario either. You don't really need to think or try very hard to be stealthy because the enemies are blind. I played through the level twice to see if there was a different way to go about winning. Doesn't seem like there is. If you are spotted you can easily mow everyone down like a superhuman snake man. You're invincible. You're invsisible. You're Super Snake! Lame cash grab at its worst. Bad port. Mouse doesn't work. Alt tab is jacked up. Mouse cursor contantly pops up on screen. On the other hand this game comes with alot of extra content like an extra difficulty level, lol. Also comes with additional content like secondary objectives. Really though its just one level and its dumb.

review:
MGS fan? You must have this! 

Everyone else? You pay 20€ for pizza and complain about a game that easily gives you 10 hours+ of fun? The heck...


Srsly, get it, show them theres a market for MGS on PC!

Played just over 2 hours of Ground Zeroes, basically a prologue to The Phantom Pain, and since I've become a huge Metal Gear fan. 

First game I've played in a long time where there has not been a single bug, glitch, or freeze. Runs above 60fps maxed out at 1080p, and looks amazing. Already love Big Boss, the Metal Gear story is just fantastic.

Very excited for MGS5, I only wish Kojima would release the Metal Gear Collection on Steam, I'd buy it in a heartbeat!
This was an amazing expirience. It was short and i just beat the story in 35 mins. Graphics were amazing. A must for any Metal Gear Solid fan.

review:
Solid intro to MGS5, despite being short and somewhat lacking in real content. The gameplay is immersive and feels very natural, they have done great things with the controls. The plot leaves a bit to be desired. 

Hideo Kojima is so far up his own ass I don't think we'll ever get him back into the real world. The game is phenomenal if you ignore the parts that aren't gameplay. They've finally done some really amazing things with the controls and environment, as well as the tools you can use to stay hidden and sneaky. I loved MGS4, and seeing its successor on the PC makes me incredibly happy. But holy shit, Kojima has gone off the deep end with the story, characters, and general feel of the world. 
I will leave out any spoilers, and simply say that Phantom Pain better be absolutely incredible story-wise to warrant the total shit-fest that was the plot of this intro. Ignoring that stain, the rest of the game's important qualities - gameplay, immersion, technical details like graphics and audio - make this a really solid entry in the series.

Also, don't purchase this expecting more than an hour or two of original gameplay - this intro title is very, very short.

review:
The stealth sandbox that I always wanted. Gameplaywise, it's pretty much the best MGS has ever been. However, the alert system feels like a step down from previous games in the series: whereas from MGS2 onwards guards would have to contact their base with the radio (which you could shoot down) to trigger an alert, in this game everyone in the base will know about you the moment a guard says "Huh?". This is mitigated by the reflex mode which triggers a slow motion when you are spotted, but it feels like a cheap clutch.

Storywise, it's hard to judge this game without knowing what TPP has in store, but it does have some moments of dialogue that are a bit cringe-worthy.

Graphically, this game is a technical wonder. It runs on a huge variety of systems and looks absolutely amazing in any modern system.

Finally, regarding content, this is a demo that already sucked 10 hours of my life. The main story mission will take you an hour or two to complete, but there are 5 additional missions, all taking place in the same map, which add a few hours to the game if you enjoy the gameplay. Even if you're in it just for the story, you owe it to yourself to at least collect all the cassette tapes.

review:
Someone else has said that only Hideo Kojima could get away with charging money for a Tech-Demo and they were absolutely right. Hideo Kojima did this game right and further more, he did the port right too. :) If you are a fan of the MGS games or of Tactical Espionage games in general, then pull up a chair and plop down your money for you will not regret buying this.

I personally love how you can choose to focus on just the objectives or rescue everyone and you get to choose how you do it too. Be it full on stealth (I hope you're better at it than I am) or going full "Loud and Proud" you won't go wrong either way. As for the story, it is very nicely done. Like VERY nicely done. Complete with a backstory.

review:
This game is beautifully ported, absolutely packed with side mission content and can have you sit there for hours upon hours playing... IF you are the sort of person who like to play for completion.
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes on it's own is short. Very short, you might not use mroe than 30 minutes on your first playthrough of it, and that's that for "the game".

But there is so much more to the game than just that. There are 5 extra side missions in this game, with unique dialog and some small cutscenes for each of them. And with lots of diffrent outcomes depending on how you finish them.

The game itself runs like a damn fiddle and you don't have to sacrifice too much to enjoy the game while it looks fancy. The controller has no problems whatsoever and keyboard and mouse works perfectly as expected.

The game is now cheap unlike early 2014. But is it still worth the money?
If you want to play more than just the story, then yes it's worth it.
If not, just look it up on youtube.

review:
Smooth as butter, and definitely worth it if you're a completionist or die hard fan of the series. Mouse and Keyboard works great as well, and is my new favorite way to play this Metal Gear.

What you put into it is what you get out of it. It's also a great way to get aqquainted with some of the game mechanics before The Phantom Pain hits in September as well.

review:
2/10 

I could not recommend against this "game" more. It is a bad joke that this costs any amount of money at all. Unless of course, buying this "game" is like a down-payment on Phantom Pain and I will get a substantial discount (I'm thinking 80-90% is fair, considering what they will likely over-price it at) for suffering this short, yet exquisite agony of an unsatisfying purchase.

Rather than some big wall of text, I'll bullet-point pros and cons.

Cons:
              - It is a woeful console port, clearly PC was an afterthought for more $$$.
              - Related to the above, as such the movement is really clunky and non-intuitive, along with the controls. An example includes, instead of arrow buttons or (shock-horror) mouse clicks in the menus, one has to use the number keys 1 and 3. That's right, not 1 and 2; 1 and 3, making navigating the menus a chore.
             - There aren't even options to LOOK at what keys do what, never mind changing them. The only controls screen you can bring up has an image of an Xbox controller with no indication of where they keys correspond on the keyboard.
             - It is the least value for money I have ever seen in a game. For the price-point of $20, I would expect around-about 5 hours of story-related game-play (at a push) as this is generally the price and length of DLC of other triple-A titles.
             - I genuinely feel this should be a free demo for the limited content it offers.
             - Any "extra" missions you unlock are the same map at a different time of day, from a different angle and have the most token-istic objectives - "Collect intel", "assassinate targets" etc...basically a piss-poor version of the VR training we have seen in previous MGS, with nothing contributing to the storyline. The "storyline" gameplay of the game takes between 5-10 minutes to complete.
             - Kieffer Sutherland is not David Hayter. I'm sorry, it may seem silly, but Solid Snake/Big Boss is David Hayter...you can't go changing voice actors out. It's just not cricket.

Pros:
           - It really is a gorgeous-looking game.
           - However short this may have been, the storytelling was superb. Kojima is a fantastic film-maker, who uses the tools of videogames to tell a story. In the one mission it does have, I certainly felt like a f***ing bad-a** hero at one point (no spoilers).

Well done Hideo, you've lost a long-time fan of the series. I think I was about 10 when I first played MGS...I'm 22 now and left almost as disappointed as when I attempted to play Peace Walker on the, again, shoddy port to Xbox 360. Seriously, get over Playstation, stop taking advantage of your fans and get back to your roots, please.

review:
The gameplay is solid, the graphics are amazing and it runs so freaking well. It also adds some new ideas to the MGS franchise which I love.

My biggest problems are:
*The main story is as short as you've heard. My first playthrough [Including exploration] was 46 minutes. That's pretty bad.
*The story is...well I guess it's good but it's clear that there's stuff you won't understand until The Phantom Pain
*The "new" Snake. So instead of asking the amazing David Hayter to do the voice of Snake [like he's always done] they went and asked Kiefer Sutherland to do it. He sounds like he's lacking passion for this and doesn't even come close to being as amazing as David Hayter.

Do I recommend this? Well the gameplay is good and the story is interesting and that's usually enough for me but this game doesn't have longevity. 

Also don't be a complete nub and say things like "It needs to be replayed for a better experience" because that's something that's said about most games :P

review:
With the quality of the port, and the support that the devs are providing on bug fixing, this was a fantastic purchace. The story only teases you with the transition into the new game, and the gameplay being limited to a single level, never has so much been done with so little. 

If you like Metal Gear Solid, PC Gaming, Stealth. Buy this game, so that we can confirm that the main game will be as taken care of as this one.

review:
Too bad it wasn't part of The Phantom Pain (which Kojima would've wanted it that way. More emotional booms), but blame Konami for making it so.

Anyway, it's a great shift to open-world stealth with guns. Really widening the MGS world to a whole new level, adding more options to what you want to do and how you want to clear your missions. Story is linear, but there are minor details added in which might shift a bit in your playthrough.

Also, it sucks that the console players had to pay 60 bucks for this. Glad we have it 20, huh?

A small taste of what the FOX engine has to offer, and what The Phantom Pain will be like. Only recommended for more familiar MGS fans, and only recommended at a discount. Do not get for the main "Ground Zeroes" mission, as that is only 2 hours long (or less if you know what you're doing)

Also, don't worry about minimal requirements too much. I have an intel core i3 and I can still get everything at least high and have a stable 60fps framerate.

review: Let me start off by saying that Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a game for those that would consider themselves avid fans of the Metal Gear Solid series. It provides a brief but satisfying glimpse at the game play mechanics of the upcoming title Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Game play is fun and fluid. The stealth mechanics are solid and you can go about completing the mission in a multitude of different ways. After completing the abysmally short campaign, you are given a few more side missions to complete in the same small map, Camp Omega. All in all, if you are planning on getting into the MGS series, it's best to start somewhere else. This game doesn't quite do the series justice. I suggest either the original Metal Gear Solid, or Metal Gear Solid 3. Both are great games to get a feel for the series. For those who are fans of the MGS series, get this game! It's well worth the price and will hold you over for when The Phantom Pain eventually is released.

review:
I have a low spec laptop: Intel Dual core 1.8ghz, Intel Graphics HD AND AMD Raedon 4000m series and a factory issued sound card.
However i can still run this on the lowest possible settings and resolution (965 x 500) while plugged into a power source and all processes lowered priority which amazes me because i had no intention of playing it on my laptop but rather saving for a good rig and playing some of these games i invested in later.
Also KOJIMA WHERE IS MY BOX!!!!!!!
