review:
Kojima's been a console guy for the vast majority of his career.  Metal Gear is finally making an appearance on Steam for the first time.  

The PC version of this game is out-performing games made by longtime PC developers.  Less bugs, better frame rate.  I'll leave it at that...

Shalashaska?

La-li-lu-le-lo???

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Solid Game Performance (Frame Rate / Visuals / Controls)
[*] Crazy improvements to CQC and movement
[*] Smoother more realistic flow between various levels of guard alertness, communication and tactics.
[*] !
[*] The main mission is glorious.  Excellent level design.
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] David Hayter got dumped.
[/list]

I myself have played this game for 8 hrs and only have 11 percent completion and only tried two missions, the main and one side(which was played multiple times) Trying to get an S rank is fun, but hard. Achievements give this game alot of replayability.

review:
It's the best game I've played in a long time. I have more play time in this than any other game (50+) bar far cry 3. 

MGS V is going to be incredibly awesome if this is anything to go by.

Worth the money all day, would buy again without hesitation.

Misson 1: 
I shot a sniper. A headshot
I was trying to shoot another sniper. I missed
Things got ugly..everyone were shooting at me
I was using the bazooka I stole ealier
Boom! A group died after the oil tank exploded ( I wonder why it's not an empty tank)

Then all the soldiers were shooting at me. 
I Died

"Snake! Talk to me. Snake..!! Snake!!!"
It is MGS game series..get your popcorn and 'play' the game.

10/10 - would die again

review:
What's to say? It's another of Hideo's Masterpeices. However it may not run well on lower end computers (especially AMD users).

Pros:
-Looks and feels amazing
-Controls are intuitive and easy to play, especially for gamepad users who have played previous MGS titles.
-Real physics
-Immersion, hear the soldiers sneeze, shoot the sh*t, talk about sensitive information, etc. Feel like you're in the sh*t for real, deep behind enemy lines.
-Completionists eat your heart out, tons of collectibles, and enough side missions and achievements to keep you occupied for a good length of time (gotta kill time till TPP somehow right?).

Cons:
-The main story mission is short. REALLY short.
-There's only one map/AO and its not that big.
-The main mission maybe takes 1-2 hours tops without alerting anyone, faster if you're skilled in Tactical Espionage ;) or aren't concerned with score.

Overall, I'd say buy it on sale. Unless you're a die-hard MGS fan.

 "Yeah, that's right... from now on... call me BIG BOSS!"

review:
Firstly I loved Ground Zeroes, i need to get that out the way seeing as there's a big old thumbs down on the left.

Ground Zeros is very much a demo / teaser for MGS5 which will come out this year. It's a very fun experience with great ideas and gameplay, runs impecably well and looks gorgeous, however they are asking for £17 and truthfully, it's just not worth it even for the Metal Gear Fan. 

There's a whole bunch of 'what if' side missions with different stories and missions, multiple ways of doing every mission, collectables and so much to do but sadly it's all on one map which might seem large at first but you soon realise it's not actually that big at all on your 3rd playthrough. 

I bought it in a sale for £11.37, I love it and can't wait for MGS5 as a result, but i still think i payed too much for it. 

IF you see this on sale, around the £7 mark then i think you'll be satisfied, but for the £17 they are asking it's a definate no from me.

review:
So where to start with Ground Zeroes? I guess first off, I'm a fan of the MGS series as a whole, and that should certainly be a prerequisite for playing MGS:GZ. This would be a terrible starting (even though it's the first one released on PC) and is certainly not going to convince someone to love MGS if they weren't a fan before. But for those of us that enjoy the previous iterations, it's worth looking at.

The biggest caveat with this game though, is that it's crazy overpriced. You are basically paying $20 for a tech demo. I currently have 3.8 hours playtime, and that was more than enough time to complete the main mission and one of side missions, even though I took them very slowly and experimented with the mechanics rather than going for completion.

Maybe even more of an issue than the price, is how repetitive it is. $20 for a preview game with 6 missions wouldn't be so bad if they weren't pretty much all the same. The missions are all the same map, with just different objectives like rescue prisoners or sneak in and eliminate a target. Completing the missions basically means sneaking into the same base 5 times (plus 1 forced loud mission) to complete tasks that aren't really that different from each other. And if you want to complete everything, you then have to do them all again on Hard difficulty. I realize that repetition isn't completely out of character for MGS (it took at minimum of 12 playthroughs of MGS4 to unlock everything I believe), but this is even more apparent in MGS:GZ because it only consists of one short missions.

So far I've been pretty negative, but I'm also recommending the game, so I should elaborate on that. First off, the FOX engine looks incredible, and the visual presentation in this game is outstanding. I also really enjoyed the gameplay, which takes some of the better facets of MGS4 and builds on them. The enemy AI is also really fun to interact with. Here's a good example the complexity it presents. I shot out a camera at one point rather than going around it. But as soon as I did, a guard was dispatched to check it out. I hid in the area to see what happened, and sure enough, a guard came over to look at the camera. Not wanting him to report it in and set off an alarm, I tranqed him. But as I was sneaking over to his unconscious body to hide it, headquarters called his radio for a status update, and then triggered an alarm when he didn't respond. From my experience, you really have to adapt to the AI and you take a risk when you eliminate someone.

I play a lot of steath games (no kill, no alarm runs of DE:HR and Dishonored for example), and the stealth feels a little off here. Well, to be fair, it feels like MGS, but stealth games have evolved a bit since the last MGS release. Not to say that this is a bad thing, but it's just different. After playing more recent stealth games, I was surprised at the lack of safe hiding places like the vents in DE:HR. This isn't a negative, but it is a different design and keeps you on your feet a bit more.

So all in all, I really liked the presentation and gameplay, but the total package here feels a bit lacking. I'll still recommend it though because most importantly, it got me really excited for MGS5, which is really the point of it's release.


*SPOILER*
I'd be remiss if I didn't call out the bomb scene. The concept of it was fine (bomb hidden inside of a prisoner that's going to be rescued as a trap), but I really didn't like the presentation. It was overly gratuitous and rather unpleasant. The MGS franchise has always had a very skewed view on women and sexuality, but this scene crossed the line for me and I hope it isn't representative of what we'll see in MGS5.

review:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes

What to say about this game?
I was reluctant to buy the game myself, after reading reviews saying how "short" the game was.
I received it as a Christmas present, but I can say now, I would have gladly bought it myself.
The game is as long as you want to make it.
I've played for 30+ hours now, and still keep finding things to do.

It's true, you can beat the main mission, pretty fast, depending on how you play.
If you go with a stealth aproach, the game gets that much harder, and in my opinion, that much more fun.

There are so many different ways to play.
You can go in all guns blazing, but that'll usually end up getting yourself killed.
When the "Ground Zeroes" mission is completed, you'll unlock "Side Ops" missions.
There are two "Extra Ops" missions which must be unlocked, but I'll let you figure out how to unlock those yourself.
It becomes addicting trying to achieve an S rank on all the missions.
With each rank, you'll unlock rewards, for the mission.
Higher ranks, unlock the lower rank rewards.
So, if you get an S rank, you'll get the rewards for S, A, B, C, and so on.
I'm still trying to achieve an S rank on all missions, on normal and hard difficulty.

I've replayed every mission several times through.
Each time I learn a new way to get through the mission faster, and new ways to take out the guards.
You'll get very used to the little patch of land, as every last mission takes place in the same area.
It sounds bad on paper, but it actually works out very well.
Things are changed enough, to keep you on your toes.
As you grow accustomed to the area, it makes getting through the missions that much easier.
If you don't explore, and simply do what the mission guidelines state, you'll be missing out on a lot.
I played one mission 4 times, only to realize the 5th time through when I was goofing around, there was more to the mission.
Make sure to try and interegate as many guards as you can, through-out all the missions.

I could say a whole lot more, but I don't want to spoil anything.
If you're a fan of the Metal Gear Solid games, or a fan of stealth action games, then you have to give this game a chance.

review:
An amazing game, but Keifer Sutherland's voice ruins Snake.  Makes me wish for Japanese audio, so I don't have to listen to him.

When Solid Snake inevitably puts an end to Big Boss, I hope Solid is voiced by David Hayter!

Still a good game, tho.

It works great as a follow-up to Peace Walker and introduction to Phantom Pain. Seems like a paid demo at first, but there's much more to it. One big map, but with different missions, and most of all, lots of randomness, emergent fun and replayability. I love it.

review:
An excellent introduction to the latest installment of the Metal Gear Solid series. As with it's predecessors, Metal Gear Solid is at the forefront of pushing the boundaries of gaming, constantly re-invnting itself and tackling real world themes such as war, love, hate, genetics and fate. 

This prelude, whilst might put some peope off for the length of the story mode will be suprised to find enormous relayability and longavity due to the extra content included, such as side operations and collectables and secrets. 
The game is a sort of "hat-tip" to fans of the series and gives player's the chance to feel out the final game the Phantom Pain will become. 

As gameplay goes, the controls are intuitive and fluid and extremly smooth for a PC port. The map is open-ended and missions can be accomplished in any manner you wish.
An example:- You are tasked with destroying three targets on the map. You Begin at a pre defined location and how you enter the base is down to the player. You can sneak through, becoming a "phantom" place the explosives and get out without anyone knowing you were even there. Alternatively, you can crack open an armoury and blow through the targets with a rocket launcher. You will alert everyone to your presence and present yourself with greater risk etc. 

There are some downsides to the game especially on PC. Without a decent setup, you will encounter a few crashes and framerate issues. This however is constantly being monitered and sorted by the developer who are working round the clock to fix these gripes. 
Additionally from a story perspective, whilst the game does include a backstory diary and a "previously on Metal Gear" menu, it does little to introduce players to the overall story so if you are a newcomer, you will play this game not knowing what a Cypher is, exactly who Kazuhira Miller is and generally being a bit lost. A suggestion would be to pick up a copy of the HD collection (or the Legacy collection) and book the week off work and enjoy a fantastic and gripping storyline that would leave Chris Nolan's eyeballs spinning. 

Overall. A fantastic game if you are a fan of the Stealth/Action Genre and a must-own for any fan of the series. 

as a final note, I've heard it rumoured that your bonuses collected in ground zeroes, unlock something special for the Phantom Pain so this is definitely worth picking up just to secure your juicy goodies.

as a final note, I've heard it rumoured that your bonuses collected in ground zeroes, unlock something special for the Phantom Pain so this is definitely worth picking up just to secure your juicy goodies.", "timestamp_created": 1421654367, "timestamp_updated": 1421654578, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
I purchased this game when it was 13.99$ on sale.

For the amount I paid, I was pretty satisfied with the game.

The controls took a bit of getting used to, they're different from previous Metal Gear games, and its much easier to be spotted in this game than in previous ones. As a demo, this is a great sample of what to expect in the full game, but I can't help but feel a tiny bit burned by having to pay for this.

Lets face facts: The main meat of this game is the main story mission, which doesn't take very long to complete. The side missions (while fun) are all on the same map as the main mission which leaves a bad taste in your mouth. Most of them seem like they were thrown together in order to justify selling the demo.

I've enjoyed my time playing the game though, thats for sure. I'm very much looking forward to the full release.

If you're a fan of MGS, I would definitely recommend picking it up (when its on sale).

Controls feel great and stealth is great for a classic feel you can turn off reflex mode. If you like Metal Gear or stealth action games grab this one.  I have played this game to completion on Xbox 360, Xbox One and now on PC.  I can not wait till Phantom Pain comes out.

review:
Some of you might complain about this game being as short as a demo, but that didn't bother me one bit. 
The game has great replay value, especially if you're into collecting, exploring areas & completing acheivements with 100% game completion. 

Each mission has various ways to have them completed, the way you want & for yo to figure out the best way to compelte them in a very short period of time (for S Ranks). 

Last but not least, ths is a very good PC port. 

Kudos to Konami!

review: What an amazing game. I couldn't believe it when the game decided to run on a smooth 60 with my old dual core processor and still looks just as amazing as the cutscenes at the same time. The controls were very nicely optimized for a console port and it even comes with the two extra missions that were seperate on the Playstation and XBox versions. The only thing I didn't like was the lack of support for the iDroid app, because calling in a chopper when under fire is a horrible idea.

review:
Much big boss
Such 60 FPS
Very metal gear
Wow

I love the Metal Gear franchise and this game is no exception. It is also essentially a demo that costs money, but damn was it a glorious demo. I recommend this game to anyone with enough extra money to waste on a 1 to 2 hour long game. I don't recommend this game to people who want a game to not be a demo when you pay over 10 dollars for it.

Length aside the port is exceptional. This is the first Metal Gear to come to the PC since Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance in 2003. I was very pleased to see this run good, and at the same time have it look so exceptional.

review:
GG, had plenty of fun BUT here's what imo requires improvement (in case devs read those):
- draw distance is too short (there is a mission where it is enough to shoot a barrel to complete objective but sadly you have to walk close enough to see it)
- DoF gets out of hand at times
- mouse movement does not scale when using zoom on binoculars or riffles which makes aiming clunky
- a bit too easy to sneak around enemies at close range 
- not every sound alerts guards - like closing doors or screaming hostages
- hard mode is too easy - there should be no cqc/less ammo/less hp/obligatory no enemy marking
- some weird key assignments that cannot be changed (P to play recording? why not space or enter?)
- I'm not a fan of the story, but meh.. whatever

It's only a single map with a few missions but it's possible to approach them in various creative ways. I have 20h on record and still I see people on yt making things I had no idea were possible. Buy it if you like sneaking of any kind. 

9/10

review:
TLDR: Stellar Story! Amazing graphics! Unbeatable Stealth gameplay! This game is a must-buy!

It may be only one story mission, but as a long-time Metal Gear Solid fan, there is so much nostalgia.
There is easily over 10 hours of gameplay to be played. Also, the missions are extremely replayable, so you will find yourself wanting to play again and again, to find different ways of completing each mission.

This is an amazing stealth game, taking the previous games and transforming it into the ultimate open-world game. There is no stealth gaming experiencebetter than this or so well optimised. The graphics are amazing (Althought there a certain features lacking eg ability to disable Depth of Field)

The story is amazing, and packed with fan-service. It is a great way to finally see how Big Boss became the person he is.The sound, and quality of cutscenes is excellent.

There is no dispute that Metal Gear Solid V is one of the greatest games ever created.
For the cheap price tag and hours of gameplay to be played, this game is a must-buy.
Once you've played this game, you will immediately add MGSV The Phantom Pain to the top of your must-buy list.

review: If you plan to play Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes solely for its campaign mission, keep in mind that it can be beaten in an hour. There is lots of extra stuff you can do to get more mileage out of the game, but if that is of no interest to you you may want to wait for the game to go on sale. Speaking for myself I enjoyed the game, and kudos needs to be given to Konami for doing a splendid job with this PC port.

review: High quality stealth action videogame. Fluid gameplay, perfect animations, smooth grapics, really good sound, relatively low system requirements. A lot of story is being told through cassette tapes - about 1 hour so you'd better get them all if you care about plot. Missions are easy enough to get A-B rank on first walkthrough and hard enough to spend 1-2 hours retrying 5 minute missions for S. Nothing stops you from choosing your own way of completing the mission, no more corridors - this adds a lot of replayabitily. Some content was cut from the final version (knocking on walls, bullet casings etc - whole list is on community forums), but it doesn't matter that much since it should be in The Phantom Pain. Get it if you are interested in stealth games with cinematographic experience (and also a perfectionist who can replay the same mission for 8 hours trying to  neutralize all enemies on the map without killing them. Without reflex. On hard.).

review: Metal Gear Solid finnaly comes to pc with this new installment in the franchise but will you want to play this or go back to the classics ? In Metal Gear Solid 5 Ground Zeroes we play as Big Boss. Were tasked to retrieve to agents Chico and Paz after the Peace Walker incident. So how is this game ? Well this is alot of fun but first of all i have to say this for the people. THIS IS A INTRODUCTION FOR THE MAIN GAME which is Phantom Pain which will come out later and not its own game. Think of it as a demo before the full project comes out. But overall this is still alot of fun. The game feels like a true MGS game should. Stealth in this game is really fun and fluid and without a doubt this game is smooth as hell. Stealth in this game works so well its always youre fault if you get spotted. The port is also outstanding. Maxed out i got a solid 60 without ever getting a single drop. There isnt many things that are bad about this game. Some Minor bugs there and there but nothing major. The game is really fun and if youre a fan of MGS definetly do not skip this title and get it right away. I give Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes a 8/10

The port is also outstanding. Maxed out i got a solid 60 without ever getting a single drop. There isnt many things that are bad about this game. Some Minor bugs there and there but nothing major. The game is really fun and if youre a fan of MGS definetly do not skip this title and get it right away. review:
I love metal gear solid, but this is nothing more than a tech DEMO!!!  It's ONE level!

Please don't waste your money like I did!  I mean I'm excited about what they're doing, but what a lousy way to make a buck.  And it doesn't even work right!  It's totally an alpha for Phantom Pain.  There's a lot of glitches that had to be fixed with a beta update--and that still didn't even fix them all.  One was: the game wouldn't start with a controller plugged in, but it's optimized to be played WITH A CONTROLLER.  There's not even really any story so you wouldn't miss anything just playing the phantom pain.

Hideo Kojima, you're just a sell out.

Don't buy it.  Instead through your money on the GROUND. Hideo Kojima is a ZERO.  It's probably called ground zero because they broke ZERO GROUND making it.  It's not worth just a zero, but plural ZEROES.  It has about ZERO hours of gameplay.  I'd rather just stare at the GROUND.  From a score of 1 to 10, its on the GROUND with a ZERO.

But for real, the cut scenes were almost longer than the gameplay...

I played the first game and was hooked since. I have played all the MGS games though I haven't beaten Peace Walker but I have to say that MGSV Ground Zeroes is amazing. It is short since it is like the equivalent of the Tanker mission or Virtous mission. Like them they can be short or long and can be replayed however Ground Zeroes comes with 4 side missions and 2 extra missions that is pretty fun!

review:
Best game available on Steam in 2014. I've a big fan of the original MGS games which all shared the spotlight of the first ps1 game. I was hoping this new storyline would go back to the first games' sucesses, and time period... and it does, all the while adding the right amount of game mechanics from the current generation of games. This game does similar things like FarCry4 in which you can mark enemies to give you awareness of your surroundings, but in this game you also have the third person view which makes sneaking around so much easier. Its clear that the designers focused a lot on making the controls more intuitive. In tense firefights the controls flow seemlessly never taking you out of the action. 

But if youve never played MGS, the crowning achievement for the franchise is sound. Realistic weapons having realistic sounds in different environments emerses you into the role of being a one man army. This new MGS delivers that in a big way. The sound and music puts you into the game better than any game ive ever played.

My favorite part of the game though has to be the side missions. I enjoyed the old VR mission game based of sons of liberty so I was happy to see they included those. All in all this game is worth every penny. 10/10

Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a short but good entry of the MGS series. The gameplay itself is like that of it's predecessors, not counting Revengeance, but it gives players some twist such as marking enemies, finding alternative routes to an objective (such as hiding in a truck, crawling in a vent, or just sneaking through the door) and looking beautiful even on low settings. 

The game does suffer some flaws. For one, it's short. The campaign itself is just a prologue for the upcoming Phantom Pain so it's just one mission, not counting the pseudo-historical missions. Another flaw (though subjective) is the fact that the checkpoint system can be abused to refill tranquilizer ammo for those that want to be the technical pacifist (I say technical since you might just end up knocking out the enemies via CQC.) though it is at least evened by penalizing players in subtracting their ranking score.

Overall, Ground Zeroes is an entry of the series that is worth playing, especially for those on PC who either want to play a Metal Gear Solid Game and/or those who want to play a game that emphasizes the importance of stealth.

I have recently played through the main Metal Gear Solid Games and also played Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance. A great series with great characters, great story, great atmosphere, music, graphics, and gameplay. Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes is the latest in the MGS series and serves as a prologue to Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain.
 
Ground Zeroes is a cheap, smaller game than what the Phantom Pain will offer. This is both a strength and a weakness for the game as it's very short. However, the game offers a large open area to experiment with the new mechanics and weapons. Metal Gear Solid 5 marks the series going open world in level design. Just from Ground Zeroes' big level, it gives me a lot of optimism for the Phantom Pain's open world levels which will be even bigger. 

However, here's the problem with the game and why people are flipping out about it. The game is just a few missions in one level. Only one mission is the prologue to the Phantom Pain and can be finished in about an hour or two depending on how you approach the level. The mission is really good and you get to really get a feel for the new mechanics which will be fleshed out even further in the main game. It's a good mission but it ends too fast and you feel  a little cheated and ripped off (I paid 13 bucks during the sale so it's not too bad for that price and there are people who spent 30 bucks). The game has a few missions after the main mission and they are fun for the most part and reach new levels of campiness. If you noticed from my play time, I found ways to extend my playtime and have a blast. I'm only about 40% done with the total progress too so there's a lot more for me to do such as all the Hard modes and getting S ranks on all the missions. There's a lot to do for a small game and if you are a Metal Gear fan, you will have fun with the Deja Vu mission and Raiden mission which are bundled for free in the PC version.

Graphically, Ground Zeroes looks amazing, especially in the main mission and the late afternoon missions. It also is a solid (No pun intended) port that is scaleable on all kinds of hardware. This is all because of the FOX engine which looks and runs incredibly well and looks nearly photorealistic. Some of the settings are tough to run but I played on some Extra High and High settings and got 60fps throughout. It's amazing that Kojima Productions made such a good port despite their long break from PC porting. It's a shame more devs aren't putting this kind of effort into their games on PC (I'm looking at you Ubisoft). 

Overall, Ground Zeroes is a great sub-game to give you a taste of what the Phantom Pain will be like. However, that taste is kind of like a tease and makes you hunger for what the Phantom Pain will offer. It's a great game and if you can get lost in Camp Omega, you will get your money's worth.

{"recommendationid": "13991069", "author": {"steamid": "76561198005547215", "num_games_owned": 0, "num_reviews": 8, "playtime_forever": 2499, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 1489, "last_played": 1442628140}, "language": "english", "review": "I have recently played through the main Metal Gear Solid Games and also played Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance. A great series with great characters, great story, great atmosphere, music, graphics, and gameplay. Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes is the latest in the MGS series and serves as a prologue to Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain.
 
Ground Zeroes is a cheap, smaller game than what the Phantom Pain will offer. This is both a strength and a weakness for the game as it's very short. However, the game offers a large open area to experiment with the new mechanics and weapons. Metal Gear Solid 5 marks the series going open world in level design. Just from Ground Zeroes' big level, it gives me a lot of optimism for the Phantom Pain's open world levels which will be even bigger. 

However, here's the problem with the game and why people are flipping out about it. The game is just a few missions in one level. Only one mission is the prologue to the Phantom Pain and can be finished in about an hour or two depending on how you approach the level. The mission is really good and you get to really get a feel for the new mechanics which will be fleshed out even further in the main game. It's a good mission but it ends too fast and you feel  a little cheated and ripped off (I paid 13 bucks during the sale so it's not too bad for that price and there are people who spent 30 bucks). The game has a few missions after the main mission and they are fun for the most part and reach new levels of campiness. If you noticed from my play time, I found ways to extend my playtime and have a blast. I'm only about 40% done with the total progress too so there's a lot more for me to do such as all the Hard modes and getting S ranks on all the missions. There's a lot to do for a small game and if you are a Metal Gear fan, you will have fun with the Deja Vu mission and Raiden mission which are bundled for free in the PC version.

review:
Amazing game. The ones complaining about the length must have not even touched the side missions. The replayability factor is also huge because there are many different ways to approach each mission. Playing the side missions also unlocks cassette tapes that explain what happened to Chico and Paz as well as foreshadows events in TPP.

10/10

review:
Mostly excellent PC version of a great game. My only complaint would be that the menus can't be navigated by mouse, but that's easy to get used to. Haven't encountered any other issues in that regard. I guess reflex mode probably makes the game a lot easier than was intended now that you can use a mouse, but you can always turn that off.

As for the game itself, some will complain that it's a demo and well... It basically is, but there's enough content here with enough replay value to merit paying over $10. The controls are very in-depth, the mechanics are top-notch (apart from the sometimes wonky marking mechanic,) the gameplay is very open-ended. There is one side mission that kind of sucks but if this game is any indication, The Phantom Pain will be one of the best MGS games. And that means a lot

It's not really essential to buy right now since I'm sure it'll be included in some kind of deal with The Phantom Pain, but if you're a fan who wants to preview the game and make the most of Ground Zeroes, I highly recommend grabbing it beforehand.

As a long time Metal Gear Solid fan, I have to recommend this game. This is some awesome Metal Gear Solid action. I do have some gripes about it, though.

First the good: Metal Gear Solid has never looked better. This may be a port, but it's a damn good one. The controls feel fluid, the graphics look amazing, and the gameplay is engaging. After the very short main mission, there are all these "Side Ops" (other missions in the same setting) to play which is nice. Not to mention, Metal Gear Solid fits pretty well in a large area. I wouldn't call it "sandbox", but there's plenty of room for roaming around and trying new tactics.

Now the bad: As a long time Metal Gear Solid, I now officially hate Kiefer Sutherland. It may be a small detail in the larger picture, but removing David Hayter as the voice of Snake is blatantly offensive to the ears. It's jarring. Snake feels like a stranger now. Before, he was this time old icon, the embodiment of apathy towards violence due to decades of constant fighting. David Hayter had that down. He *was* Snake. Kiefer Sutherland... he's a stranger. It may seem petty, but it's a big deal to me.

But now that Metal Gear has come to PC, it's now capable of being modded. Maybe, in a dream world, David Hayter will agree to work on a fan-based voice acting replacement mod. Then... this game (and Phantom Pain to come) will truly be great.

review:
If you're planning to buy this "paid demo", u gotta ask yourself one question.
Do you feel lucky? 
Huh?
I mean, do you like Metal Gear Solid? 
Did  u enjoy previous Kojima productions, shed a tear at snake eater ending, and spend days reading about the story online? If the answers to previous questions were yes, im glad youre feeling lucky and u should get this game. The main mission on first try is about 2-3 hours of top notch stealth action quality gaming, with amazing cutscenes, bloody and dark themes  (seriously, this might not be a game for everyone), great voice acting and everything MGS has always been. With all the lighting effects, sharp textures and fluid animations sometimes it's hard to belive its not rendered CGI . With addtional side ops, easter eggs, ranking system, the replayability is quite high, no to mention story itself was designed in such a way that in order to fully grasp it u have to  do multiple playthroughs and search for cassetes. Add to that a high difficulty curve, with enemies on hard having better sight then most humans, amazing PC port (no crashes, fluid  60 fps on high/very high, only problem I had is display turning off randomly for few secs during gameplay) Not to mention getting highest ranks and learning the game mechanisms, the whole"getting gud" part, were  one of the most satisfaying experiences i had in gaming in years. If youre looking for a reason no to buy it - perhaps 20 euro for a engine demo is a bit steep, also the learning process is quite painful, with countless retries and "that wasn't my fault... okt maybe it was" moments. Other then that, if u love MGS and can't wait for TPP, GZ will drill a hole in your skull that will give u certain distate for every other game that isn't The Phantom Pain, and make every day without TPP seem boring and wasted. 
I warned you.

review:
Back in the day, a game with this much content would have been considered a demo and given out for a free download from a fileplanet FTP or something along those lines... But, now we are in the age where people spend money to put armor on a horse, so, here it is.

Despite that, this game is amazingly well done, and there's honestly a surprising amount of content here. If you're the kind of person to go digging for extras and to play alternate missions, you'll probably get a few good hours out of this game. If you're just interested in the story, it's between an hour or two to finish. The story is also the typical confusing MGS flavor, with not much making sense, but hey, that's Kojima for you.

I don't regret paying $13 to get a taste of MGS again, since it has been a long time. I'm also incredibly excited to play MGS V after playing this, because the port was fantastic and the gameplay was great. The guards are much smarter here, and the world feels a lot more dynamic. If this demo is any indication, the full game is going to be absolutely fantastic.

On another note, I really miss David Hayter as the voice of Snake.

review:
First the good.  The graphics are great. The game looks superb. The gameplay is excellent. You are free to approach your objective any way you like.  Enemy AI is fair and consistent. Decent voice acting. 

The bad: WAAAY too short, I beat the game in less than three hours. Then they want you to play the same mission again only different objectives and in daylight, wow. This would have been a free demo 10 years ago. 

Cutscenes are way too long and make no sense at all. I know that is kinda a Kojima trademark, but it's still annoying.  Lots of credits.  I know that sounds weird but every 5 minutes something pops up like "Written by Hideo Kojima, Music by Hideo Kojima, Craft Services by Hideo Kojima". Yeah, we get it, Hideo Kojima is a superhuman who did everything in the game. 

Controls are ported from console with very little modification for PC.  The is especially true in menus and the iDroid. You can't even click on things at some points, but instead you need to press 1 or 3 to cycle through your options.  So annoying.

This is not worth $20.  They basically peeled off the first mission of Phantom Pain and decided to sell it.  Total BS, IMHO. There are better games on steam for less than half this price.

review:
As an "old" fan of the serie I was afraid to play with a bad PC port but I was wrong.

This prequel is awesome and I hope to play MGSV The Phantom Pain.

+ Stealth actions as always
+ Big Boss 
+ Incredible Graphics for a PC port
+ UI/UX on menu is easy to navigate
+ Story, even if you are new to the saga (and you shouldn't) this prequel help you understand something
+ To finish up this game 100% you have to play a lot, even if is a "short" prequel

- Hard mode not so hard, back in the days of MGS1 that was really hard :-D
- Too much lens

review:
I recommend Ground Zeroes but you must know is not a common standalone game. Is a prologue for MGSV The Phantom Pain. And of course a demo, benchmark etc etc etc...haha!

If you're MGS fan play this before TPP release date. It has not a bad price. At least now a year after its release (just wait for a sale). I have the PS4 version. I was not happy about the pricing at the beginning (even with the drop) but now the game is at a good price and is a good opportunity to have a 4k legacy version (this PC version).

It's a achievement based game (if you like that). So if take this as a 6 mission VR training game and you want to complete it at 100% you'll enjoy it. I find myself playing it a lot the last year.

Also I wanna mention that the game has one main cannon mission "Ground Zeroes" and it's very very short and not very rewarding in story terms but is there.

FOX Engine looks nice, and works good on PC too (after a one year delay it was mandatory to have a good "port". Sorry it is not but a port but is the first game on PC with this Engine working OK...PES 2014...:V ).

Finally for those who didn't play MGS in the past. I don't think is a good choice for them to start here. But I recommend they borrow this via Steam Family Share or a console version (only 8th Gen. 7th looks awful) :)

review:
First of all if you're just looking for a linear story experience then buy something else, this is not the cutscene heavy go from point a to point b typical metal gear game.

If you can get over that and actually adapt to the new gameplay style you will vastly enjoy this game and get more than your money's worth. This is a game about exploration and experimentation. There is one main mission and six side missions, two of which are unlockable. If you just go through the missions just to beat them you'll probably get 4-5 hours of content, possibly more depending on how long it takes you to tackle those missions. 

The real meat of the game is experimenting with the new fox engine and how to tackle those missions. For example there is a side mission where you have to assassinate two targets, now you can just go and kill them, you can go and grab a sniper rifle and take them out from a distance to more easily escape, you can extract both of the targets by chopper to get more information, it's up to you.

There's also prisoners and hidden secrets in every mission and context sensitive events that can be uncovered and triggered. All of these hidden secrets are the main story of this game. If you want to understand why certain characters act a certain way during the main game or what happened before you got there you have to uncover the tapes, they also potentially reveal information about The Phantom Pain. There's also XOF patches to find to unlock the two extra missions as well as unlockable weapons that can be placed at the starting point of each mission.

The gameplay is amazing in this game, with the addition of open world gameplay you have no radar so you have to mark and pay attention to enemies, there are such small details added that affect gameplay like the difference in knockout time between choking a guard, tranquilizing a guard and punching out a guard, how long a guard will stay asleep in a dark area versus a sunny area and other features. Reflex mode is an optional bullet time that triggers when you're spotted and it balances out the guard AI which can spot you from anywhere and from far distances especially on hard difficulty,

As a PC port of a console game this is one of the best PC ports I've ever played, there are so many customization options and it has been optimized perfectly and the controls are excellent with the exception of no mouse control in menus.

There is also a lot of mod support for this game and I have no doubt the modding community for this game will expand and produce more content in the future, this game is amazing and definitely worth the money if you can accept it as a new type of experience.

review:
If this weren't simply a prequel I'd have given it my personal Game of the Year for 2014, but I expect Phantom Pain to deliver that for me in 2015. In case you're wondering, GOTY 2014 for me was Wolfenstein: The New Order.

In my mind this is a complete return to what made MGS 1-3 so fantastic. 4, while great in it's own way, was largely a playable movie with a bit of gameplay thrown in. Ground Zeroes has almost as much gameplay as 4 if you do all of the side missions and challenges so don't believe the rumors that there isn't much to this. Replayability is huge, take the time to train for Phantom Pain with some of the new features, because I found about a dozen ways to beat each mission and had an absolute blast doing it.

The ambience, gun control, stealth mechanics and general visual appeal of Ground Zeroes was near flawless for me. I love stealth games in general with MGS being my all time favorite franchise so I can be very picky about how it's done.

I'd love to see a little bit more consideration given to challenge timers for those of us who feel the need to kill enemies now and then. I love to do complete stealth runs of all types and I thoroughly enjoy the pacifist approach, but a challenge timer for simply getting in and out without being detected would be fantastic. I like to roleplay this series so while I do go completely pacifist at least once I find it logical to kill people now and then.

Overall, worth every penny, can't wait for Phantom Pain.

review:
Despite being a huge Metal Gear fan, I can't recommend the game at this price point. $20/£16.99 is a real slap in the face for fans who want a sneak peak at Phantom Pain. 

This type of thing would have been released on a demo disc back when MGS was released for the Playstation, along with 4-5 other demos for $5 including the magazine.

There is a single mission to rescue two rather obscure characters who we are given limited information about. The unlocked "side missions" are extremely straightforward, basic/scripted kill this/take out this missions that feel rushed and that re-use the original map from the "main" level. (These are clearly an attempt to pad-out what I'm sure they knew would look like a cash-grab). 

The game's visuals and engine looks fantastic - I'm sure Phantom Pain is going to be excellent. That said, I would not part with the money again for what is essentially an hour (at best) sneak peak at the completed game. 

Good on Konami for giving us the sneak peak - shame on them for charging through the nose for it.

review:
I wont lie, this is just a demo, but it's a really fun, really well made demo. Runs smooth, looks great. Snake's rear end isn't the main star either. 

It looks as if they toned down the well formed curves on the butt we all grew to know and love, but it takes away very little from the over all demo. 

5/5 I like the new buttless direction we seem to be going in.

-An excellent PC port except there's no mouse cursor in menu. M+KB controls work fine in-game. 

-Really Nice Graphics and Story is awesome as always. 

-Side Ops and Extra Ops have quite a lot variations to play through although there's only a single Map to play in the game. 

-Gameplay is solid and is a great introduction to the world of Metal Gear Solid to players. 

-If you take out the Side Ops and Extra Ops then game is short but it was meant as a Prologue to The Phantom Pain, the main game which is touted by Hideo Kojima himself to be 200 times bigger than Ground Zeroes (HYPE!)

-My Rating for this game would be 8.5 out of 10 due to only 1 map being available to play for a $20 game although i got it on a 33% Discount. I would've given it a full 10 if it was somewhat longer in length.

review:
Like A BOSS!!

I've played all the Metal Gear games and I have to say the way they are going with the new games is amazing. It's now an open world where every time you play is different. Do whatever you want, take on the mission any way you want. Unlike with other games where they changed things and totally lost the feel of what made the game good, the changes Kojima Productions did only made Metal Gear Solid better. They did'nt loose that Metal Gear Solid feel. You still use alot of the crawling and sneaking. Another thing I like is the HUD it has the bare minimum. No on screen map showing you where the enemy is. The only way to keep track of your enemy is to tag them with your binoculars. This makes the game feel real and full of suspense.

This is just a prologue! You only get one map with this game. When I found this out I was kind of dissapointed at first. After I completed the first mission which was awsome. It unlocked other missions within the same map. So you can replay this alot and not get bored. 

This game is worth it if your a hardcore Metal Gear Solid fan like me. It's a nice little taste of what is to come of The Phantom Pain.

intel i7 3770k
EVGA GTX 970 FTW

review:
It costs you a dollar a minute to play this game/Demo. That is how long you will play it. 20 minutes, not including cut scenes. 

On the plus side the game/demo is fun. I would love it if I had a full game of this to play. However, I don't. I have a 20 dollar demo. The graphics are amazing and the game has good character movement and control. I just wish there was more to it. 
There are some side missions but they are on the same map just different times of the day. Sad panda.
Well, what I thought was the intro to the game was, in fact, the entire game. Much disappoint.

review: Not my type of game.  Game's narrative is well written, greate graphics, but little in story content that I would consider entertainment.  The creator is clearly attempting to depict the US in a bad light.  In my opinion, the gaming genre is not an adecuate medium of expression where politics are concerned.  To be honest, I did not get past the opening cut scene where a young boy is caged like a dog.  Factoring out my dislike for the game's message, the game's mechanics look good and the graphics are really really good.

review:
The enemy AI in this game is absolutely why I continue to play, and replay this game at least once a week.

When I play stealth games, I'm not interested in learning patrol patterns and sneaking around them with no problem. What I'm really interested in is an AI system that has context and situational awareness. This game has both. The main mission takes place during a hurricane, naturally this gives the AI reduced sight/hearing and what have you. I'll give a very brief example of the AI's contextual awareness.

After getting spotted and going into the, as I understand it, new slow motion 'second chance' system where you can take out the enemy that spotted you and go unnoticed, I shot the unlucky guard in the face with a suppressed weapon. Minutes later I intercept a radio transmission from the control tower the the guard I just took out. From what I can tell each guard is assigned a number 'Delta 1, Delta 2' and so on. Since the guard they were radioing was out of commision, they sent another guard to check on him. Soon they found the body. 

In most stealth games you'd expect them to see the body and then either that guard doesn't tell anybody and searches for you, or other guards that have no idea what happened all know you're there. This game was different.
He assessed the situation and radioed back to the tower that he died of a gunshot wound and since nobody reported hearing one, concluded that the intruder responsible must be using a suppressed weapon. After hearing this information, the entire base went on alert with sirens going off all over the place and backup arriving just a minute later.

Most stealth games these days have me feeling pretty confident that I can hide around a corner and I won't get spotted. This is not the case for Ground Zeroes. If you want to get 20 feet inside this base without getting seen or heard, you need to find a vantage point and survey the area for a good 5 minutes, tagging enemies, trucks, watch towers ect.
This is as true to life as any stealth game I've played has come for me in the past 20 years. If you like MGS, this is worth checking out to get a taste of the Phantom Pain. If you like stealth games, there's enough here to keep you busy without knowing the setting or story.

This is just an example of how advanced this AI is for this type of open world setting. I'm a new fan of the MGS games and other than the Metal Gear Acid 'board games' for the PSP is my first time playing any MGS game. I can already say that without a doubt, I'm buying Phantom Pain when it releases and for stealth lovers, this is a lovely distraction from the wait until Phantom Pain comes out.

review:
Recommended if you can get it for under $15.

My first impression of this game was that it was a steaming pile of horse-shit since I got a somewhat common bug where it won't read your 360 controller input AND screws up key bindings, rendering the game unplayable until you do some mundane fixes. So that was dumb.

Afterwards, having gotten everything working, the game ran beautifully and was fun. It's short, but there's plenty of optional missions and tasks to accomplish so for those of us not completely bored by the map after one runthrough, there is replayability here. AND RAIDEN! Even if it's just a glorified skin.
MGS snake eater better :/

review:
This game is superfun, the graphics are amazing, the port from the consoles to pc was made really well, the game runs really smooth, no fps drops, and the options you have how you want to do the missions is epic.

I bought this game on sale, i thought it was the new releasy of the game, watched the AngryJoe review and was horrified, i thought ' did i just buy a demo? oh no' and then i started playing the game and WOW. Blabla yeah the story is short but if you play the sidemissions too (which you will) it is so fun. Also i had the feeling the steam achivements were part of the mission i have never felt so before but it is so satisfying to do them.

The key to playing this game is to explore the possibilities of approaching your goal. I spent hours upon hours doing the first mission in one try undetected and without killing anyone. It just gives you that feel that you have accomplished something. 

Yeah you can go ahead and whine that the map is small and stuff, but to me it feels big, all the missions are played on the same map but the patrols are different, you have to go to different places on the map, it has nice variety in my opinion and is definitely worth the price i paid when it was on sale.

review:
Lemme start off by saying this game is amazing, runs fantastically and manages to look really good doing it. However, don't buy it for any more than $15 as it is pretty short.

As for the game itself, the gameplay is fantastic, everything feels fluid and CQC has never been more satisfying than it is in this game. There's a fair amount of stuff to do, I've gotten 18 hours out of it but I've pretty much run out of things to do, and half of that was due to modding. And there is some minor modding going on, so if you get a kick out of that it may be more worthwhile for you.

Either way, if this is anything to go by, the actual MGS5 is gonna be amazing, probably game of the year for 2015.

It's simple:  an expensive DEMO, they should charge 5-10 dollars max.There is no need to charge more than 10 for a demo you really want to play. I believe even tomb raider or saints row the third it's at 20 dollar price and are considered also AAA games, FULL games.
   
   On the gameplay side controls are not totally explained and better played with a controller. The AI functions like a game, sometimes they get you, sometimes they ignore you even when you are infront of them, sometimes killing them and they will keep you at peace.
 
   Either way I'm buying "The Phantom Pain", I am really happy to see the newest Metal Gear games coming to Pc since the  Sons Of Liberty back in 2001 (I believe).

It's a shame people only talk about the lenght of this game, and not about its undeniable quality.
Metal Gear Solid V Ground Zeroes is a really well-done product.
Yes, the game is just a prologue, featuring the same very big map, but its more than worth the very very small price you can buy it for.
The gameplay is amazing!
The older metal gear solid games (which i still love) stiffness is gone, and now Big Boss finally is a fluid character.
This is the perfect evolution of the classic stealth gameplay of the saga, and there are so many welcome changes.
This is the first metal gear solid game in which you are actually free to approach the mission however you like to.
The "Camp Omega" (the map of the game) is a very big and articulated sandbox, that can be navigated in many different ways.
You can finally forget about those corridors of the older games.
The map offers a lot of covers and sneaking routes but, at the same time, is literally filled with enemies, and so some times you need all of your stealth skills to pass undetected.
Sure, you can still go "All Guns Blazing", or neutralise all enemies with the tranquilizer gun, but these are the worst ways to play the game.
Disable reflex, try to avoid enemies, complete all secondary objects and do not trigger any alarm.
This way you'll be rewarded with one of the best (and most challenging) stealth experiences available!
For the first time in the saga the enemies can finally spot you; even from a distance! So passing under their eyes this time will take so much more skill (and that's a good thing).
Some people believe the game only features the main mission (Ground Zeroes), but there's so much more to the package!
The 6 side/extra missions (which take place in the same map, but different times of the day) are really well made and they offer a complexity and dynamism i really didn't expect.
It was a true joy playing them.
So in the end you get a very well made prologue with 7 missions that can easily take you something like 8 hours to complete with an s-rank, and that assuming you don't want to chase achievements (For that you'll need so many more hours), all for a very very small price (You can find this game online (legit keys) for 10 dollars).
A brief note on the technical side; the port is amazing! It's greatly optimised and works flawlessly.
The graphics are perfect! A huge amount of detail and an amazing lighting system. the fox engine is a true beast.
This prologue really gives us a small teste of the masterpiece the phantom pain will be, and it's highly recommended to all MGS fans.

Pros:

- Modern Stealth Gameplay
- Fluid Character's Movements
- Satisfying Difficulty (If played as a stealth purist)
- Amazing "Sandbox-Style" map
- Many different approaches to the same goals
- Inspired side missions
- Many easter eggs
- Many Collectables/Hidden objectives
- Greatly Optimised Port
- AMAZING Graphics
- Amazing presentation (As usual with Kojima)

Cons:

- Only one (Even if very big and articulated) map
- Needs too much patience to complete achievements (Some of which ask you to complete the same missions over and over and over again)
- The game can be completed in a very short time, if played without chasing the ultimate stealth experience.
- Makes the wait for the phantom Pain even harder than it used to be

10/10

review:
This game is definetely worth a playthrough or 2 or 3 however beware of the price tag, As it was at the time of this review it cost £17.99 which is quite pricey for something which i completed first go after not playing mgs in about 3 years in about 1 1/2 hours.

The game looks great, the stealth system works as realistically as ever, there is a lot of side content which could extend a playthrough to another hour or 2 if pushed and stealth is not required if you want to go against everything metal gear solid stands for so you can run and gun your way through to the objectives.

As long as the phantom pain is longer than this then I will be looking forward to buying it on steam also because consoles r for children :)

review:
Gear Up!

Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes, now with a quick google and forum search, you'll see the torrents of abuse towards this "Half the price as a full retail game tech demo" nonsense. On top of it all, ignore that.

This is Kojima's masterpiece of advertising, almost a teaser. 
From the moment you press start, this amazing cinematic of ground zeroes instantly pulls you in. The sound, the atmosphere, you feel as if you're part of some summer blockbuster.

Then once you begin, you're awestruck by what even a modest PC can show you. 
Using the binoculars I zoomed in on two marines having a chat about an event in the opening cinematic, the faces photorealistic, not a single balaclava or full faced helmet in the entire complex (Apart from prisoners I must add, but see any camp x-ray photo of prisoners if you think why would they do this?).

On one of the missions you are to retrieve intelligence, but knowing the events of the mission, I snuck around and nosed at what the soldiers of camp omega where upto. I was amazed to hear two soldiers chatting about knowing a certain secret of the mission and how its been altered in a subtle way. Now 99% of players wouldn't of heard this, but for it to be put it, on the off chance, astounded me.

Now to move onto the missions on ground zeroes, yes they're short, but you can tackle them a million plus ways!
I did playthroughs of most missions where I pretty much crawled through any possible track of cover to get this done, I then did this whilst doing my very best Rambo / Arnie impressions. 
Every single mission, every single play style, resulted in totally different results and reactions.

Kojima is a master advertiser, by releasing this he has ramped up so much anticipation, I don't believe any trailers, press releases or even a leak (barring an iso leak) could of drummed up the attention focused on the phantom pain.

review:
AWESOME

Never liked 100%-ing games before, but THIS one, with a tiny map being played over and over, forcefully makes me play it again and again until i get all those S-ranks, until I evade every single troop and leave no trail of my presence.

(finished the GZ mission in 1 hour. still playing. awesome)

unlimited empty mags supply

10/10

review:
For everyone who loves the Metal Gear franchise and wants to prepare for Phantom Pain this is a nice little game to get some tasting and train some of the new mechanics. Be aware though The main game doesnt last very long, however if you are a diehard fan and go looking for all hidden tapes you can squeeze out some decent time as you can see from my time spent. 

However its recommended to buy it when it is on any kind of discount I picked it up during the christmas sale and spet 14 bucks iirc.

So if you are a fan of the MGS series, easy recommandation, if not, I dont know rather wait for the release of Phantom Pain I guess.
A demo more worth your $20 than most AAA full releases.

review: Like my day to day life, I'm always saying "in the end nothing really matters" You know like I'm some fucking record on repeat, the on going repetition of my mundane self quotes. Maybe it's because I want to feel important, like I'm really above the riff raff, like, look at me peasants, bow to your new savior because I have life all figured out. Excuse me while I click my heels and tip my fedora, I'm paving a new way of life for you guys here. This is some doomsday book level of philosophy, I'm towing planets while you still gazing at stars in bewilderment. It's all conceit, and it's contention with my own shadow, I'm bigger than life, and smaller than a microbe. Day in and day out, the same ol shit. The ones who are afraid to be alone, and the ones who blend with a crowd. I dreamt I was chilling with some rich douche bag ex friend of mine, and we were chilling in his mansion, I question why live such a life of luxury when you could be helping those in need. He said, and I quote, " it's not about living the life of luxury, it's all about never having enough and wanting more, so you really don't truly have an understanding of being rich, because in our minds, we aren't rich enough, nor will we ever will be". I said damn, that's some deep shit, I bet if I was pissing in lambos and snorting snow by the pounds, I wouldn't really be thinking of shit either. You know, like I would totally be justifying my way of life to the lesser peons of the world. So where does this all leave me? On a one way road at full speed to meet a brick wall. I will never attain happiness, I will never understand the inner workings of humanity, and I will never have a normal albeit limited functioning brain that most of society has, to bask in my own ignorance. What I have and all I will ever have, is my Diamond Dogs.

review:
Pros : The game in itself is amazing, it's beautiful and you start getting involved quite easily.
           It also runs great on 4k with a GTX 760, no lagging issue

Cons : The story mode lasts 40 minutes

Pretty sure that "The Phantom Pain" is going to be amazing
I already knew about it's lenght so i can't really complain, but i still expectect something a little bit longer.
On a personnal note, i was used to the classic MGS controls and i'm more invested in the story then the side mission.

Buy the game on sales, 10-15$ max.
I'll pay full price for "The Phantom Pain"

review:
The good:
Excellent port of what is, at its core, an excellent game. The classic MGS stealth reimagined in an open world, with some minor tweaks to mechanics. Let me begin by saying that I really like this game, and could go on at great length as to why I like it. Instead of doing this, I'm going to focus on the few small issues that I dislike about this game, as I hope this will be more informative. (Also, I played this quite a bit more on PS3, so please disregard my low hour count on PC). 

1. Keifer freakin' Sutherland. They didn't even try to get someone who SOUNDED like the Snake/Big Boss from the previous games. Really breaks the immersion for me. I'm really hoping this is explained through some plot twist in MGS5, such as it actually being Grey Fox or someone other than BB. 

2. The "awareness detection" mechanic is a little overpowered. It's pretty common for the game to indicate that some far-off enemy that I cannot see at all has spotted me, and I can simply hide until he looks away. The entire point of MGS is to truly engage with the stealth, and that means relying on your own senses rather than some magical sixth-sense that the Boss has. Makes me miss the days of the Soliton Radar, or the pretty excellent sense ring from MGS4.

3. Likewise, the "slow time" mechanic when you're spotted seems pretty OP. Being able to run into a group of four grunts and easily put tranq darts into each of their faces during slow-mo makes it a lot less punishing to be caught. I know you can disable this, but it feels wrong to have it included in the first place. 

4. I don't like the COD-style health regen. Give me the health system from Snake Eater any day, where wounds are permanent(ish) and actively affect your performance, and you also have to worry about hunger and mental state. 

All in all, it's still a really good game. The MGS series has always been about balancing that line between stealth and force, but this one seems to lean more towards force.

review:
The game crashes during the final cutscene and I am unable to proceed.

The frame-rate drops drastically and my computer slows down. I've read that the graphics settings must be set to the lowest in order for the cutscene to play but it's still not working.

That being said, the actual game is really good. It's very short, however. A lot of the replay value is from going back and completing little missions.

I can't wait for the Phantom Pain.

review: Big fan of the series but this definitely feels different. the controls are far from classic and the system as a whole has changed. Still not used to it after finishing the main mission but overall it was enjoyable. Some of the best graphics I've seen from Fox engine and even in general. If you're a fan of MGS and are willing to spend a hefty fee for a little insight into the beginnings of The Phantom Pain then you'll enjo this. If you're an outsider looking in, just wait until MGSV comes out.

review:
Excellent graphics.  Fox Engine is truly efficient. The game is fun to play as there are so many different ways to clear each mission.  A good value at the sale price.  I had problems configuring my PS2 controller (a community fix helped).  The depth of field needs some rework.  Most of the time, Snake looks blurred even when he's in focus.  Sometimes the graphics look better with DOF off.  Cutscenes are correct though.  Overall a great experience.

Also glad that a really annoying character dies in this game ... hopefully.

I prefer the PC version, but if Phantom Pain does not get the same release date as consoles, I will end up buying the PS4 version and pass on a deferred PC version.

Short, but sweet. Ground Zeroes shows us whaty a proper port can be. Runs incredibly well on my multiple PCs. Looks great and plays great. If this is a preview of whats to come, then TPP is most definitely going to deliver.

review:
Well I am a hugh Metal Gear fan and seeing the MGS franchise finally hitting the consoles is amazing.
The first release was Rising Revengance witch delivered at steady 60 fps with and mid-range card... 
And now this
This game is one of the few ports that feels optimized also for the PC platform, there is not a lot of performance issues (the only one I noticed was when I entered another area and the game saved, I got some frame drops, but not too much to ruin the experience)
I will recommend this to all MGS fans to see how far the franchise has come, if you care about story and this is your first, I would not recommend it to you, but if you like a fun stealth sandbox, please go ahed and buy it :D

On the rating scale I would give this a 9.5 out of 10, but that is more a personal score. 

(Both positive and bad) 
Honestly the game is hard, without the fine ability called reflex mode you got less than a second to act before the alarm goes off, I wish I got a chance to do something about it without the reflex. But with reflex it could get hard aswell. 

 - The cutscenes feel sloppy (Unstedy cams, maybe meant to be, but not cool to look at)
 - Soldiers in Camp Omega has no voices, WHY? (MGS3 every soldier had a voice, makes this game feel cheep)
 - Could have gotten more stealth sidemissions in the night, most of the side missions are in daytime and not that fun
 - Kazuhira Miller and tutorials, just won't sh*t up (pardon my language)

 + The game main story is 1 - 2 hours long, but that only gets you 18% THIS means replayability wich is good.
 + SIDE MISSIONS!
 + Fun gameplay
 + Steady 60 FPS with a mid range GPU

______________________BOTTOM LINE______________________________________________________

9.5/10 - Recommended for those of you who have played some MGS games before and like the stealth genre :)

review:
Great game.  I was amazed with the graphics and how smooth the movement is.  Going stealth is very tricky and challenging but rewarding.

However, I thought that this is a full game. It is more of a teaser for the main game, The Phantom Pain.  Like they say, this could have been just a free demo.  It only contains one main mission and some side missions to complete.  I should have just waited for the main event.

review:
Finally a proper Metal Gear game on PC! 

Absolutely fantastic single player experience that I think appeals to fans of the series and new players alike. The gameplay and presentation are polished to a mirror shine as expected from Kojima's previous titles on console platform.

The narrative here will  be a little daunting to players unfamiliar with the story so far but doesn't detract from the gameplay if you decide to give it a go anyway. The cutscenes are all in engine and push a level of details few games have reached up to this point.

This is the first release I've played that technically feels properly "Next Gen", I had no technical issues and the game ran smoothly whilst looking and playing great.

Expect to get a few hours out of this game so only purchase if you believe the price is right.

review:
It is a fun game but it's very much not finished on the PC.

Crashes and freezes are common on my hardware (which surpass minimum specs quite alot).  Even when I'm getting 60 FPS it will freeze for a second or two, unfreeze, and freeze again 10 seconds later.  Keyboard and mouse controlls are awful, but to be honest with the ammount of actions you need to do it's not really their fault, and they do let you maps your keys which is a huge plus.  And yes it is VERY short.  19.99 is a more fair price though then the original 39.99 it was on PS3.  Kiefer's preformance is very generic, and is going alone with the "If I talk as low as I can and sound cool and calm about everything I'm a great actor", thing that is popular nowadays.  I really miss Hayter because at least he had a pulse.

Would love to give this a thumbs up and will when it's fixed.

Plus the fanboys will eat up ANYTHING

review: It's been a long time since I've played a MGS game and I decided to rekindle the enjoyment I have had for earlier installments.  I was really looking for a game with a fun plot to play through so I threw my money at a franchise I trusted.  Only there is no plot to play through. Just one map and you're done.  There really should be a disclaimer about this on steam that this is not an actual game.  It's mere a teaser FOR the actually game. This is the part of the game that other companies give out for free.  I paid for shiny pixels and a couple cut scenes.  This is the first time I've actually purchased a game and felt genuinley swindled.  I keep telling myself maybe the people who bought this get te actual game for free when it comes out but I know it's merely a pipe dream.  First bad review I've given, and I don't think I'll pick up another MGS game again for the selfishness the company has demonstrated here. Pity I always liked Snake too.

review:
If you are a noisy doofus with snail reactions, butter-fingers and horrible spatial coordination like me you're gonna have a hard time from the beginning by being constantly shot at. But in that is its beauty - I enjoyed every second of this "demo" trying to get better and better with my cunning and stealth skills. This game has some replay value  - different missions on the same map and getting better scores.

Oh, and yes, Phantom Pain can't get released soon enough, I am SO stoked for what happens next in Big Boss' adventure after seeing the outro.

review:
Metal Gear Solid 5: Prologue. (If you ever played Gran Turismo)

If you are a Metal Gear fan you probably already decided to buy this, but for those who are not so big of fans or on the fence I would say wait for a good sale to get your money's worth.

This is very short game in both story and content, but it showcases what the new Fox Engine can achieve.
Only one map is available but different missions and each mission has different objecteves and layouts (time of day, ememy placement, POW placements, items, etc.) for the map. Plus a Ranking system for each mission to keep you going for higher and higher scores.

The gameplay is what I expected; par the course for the next step of the Metal Gear Solid games, adding new items, weapons, and ways to interect with NPCs and the environment. Being able to scale objects and get on rooftops and the ability to drive vehicles or just simply ride inn the back of a truck adds so much in the way you can tackle objectives.

review: Don't waste your money on a glorified tutorial level. If you're interested in MGSV, then save your money for Peace Walker. There's no important plot development, just skip this entirely. If this tech demo is any indication, Peace Walker should be an amazing stealth game. That said, there's only one mission in Ground Zeroes. It will take you about an hour, with another 20 minutes or so for cutscenes, credits and what amounts to an exended advertisement for Peace Walker. The only other content in the game comes in the form of a handful of unlockable alternate missions in the same level. It's a well-built level in a well-optimized engine with pretty solid mechanics, but there's less content here than in most Early Access games. I cannot in all good conscience recommend that anyone buy this game with Peace Walker right around the corner.
