review:
For fans of the series, there is no reason not to play this. For those of you looking for a good, story-driven sneaking game... Wait for The Phantom Pain or play Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker first. Most references, characters and story arcs can be found in Peace Walker.

As for the length of the main campaign... I think there's been enough talk about that already. Only true fans will appreciate the collectibles, the easter eggs and the story teasers that can be found within this game.

... oh, and it also includes a rape-tape. You perverts.

An excellent PC port with serviceable controls. A controller would still be best in this particular case, but anybody can make due.

The graphics are top notch, gameplay is a very refined and much more fluid version of the previous games, and the story is about as nonsensical and prone to being a huge topic of debate for years to come - as you remember. My only grips with this is the fact that innately you can spot the enemies and follow their locations through walls, and that you have a reflex mode which triggers when you're first spotted that slows down time and allows to you dispatch the person who saw you. Thankfully, these can be disabled - I just hope the gameplay isn't balanced around those two things.

review:
This may be my favioute game of 2014. Sure, its short. but i've gotten so much enjoyment out of it. I rarely get emotional over games, but i got so angry over what happened at the ending, I havent felt such emotion out of any other series. 


The gameplay, is actually really good. I expected it not to translate well from console to keyboard, but i was honestly suprised.

This game is worth every penny. The only problem is you need to know your MGS lore to get into everything. You have the games before it to really understand who these people are, and pretty much everything going on. I'd recommend playing the whole series before playing this. DO NOT make this your first MGS game.

Overall, its a great game with brilliant storytelling, but the shortness off it is a bit of a worry.

review:
This, ladies and gentlemen, is how you do a port.

After spending nigh on 15 hours with the PS3 version, there was no doubt left in my mind that Ground Zeroes was worthy of being a Metal Gear Solid game. Say what you will about the length of the main mission, but this game clearly makes a case for the term "content" being much more nuanced than how most people refer to it.

Camp Omega is the real star of the show in Ground Zeroes - feeling like an amalgamation of the very best levels from Thief, Hitman, and the Splinter Cell series in their heyday - and it reinforces how the stealth genre is more about the levels than anything else. Everything about Camp Omega feels like it was crafted by experts: The believable vantage points, the sparing-yet-dense use of both high and low grounds, the use of light and shadow, it's all there.

The PC version (both surprisingly and unsurprisingly) is the definitive way to play this game. The FOX Engine truly shines when left to flex its muscles on superior hardware. Seeing rainwater drip down the face of one of the many nameless soldiers I would chokehold into submission later on in the opening cutscene was the first sign of the capabilities of this new engine.

I feel like the bar has been raised impossibly high by Ground Zeroes as a prologue to the upcoming The Phantom Pain. If the levels in the full game can capture even a fraction of the craft seen on display in this game, it will be more than something special.

review:
ONLY recommended FOR HARDCORE FANS !
Why ? Well, personally, i wasn't too much against the idea of payed prequel if it were something like good old "VR Missions" packs of tens or hundreds (which were free addons for updated editions of the games) on the new engine or the prequel mission would have decent length and a boss fight (like Tanker from MGS2). Sadly, there is none of that. Camp Omega area is super small, even "the admin building" is not a building but a box, and you don't "go inside" but around the walls.

There are serious gameplay issues:
• Turning auto-compensation / bad movement transitions: BB does additional movements that are not requested by user (This is especially embarrassing since MGS1 is known for its fluid controls and sharp turning). In a stealth game [especially of The Stealth Franchise] it makes a difference between successful manoeuvre or mission failure
• Wall sticking is replaced by clunky cover mechanic. Now BB tends to clumsily stick out of cover, wall throws/shots are almost impossible because line of sight is obscured while BB manages to stick out and be seen by enemies
• Bullet replenishment on save's reload. And that in the series that is known for putting player in interesting tactical situations, like having 3 bullets and empty mag for 7 enemies. Blasphemy !
• Aggressive health regeneration
• Enemies lie down indefinitely on the ground with their rifles beside them (that's just silly)
• Enemy telepathy & "reflex mode" instead of great MGS2 alert system
• Magazines are infinite
• You can't "cook" grenades or throw them slow and under or, better yet, control the arc (see Syphon Filter 1-3 for great example)
• Kaz never shuts the fuck up on replay
• Konami hasn't bothered to put sword gameplay in Raiden's mission or update models for MGS1-styled mission

Some upsetting technical deficiencies:
• Camera is too shaky
• Geometry clipping
• Knocked out enemies and POWs sometimes disappear and suddenly reappear
• Mouse sensitivity for aiming is not adjustable and too big
• Additional mouse buttons are not recognized
• DOF is insanely overblown
• Critical settings like AA, DOF and exact level of filtering are not clearly exposed
• LOD changes are too visible
• PC version doesn't have "music import" even thought Steam has it's own music library now

Moreover, it has story inconsistencies too:
• Disastrous lack of cutscenes and dialogues
• How Snake can be "formerly known as Big Boss" if in the ending of PW (that GZ starts almost immediately after) he ordered to be called like that ?
• Paz's name is incorrect, it should be "Pacifica Ocean"[spoiler]
• There can't be "no time for anaesthetic", the only thing they needed is a quick morphine injection, but then cutscene wouldn't be so dramatic
• A vagina-bomb ? Seriously ?! (see South Park "The Snuke" episode and "24" series)
• Runaway prisoner has a bag on his head. How the hell he got away and successfully hidden ?[/spoiler]

review:
I love MGS (Well, the ones done by Kojima) but I don't like game consoles, mainly because I think aiming with a joystick is idiotic when you can use a mouse.

I saw this on Steam, and figured I would buy it and use a USB controller.

Imagine my intense joy and gratification when the keyboard/mouse controls were not only possible, but were well done and felt entirely fluid and natural.

I am now twice as excited for Phantom Pain, because I know that actually playing it will be a joy, and I won't have to struggle through just to enjoy the storyline.

As a prequel and a showcase to the Fox engine and PC gameplay, this was excellent. 10/10 from me.

review:
This game is so damn awesome thank you Kojima sensei for giving it to us and making it one of the best pc ports out there, works greatly with my 5 year old processor i5 760 and 3 year old vga gtx 560ti. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T--JS16uSV8

Game is so great that I am super hyped for Metal Gear Solid V The Phantom Pain. MGSV GZ is a great game but it only have one mission with 2 main objectives and different scenarios with different challenges after you beat the mission so the price tag of $19.99 might be not justifiable for some but nevertheless you can get good 10-15 hours out of this if you want to 100% everything in the game including listening to all the cassette tapes for the story. 

Go for it if you are a fan of Metal Gear series or a fan of stealth games cos this game wont disappoint you.

review:
The prologue to The Phantom Pain--this thing is awesome. MGS:GZ may be only a couple hours long, and if you know where to go and are good at this then the game "can" be completed in as little as a few minutes (my current best is ~50 minutes). STILL, however, the game has so many ways to complete it, there are extra side ops to do afterwards (taking place at different times of day/weather), hidden goodies, etc that it really is a great game. I guess how much you get out of it depends on how much you like stealth games (I love'em), but the production values, the fine details, the price of entry--this game is worth it. Totally got my money's worth.

And oh yeah: great job porting this thing as the graphics are great for the power required. Longer draw distance (almost no pop-in at all at max), better shadows & lighting and higher resolutions for the PC master race of course. Very unexpected from a franchise that has a long history of pandering to consoles.

review:
As you can see by my hours played, i am very early in but i have already completed the game's main campaign.  I planned to buy this game on Xbox One when it was originally released but after hearing the initial reviews stating that the game could be beaten in under 30 minutes, i decided it was not worth the $40 price tag.

Enter MGS V: Ground Zeroes for PC.  Perfect timing in a plethora of ways.  Built my new rig a week before it was released which took me from barely meeting the low minimum specs to surpassing the recommended specs.  With the recent port releases spanning from RYSE, Dead Rising 3, Assassins Creed Unity and Far Cry 4, i had a bad taste in my mouth of ports.  While Far Cry 4 is playable, it suffered from some bad stuttering on release.  Unity was a bad prank that ubisoft should have waited until April to unleash.  I digress...To be blunt, MGS V is as perfect as you can get with a port.  Thanks Kojima!

MGS V was $13 when i purchased and at the moment i feel it has been worth every penny spent(DISCLAIMER: i am a MGS fan and have played all of them).  The gameplay is as fluid as ever and graphics look incredible at 1080p running somewhere around 60fps with a FX-8320+GTX750Ti SC+12gb Ram.  Not to mention the fact that i had OBS running in the background recording the entire thing, meaning i would probably gain 5-10fps.

While the actual story is quite short, this game is meant to be a short demo/prequel to the actual Metal Gear Sequel entitled the Phantom Pain.  Even after completing the Main campaign the game shows me somewhere around 10% completion which means there is a plethora of other things left to do outside the campaign.  

For those who love to mod your games, there are mods available already that allow you to play as Hideo Kojima, Classic Snake, Raiden, Fix your DOF, etc.

For those who love to mod your games, there are mods available already that allow you to play as Hideo Kojima, Classic Snake, Raiden, Fix your DOF, etc.", "timestamp_created": 1419879070, "timestamp_updated": 1419879070, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 1, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.499284446239471436", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
I hate to say it but this Snake seems to be more better in voice acting than the previous voice actor. A lot of memorable quotes were revisited and the game sucks you in by its emotional content. The game itself is graphically beautiful and the controls, albeit slow and awkward at times (hugging walls to avoid detection or look around corners, running nearby cliffs)  is fine and feels natural on an xbox controller.

I was playing on a 3570k i5, r9280x with settings cranked to the max. I have to say this engine and this prologue has gotten me excited for the next installment in the series.

review:
They kept us waiting huh? But because of that the game plays like a damn fiddle!


First of all I have to say that this is by far the best pc-port ive seen in years! I never experienced any drop in performance. The people over at ubisoft should bow before konami as they have much to learn from them! This is how you port ubisoft! 
Performance aside this game is awesome! even though its rather short it feels like the true ending of the psp game metal gear solid peace walker (which ends just before this game begins with the same characters and everything). All I can say is this is a MUST BUY if you have some money and time to spare!

Damn, Metal Gear Solid series, never fail to amuse or entertain, with its amazing [u]Cinematic scenes and Facial expressions along with the character emotions, the music, the smooth gameplay, the stealth, the explosions and the ofcourse Snake[/u]. The game is just mind blowing regardless if its just an hour long or so, it delivers, worth every penny I have spent this Christmas.

This is just a tease of what and more the actual MGS V: The Phantom Pain will be like, which will just blow our minds away, the scenes in this and the emotional band wagon it drags is just done flawlessly amazing,

Definitely recommended for you to go ahead and see whats instored for you! on the MGS V: The Phantaim Pain

[i]P.S For those, having issues with the game non starting, make sure you remove the wirelesss reciever of your Gamepad, worked like a charm after I did that!! :)![/i]

review:
You ask, "Is this worth the money?" Well, I have two answers for that.

[b]YES:[/b] If you care about the story, have been playing Metal Gear since 1998, and/or want the immersive experience that watching a playthrough on streaming website could not even come close to.

[b]NO:[/b] If you are really that concerned about beating this in five minutes, can't see any fun messing around in a sandbox environment, or do not lust for getting a first-hand/first-look experience with the Fox engine.

I cannot stress enough how crucial plot is, and to just stream this feels like it would not have intended impact it should have if one was playing through this themself. Just do yourself a favor and play this before Phantom Pain comes out.

review:
There's not a whole lot to say. The stealth is perfect, with hard mode approaching true realism. The gameplay itself is phenomenally deep, and I'd be hard pressed to get bored in TPP with just the mechanics shown here. The engine and optimization are phenomenal; Let's put it this way. My rig can run AC: Unity at about 15 fps on minimum settings. It can also run Ground Zeroes exactly as well as a PS4 or XB1 with perfect framerates. 

It's also pretty fun.

review:
You might think this game is not worth it at all. "Oh, there's only one mission pertaining to the story of Metal Gear Solid? It's no better than a demo and it's $20 dollars. Hell no, man." Well, You are wrong, my friend. This is game, does only contain one main mission pertaining to the story but multiple side ops and bonus ops. I'm very glad I bought this on PC since I have both Bonus Ops since each of them were console exclusives, I believe (they were later patched in so both consoles had both bonus mission. How nice of them). The "Ground Zeroes" mission is very fun to paly many times over and attempt to master. The side ops provide a little variety from the main mission and let you have some fun like the one where you save Hide Kojima and the Jamais Vu where you play as Raiden. Overall, just because this game is so short doesn't mean it's not worth it. I mean it's even more worth it because the day it came out, it was on sale for about 13 bucks. I recommend this game to anyone who is a hardcore MGS fan or anyone who's new. I mean, the story is fucked anyway. You'll learn soon hahaha.

NOTE: If you use Dxtory - a video recording software - or have it open, this game will not launch. You must have that off.

review:
Yuppers this can be beaten in 15 minutes. But if you can accomplish that then you've put in a lot of time and effort to achieve that. This is a MASSIVE change in gameplay style from previous MGS games, it's tense, it's claustrophobic, it's an amazing sense of scale, difficult but friendly for new players. It's amazing how much there is to do in just a "small" map and while the game is darker it's still has a wonderful sense of humor that is true to MGS fanboys out there.

The PC port is phenomenal, freaking sharp and beautiful. I do have complaints over the analog stick sensitivity is off compared to the console versions, and also the music tracks for the helicopter were cut. I need Boss to run around to Queen's "Don't Stop Me Now." And really surprised how little Kiefer Sutherland is in this game. I nerd out over the final cinematic the fight on Motherbase, "WAS HE D RANK OR S RANK, I'd never have a D Rank guy on there. that would be horrible if the guy who died was S rank."

It's worth rebuying this "demo". And so was Zone of the Enders 1 and the PS1 demo disc also ;)

Excellent game. Having Metal Gear on PC is awesome. Even my craptop can play this game on a mix of Medium and High.
Kojima-san could teach other devs about optimization and making a great playing/looking game.
Making a mockery of the guards at Camp Omega doesn't get old. Highly Recommended.

review:
GZ Basically gets you into the groove of what TPP is going to be like, and the gunplay is pretty sweet. chances are you've heard about it being a demo, and for the most part; and it is. Heres a good way to look at it when you are considering whether or not to buy it:

If you are genuinley concerned as to whether or not your money is worth it, chances are you aren't going to enjoy it.

If you're a hardcore MGS fan and know how to keep yourself entertained by setting your own goals and screwing around, might as well give it a try.

An excellent showcase of the gameplay systems coming in the full game The Phantom Pain, but Ground Zeroes is very short and only worth the money to you if you love toying around with great stealth/shooter mechanics.

I don't regret the price tag at all, but I love MGS as well as stealth games. Your own experiences may vary.

review:
Ground Zeroes, when capped at 60fps, is formerly amazing at THIS price tag. It's almost like a rogue-like, a fully "arcade" session of Metal Gear Solid V. Lots, LOTS of options and things to do (but not AS much someone could think of looking at the absolute photo-realism of the enviroenment) if you look forward them. 

I'm not going to talk about the storyline or the heavy importance it has on the Saga, so I'll add one last line: the game is very, VERY "score"-centric, if you don't like to go for multiple runs, records or unlockables, I suggest to wait for a most likely future "GZ + TPP bundle".

review:
It's good to finally see the Metal Gear Solid on PC. Unfortunately the PC controls saw no extra love and the menu controls really suffer for it.

Note: This is the first time I've played a Metal Gear Solid game.

+ Excellent cinematography.
+ The story has me looking forward to Phantom Pain.

- Movement feels rough, especially fine movement (like trying to turn around to better hide in the bush you are right on top of).
- Weapon/Item select is terrible. There's no reason you shouldn't be able to throw a grenade, toggle night vision or toggle attachments with a single button press.
- No mouse support for the menus.

Playtime: ~ 6h
8/10

review: Is it weird to say that I went out of my way to purchase a GTX 760 just to run this game to find out that my original 660 would have been just fine. A superior port, which gives me new hype for Phantom Pain. But, yes, the game is short and I won't speed run it, took about 2 hours for me because I was trying to be semi-thorough and move the other prisoners to the chopper. I didn't realize I could bunch them together and extract them at the same time, so I spent a few minutes running back and forth from the compound to the LZ. Whatever. The Fox Engine looks great, it sounds great, and it ran like a charm. The only thing I ask now is; ETA on Phantom Pain, and possible ports of previous titles? If anyone can do it, it is the dev team at Kojima Productions. Keep up the great work.

review:
This is easily one of the best games I've played in 2014. I've been waiting for a game I felt like I could call "next-gen" in both its visuals and its gameplay and this is the first game that truly feels like a step up using the technology and the game design progression the decades of video games have seen. 

This is basically Metal Gear Solid distilled to its simplest yet most entertaining form. Every aspect of the game was perfectly designed to be balanced and entertaining. Plus this game is absolutely gorgeous.

If you've heard this game is short it is by no means too little. You can play this missions over and over again trying to improve your rank, and each time it will be a new experience due to the dynamic and free flowing nature of the game. Its one of those games that just feels good when you play it, everything in the game progresses in a fair and exiciting way. I've played this game for 20 hours and I still plan on playing it and unlocking the rest of the missions and getting S-rank on all the missions (a very challenging but fair task indeed). 

Seriously, this is a great game, and I can't wait to play The Phantom Pain.

Phantom Pain will surely be amazing.

review:
Metal Gear Solid is in my top 3 if we talk about the best games or stories. 
But I was against this game at the time of the console release, because i didnt wanted to support a one and a half hours "long" game. Well,I was wrong.

Maybe the main story mission is short (around 90 minutes at first try), but there are 6 more missions takes another 50-90 minutes to complete each. At this time I have 14+ hours in this game and haven't completed all of the content, so i will go back again and continue this great game.

The open world setting and the very polished gameplay mechanics makes the thing so great. You can go from any direction, with any weapon, using any tactics from killing all, to sleep/stun the guys or just avoid them.

The various missions taking place different times of a day, and the camp's layout offers many possibilities to take on or fool those guards, who are present in different numbers and walking on different patrol routes in each mission.

An the top of that there is a real big replay value in this game. I am really not the guy, who likes to repeat the same thing all over again, but the rating system at the mission's end, and the unlockable weapons, skins, or easter eggs made me having great fun with this game.

Playing this game is the most fun from actual gameplay aspect than any other previous MGS title.

9/10 where the 9 means that this game is one of the best games in the genre if not.

+ Exemplary optimalization and port quality. Best of 2014
+ Very nice graphics and performance
+ Hell lots of ways to complete any mission
+ Perfect dark tone story, great execution
+ Tons of easter eggs for the fans
+ Lots of unlockable bonuses
+ Save game carries over to the Phantom Pain

- If it would be 40 hours long, i would say it is short


If you like stealth, or you are familiar with the series just give it a go, you will not regret it.

review:
Good Stuff
Never watched walkthroughs of this game before, took me approximately 1hr 30 mins to complete, the main mission,with all the sneaking and looking for hostages, still doing side missions intense and fun, Smooth FPS, Dramatic Cut Scenes, good gameplay/ storyline, love the improved CQC,no more Above view,fluid movements and gunplay, lots of choices on how you want to complete a mission, different entry points , play according to your play style, loud or stealth, I've read about people crys about this game, but i truely enjoyed it. Can't wait for the Phantom Pain to release.

Only Bad things i encountered is the AI- #slightly retarded,
Was spotted in a back of a vehicle, layed in it and they just left after a few seconds back to patrolling, even in MGS 1 for PS1 they will flush you out with grenades.

Body parts no clipping through objects, knocking out guards ,character body movements goes into objects looks funny/bad, its 2014 fix that shit.

Interogation: you interogate and don't hear shit?, then you magically get intel. MGS 3 had this on point,

Bring back being a medic for yourself, remove bullets ,mend wounds, fix broken limbs.

Rate an 8/10.

review:
This game is a prologue to what is clearly going to be the next of Hideo Kojima's masterpieces. It is the new Pièce de résistance of the Metal Gear series.

You'll see complaints about the length of this game. To clarify, the main mission in this game averages around an hour and forty minutes long. There are also numerous side missions to complete, which bump the playtime up to an average of six hours long. 

To complete the game 100%, that is collecting all cassette tapes, getting all accolades in-game, rescuing everybody you're supposed to, and getting the best rank you can in the game, unlocking absolutely everything there is to unlock, you're looking at an average of at least 16 and a half hours of game-play out of this game.

To reiterate, if you play it just for the main mission and put it down after that, you're going to be disappointed. The intent with the release of this product was for fans of the series to try out the new game, get performance statistics over a wide series of systems, and see how the community responded to major changes in how the game operated. 

Choose your own destiny. Are you going to play this as a four minute speed-run of just one mission, or are you going to actually completely play the game and enjoy every last bit of what you paid for?


Performance is excellent. You can tell that the Fox engine has been given tons of love with a multiplatform focus being the centric point behind it. Running a GeForce 660, I'm able to achieve 60FPS constantly in all situations with all settings maxxed (with the exception of SSAO being on high as opposed to very high.) 

The controls are excellent, keyboard and mouse users will not be disappointed - you can rebind any key to where you want. Yes, I know it sounds ridiculous for me to even have to say that, but you'd be surprised with the massive number of shoddy console ports that have left this most basic function out. There are also a number of default controller layouts available for users whom are using standardized gamepads. 

Likewise, one of the most common complaints people have about the controls is the usage of arrow keys while in the menus - however they are not necessary. Somehow, everybody has overlooked the big prompts that say "1" and "3" in the menus, which should typically be enough to tell people that instead of relying on arrow keys to move the menus left and right, you can just use the "1" and "3" keys to scroll left and right respectively.

Story - 10/10. Yes, it's short, but this is intended as a prologue for the main game. The cassette tapes which can be found in all the missions provide more tastes of the story, making you desire for more. 

Kojima-san, you magnificent bastard, why do you tease us so?

review:
A demo for MGS 5 : Phantom Pain, buy it if you want extra acheivements, or need to test Phantom Pain's engine on your hardware before forking out the real moneys ( https://store.steampowered.com/app/287700/METAL_GEAR_SOLID_V_THE_PHANTOM_PAIN/ ).  Once again, Solid Snake is nowhere to be found, so the series name is a misnomer.  There are a couple of extra "replay value" modes, and the usual in-game cutscenes that last faaar too long.  But hey, they are a hallmark, right?

This entry includes some neat new tech, such as driving bulky vehicles and shoulder-carrying bodies (live or dead).  Oh, and the chopper extraction is a neat touch, throwing each person in there one at a time, and then jumping out again so you can climb in yourself.  Aiming is as hard as ever, there is little information to tell you which guns are better than others, and somehow Snake has the local radio frequencies before he gets there, and a holographic map projector in the nineteen seventies.

On the other hand, it is a near-photorealistic Stealth-Action game and despite the lack of lockers in this one level, it manages to hit every MGS nerve I have.  I do wish it had been US$10 before the special rate though, or longer.  Tech Demos should be free, and a bit shorter than this was.

The natural progression from the gameplay enhancements that appeared in MGS4. It's still distinctly Snake, but brought into the modern era of action games with brilliant execution.

If this is a brief taste of what is to come in The Phantom Pain, I await with bated breath to see it's eventual arrival.

review:
1. Impressive Graphics (nice rain and lighting effects)

2. Impressive Gameplay and mechanic (The movement look , feel and sound right)

3. Decent A.I (Found most times when setting off the alarm, soldiers will either charge towards my location or fall back and regroup forming a group of 4 or 3 soldiers to back each other up)

4. Vehicles (riding the helicopter and driving any vehicle is awesome, especially the ability to knock soldiers out and take them for a ride) 

5. Short....like a demo (The game is more of a tech demo, it does give a bit of a story leading towards Phantom Pain but there is just not enough there to keep you busy. The few missions there are do offer a bit of fun and enjoyment but being played on the same map as the story it gets boring fast) 

6. Price (Buying it during the sale was great but I sometimes wish the game was priced $10 or should be included as a pre-order towards Phantom Pain, for it to be a standalone is just not strong and I find myself pacing back and forth wanting Phantom Pain to be released) 

Overall Ground Zeroes offer a good taste of what is to come for the Metal Gear series, showing a bit of the gameplay and features that will appear in phantom pain. However for new players just entering the series it may feel strange charging $20 for a tech demo as well as create a bit of confusing as who is who and what is going on as the story branches off Peace walker. 

If your a diehard fan of Metal Gear I would recommend getting this and go around looking for all the cool little items and points of interests. If your just starting the series I would recommend picking up Peace walker for PSP or PS3/Xbox 360 to help establish a bit of the story or wait for the price to come down a bit to $10. I enjoyed it and still waiting for phantom pain...............any time now........................................soon I hope......................hmm......any minute .....I guess not yet.....maybe now...................SNNNNNAAAAAKKKKKEEEE!!!!!

review:
Despite it being literally a single area, it's got loads of replayability going for it (pursuing 100% being a good example). Don't simply complete the Main Mission and call it a day. Go for the Side and Extra Ops. They give a lot of background to MSF's previous operations in the Area of Operations. Also, despite it's short length, it's got a lot of emotional deepness, hidden in the tapes (which you can find during your missions, though you already own some), with Hideo being a bastard and playing with your feelings "like a damn fiddle". You first grow to detest Paz, but then you *might(was the case for me)* pity her fate, and even have sympathy for her. And then you got Skull Face. Okay, how can we put it? Take Volgin, keep the sadomasochist part, amplify it, remove his easy-to-annoy personality, add intelligence, cleverness, and make of him a cold-hearded bastard. You'll end up getting a character that is 100 times nastier and worse than Volgin.

To put it short, buy this damn game. Loads of replayability (28 hours at the time I made this review, trying to get 100%). It's deep. It's very fun as well ( many Easter Eggs and missions extras that helps to get the sad and serious ambient a bit loose). Also helps explain why Snake goes apparently evil in The Phantom Pain. Finally, it's only 20 USD. Combine a random Steam discount and it's left at $15 or $10 (I got it at $13,30 on the day of it's release). Another fantastic game from Hideo Kojima.

review:
Ground Zeroes has been accused of being a paid demo, a single mission shipped to simply hype MGS5's eventual release. However, I found it to much more than that; My most recent MGS game being 4 at it's release in 2008, I felt quite rusty going into this. Ground Zeroes is a good warm-up for MGS5, consisting of six missions that take place in the same ficticious Cuban military base, Camp Omega. The "Ground Zeroes" mission is the meat of the story, involving the rescue of two minors on opposite sides of the base that were apparently major characters from Peace Walker. Interspersed cutscenes and collectible cassette tapes flesh out the character's back stories and their experiences on the base. The extra missions provide vastly different approaches and playstyles to infiltrating (or assaulting) the base, ranging from a helicopter ride providing covering fire to an assassination mission that fails easily if you are even spotted. After you finish each mission there's still plenty of unlocks and time trials for purists, along with the last two missions for waxing nostalgia. 

Ground Zeroes helps to connect the events of Peace Walker with MGS5 and acts as a catalyst for the time jump been the two games. Overall, this probably won't win over any new fans but is a thoroughly fleshed out "VR Mission"-style side game that provides a solid intro to The Phantom Pain.

review:
Greatly optimized. Was able to run the game with fluid FPS with a laptop with specs way under the mininum requirements (albeit it was on medium low, 720p (the default settings were put on high to my surprise) the game still looks gorgeous)

I've been a huge fan of the Metal Gear series and I am grateful that it has come to PC (no need to drop $400 on a PS4) This game still upholds to the high standards that the series has been known for, and although the main story of the game is very short, Metal Gear Solid has better polish than a lot the the AAA titles out there, paying close attention to the fine details.

review:
Never been the fan of the franchise and probably never will, what i've heard and seen about previous games i didnt liked.
Nothing will ever make me play previous games, nothing will make me love them. But you dont need to be brain-dead Kojima-zombie to understand that here and now you have a demo version that represents the very, very high gameplay and tech quality of the upcoming Phantom Pain.
Bear in mind that this is a DEMO VERSION of the upcoming game, and you are actually have to pay real money for it. I have no idea how much it costs outside CIS, but in Russia i just spent less than 8 bucks for it (btw wasnt it 40 when it came out on consoles?). I was curious enough to try this one, since you dont have to own PS console for that. And I was shocked by the high quality of the PC version of the game that originally was Playstation exclusive. Decent visuals that can run at stable 60 fps on old soviet "ZIL" refrigerator, fairly pretty handmade sandbox location that allows player to choose many ways to approach your target, comfortable controls, minimalistic and informative interface, core gameplay mechanics - it is all pure tripple A shit at its greatest form. However the plot and setting are still looking a bit retarded, though not that retarded since everything is happening in 80s or something like that. But it doesnt really matter, cause at least for me gameplay and tech quality completely outshines whatever story this game might possibly tell.
Stealth-action is my 2nd favorite genre and being a fan of high-quality PC games i must support this, give it a thumb up and wait for the Phantom Pain. Yes, this is how you become the Kojima-zombie.

review:
Before I say anything about the gameplay, let me first address the controversial topic of the game's length.

If you speedrun the game, you can complete every mission in about 2-3 hours. HOWEVER, if you are a completionist or enjoy the replay value that the map and missions have to offer, you can easily get about a dollar-per-hour of value out of the game. I didn't even S-rank everything and I got 17 hours out of the game for only ~42% completion. Be creative and don't expect to be spoon-fed your fun.

Now, for the gameplay. This is an exciting taste of what's to come for The Phantom Pain. There's a lot of loving detail included in the little things. The movement animations for Snake are amazing - 99% of his animations are believable save for a few cases where you can intentionally make him look stupid. The AI is decent, but predictable - however, it's hard to make AI that doesn't at some point become predictable. Having played on both a PS3 controller and a mouse + keyboard, I prefer the controller but the PC controls are ALMOST as comfortable save for a few hitches (which can be helped with some key rebindings.) Above all, the stealth action is challenging but satisfying, rewarding careful planning, quick execution, and ability to improvise.

The graphics are amazing and the game is optimized well. The story is admittedly edgy and kind of grimdark for a MGS game, but the series' brand of quirky humor still shines through in some missions.

Overall, I highly recommend if you like stealth games and like to go for extras/collectibles/high scores. If you don't, it's still worth it in my opinion, but you may want to wait for it to go on sale.

review: Sort and sweet, good prequel to Phantom Pain. Really shows off the Fox Engine and gameplay mechanics well. I didn't expect a MGS game to be so comfortable on PC, but to my surprise I could play it pretty well without a controller. The game, or "demo" is very short, unless you spend the extra time trying to get all the achievements. Worth buying, especially if you are a MGS fan/veteran!

review: Albeit the main singleplayer mission is indeed short, there is a lot more to get out of the game to be fully prepared for the upcoming Phantom Pain. I spent quite a few hours figuring out new pathways in the base area you've been given in several missions, where I found a whole bunch of references and secrets to older games. Make sure to collect all the tapes, look up a guide for them if possible. And make sure to listen to the tapes you've been given at the start!  Phantom Pain here I come! <3

review:
Ok ill be honest, this is a short game and its basically a pre game to the next release, if you dont mind that by the nature of this game its replayable and so enjoyable, i want a perfect mission damit!. Its also so cinamatic my hole family watched me played it over chrismas its was like watching a bond movie, they all loved just watching, screaming and yelling when Snake was inches away from being caught, that was fun. Its splinter cell on drugs. If you havent read other comments lets me tell you, its the best port from playstation i have ever played. I wish they would port all the old metal gear games to pc like this. Metal Gear Solid - Solid Snake 1080p 60fps, just take my money allready. I only have one warning, once you played this game, Metal Gear Solid Phantom Pain will magically jump to the top of your wishlist for 2015 and i think that was the idea of this game, and it worked. . You have been warned. Stop reading and buy it. Oh and Hideo Kojima you can make my games anytime..

Double Thumps up from me!

review:
I wish I could leave a middle of the ground review for this.

I'm a huge fan of the metal gear series, dating back to MGS.  This game is everything you would expect from Hideo.  Solid visuals, thematic story, classic gameplay.  Really quite lovable.

My big gripe is the length of this.  It is intended to be an introduction to Phantom Pain and feels that way.  It sort of feels like a demo in its length - however, it is not priced as a demo.  It is priced well above what I feel I received in gameplay.  

That being said, if you want to throw some cash towards Kojima, go for it. You'll enjoy it while it lasts.

review:
Most fun I have ever had running the same missions over and over to get all the achievements and 100% a game. Every retry plays differently, every corner is full of discovery and sometimes it's even extremely relaxing. Even if you do a intel retrieval mission for the tenth time, you can just pull up an iDroid and listen to some music or character diaries that are full of additional information and story elements. And the story that lays the foundation for the upcoming Phantom Pain just rocks.

It was every bit worth the time and money.

excellent introduction 10/10 cant wait for phantom pain.
really good pc port too runs extremely well

review:
Solid port, solid game.
A bit short, since you can beat the single "story" mission in an hour or so, but... you can easily get a lot more from the bonus missions, getting S ranks and other stuff.
For some, it's a "paid demo" for the MGSV: The Phantom Pain, which is "the real deal", for others, a nice game that's worth it's "not so high" price.

review:
It's a pretty good prologue to the upcoming MGS5, but be aware it is just that. It has about 4 hours worth of content in it for the average gamer, and perhaps up to 10 hours for a completionist. All missions are on the same small map. It gets repititive. You're buying it for a taste of the engine and game (which is a pretty good design). It's a bit pricey for my liking, and should have been half this price or a free demo even in my opinion, but it is worth it if you get it on special.

Little content, and I'm left hungry for the upcoming game.

review: Oh man it's been a while since I played a Metal Gear game. I got caught trying to kidnap an annoying little hispanic kid about 15 times. After that I threw him on a helicopter and then was forced to listen to a recording of this woman moaning for 2 minutes and 30 seconds. Turns out she was a kinky character who loved to stuff bombs in places I don't think I need to explain. Overall I would say I had a positive experience playing this game. I just hope the 5th metal gear solid doesn't have a Fat Man equivalent in it. That was brutal.

review:
How to put this. It's one awesome game, but it's actually a demo for Phantom Pain, not a full game. It reminded me greatly of VR Missions. It has one map, lots of missions, in the end it's just teasing you to what Phantom Pain will be. Worth the price, definetly worth the wait for Phantom Pain.

My opinion: Wait for Phantom Pain if you can. If you want to train for it while you wait, buy this.

review:
SNAKE?! SNAKE! SNAAAAAAAAAAAKE!!!!

[b]+Graphics[/b]
A japanese game with a perfect performance and it's one of the best examples of how is a good port, what is happening? 
Ah yes, NVIDIA support <3.
I tested the game in two different pc's (1st: GTX970, i5 2500K 4.5Ghz, 8GB / 2nd: GTX560Ti,  i5 3570 3.4Ghz, 8GB) and both runs the game smothly at 60fps and with everything in High and Extra High. It's incredible how good is this port. Very nice job from Kojima Productions and the graphics are incredible, the lightning effects are absolutely awesome.
[b]+Story[/b]
The main mission is very short... It's like if you cut just the cargo part of MGS2 and put it on a "different ¿game?", let's be honest it's just a demo of The Phantom Pain but in my opinion and as very fan of the series that cliffhanger at the end deserve that 13 euros I paid for this on the sales.
[b]+Extra missions[/b]
You also have some extra missions and two top secret missions and that ones are very funny, I dont want spoil but if you are a fan of the saga you will enjoy a lot that top secret stuff.
[b]+Gameplay[/b]
It's MGS4 but even better. I love the animations of this game for whatever you do is super smooth and the transitions between them are very good done.
The CQC is very fun and even more if you have several enemies around you. Dat slow motion for the CQC... <3
[b]+Map[/b]
The first time you play and they let you at that military base gives you the feeling of something very huge. It's true that after some hours playing you'll realize that the map it is actually quite small but the first impression playing the GZ mission is very spectacular.


[b]-Duration[/b]
It's a demo, benchmark or whatever you want call it of The Phantom Pain. That's all. Buy it with this in mind or wait hoping for a pack of Ground Zeroes and The Phantom Pain.
[b]-No sound options[/b]
I dont know the reason about this... It's just very weird you cant configure nothing of the sound in the game, voices, sfx, music... Nothing, so you will open the windows volume mixer for this D:
[b]-Kaz[/b]
Kaz... I like you but man... Shut up a little bit please.


Like I said if you are a fan of the saga and you cant wait more for play some MGS on PC, buy it but keep in mind this, it is a demo. Now it's your call decide if this deserve your money or not. I enjoyed this a lot and Ground Zeroes it's just the confirmation of I'm going buy The Phantom Pain instantly when comes out.

review:
BE WARNED!

This is a prologue game to the Phantom Pain coming to PC soon.  It is a single level so don't expect hours and hours of gameplay.

With that warning in place, this game is fantastic.  VERY solid gameplay and machanics.  I've been a Metal Gear fan for years and have played every single game they have made.  Story line is complicated as all hell but a lot of fun.

To keep this short and sweet.  No glitches, no bugs, gameplay is tight, story is intriguing.   If you are new to the Metal Gear universe this is a great place to start.  Be advised there is a HUGE amount of backstory to what is going on.  Still enjoyable if you don't know the back story but probably more enjoyable if you watched a youtube video that caught you up to speed.

Still enjoyable if you don't know the back story but probably more enjoyable if you watched a youtube video that caught you up to speed.", "timestamp_created": 1419634238, "timestamp_updated": 1419634238, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 3, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.536747872829437256", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
Finally I feel like I'm playing the classic MGS series again. Although being a steep price for a single map/mission, the replay value comes to life as you discover new and more interesting ways to be a master of the stealth or a guns-blazing firefight. I think this is a great playthrough for any MGS true fan. And SURELY, if anything, is excellent practice before the next installment!

Coming from a long time MGS fan,
-4.7 out of 5

Excellent port, runs great on my mid-range PC. I'm really glad the engine is well optimized, it makes me hopeful that MGS5 will run just as well. The FOX engine looks great , gameplay is awsome , i tell you what when i was a young boy & playin this series on the PSX man i would have never thought this would be possible but Kojima shows the world how to PC port the right way.

I CANT WAIT TO SEE WHAT PHANTOM PAIN HAS TO GIVE.. 

Gameplay 10/10
Action 10/10
Stealth 10/10
CQC 10/10
Banter 10/10

review:
I love stealth games, and my favorite has always been the MGS series. Got this mainly since this is the first MGS game ported to PC in years, and also I couldn't wait to see how The Phantom Pain would look and feel like. Here are my thoughts:

Cool stuff:
+ Excellent stealth mechanics and gameplay. Some carried over from MGS 4.
+ Smart AI. Much improved, and keeps you on your toes at all times.
+ Organic character animations and CQC.
+ Vehicles are driveable!
+ Movie quality soundtrack.
+ No game breaking bugs (and no glaring bugs within the game) encountered.
+ Incredible visual fidelity. Fox engine really shines! Special mention: the rain soaked battlefield is spectacular to look at. (Big Boss' mullet does not get wet in the rain though...lol)

Uncool stuff:
- Short campaign...feels like a demo. There are good reasons to replay to understand how non-linear the game is. There are 5 side missions and collectibles that are hard to find, to increase play time.
- Signature gameplay elements like camouflage system (returns in the Phantom Pain) and food consumption/meal management to regain health/stamina are not in here.

Nitpicks:
* Not a fan of reflex mode as it turns your playthrough super-simple. Thankfully, it can be turned off.
* No boss fights. MGS is well-known for its awesome boss fights.
* Seems like Kojima-san was inspired by mechanics in games like Far Cry 3, Splinter cell etc. He borrows few ideas. Doesn't spoil experience, but makes it more like other action games.
* No David Hayter as Snake! New VA performance is not as memorable.
* This is a smooth PC port for the most part. There is some screen tearing even at max settings. (i7 3770K 4.4 Ghz+Geforce 780 OC.) To my chagrin, it happens when the vsync is on from the game, or if Nvidia adaptive vsync is on, or if no vsync of any sort is on at all. Appears like the game is locked to 60 FPS albeit you don't force vsync on. My monitor refresh rate is 60 Hz, by the way.

review:
Highly recommended to have played "MGS3 Snake Eater" and "MGS Peace Walker" to understand what you are doing in the main mission. If not, there are lot of movies to catch up on youtube.
The main story may be short, buy there is so much to do on the side missions that the replay value is just massive.
Game runs perfect, this is the best MGS gameplay yet.

One of the few games that I will be aiming to complete with all the achievements, because is just fun!

9/10 No perfect score because of the lack of cardboard boxes (?)

review:
Spoiler Alert: shiny buttocks.

In all seriousness though- this is a good installment in the Metal Gear series, albeit a short one. The gameplay is smooth and flows nicely. The graphics are absolutely amazing given the relatively low specs asked for. Lots of extra add-on gameplay for when you've finished the campaign. 
Does its job in preparing you for Phantom Pain. Is it worth the £35 it was originally released for in retailers? No. Is it worth the £17 it's going for on Steam? Maybe, if you're a big Metal Gear fan. Replayability? Not much. That said, would I recommend it? Yes.

Maybe for you who need long gameplay this game is not yours Metal Gear solid V : Ground Zeroes is proloque to Metal Gear Solid V Phantom Pain.
You can finish this game on 3 hours for story...and that's it 
sure you can unlock side mission which unlock with 9 XOF Patches 

The game is only have one map with variations of Days, Night etc...overall the layout is the same

Now for the plus side this game is very optimized for my older PC with A8-3850 and AMD 7850 is run perfectly with no stuttering with custome tweak for maade the game playable overall there's no problem with the graphic setting is better than Assassin Creed Unity

now for the downside 
is that there's no item unlocked like silenced sniper and cardboard box...cmon this is MGS game why no cardboard box and no stealth device. 
but for Graphics this is amazing game I happy to tell you that if you buy this game you will not regret it. because all you doing in ground zeroes will carry over to phantom pain so all your sacrifice will not be in vain I think

SO that's my review of MGS V: GZ 

See you again

review:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is the entry title into Metal Gear Solid V. Released as a standalone story, the game is offered to allow players early access to some of the features of the FOX Engine, as well as the new gameplay mechanics being released in The Phantom Pain.

The game offers a short story after the events of Peace Walker, as well as a few side missions. While the content is limited, there is a lot of content in the gameplay. There are side missions the user can play, as well as smaller objectives in each mission. While it probably plays closer to the older MGS1: VR Training game (Which was just mini-games and released at full price, mind you), the game offers a much more enriching experience than previous titles. 

A lot of the systems in Ground Zeroes are scripted, but there are a lot of subtle variations, sometimes leading to some big changes. Example: I witnessed a guard kill another guard with their jeep, check, and then drive away. This led to an easier time for me to get through that area. 

Other than that, the game IS short, but there are a lot of things to do. I, for one, enjoy getting this experience rather than being completely without. :)

review:
this, this is a prime example of how a port game should be, flawless movement, no stuttering, no fps drop, why cant all dev make a port game like this?

i have only one issue with this game, very short main mission, leaving a big question mark about the main story, and phantom pain is still long in the future :(

otherwise, its all good, graphic? very good, movement? smooth as silk, although if i plug in a controller, the game will crash, still have no idea why
It is perfect in visuals and gameplay, but the fact that it only contains ONE mission and lots of sidequesting makes it not recommendable.

review:
Great PROLOGUE to The Phantom Pain. (yes it has allot less content thats why its priced so low.)

GREAT port compared to the horrible and simply disgusting pc ports ubisoft has been releasing this year 2014.

i got this game to run on a dual core E6420 @2.4Ghz with amd 6970 with roughly 25-45 FPS @ 1080p.  (try doing that with ubi games)

on my main rig i got a solid 60 FPS with i7 2600K @ 4Ghz and a AMD 280x with graphic settings set to extra high/high mixed @ 1080p.


i played most of the game and im still nowhere near 100% completion, so the people saying this game is short need to boot up the game and dig deeper in the game because there is more to do then just the GZ mission.
the game is a bit repetetive after a while because you will need to do several playthroughs of each mission to get to 100% completion and all of it taking place in the same military base doesnt help.

+PROS

mouse keyboard controles are OK, but controller recommended.
lots of replay value
sandbox enviorment
great story for those who are cought up on the series
great stealth gameplay
lots of collectables
good AI on HARD mode
great music
nostalgia for those who played the other games
runs great on a wide variety of hardware
makes you thirsty for more ! (i guess you could also see this as a CON)

-CONS

default mouse keyboard controls could be better but actually not that bad its acceptable.
sometimes prompts are stuck on the screen
sometimes button inputs are buggy
auto cover system is a bit annoying at times
one or two extra missions would have been nice or access to a MGO beta
AMD seems to have a lack of Anti-Aliasing and slightly slower performance compared to Nvidia cards.

review: I've never played any Metal Gear Solid before... but after playing this short intro and getting background and histroty... plus the gameplay and the graphics jacked up to Ultimate... man, I am sold.  I simply cannot wait for the full game to release.  I love the diversity of HOW you can tackle a mission... and it's fun going back and trying it different ways.  Although it lacks RPG elements, this kind of gives me my Deus Ex fix for the time being.  THIS is how I wish all FPS worked. I'm tired of being led through a single-solution maze by NPCs yelling at me and telling me where to go & what to do.  THIS is how shooters should work (can you imagine a kick ass Modern Warfare with this kind of freedom... and maybe add in some RPG elements as well....?  Well, I can wish, can't ?)

review:
Many people would consider what's on offer here little more than an attempt to charge for what should be a free demo and it would be difficult to argue with that point of view as their isn't much content here for the £14.39 I paid for the game on sale. However I believe what is on offer is very good if slight. The game contains a two hour story prequel mission with your typical MGS production that tasks you with rescuing 2 targets from a sandbox style prison camp. There are other things to do in the camp such as find collectables which unlock a set of bonus mission etc. After you finish the main campaign there are something called side ops, which change the time of day and give you different objectives to complete inside the same prison. Their are also a lot of lore filling audio logs regarding the characters in the game. Visually the game looks great, running at almost 3 times the visual fidelity of the next gen console version on max settings, and is easily one of the best optimised; If not the best, games of the year. 

I would say if your a Metal Gear fan this is easily worth the asking price simply for the production values and being able to play in the stealth sandbox, others may want to wait for a sale before grabbing it. 
My opinion is it's a great taster of what is to come and well worth playing.

+ Absolutely stunning visuals
+ Weather effects look fantastic, and do much to add to the atmosphere
+ The new FOX engine runs incredibly well; this game is so ridiculously optimized, I was running it at max settings, and my GPU was barely running above idling temperatures - I was STUNNED
+ Voice-acting is top-notch, although I miss David Hayter (I won't count this as a negative, because Kiefer Sutherland voiced Snake, admittedly, well)
+ Controls are as solid as they get; did not feel one bit like a PC port, everything was mapped so naturally
+ The whole atmosphere stayed true to the spirit of the franchise; everthing form the dialogue, the movements, the cinematics and camera work - this game FEELS like an MGS title
+ Lengthy cinematics were absolutely phenomenal, and really pump you up for the full product (Phantom Payne, ETA 2015)

- Seems to be missing a few of the trademark nuances (e.g. knocking on walls, hiding in boxes, naked cartwheels)
- This is well-known, but the length is abysmal (you can beat the main story in less than 20 minutes); treat this like an interactive teaser-trailer, though, and this won't bother you as much

review:
Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes takes a step closer at narrowing the gap between movies and video games by giving players great cinematography, amazing cut scene directing and flawless game play with plenty of replay-ability all beautifully paving the way and laying down the red carpet for Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain. 
 Once more players are put into the role Big Boss set off on a rescue mission which relies heavily on sneak elements which pay homage to previous Metal Gear Installments with that said there are limited action orientated game play elements such driving and using vehicle weapons, fresh new gun mechanics and the finally perfected CQC. The sound effects and voice acting in Ground Zero are well executed and performed everything from the music to the voice performances are a pleasure to listen to. It's fair to point out that  David Hayter's replacement Kiefer Sutherland manages to give Big Boss a more suited voice.
  Ground Zeroes story only takes two and a half hours to finish with most time occupied by cut scenes making you feel like your watching a live action movie. For the full price you get what you pay for, art on screen.

review:
A GREAT WAY FOR HIDEO KOJIMA TO SHOW OFF his new FOX ENGINE. 17 dollars and this is all you'll be getting folks, a taste of things to come and its damn as delicious as that food you ate for Christmas dinner.

I beaten this on the console and I just did it again on the pc
It took me 45 mins gun blazing and done since i've played the hell out of it on my ps4.

The game environment and opening is amazing. The game is meant to be played the way you want to play it but mainly  it's  astealth game. I just felt like shooting everything down like an fps because iam mother fucking snake.

The new engine is amazing, the game is amazing however its shit short and you get what you paid for
Don't like? Don't waste the 17 dollars.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+ Graphics is immersive and fantastic.
+ Game Engine potential
+ Optimization on pc runs sexy as hell
+ Music in the game openinig made me shed a tear
+ Weather effects and environment
+ The amount of ways you can approach a situation, stealth, guns blazin, etc whatever.
+ Multiple missions you can take on the map to prolong playability

[h1] Cons [/h1]
- Its short you can literally try to speed run it in less than 1 hour 
- Its just a tech demo for the upcoming game

Alle Hagel  Hideo Kojima

and yes It does play like a damn fiddle.

I´ll be waiting god knows for how long for The Phantom Pain and I just want to play it to continue Big Boss story!, really awesome, loved it! 10/10", "timestamp_created": 1419562005, "timestamp_updated": 1419562005, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.486561626195907593", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
This is just a paid demo, buy if you want to support the devs, pirate it if you're just looking foward to Phantom Pain.
You can finish the main mission in under 15 minutes easily, however It has an amazingly fun engine to play with, even though it's repetitive, you may never tire of playing it because there are so many things you can do.

The rating system is ret*rded and annoying though, I really hope they don't bring this into Phantom Pain, sometimes I just want to kill everyone and sometimes I want to play safe without being spotted, but I don't want to recieve a rating that isn't based on the playstyle that I chose, for instance, if you snipe everyone, go in guns blazing, speed run or take too long to finish because you were playing safe you'll probably recieve a bad rating, that's annoying. But the most annoying thing of all, is that sometimes I speed run missions and get this close to beating word record time and still recieve an "A" rating... The problem isn't the rating itself, but rather the system, see, this is the same exact thing that ruined the Hitman series, in Blood Money the rating was very fun to play with, you'd always recieve a different rating based on your playstyle and if you didn't care about the ratings it was still pretty easy to ignore, but on Absolution they changed that, they introduced and shoved down the players throat a score based system, and no options to turn off, it was really fucking annoying to have a big ass score telling me what I'm supposed to do and how I'm supposed to play.

Well, other than the rating system I really like MGS:V GZ, or should I say, Spotted Through Walls: The Game, it's really fun and challanging (especially with all the glitches and AI problems) but if you're looking to get 100% completion and all the achievements I'll have to opose that, I sincerelly do not recommend this game if you're going to try to finish it clean, since some of the "trials" are almost, if not impossible do to (no seriously, not joking, depending on the map/enemies behavior layout you just can't do some trials, you have to restart the game and hope for the layout to change) therefore you'll probably get very mad very often, it really messes with your head, I do not recommend that to anyone.

The rating system is ret*rded and annoying though, I really hope they don't bring this into Phantom Pain, sometimes I just want to kill everyone and sometimes I want to play safe without being spotted, but I don't want to recieve a rating that isn't based on the playstyle that I chose, for instance, if you snipe everyone, go in guns blazing, speed run or take too long to finish because you were playing safe you'll probably recieve a bad rating, that's annoying. But the most annoying thing of all, is that sometimes I speed run missions and get this close to beating word record time and still recieve an "A" rating... The problem isn't the rating itself, but rather the system, see, this is the same exact thing that ruined the Hitman series, in Blood Money the rating was very fun to play with, you'd always recieve a different rating based on your playstyle and if you didn't care about the ratings it was still pretty easy to ignore, but on Absolution they changed that, they introduced and shoved down the players throat a score based system, and no options to turn off, it was really fucking annoying to have a big ass score telling me what I'm supposed to do and how I'm supposed to play.

Well, other than the rating system I really like MGS:V GZ, or should I say, Spotted Through Walls: The Game, it's really fun and challanging (especially with all the glitches and AI problems) but if you're looking to get 100% completion and all the achievements I'll have to opose that, I sincerelly do not recommend this game if you're going to try to finish it clean, since some of the "trials" are almost, if not impossible do to (no seriously, not joking, depending on the map/enemies behavior layout you just can't do some trials, you have to restart the game and hope for the layout to change) therefore you'll probably get very mad very often, it really messes with your head, I do not recommend that to anyone.", "timestamp_created": 1419560696, "timestamp_updated": 1423035985, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.486561626195907593", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
Well, Metal Gear Solid is back on PC and even BETTER yet, it is on Steam! For the first time ever the stealth genre has hit Steam with a quality port that never ceases too impress. After playing over 25 hours on my PS3 I can safely say this is a pretty big improvement. Majorly increased Draw Distance and a multiplied number of light sources this game is great to stare at alone. Game play is another thing, after almost 16 years of 3D Metal Gear Solid I love how they continue to shake things up with new gameplay mechanics and now it is shifting into an open world map. Ground Zeroes feels fresher than ever. The story is not long in length but there are so many different option of infiltration that if you are creative enough it will keep you coming back for over 20 hours. For (at the time) 11 or so dollars is well worth it as it builds off of Peace Walker and gets you ready for The Phantom Pain. 

Personal Score: 8.7/10

review:
I'm a massive Metal Gear Solid fanboy and would probably like this game even if it was awful.
Short but replayable. Runs super smooth & looks really, really good. Solid controls apart from in the menus.

The mission is very open, if you want to sneak in classic MGS style you can. I had MGS nostalgia infiltrating the base by hiding in the back of a truck (Haven't found a cardboard box yet).
Alternatively, you can just shoot the entire place up as the gunplay is really enjoyable. You can even get in a tank. 

This game acts as a prelude to The Phantom Pain and so the ending is pretty ****ing insane (and tense). I thoroughly enjoyed it. A little expensive. Buy on sale.

review:
WARNING!
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF INVERT Y-AXIS IS YOUR PRIMARY MOUSE STYLE!

Of all the things the developers missed when they made this port to PC, they forgot to add in-depth mouse movements options. This is a MUST for PC gamers.

"Camera Options" are not always the same as "Mouselook Option". There is no way to set the Y-Axis to inverted, as third-party software to do this is over-ridden by the game mechanics.

UPDATE: Well here we go... Looks like enough people brought this issue forward to attention that they finally decided to release a patch for the Y Axis. TYVM!

review:
Amazing return of the MGS series to PC. While having played only MGS and 2 on pc (no consoles), I am very lost in the story, but I refuse to read/watch it, I'll just wait for the collection to come to PC. This game is amazing and maintains the essence of MGS I remember back in the day when I played the aforementioned games. Controlling Snake feels pretty good both on keyboard+mouse and gamepay (started playing with a gamepad but moved to the GLORIOUS keyboard+mouse combination for controlling the character and being able to aim accurately). 

The main mission took me a while (probably 3 hours) because, since I am kinda "new" to the game, I wasn't quite used to the descriptions, so it took some time finding the targets. Side ops are taking me about 1 hour each. You then get to replay them in hard difficulty and you can try to beat your score to unlock extra content. There's  2 extra missions I haven't unlocked as you have to get all the XOF patches in one playthrough (which you can continue, of course) during the main mission. I'm looking forward to playing them.

Pros:
- graphics and optimization: is is how a port should work. 10/10
- voice acting by Keifer Sutherland
- lots of gameplay time for this so-called "demo" (by many idiots)
- different approaches to missions

Cons:
- CAMERA TOO DAMN CLOSE. Specially when carrying someone or while close to the wall. This DEFINITELY needs to be addressed.
- AI can be a bit stupid at times
- Controlling Snake some times can be annoying because he doesn't respond the way you intend him to.


All in all, get this game. It is on sale on many places!

review:
Bloody Excellent port. Playing this with sli GT 750ms and I get 60 fps even with most settings cranked up to their limit. This port doesn't play you like a damn fiddle.

I know this has been said ad nauseum, but despite the aforementioned pro, I'd also like there to be a mixed recommendation rating because of one caveat: the game is pretty short.

This game is excellent when it comes to its mechanics, story (what little of it there is), and graphical fidelity. However, although the likes of a Metal Gear fanboy like me Played this game on a ps3 for over 20 hours and bought the game when it was priced 30 bucks, someone who is new to the franchise and is thinking about starting with this game should avoid it and wait for Phantom Pain instead. Or, otherwise, just blast through the previous MGS games if he/she owns a ps3 and then decide whether they're brainwashed enough to buy this game or not.

I think the problem is not in of itself the length, but the scale. There are a variety of missions, sure, including two fanservicy ones that are very special, and there's record times and complete percentages for good measure , but just remember that they all take place on a 500 sqm cuban base.

review:
Great PC port game with enchanced in visual and everything

I hope all the series goes to PC too.

can't wait for the phantom pain

Without a doubt would recommend this to anyone, who is a fan of MGS and who has played at least MGS3 - MGS: PW.
Would not so surely recommend this to anyone else. This game (or at least a prologue of a much larger game) has great stealth gameplay and top notch optimisation and graphics, but the plot is already too deep to understand it without knowing what happened in previous games and the main mission is pretty short, so you might be disapointed in that.
As a fan, I r8 this 7.3/8, it's gr8.

review:
Now THIS is how ports are meant to be made!

Being a [strike] obsessive [/strike] pretty big fan of MGS, I purchased the initial release of Ground Zeroes on the PS3 and 100%'d the game, leaving no stone unturned. The steam release for me was really a way of supporting development on The Phantom Pain as I didn't really think there much else I could experience that I haven't already done but boy was I wrong!

After 100%'ing the steam release of MGSV: GZ I'm happy to say I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this title to any Metal Gear fan or someone who's looking for a photo realistic, infiltration game with a lot of mystery.

Okay let's get the big obvious one out the way. You CAN complete the MAIN mission of this game in less than five minutes pretty easily but this is certainly a title of quality over quantity and considering the quality of this port? It's 5 fucking stars my friend!

The official reasoning of the existance of GZ as a standalone title when it was originally going to be a tutorial intro for TPP is that GZ is radically different in playstyle to previous MGS titles and the team wanted to ease people in to this new style of stealth. Let's be real, that's bull. GZ IS however a great test in which the team received A TONNE of data and a lot of finance for development of TPP and to me that's great! They made a solid experience with GZ and can take further refinements to make TPP even better! 

Ground Zeroes is a fantastic showcase of the Fox Engine's capabilities and how friendly it is for both developer and consumer! You take one look at GZ and you think "Wow! VERY realistic graphics! Doubt my old spud of a PC could run that..." and here's the beauty of this port, you most likely can. While I can run it on ultra and at a over 60 FPS average, I've seen people who don't even meet the MINIMUM specs on the store page and they run it absolutely fine! You don't need a silly SUPER ULTRA MEGA RAM THROTLING PHYSX 50GB VRAM 2 TITAN i7 10.00 Ghz setup at all and I find that jaw droppingly impressive, especially when GZ is practically Kojima Productions' first contribution to PC gaming for a LONG time (Like what? MGS 2 Substance??)

The gameplay (while taking a few moments to adjust if you've played MGS since the start) is great! You are truly in the thick of it and it is your decision making, actions and ability to adapt that'll decide on your success or failure. Gun handling and animations of you using them give you a respect for the weapon. I personally love seeing the sniper rifle on my back! While it is an offensive weapon and I like to ghost my runs, it's nice to just hold it!

The sound effects and graphics are amazing! GZ is a game about detail. Nothing is just simply slapped on or tacked in. It's there for a reason and it's done to a level of near perfection. For example, you have binoculars that are used to zoom in and scout enemies, vehicles and things like security cameras up ahead. You get a number of 2 zooms on it that really close in on your target. Now say you go and knock out a dude and you just feel like popping out the binos for a closer look-see. You instantly get a close up shot of the guys face but then you zoom in TWICE and the image is still SO clear to the point you actually see the pores of the person's skin, it's that crazy! And it's that level of detail in imagery and the believeable sound effects that accompany everything from the rain, to footsteps in the wet mud to footsteps on metallic stairs to even a light bulb beaming and it's hinges creaking when it turns! Nothing is left out. You get so much information as an infiltrationist that you can't help but be in the situation. You are there, feeling the wind and rain on your face, 

As a teaser for TPP, GZ does a lot to fuel the hype and while I DO have my issues as an MGS fan (My Snakeu~ voice) GZ is the level of quality and passion that I really wish will one day be the industry standard, because it's games like this that further the level and reason as to why games ARE the ultimate form of entertainment and immersion. No more annual cash cow IPs. The true future of gaming is here!

review:
Another solid Kojima production here. Again what  I love about the series is not two MGS's are the same. They all have different takes on the same genre so it's always refreshing to pick up a new game. For you Die Hard MGS fans, like myself, don't dwindle on the fact they've replaced Hayter, Snake rarely talks in this game so it's a minor snag. Very entertaining game with lots of replay value, considering it's short length. 

I've played all the Metal Gears and I will say this is up there with the greats. Fantastic graphics and an exceptional port. I haven't had the game Glitch out on me yet.

review:
Gaming has changed. It's no longer about delivering an enjoyable, reliable, stable experience to fans. It's an endless series of AAA titles being being pushed out the door prematurely. The gaming industry, and its consumption of wallets, has become a well-oiled machine. Gaming has changed.

A truly enjoyable stealth/espionage experience as presented by the illustrious Kojima. Haven't had this much fun with a stealth title since Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory (One of my favourite games of all time!).

Having said that, this game is extremely short. I would recommend purchasing this whilst on sale (although to be honest it's probably worth the quality at full price).

This will certainly whet the appetite of any veteran Metal Gear fans waiting for the final installment of the franchise - The Phantom Pain. I eagerly await it's arrival and will definitely try my best to 100% Ground Zeroes.

TLDR
- Solid mechanics, awesome stealth, branching pathways for infiltration & above all - KEPT YOU WAITING, HUH?

- Solid mechanics, awesome stealth, branching pathways for infiltration & above all - KEPT YOU WAITING, HUH?", "timestamp_created": 1419484074, "timestamp_updated": 1419484074, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
It's Metal Gear Solid with tighter controls and on PC.

Doesn't beat MGS3 in my opinion but for this little slice it's great.

And it runs really good, even on my sub-par PC.

While MGS: The Phantom Pain is the superior game, MGS: Ground Zeroes is the better "MGS style" game. You don't have nearly as many OP gadgets and the various missions are all played on one location. You better be on your guard at all times to make it through this distilled MGS experience!

Play it to get your OG MGS fix!

review:
I love this so much.

Specs/optimization: Holy cow, for a game this pretty, it should NOT run this well. I'm running pretty old hardware and it's beautiful. I have a triple core Phenom II at 2.6ghz, 8gb of DDR2 and an HD 5770 and I can run it at medium-high, 1080, with no slowdown. It's insanely well done.

Gameplay: For the PC release, the keyboard/mouse controls were given focus. It actually feels very usable, with nothing too crazy requiring a controller. It's the same game as on consoles, so it is a short prequel with 15-20 hours of real content, and only 2 or so of plot, so make sure you are aware of that.
No refund needed.

review:
Easily the best PC "port" in all of gaming history. I have trouble calling it that, though-- it's more like the PC "version".

Mouse and keyboard is the best way to enjoy MGSV, but here's a tip: remap walk to spacebar.

FOX Engine is beautiful and buttery smooth. I haven't had a single crash. I was worried about the series coming to PC but Kojima has not disappointed. Now I cannot contain my excitement for MGSV Fantom Gainz.

Don't keep us waiting.
