review:
Praise Lord Kojima-san for this masterpiece of a great port.

-It plays like a damn fiddle even without great specs.
-Graphics are gr8 m8, they will give you a solid snake.
-You can use reflex mode if ur skrub, if not skrub you can go through the hell that is trying to go through without detection or reflex.
-You can take people's guns and hold them up with them just to be an asshole.
-You can beat people to the ground and then kick their bruised body as they struggle and fail to get up to rub in the superiority of Big Boss.
-You can attach C4 to a truck, drive it at a watch tower, then leap out of the truck and blow up the C4 and cause a base-wide alert that's totally worth the badassery as you watch the tower crumble and the truck explode.
-You can throw empty magazines at your enemies' heads just to piss 'em off.
-You can run around shooting people in the knees and leaving them just to be an asshole.
-You can attach C4 to your enemies (Albeit not inside them) to make them feel Paz's pain.
-You can get played like a damn fiddle.

-If you S-rank the intel operative extraction, Kojima-san tells you you did perfect.  Love life instantly.

I r8 it 8/8
Short main mission, but it's easy to complete (Provided you use reflex mode like a skrub and still get an E-rank), difficult to master (Trying to S-rank shit without reflex mode), and has extremely high replayability.

review:
If you're going in expecting to just beat the main mission without and replays, then you will be dissapointed of how short of a game this is.

However if youre willing to put time into the side missions, youll get a good 8+ hours out of it (if youre even good at stealth or careabout rank).

Its everything you should be expecting from a metal gear game, with all the serious story, hilarious fanservice, and just downright silly kojima hijinx thrown in.

If the purpose of this game was to excite the fans for the upcoming Phantom Pain, then it does a damn good job.

raw_json: {"recommendationid": "13576135", "author": {"steamid": "76561198038072376", "num_games_owned": 394, "num_reviews": 2, "playtime_forever": 928, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 573, "last_played": 1441080873}, "language": "english", "review": "10/10 port.", "timestamp_created": 1419454625, "timestamp_updated": 1419454625, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 1, "votes_funny": 2, "weighted_vote_score": "0.502487540245056152", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
First and foremost: this is a game based almost entirely off replay value, collectable hunting, and playing for score. If you do not enjoy these things, you may just want to wait for The Phantom Pain or pick this up cheap.

For the unintiated, Ground Zeroes is the first chapter to the Metal Gear Solid 5 narrative. The titular mission contains the actual plot and cutscenes you would expect from an MGS game, but be warned, it's the only mission with these qualities. The remaining handful of Side Ops and Extra Ops are basically fluff and so they do not contain very much story beyond basic briefings and ramblings over the radio as you play.

These additional missions, however, bring quite a bit of variety to the table. Along with completely different times of day and weather (all of which affect guard sight and hearing), you're presented with brand new objectives of all sorts of espionage-y type things. Collecting intel, destroying enemy assets, extracting prisoners, assassination, and even some oddball fanservice await you. While all of these missions take place on the same map, it doesn't hurt the game too badly as it is a surprisingly deep area with lots of routes and techniques to be discovered.

As previously mentioned, this is a game filled with replay value. A nice selection of collectables and unlockables are presented here, some of which even add to the greater narrative. Each mission can be played on Normal and Hard difficulties, which admittedly doesn't change up too much, other than guard perception and accuracy. Additionally, at the end of each mission, you are graded on your performance. Things like playing non-lethal, avoiding enemy alerts, and time taken are added up into a score and the game gives you a letter grade based on this. Interestingly, some missions actually have hidden objectives that you have to discover for yourself which add even more points to your score and even give you a collectable and narrative for your troubles.

But what about the gameplay itself, you say? It's good, basically. Snake is a very agile and resourceful guy and it's presented expertly through the controls (of which, the mouse and keyboard work nicely, barring some small issues). You've got your basic stealth game movements like crouching and crawling, as well as a brand new sprint function and a very useful dive; handy for diving into cover just before someone catches sight of you. The CQC system has been overhauled and is now, quite frankly, far better. While some miscellaneous moves have been removed, it's just plain old easier to get Snake to do what you want now, rather than fumbling around and accidentally killing someone.

Gunplay in this chapter is the best in the series, hands down. It's setup similarly to MGS4 but now much faster and easier to get on target. This results in the feeling that Snake is actually that legendary soldier everyone claims him to be. This, of course, extends to the obligatory tranquilizer gun which now has a much slower flying round and even pretty severe drop to compensate for how powerful it can be. No longer can you just place a laser sight on the enemy's head and knock them out, you must actively compensate for range and movement. The game also features a pretty handy little recon system where spotting an enemy through your binoculars or just giving them a good look can mark them, allowing you to view them through walls while in close proximity. While some players may offer the opinion that this makes the game too easy, the act of actually doing recon to gain these abilities makes it much more than just a cheat. Reflex Mode is another new addition to help players out, slowing time down to a crawl if they're spotted so they can attempt to silence the guard before he gives them away. Thankfully, the option to disable these and all the other sneaking aids in the game is offered.

The camo system of MGS3 and 4 has been removed in favor of a more natural approach to stealth, almost in line with the older Splinter Cell games. The lower your stance, the harder you are to see. Shadows and bushes can also be used to conceal your presence. Guards in this iteration are much more capable than they were in previous MGS games as well. Their sight ranges and detection capabilities are far greater than any previous Metal Gear Solid and they generally behave a whole lot more realistically as a consequence. This can make sneaking in feel very slow paced and tense but incredibly fun to pull off. Additionally, if you just feel like going in loud, you'll probably enjoy yourself too. Guards now put up a much better fight over long range and offer a very satisfying reaction to being shot, each hit providing varied feedback beyond the typical "hurt" animation. (Also, the headshot sound is up there with Counter-Strike's in terms of sheer morbid pleasure.)

The game isn't without it's problems too. Guard behavior can feel clueless occasionally and their ability to randomly turn their heads to look around and do different animations can actually mess up speedrun-y tactics that worked the last few retries. The Camp Omega map isn't quite big enough in my opinion and it definitely starts to feel same-y after 10 to 20 hours of attempting to 100% the game. The PC port has no mouse controlled menus but the WASD and mouse click controlled alternative isn't terrible. Mouse aim doesn't scale for zoom, meaning aiming through scopes or just the zoomed in binoculars is incredibly twitchy and hard to get on target. There's also, inexplicably, no toggle binoculars key, meaning you have to awkwardly hold down the F key the entire time you're using them. This wouldn't be too bad if you could put the binoculars function on an additional mouse button but the game doesn't support binding to Mouse 4 and 5 either.

If you're a die-hard MGS fan, you've probably already played this on your console of choice but if you waited patiently for the PC release, you really should pick up this version. It's amazingly well optimized, only demanding a DX11-capable graphics card and a 64-bit OS. If you meet those requirements, you can run this. The graphics menu is deep enough to get this beast working on any toaster and those with monster rigs will get the eye-candy they seek. Admittedly, the graphics menu has a few problems like clumping depth of field, motion blur, and post-processing anti-aliasing together into one setting but these can be (mostly) forgiven based on just how nicely it runs. You might even be surprised at how high you can turn the settings up.

Overall, Ground Zeroes is a promising tease of open world MGS, reaching Hitman-esque levels of techniques to beat each mission. If a game this sparse can provide that amount of depth, it's hard not to be excited for The Phantom Pain and its expanded sandbox.

This, of course, extends to the obligatory tranquilizer gun which now has a much slower flying round and even pretty severe drop to compensate for how powerful it can be. No longer can you just place a laser sight on the enemy's head and knock them out, you must actively compensate for range and movement. The game also features a pretty handy little recon system where spotting an enemy through your binoculars or just giving them a good look can mark them, allowing you to view them through walls while in close proximity. While some players may offer the opinion that this makes the game too easy, the act of actually doing recon to gain these abilities makes it much more than just a cheat. Reflex Mode is another new addition to help players out, slowing time down to a crawl if they're spotted so they can attempt to silence the guard before he gives them away. Thankfully, the option to disable these and all the other sneaking aids in the game is offered.

The camo system of MGS3 and 4 has been removed in favor of a more natural approach to stealth, almost in line with the older Splinter Cell games. The lower your stance, the harder you are to see. Shadows and bushes can also be used to conceal your presence. Guards in this iteration are much more capable than they were in previous MGS games as well. Their sight ranges and detection capabilities are far greater than any previous Metal Gear Solid and they generally behave a whole lot more realistically as a consequence. This can make sneaking in feel very slow paced and tense but incredibly fun to pull off. Additionally, if you just feel like going in loud, you'll probably enjoy yourself too. Guards now put up a much better fight over long range and offer a very satisfying reaction to being shot, each hit providing varied feedback beyond the typical "hurt" animation. (Also, the headshot sound is up there with Counter-Strike's in terms of sheer morbid pleasure.)

The game isn't without it's problems too. Guard behavior can feel clueless occasionally and their ability to randomly turn their heads to look around and do different animations can actually mess up speedrun-y tactics that worked the last few retries. The Camp Omega map isn't quite big enough in my opinion and it definitely starts to feel same-y after 10 to 20 hours of attempting to 100% the game. The PC port has no mouse controlled menus but the WASD and mouse click controlled alternative isn't terrible. Mouse aim doesn't scale for zoom, meaning aiming through scopes or just the zoomed in binoculars is incredibly twitchy and hard to get on target. There's also, inexplicably, no toggle binoculars key, meaning you have to awkwardly hold down the F key the entire time you're using them. This wouldn't be too bad if you could put the binoculars function on an additional mouse button but the game doesn't support binding to Mouse 4 and 5 either.

If you're a die-hard MGS fan, you've probably already played this on your console of choice but if you waited patiently for the PC release, you really should pick up this version. It's amazingly well optimized, only demanding a DX11-capable graphics card and a 64-bit OS. If you meet those requirements, you can run this. The graphics menu is deep enough to get this beast working on any toaster and those with monster rigs will get the eye-candy they seek. Admittedly, the graphics menu has a few problems like clumping depth of field, motion blur, and post-processing anti-aliasing together into one setting but these can be (mostly) forgiven based on just how nicely it runs. You might even be surprised at how high you can turn the settings up.

Overall, Ground Zeroes is a promising tease of open world MGS, reaching Hitman-esque levels of techniques to beat each mission. If a game this sparse can provide that amount of depth, it's hard not to be excited for The Phantom Pain and its expanded sandbox.", "timestamp_created": 1419453516, "timestamp_updated": 1419619369, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 1, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: Was nervous going into this since it is sort of a Demo/ prequal.  For any MGS fan this is certainly a must have.  Yes, you can run and gun through the main mission in 20 minutes.  Each time you go through you find new items, secondary objectives, and once you complete the main part, you unlock other missions.  If you are true to the series like myself, take your time, enjoy the game, there is hours to spend.  I played 3.4 hours so far, and have unlocked only 12% of the game.  I still have new weapons, objectives and collectables to find.  Once earned you can use them in the misisons you already played.  Best 14$ I spent on a game in my entire life.

review:
[h1]DADDY'S BACK BIT***S!!! BIG BOSS HAILING ON PC FOR THE FIRST TIME!!!![/h1]
*ahem ahem*
Ok so this is an Amazing Game Done right on PC. for a port, it's surprisingly outstanding.
Metal Gear Solid V, despite numbered '5', it's not a sequel to MGS4, but rather a direct sequel to Peace Walker. (Name it Peace Walker 2)
I think people who skipped Peace Walker will miss many things and won't have the same experience.
I STRONGLY RECOMMEND PLAYING BIG BOSS SAGA GAMES BEFORE PLAYING THIS OR PHANTOM PAIN.

Out of the technical and background info side:
[h1]------What's to expect?[/h1]
Imagine Hideo Kojima used "Polymerization Card" fusing Metal Gear Solid and Splinter Cell.
Yes, Actually Ground Zeroes don't play much like the older games. it borrowed many things from Splinter Cell games, most notably Blacklist, and built them upon Peace Walker.
This Game will give you 2-Hours (more or less) "Main Ops" mission. That's is the entrance to The Phantom Pain.
when you finish that, you will be given 4 "Side Ops" missions to complete and that for the rest of hours for your money.
Finding Certain Collectibles will give you 2 "Extra Ops", and these two for old fans. they are filled with "nostalgia" moments, easter eggs, and jokes only old fans will get.
  
[h1]------What's Good?[/h1]
-A Thrilling story with a great cliffhanger : Note, Probably only those who at least have a background about Snake Eater, Portable Ops and Peace Walker will get hooked into GZ/PP story. 
-Breathtaking 60FPS Gameplay.
-Absolutely reliable and great Controls for Keyboard/Mouse, i played the first hours using Xbox 360 Controllers, but honestly it not that good. Aiming soldiers by Tranq.Gun using stick is a pain in the a$$.
-semi-Free Roam gameplay with vehicles to use for transportations or giving hell to soldiers.
-Realistic environment and Realistic mechanism
-The Ambient, the environment sounds, They Sound unbelievably realistic.
-Graphics are top notch!
-Challenging Missions.

[h1]------What's Bad (a.k.a Personal letdowns)?[/h1]
-Story is found in just few scenes.
-No Fulton Recovery System (Peace Walker's POW recovery system)
-Very limited weapons to use
-Soldiers have really "over-miles" eyes, and you don't have a big chances to avoid alerts. Yes, they can see you from very long distance, and this made me suffer of repeating missions countless of times just to achieve no-detection mission completion.
-unmerciful towards achieving S rank

[h1]------What's to do?[/h1]
-If you are new to MGS series, i suggest you skip this game. and Begin playing MGS games in this order
MGS3 Subsistence, Portable Ops, Peace Walker, then this, then wait until Phantom Pain, and continue from there into Solid Snake Games.
-If you played MGS Games but didn't give chance to the (less popular) titles of Portable Ops and Peace Walker
do it now, and this play this game. they are really games with great storylines.

Believe me, you will miss out A TONS OF TONS of the story, easter eggs and many other things if you don't.

final words.......


ALL HAIL BIG BOSS!!!

review:
As a fan of the franchise it was hard for me to not recommend this game, but there are some serious issues that need to be taken care off, the potential for great game is there, it just need some extra work and polishing before releasing the full title. 

The hardware optimization is very well done, the game runs smoothly and has no issues with FPS drops. The graphics are gorgeous with some nice lighting effects and good use of DoF. 

The controls optimization for PC is different story altogether, the controls are clunky at best, default key binds are odd, no optimization to use extra mouse buttons or the scroll button. The menus are not at all optimized for the KBM users, no scrolling with your mouse, menus are not clickable, menus within menus within menus with millions of confirm dialogs. 

[b]The basic gameplay was fun, but quite short and I fell, that it certainly was not worth the 17€.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
 [*]Unbelievable optimization for the PC, the game runs smoothly without any FPS drops.
 [*]Great graphics and sound effects.
 [*]Realistic bullet drop.
 [*]There is more than one way how to finish the mission, so there is some replay value.
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
 [*]The game is short, there is only main mission and few more side ops, all in the same zone. This might not necessarily be a bad thing, because of the replayability, but there will be some pissed off people if you don’t put a big warning in the description.
 [*]The AI in this game is quite stupid, those soldiers with rocket launchers will often kill themselves or their teammates. 
 [*]Guards on the towers ignore killed / disabled enemies on the ground, even when they have clear line of sight. 
 [*][spoiler]Skull Face… seriously skull face? If you have to go for tacky villain at least slap a cape on him…[/spoiler]
 [*]Some features from previous games seems to be missing, leaning corners, ability to shoot weapon / radio out of someone’s hand, knocking on the wall, etc.
 [*]If you stack more than 3 disabled enemies, they will disappear, it is easy to forget somebody on the ground who will appear later just to be discovered by patrolling soldiers.
 [*]Soldiers can see through some walls or closed doors.
 [*]The save (checkpoint) system is well weird at best. If you load checkpoint you sometimes get spawned in completely different area, even one you have not visited yet, on top of that some enemies will rise from the dead and man their posts again. You also hear the scripted radio communications every time and it gets old really quick. The random spawning happens even if you specifically run to the place where the game saves.
 [*]Game does not adjust the mouse speed when zoomed in with scope or binoculars.
 [*]The camera is abysmal in some situations, often you can’t see anything at all. Especially some tight spaces are really tough on the camera control.
 [*]No mouse navigation in menus and iDroid (iDroid, really?).
 [*]The grab / interrogate / kill menu is terrible.
 [*]Menus within menus within menus WTF?
 [*]No support to bind actions to your extra mouse buttons.
 [*]There is no sound menu (2014 WTF?).
 [*]Do we really have to confirm everything in the menus 3 times?
 [*]My mouse has a scroll button, please put it to work.
 [*]Not the best KBM controls, you can line up a headshot point blank from the cover, adjust for the targets movement and watch the bullet magically miss.
 [*]No separate key for ducking? Why isn’t the jump assigned to space by default? There is no button to go to cover, the game randomly decides whether your character will or will not jump to cover.
 [*]The gameplay hints / command tutorials doesn’t adjust for KBM users, the controls are displayed for controller only.
 [*]The helicopter can carry infinite amount of enemy soldiers.
[/list]

review:
Metal Gear Solid V. It's pretty hard to reccomend the game, since what I saw from the trailers and even someone from the studio play it [i]doesn't tell you everything[/i]. In fact, there are many many many things that are mislead during gameplay. There are in fact restrictions, there are limits, and there are certainly some frustrating moments. I will get to those after I peel what is good in the game.

The graphics in the game are absolutly flawless. Very, very well made art and the level design is great. The grass is swaying, and many of the animations are on point. There are things that bugged me though, one of them being that the animations just loop, but it's hard to tell. Another one, and I have been meaning to get to this since the beginning, [b]there is only [i]one[/i] level[/b]. One. That's it. And this just made me so POd when I found out. The side ops are the same damn map the whole way. It does get old after the 2nd side op. Well that's really it for the graphics.

How about the restrictions? Ah, yes. There are indeed restrictions. For example, if you shoot the target, mission is over. If the target dies, mission over. Sure, your helicopter can be blown up, but you get punished for it at the end because it deducts points from you. How is that not a restriction? That really disappointed me when I bought the game expecting not to have any restrictions. Oh yeah, you can't leaave the mission area... or you fail. Yeah, that's not right.

Moving on, the voice acting is incredibly done, as was all of the MG games. Rising, solid, you name it, I think it has really good voice acting. The scripted speeches, you know, the ones where the enemy spots you and radios in, those get repetitive. There are no variations to those lines at all. "This is CP - Understood!" never changes. It's the same guy that says it in the same tone the whole game. No variation at all, and I believe that could have been changed.

Also, the amount of bugs I encountered just by starting the game out was disappointing. I could not use my controller for  [i]THREE[/i] reasons. The first one was because the control scheme isn't what it says it is. It says that "Y" is to use but the "DPAD DOWN" button actually uses. The shoot button is right trigger, sure, but aim is "START". Like, that's poor programming right there. Also, I can't really play the game with my controller anyway, since my mouse gets in the game and the camera is forced to be looking up. Can't move or look around at all. So, if you are buying the game for the controller, don't, otherwise you will be so disappointed. Let's move on the the keyboard and mouse controls. I could not get this until I started the game up the 5th time. You can't use a controller. Duh. You know that now. It breaks the game. So being forced to use a keyboard for a console-made game, was not a good concept for me. However, when I tried it, it seemed to integrate flawlessly with keyboard and mouse controls. Even so, it's going to take some getting used to. First off, there are no cover buttons; you have to move up against a wall to take cover, and hold your walk button to get even close to the side of the cover. The dash button says it needs to be held, but the only way to get out of dash mode is to either change stance (crouch) or to tap your walk button, which isn't a bother for me. I made it through the first 15 minutes of figuring out the controls, but I never knew I needed to hold the change stance button to prone. I mean, it's plausable, but still, I think there could've been at least an option maybe to have a prone button? I don't know. Oh well, like I said, you can't just jump in and play on a keyboard; you have to get used to it first. Not so many flaws, but the "ready weapon" while proned is very annoying. If I wanted to lay on my side and start shooting *just* out of my cover, but I need to move a little bit to the right, oh no. There goes my "on the side" technique. Now I am getting shot at from all over. But that's very minor and that's what the actual cover system is for.

Mechanics are a very hard spot of the game; very hard to get perfect, yet easy to bring down the quality of the game. Personally, I have found no problems with the mechanics of the game, besides having the weird menu where you have to use the WASD keys to navigate. Also, if you complete a certain mission, some guy that you rescue is actually ON THE SCREEN in the main menu! I only wanted Snake to be on there! Not this guy no one knows about! Anyway, like I said, no real problems with the mechanics that I could see. You can crawl under buildings and climb over things, you can carry and throw bodies, you can hang off of the only cliff in the game and fall directly into the ocean where it automaticly kills you, etc. Dying isn't really a problem besides the score deduction at the end. It doesn't take too long to get back in the action. The loading screens are actually interactive with hints that you can use the arrow keys to switch hints and read through them. A problem I have found is that it is not very easy to "stick someone up" by holding a gun to their head. I got right behind someone and held a gun to their face, but no, I go into reflex mode and end up shooting the guy. I tried the same thing with at least 5 other soldiers but with the same result. Let's go on to the story.

The story is actually pretty good. There is a backstory, too, since that's what Metal Gear is all about. But one thing that just really, really, REALLY disappoints me, is... [b]THERE IS ONLY ONE, AND ONLY ONE STORY MISSION![/b] Why? That pissed me off! That was very disappointing, and I would have liked more. There's even a cutscene with Snake in a coma for 9 years. That's a very annoying loose end! How did he get into the coma? Since this isn't revealed in the plot itself, I wouldn't consider this a spoiler. That drove me crazy. I can't comprehend why they would take the story and just take a shit on it like that. One mission. Really? The rest are side ops. Even the side ops could be tied in with the story! They were so good. "Rescue this guy named, Jarry let's call him, and he has a tape that contains an interrogation between some guy we need to kill and another guy we need to capture" would have been a great objective and might have tied in with the story had it been given some polish. When someone needs to make up a story because a game's side mission could be a part of the story just means that the developers didn't do a very good job with it, and that is bringing down my final score. Speaking of which...

The game is beautiful on the outside, but the devs totally mislead you into buying the game and getting you disappointed. This really pissed me off, but hey, it's still really fun to just sneak around or go in guns blazing and I had a ton of fun playing this game and I still am having fun. That being said, the game is actually pretty good, but not what was expected from the trailers and the dev notes bringing this score to a [b][i][u]7/10.[/b][/i]/u] If I played the game and there were more story missions, [i]more maps and not the same cheap-ass map over and over again[/i] then it probably would have gotten a higher score and my 3 Thumbs Up mark, but it's not what was expected and it could have been polished a bit more, however it is still a good game and I think that people that just want to pretend the story is not there and you want to play something like Splinter Cell Chaos Theory, then I highly reccomend it. If you are looking for a game with a well thought out story and plentiful maps, then I suggest looking for another game. Thanks for reading my long-ass review and I hope this helped a bit.
raw_json:
{"recommendationid": "13572215", "author": {"steamid": "76561198099934365", "num_games_owned": 1103, "num_reviews": 20, "playtime_forever": 1302, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 314, "last_played": 1511635350}, "language": "english", "review": "Metal Gear Solid V. It's pretty hard to reccomend the game, since what I saw from the trailers and even someone from the studio play it [i]doesn't tell you everything[/i]. In fact, there are many many many things that are mislead during gameplay. There are in fact restrictions, there are limits, and there are certainly some frustrating moments. I will get to those after I peel what is good in the game.

The graphics in the game are absolutly flawless. Very, very well made art and the level design is great. The grass is swaying, and many of the animations are on point. There are things that bugged me though, one of them being that the animations just loop, but it's hard to tell. Another one, and I have been meaning to get to this since the beginning, [b]there is only [i]one[/i] level[/b]. One. That's it. And this just made me so POd when I found out. The side ops are the same damn map the whole way. It does get old after the 2nd side op. Well that's really it for the graphics.

How about the restrictions? Ah, yes. There are indeed restrictions. For example, if you shoot the target, mission is over. If the target dies, mission over. Sure, your helicopter can be blown up, but you get punished for it at the end because it deducts points from you. How is that not a restriction? That really disappointed me when I bought the game expecting not to have any restrictions. Oh yeah, you can't leaave the mission area... or you fail. Yeah, that's not right.

Moving on, the voice acting is incredibly done, as was all of the MG games. Rising, solid, you name it, I think it has really good voice acting. The scripted speeches, you know, the ones where the enemy spots you and radios in, those get repetitive. There are no variations to those lines at all. "This is CP - Understood!" never changes. It's the same guy that says it in the same tone the whole game. No variation at all, and I believe that could have been changed.

Also, the amount of bugs I encountered just by starting the game out was disappointing. I could not use my controller for  [i]THREE[/i] reasons. The first one was because the control scheme isn't what it says it is. It says that "Y" is to use but the "DPAD DOWN" button actually uses. The shoot button is right trigger, sure, but aim is "START". Like, that's poor programming right there. Also, I can't really play the game with my controller anyway, since my mouse gets in the game and the camera is forced to be looking up. Can't move or look around at all. So, if you are buying the game for the controller, don't, otherwise you will be so disappointed. Let's move on the the keyboard and mouse controls. I could not get this until I started the game up the 5th time. You can't use a controller. Duh. You know that now. It breaks the game. So being forced to use a keyboard for a console-made game, was not a good concept for me. However, when I tried it, it seemed to integrate flawlessly with keyboard and mouse controls. Even so, it's going to take some getting used to. First off, there are no cover buttons; you have to move up against a wall to take cover, and hold your walk button to get even close to the side of the cover. The dash button says it needs to be held, but the only way to get out of dash mode is to either change stance (crouch) or to tap your walk button, which isn't a bother for me. I made it through the first 15 minutes of figuring out the controls, but I never knew I needed to hold the change stance button to prone. I mean, it's plausable, but still, I think there could've been at least an option maybe to have a prone button? I don't know. Oh well, like I said, you can't just jump in and play on a keyboard; you have to get used to it first. Not so many flaws, but the "ready weapon" while proned is very annoying. If I wanted to lay on my side and start shooting *just* out of my cover, but I need to move a little bit to the right, oh no. There goes my "on the side" technique. Now I am getting shot at from all over. But that's very minor and that's what the actual cover system is for.

Mechanics are a very hard spot of the game; very hard to get perfect, yet easy to bring down the quality of the game. Personally, I have found no problems with the mechanics of the game, besides having the weird menu where you have to use the WASD keys to navigate. Also, if you complete a certain mission, some guy that you rescue is actually ON THE SCREEN in the main menu! I only wanted Snake to be on there! Not this guy no one knows about! Anyway, like I said, no real problems with the mechanics that I could see. You can crawl under buildings and climb over things, you can carry and throw bodies, you can hang off of the only cliff in the game and fall directly into the ocean where it automaticly kills you, etc. Dying isn't really a problem besides the score deduction at the end. It doesn't take too long to get back in the action. The loading screens are actually interactive with hints that you can use the arrow keys to switch hints and read through them. review:
This game is great.

As a long standing fan of MGS I do have a slight bias, however this is really good. Players who have played the earlier MGS games will notice a lot of differences in the gameplay, some I don't think should have been done, some things taken away that should have been left in my opinion, however overall I think this game is the right direction for MGS and I very much look forward to The Phantom Pain.

There is plenty to do if you are a completionist, and as a lot of reviews have said you can spend 20 minutes to 20 hours on this game easily depending on what kind of player you are.

[strike]8/10[/strike] 9/10, just because the easter eggs really tickled me.

review:
This game is short. Like, really short. The main mission took me an hour to complete, and that was with me not knowing where I was going or what I was doing. And this game is supposed to be short -- The Phantom Pain should be a lot longer.

I was blown away by the visuals. When the game started, I honestly thought I was watching a pre-rendered cutscene - the rain on Big Boss' face, the bloom in the lights, everything just looked great. I was stunned when the intro shifted right to the gameplay and I realised that I was watching a real-time cinematic.

My PC is a few years old now and can barely run Watch_Dogs on "low", but MGS: GZ was running quite comfortably on High. Cranking it up to "Very High" caused some really bad stutter, but I expected that out of a 3 year old PC.

Graphics aside, the controls are good (but a touch confusing in the heat of the moment, especially when playing with a gamepad and you're not au fait with the buttons yet) and gameplay is good. The AI is still that good ol' MGS AI, where they forget about you 2 minutes after you steal a tank and blow up half the facility. They're smarter, as they now surround you, and after a few bodies show up around the place, they ratchet up the alert level, but it soon subsides.

The story is interesting, though it has been a while since I played MGS 3, so I'm a bit rusty on who half of these people are. Having Kiefer Sutherland do the voice and face of Snake rustled my jimmies initially (David Hayter was always "Snake" to me) but reading up on it, I can see why Kojima did it. Basically, at some point Big Boss and Snake will have to meet, and having two Snakes with the same voice would be strange. Plus David Hayter probably nearly mangled his voicebox doing Snake for so long. There was also some talk about MGS: GZ being made for American audiences first or something, but I dunno.

So yeah, this is a MGS like the rest, and the story should prove to be amazing like always, plus the graphics. Take a lesson from this, Watch_Dogs, your game looks bad and you should feel bad, and take some lessons from the FOX Engine.

review:
**The thumbs up is a little more complex than it seems. I really wish Steam would implement a middle ground choice.**

Being a noob to the MGS series, I felt that this was a pretty good place to start, based on the very positive reviews (especially when talking about the optimization of the PC port). I was excited to try it out, and after a couple frustrating hours of trying to fix control bugs, I was in. 

First of all, the game is drop-dead gorgeous. Kojima Productions really shows the modern-day AAA dev how to make a PC port correctly. As far as I can tell, the game as a whole runs beautifully on almost any gaming machine you throw it at. My mid-high range system runs the game maxed out at 50-60 fps consistently. The production values really shine through on this one. The cut-scenes and voice acting are just as ingaging as the gameplay itself. 

Being new to the series, I had a little trouble getting into the mind set of a MGS game, but once I was there, I was hooked. The controls feel really intuitive and moving Snake around the open enviornment works really well. From what I can tell, this entry takes the mechanics of previous MGS games and puts them into an open-world eske enviornment, where you can take on missions the way YOU want to play. Want to feel like a spy, infultraiting a base with high-skill and finesse? You can do that. Want to go in guns blaizing and blow up every red barrel in sight? You can do that too. Most likely with little sucess, but you can do it. This is a really good look at how MGS V The Phantom Pain will play.

But that's the problem. The game feels like a sneak peak to The Phantom Pain. I felt as though I did very poorly in the game, dying a lot and I only really focused on getting to my objectives. And still, my game time came out to around 1.5 hours. I don't really feel like I got my moneys worth, even at the $13 sale. Now keep in mind, I've never played the MGS series, so that may alter my final views on the game, but from what I played, I feel like this is an overpriced demo. If it was $10 normally, I would have no problems, because I feel that even with the short play time, the production values and the quality of the port make it worth that.

But seeing how that isn't the case, I would be very careful recommending this to someone. If you are a fan of the series and can't wait for the Phantom Pain to come out, go ahead and get it. You will probably get more enjoyment out of it than I did and justify the $20. But if you aren't a fan of the series, wait till it goes on sale around $10 again.

Don't get me wrong. I really did enjoy my time with Ground Zeroes. The gameplay feels really nice, the world it presents is gorgeous and complex, and the production values are through the f***ing roof. But since the game's total play time doesn't neccesarily coinside with the normal $20 price tag, I would have a hard time recommending this game to people who had a similar gaming background and taste to my own.

Pros:
-The world is immersive and drop dead gorgeous
-Hands down one of the best optimizations of a PC port from a AAA dev in the past several years
-Fun and exciting gameplay that allows you to play MGS the way you want to play
-Amazing production values

Cons:
-No benchmarking mode(this game really deserves one)
-IMO the amount of content won't be enough to justify the $20 price tag
-I experienced some bugs with the controls making the game unplayable, but eventually fixed them. Seems to be a case by case issue that can be patched in.

-If you are a huge MGS fan, go ahead and get it. If not, wait for another decent sale.-

Cons:
-No benchmarking mode(this game really deserves one)
-IMO the amount of content won't be enough to justify the $20 price tag
-I experienced some bugs with the controls making the game unplayable, but eventually fixed them. Seems to be a case by case issue that can be patched in.

-If you are a huge MGS fan, go ahead and get it. If not, wait for another decent sale.-", "timestamp_created": 1419406241, "timestamp_updated": 1419487338, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 3, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.532876133918762207", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
I tranq'd a rat.

10/10, would tranq again.

Seriously though, the actual review: For 10-15$, it is quite enjoyable. If you are a completionist like myself, you will find plenty to do. The gameplay is the best metal gear yet, the story was short but intense, and as a pc port it runs very well.

Running the game near maxed on core i7 2600k, gtx 570 sc and 16gb ram rig @ 60 FPS w/ v sync on.

It's basically the warmup you need before Phantom Pain.. because damn, the gameplay is sweet.

review:
Not worth it.....The story can be understood by watching all of the cutscenes...and the gameplay consists of you looking for a kid and a girl and carrying them back to a helicopter.....
Sure the game runs great and looks like it should on a PC, but that shouldn't be a plus, it should be expected.

WHY DID I BUY THIS

This isnt a game that is for sale its ONE single map.  Payday 2 sells heists that can be completed different ways.  That is all this game is, except instead of getting different locations there is only one location.  Hideo Kojima who made Metal Gear has been around alot longer than Overkill and should know more about game design but here on PC we get ONE map, oh gee thanks Kojima.

This game is more like the Sniper Challenge which was free as a preorder bonus for Hitman.  It was one map with alot of stuff to do, lots of records to go for and trials, exactly like this game except for Hitman it was FREE.  This is just stupid, after finishing the first mission, I thought alright lets see whats next, but its the same thing, the same place.

This game feels like some weird hybrid mix of a poor mans splinter cell and assassins creed.  There are takedowns like assassins creed if you stand behind a wall or around a corner, wow so NOT original.  Checking the reviews for this game their ALL positive, many saying, "The game works", or "awesome graphics".  Is that the standard for PC gaming?  That it just "works"?  

Thats a bold faced lie the controls are crap, you hit "B" to reload, in what world is that the reload button?  The controls are like their from 1987 when Metal Gear was first released.  There is no duck button, he will arbitrarily decide to move into cover or not.  Its completely random, this game is very random.  When diving he seems to randomly decide to just get back up and get shot or stay down, its a crazy random thing where you feel completely out of control.  The AI is borderline stupid, setting the industry back at least 5-7 years.  Typical AI if they hear a sound everyone knows right where you are, they can see through walls even.  A clear example of bad AI is the rocket launcher soldiers that are so Gung Ho as marines they will fire a rocket in your direction hitting a wall or another of their marines right in front of them killing themself their friends everybody, those Marines are pretty hardcore. The camera sucks, often you cant see around anything or anywhere really.  Just like sniper elite, the enemies simply run back and forth shooting at you from so far away their almost not even visible, just small blobs of what could be a person.   So great the game works, it runs, the rest of it sucks.  

And the menus in this game!  dear god, its like playing on windows with UAC turned on, everything must be confirmed.  The game doesnt even start unless you press a button.  There is no hot swapping of weapons, to switch your main weapons you press "up" on the dpad twice, why twice?  Why not once?  Actually had friends over and discussed how the person who made the menus for this game must have spent their days figuring out every conceivable way make their job more important by making more and more menus, popups, confirmations, and useless screens that say press a button to continue.

For people who like this thats great then get Payday 2 which is half the price has online, co-op, and even stealth, its the SAME game basically.  MGSV shoulda been a free preorder bonus for a REAL game like it was with Sniper Challenge for Hitman.  Not some cheap way to rip off gamers, specially not nice to do around Christmas when gamers could be getting games to play for longer times, year round, at lower prices.

haters gonna hate...
Rating:  3/10  Value:  $4.99

review:
This review will focus on hardware settings for others to compare.  I'll be posting a few more reviews if they work on any other configurations that may work.

So far, I've tested this on a gamble that my computer could actually play this game, and it does.

These are the specs of my computer, if you have the same or better hardware, you probably will be able to play this game.

-Intel Pentium g3258 dual core processer (not overclocked)
-4gb + 1gb ram
-XFX R7 250 1GB
-750gb WD Black laptop drive

I was able to play this game with all low 1080p settings and medium 720p settings (can adjust higher).  I'm unable to check the fps but these settings feel playable.

review:
This is how a Modern single player game should be. A very cinematic experience and a rich storyline.
and the Graphics - Better than good and was absolutely no fuss at all with drivers or my SLI config, Silky smooth gameplay.

This game is little more than a intro/teaser for upcoming Phantom Pain. But it's well worth it.
Gives the hardcore PC community a chance to see what a metal gear game is made of.

I definately recommend this and yes i will now preorder phantom pain when i can!

review:
perfect example of "even better on PC" - can't find any user complaining who is in the proper specs, only users praising this as the superior version which will carry over to MGSV: THE PHANTOM PAIN which is now in my top 3 most anticipated titles after playing the A+ 100/100 (110/100 if purchased steam sale day 1!)

- eye popping mouth watering visuals with the Nvidia Gameswork powered FOX ENGINE
- Supports 4K resolution right off the bat. 
- Never experienced any fps slow down even when making a point of hijacking a tank whilst running soldier into a proximity minefield
- 100% open ended sandbox approach to The Metal Gear series for the first time. Done in a way that no two players wil decide to approach any scenario the same way, and oh how the results will change due to the real-time constants and variables.
- A ---masterpiece--- in Direction and Storytelling after the main "prequel" to MGSV mission your jaw will be left open.
- The prequel/TECH Demo to MGSV: THE PHANTOM PAIN which is the finale in the Metal Gear (1 & 2) and The Metal Gear Solid titles, being the final part of the Timeline before the start of the NES Original's story.
- masterful keyboard+mouse controls lending itself to seem to be better by game design especiakky when using First-Person VIEW mode.
- Realistic bulletdrom / aim for distance
- You can re-inact A WEEKEND AT BERNY'S by placing corpses or knocked out enemies in varous seats of a vehicle then stroll around guard posts all like "naah berny isnt dead!"
- Directed by Hideo Kojima       !!!!!!!

review:
This game is honestly just a demo with a story for Metal Gear Solid V The Phantom Pain. You can beat the main campaign in 2 hours, and while it unlocks side missions which may last you a while really it's just redressing up the map and throwing different challenges at you much in the vein of the old VR Missions from 1 and 2. Kiefer Sutherland sounded very phoned in. I hope he gives a better performance with the meater content of Phantom Pain.

That said I paid about the price of a movie ticket and as such don't really feel cheated. The port was fantastic, the mechanics were solid, the graphics were beautiful and it did exactly what it was supposed to do: get me extremely excited for The Phantom Pain. It was sort of like a good minimal-plot interactive movie, but the middle movie in a trillogy where if you didn't see the first one you'll have no idea what is going on nor will you care, and it doesn't wrap up that well (Though the chopper ride out is satisfying enough to make it feel like it wraps up better than some clifhangger fiction).

review:
It is running faster than 30FPS on my second gen dual core i3 3.2GHz (4GB GDDR3) and Radion HD 6570M (512MB of GDDR3).

Now I cannot run it on high and at my native screen res of 2560x1440, but at 1920 and on low it plays just like it should. Probably getting 30-45 fps with everything on the lowest settings. Which it is really impressive that the engine is so well optimized. I was just buying this to see if my computer had any hope of running MGS V: The Phantom Pain and it looks like I will be joining everyone soon :D

If I drop the res farther I can get all the extra effects and stuff and the same frame rate, and since I am using a wired 360 controler I can enjoy the game from a far distance on my 25 inch LCD.

The game is exactly what would be expected from the PS3 version, nothing less and a lot more options of play on PC :D

So will it run well on outdated hardware that you could get much better for $500? YES!!!

I highly recomend this game to anyone that likes the series and wants to try it on their PC.

review:
Before I built my PC, I was on the fence. Mainly due to certain games that were coming out for consoles. I decided to build my PC knowing that I was going to miss out on games I loved on console such as the MGS series, and Halo. 

I grew up playing MGS on PS1, I never did get the gameboy versions. But I have very fond memories of MGS 1 on PS1. 
When I found out PC was getting a port of MGS I was excited and I was going to buy it no matter how awful the port was.

Well I'm here to tell you, this game is amazing. Runs EXTREMELY smooth on extra high. The controls are very easy to get used to. 

Although, this game is a teaser to the actual MGSV, it still provides a lot of hours of gameplay and replayability. Honestly I'm so glad this is an amazing port, of an amazing series. I really hope they bring out the rest of the old series revamped for PC.

You definitely should get this game, even if you have never played the series. Now is the time to start.

With this combination of graphical aspect , technical marvelous , fully PC gameplay-wise with captivating and breathtaking , heart-stopping , cliffhanging storytelling that made us crave for more . 

Metal Gear Solid V : Ground Zeroes is truly one of the best 'Prologue' to the next part , The Phantom Pain , and is one of the best in Metal Gear Solid Saga which Hideo Kojima-Sensei play it really masterfully and crafty ..... 'Like a damn Fiddle'!

PS.Please don't be discourage by my playtime on Steam , I played it on Playstation 4 from tips to toes before PC release :).
Metal... Gear?

review:
Wow pretty damn impressed as are a lot of people apparently. 

I bought a PS4 so I could play this originally and was very impressed but disapointed with the consoles capabilities. This is currently one of the few games I can play properly at 2400p 60fps (GTX 980 SLI). With all the settings maxed out it doesn't even flinch and looks fantastic. Some of wet textures look like plastic and the lack of real AA options is annoying, but this is becoming quite common now it seems.

The bottom line is that a Japanese developer not entirely familiar with our platform has made a lot of the big developers look like morons. Damn impressed with how well optimised this game is! Just a shame this game won't get the traditional retail treatment the peasant versions will.
The only bad thing about this game, is that it makes me sad Phantom Pain isn't out yet.

review:
A well done port, in my honest opinion. MGS team did a really great job with it.

Played through the whole main mission with mouse & keyboard, it was pretty awesome. Controls were smooth and nothing awkward. I think they thought it out pretty well.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Beautiful, absolutely beautiful. Fox Engine might be my new favorite. lol

Even when it's set to low, it's still stunning. The way it can scale and all the stuff, amazing.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Fantastic. Every little detail, from rain hitting the surface to far off distant yawn. Well done.

[h1]Other Stuff[/h1]
At the time of posting/playing this. My PC's specs are:
AMD Phenom II x4 955 @ 3.2Ghz
4GB of RAM
AMD/ATi 6770

After tweaking some graphic settings, it'll run very smooth. I did lock FPS at 30, I did this to prevent any unexpecting issues. So, if you're wondering if your PC can run it and you have similar specs. Here's your answer. :)

There is plenty of replay too. Stuff like Side Ops and Extra Ops. Or maybe you're a trial record setter or an achievement hunter. There is still tons of stuff you can do.

If the quality of this is the same for The Phantom Pain, then that will be fantastic aswell.

-stamps paper- [b]Recommended.[/b]

review:
Below you'll find a video and written impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pN1ngQoNv9U
MGSV:GZ has all the gameplay qualities that most of you have come to expect from the MGS series. Ground Zeroes is a great looking game, especially if you are running it from a mid-high tier machine or above. It's very well optimized and shows noticeable improvement from it's console counterpart.

If you're into the MGS series this is an easy recommendation, but every one needs to be aware that your first play through will only be between 2-4 hours depending on how you play. It's not a lot, and certainly much less from what we've come to be used to from AAA release. But the game does offer multiple ways to play, and gives incentive to multiple playthroghs. If you are to look at a game like Transistor which is about the same price, it also only has 2-4 hours first time through. From that perspective I feel I can still recommend MGSV:GZ even with it's short play time.

Overall I enjoyed what the game had to offer and I am very very excited for the Phantom Pain

Pros:
- Great visuals
- Great optimization for the PC
- Classic MGS gameplay
- Multiple ways to play, multiple playthrough possibilities

Cons:
- Very short for a AAA release
- Only features one area

review:
After missing on All the other Metal Gear Solid games after Metal Gear Solid and Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance its great to see another Metal Gear Solid franchise game on the PC Platform. There is a few people that are classing this as a Payware DEMO.


Yes this game only has one Level in the Main mission which is then used as a base level for the rest of the side missions (Side Ops) how ever there is more then 1 hours worth of game play.

The new graphics engine shows some real potential and is not locked down to 30 FPS although there is an option to do so. Game play is fluid and fun. The also has an Option to skip the cinematics which is a bonus!!.

For once this is no Console Port with Performance issues it runs smooth and allows for Keyboard and Gamepad control.

This game is also the starting point for Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain which if its using the same game engine looks to be a well worth purchase.

Overal i would recommend this to anyone whom is a Metal Gear Solid fan or not as its worth while game to play even if its just one base level'd game.

I rate it a BIG 10/10

review:
Despite all those negativities, I really enjoy this prologue of a larger epicness. 

Runs perfectly smooth on my mid-range 2-year-old too @ 1080p with all options on Extra High except Screen Filtering (Extra High filtering has too much DOF effects that kinda make my head spin) and AO on High.

Many nay-sayers complained this should be a free demo and it's way too short, but know this: no one complained about the shortness and repetitiveness of the likes of LoL or TF2 and they've probably spent more than what this game costed for those custom skins and hats. And this is a full prologue, not even a demo.

If it was up to me, a demo would be what you played up to the point when you're about to rescue your first prisoner...

review:
You only get one mission area, but it supposedly links up with the main game when you buy it. The Area is huge though and there are a lot of different missions you can do in that area. 

Game is mission based, not quest giver or discovery based which I like as I don't see MGS as an RPG in open world type combat. That being said there are still discovery components. Like one mission has you find 2 people and eliminate them, you have to look for them, follow their patterns and find the best way to kill them.

If you only care about the story and the main mission campaign then this is not for you but it will give you an insight into what the main game will be about as this is a prequel. If you like MGS, want to show support for them bringing it to PC, want to start building the hype train to MGS V, want to see some GORGEOUS cinematics, and do some fun missions at different times of the day/weather effects for each one then this is for sure for you.

The port is solid, KB/M feels fine and I cannot wait for the release.

You see that silky smooth 60fps and maximum AA? You can't do this on a console, at least until maybe 2019.

review:
As a big fan of the Metal Gear series, this one does not disappoint!
MGS4 was a bit too linear, this is closer to 3 (the best!).

Just keep in mind, this is only the "prologue" to MGS5: Phantom Pain, so it's fairly short with only one mission. But it is very re-playable!

Kojima shows the world how to PC port the right way!

[h1]Pros +++[/h1]
[list]
[*]Fox Engine runs smoothly at 1080p + highest settings on GTX 760 + i5-2500k with stock speed (my CPU wasn't even meet the minimum requirement), no patch needed!
[*]Great amount of fun for a "demo" game.
[*]Graphics looks superb even on the default settings.
[/list]

[h1]Cons ---[/h1]
[list]
[*]No mouse navigation support in menus & iDroid.
[*]Clunky mouse controls in binocular & sniper scope.
[*]I have nightmares after collecting all the audio tapes.
[/list]

review:
If your a happy trigger COD player, than this game might not be for you. If your into spec ops, going rogue, etc... than this game is just for you.

This game is freaking awesome! The game is so well optimize, it's all look pretty as hell, smooth gameplay, and the AI are freaking great, and I love the slow motion of when your being seen when he about to set off the alarm, giving you enough time just to silence him before he set off the alarm. I'm a big MGS fan, and by far this is the best MGS I have played, I can't wait for the phantom pain to come out.

For $13 CAD, GREAT DEAL! Still worth it for $20 even though the game may be short, but you can do so much, and it's a open world. If I have to rate this game, I give it 8/10 because the game so well made.

Let me list what you can't do that you could do in a previous version of the games:
Can't feign death.
*1 Can't antagonize held up enemies by aiming the gun at certain body parts.
Can't judo/knock a weapon out of someone's hand.
Can't hold more than one weapon.
*1 Can't shake enemies down for extra ammo/items.
Can't lean corners.
Can't shoot a gun out of someone's hand.
Can't shoot a radio out of someone's hand.
Can't shoot a grenade on person/hand and watch it explode.
(controller) There's 3 buttons that don't do anything when in standard/idle position. (Hey maybe that could of been a cover button?)
Can't blind fire around the corner.
Can't knock on walls. (That's fucking trademark to the metal gear series and this is the only one with out it.)
Mah knife.
Keifer Sutherland sounds like generic soldier #8, forgetable.
Can't slide. (Exlusive to MGS4)

Other gripes:
Seems to be only one mouse sensitivity level for looking/hip/aim. Very akward unless you got a mouse with adjustable DPI.
The auto covers is annoying as hell.
Aiming directly horizontal from cover will still put your head up. (This wasn't an issue in MGS4)

The game is tailored to multi-platform use which is not good because originally was played by a controller with sensitivity levels on all the buttons, which by the way had different variations in actions on the amount of pressure delievered to the button, and is now losed to xinput/keyboard nonsense. I don't mind playing my fps with a mouse, but when you need to do several different actions at once while shooting a controller is easier.

[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]
This was a pretty terrible demo from a gameplay perspective. Graphics were pretty. Would not buy, played this through share. Would not buy full game with this type of header.
If being nuclear was destroying your old fan base, you've succeeded. Weclome 360noscope420blazeitfaggots, ez mode all day.

review: Absolutely fantastic..... Game? Demo?  Who cares what you call it.  For the price this is a great experience and one that I have kept myself from by not purchasing the newest generation of consoles to enjoy.  Now that it is on PC it has truly arrived in its most definitive form.  Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a prime example of how PC Ports should be done.  Utilizes 4 cores on my i7 and has never dipped below 60 fps on my GTX 780 with highest settings turned on.  This definitely has primed me for the forthcoming Phantom Pain.  Sure the main mission is short and can be completed rather quickly but the extras thrown in here allow you to hone your skills and prepare for the real meal.  Very intuitive controls, unlike past Metal Gear Solid games, allow you to sneak into a full sprint over a short fence and choke somebody with minimal effort.  Awesome but short game.

review:
Finally after several years, another MGS title arrives on the PC and happens to be 64-bit.
That explains why it runs so smoothly without the usual PC game choppiness.

Playing with a gamepad is a must, in my case I used my PS3 Dualshock 3 controller.
It requires seeking out 3rd party drivers to function, but it's well worth it.

review:
After spending countless hours 100% full clearing the PS4 version of this title I was excited to see what it would be like on a pc with the promise of the fox engine being able to really turn some heads. I can honestly say my thoughts of the same game with more or less better graphics was blown outta the water completely. Not only is there extra geometry that ive noticed compared to the ps4 version the ability to have more bodies on the field at once is a plus as for people like me who love to pile up a dozen or so bodies for extraction for it to carry over to TPP can do that now. 

The game is silky smooth and had 60fps even after I had put the settings to higher then 1920x1080 with DSR in effect and it looked stunning to boot. especially on sale now its almost the worlds safest choice on a holiday sale buy.

review:
[h1]Outstanding[/h1]
A very well optimized game that conveys all the player needs to know prior to playing The Phantom Pain. The short main mission leaves the player asking for more, and the side ops and extra intel like the cassette tapes provide a taste of what we should expect in The Phantom Pain.

For newcomers to the saga, the gameplay feels easy to learn and the backstory option in the main menu succedes in introducing the new players to the game's lore.

Graphically, the game looks outstanding, and it doesn't require a lot of horsepower to run it, since it is well optimized. We should expect nothing less than this optimization level from console ports from now and on.

Overall, the short prologe to The Phantom Pain is a masterpiece on its own.

review:
It took me about 2 hours to complete the campaign. There are many complaints about how long this game is, it's only $20 I didn't expect a whole lot from it, but I had a really good time playing it. I welcome back Metal Gear's elements it's known for.

Gameplay: The controls are excellent, there's no more countdown timer or mini-map. This game seems to be more realistic than the previous ones. It feels like a real Metal Gear, but obviously different. The motions feel very fluid when compared to the other Metal Gears. This is a new generation that expects different things. It has to change to not become tiring and it has done a great job at that. There were some areas where I thought Kojima went too far, such as the tape you listen to from Chico. And the helicopter scene with Paz. It's basically forced torture to say the least. I can't give the game a higher rating than 8 because of those just disturbing things.

Issues: My main issue was that I have AMD hardware and this game doesn't seem to have been tested or implemented correctly on AMD desktop architecture hardware . The consoles this game is on does use AMD hardware, but a different architecture than used in PC's. The game suffers from a memory leak on this hardware it may depend on which type of AMD graphics cards you have, but on mine (R9 290) and others have also said the same thing about this problem. It force closes the game and causes some problems also in the Windows operating system.

All-in-all I would recommend buying this, the price and experience you can get from this would be well worth it. This is the Prologue to the upcoming game Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain.

8/10

review:
snake, what took you so long :'(

basicly it's just one island, slightly large adult-playground with several missions and infinite possibilities. i've played mgs 1 and 2 on pc. my mind blew back then, double time, now it gets to blow again. you play as the legendary hero, snake, dropped in to an island and got to carry out several missions. whole island is your playground, you get to choose how to carry out the mission, even whom to carry inside the extraction chopper. yes! even dead bodies.

pros:
[list]
    [*]awesome graphics of fox game engine. even my laptop(msi gt780dxr) is way below min settings written in store page, i was able to pay in highest settings with no lags. so no worries, your wooden pc might be able to run it.
    [*]freedom. ahhh sweet smell of democracy on a u.s. base, however you want. roleplay as snake, or call of duty style, heck even go jackie chan on enemies. blow stuff up, or go silent.
    [*]moar freedom. get inside an armored vehicle and travel around the enemy base with ease.
    [*]better ai. be honest, when was the last time you've heard an enemy reporting 'yo base, just saw something suspicious over there gonna check it out. will radio the result later'
[/list]

cons:
[list]
    [*]too short :'(
[/list]

bugs n requests:
[list]
    [*]walking over dead bodies and my feet throws them around like some football. seriously no deadweight :( i just have to carry them back to bushes...
    [*]cannot grab unconcious enemies :( why do i have to kick them to wake up? its rude.
    [*]no handcuffs or ropes or anything to bind their hands :( i cant take any war prisoners like they did to those poor men. well, actually i can, but gotta grab and knock out before carrying in that chopper. its quite not the same.
    [*]listening a recording to find out a certain place... that was awesome, i love it. i-totally-love-it. there should be more of this, rather than marking a circle on map after whatever that soldier told me. tracking the sound step by step while hiding was too awesome. please have this feature on phantom pain.
[/list]

review:
Like others have stated it's more of a demo, but overall good. At the end screen it took me 56 minutes to complete. The rest of my played time (1.5 hrs at the time of writing this) was cutscenes or trying to get my controller to work.

Just posting this as a warning to anyone who prefers to play with a controller, I could not get a controller to work with this game. Everything was mapped wrong, and I couldn't remap it as the options I found were just presets. B was A, Clicking the right stick was start, left and right triggers were looking left and right and it was perpetually stuck staring straight up. 

After restarting the game several times, I unplugged my controller and I had no issues with the PC controls.
It plays like a damn fiddle

review:
Let me start off with this: This is probably the best port I've ever played in my life. By that, I mean there's pretty much no optimization problems. It runs like butter. I point this out, because for the past few months, PC Gaming has had a mean streak with ports (a lot of them coming from our favorite publisher, Ubisoft) in which potentially good or bad games are immediately hampered with frames per second rates so bad I feel like I'm playing a stop motion film. It's almost like Kojima saw this, and thought "It's time", and released this to show that "Hey, Phantom Pain is still coming to PC, and we're not going to drop the ball on this. Don't believe us? Check this out." And for that, I'm very happy.

Onto the actual game: This is the infamous "2-hour game for $20", originally going to be priced at $30. Take that what you will. People will argue that it has a fantastic replayability, and it does, it really does, but that doesn't necessary take away from the fact that the actual story campaign is very minimal and doesn't quite contribute as much as it should have. We came here with a dozen questions, and left with a hundred more. 

That being said, the brief time I've played this game on just the main mission has been incredible simply for how flexible everything plays out. Say you wanted to do a completely non-lethal approach on a mission. 
And then there's the side-ops. These are missions that don't take you to a new map, mind you, but give you different kinds of objectives to approach. Kill a guy here, retrieve some intel there, etc. There's even a nice not-so-little cameo appearance from our favorite Japanese video game director. 
In my opinion, to get through all the content in and outside of the main mission, it will take you longer than 2 hours, especially if you want to try experimenting with different playthroughs or want to achieve S rank in everything. It would be much better if the side-ops were integrated more into the main story rather than just non-canon side quests like the way they are now, but it's something of a very small sample to what Phantom Pain is going to turn out to be, and the future looks bright. 
Overall, Ground Zeroes proves to be a phenomenal prologue that gives a lot of hope for the main entry, in which we'll see Big Boss in his transformation stages to the villanous character of the early Metal Gear games. 
It's also the only game where you can't have Snake smoke during a mission. 0/10.

review:
Long time MGS player here since the Nintendo era.

The FOX engine runs very well on the PC, zero crashes or stutter whatsoever, looks great and most importantly it's a blast to play.

This is a shining example on how ports should be done! 

Don't listen to people complaining about it's length or size of the map.

It's has good replay value and should tide you over until Phantom Pain comes out.

If you like stealth games like Splinter Cell or Thief, you would be doing yourself a disservice not to get this one.

review:
If you're a Metal Gear Solid fan this is a must buy.  Nostalgia alone brought me to Ground Zeros but the game itself kept me.  This is the very best of the original and best "Tactical Espionage Action" with improved graphics, improved AI and a damn hard mission objective. Sure it's short but for the sale price of 16 euro this was a steal. It also has massive replayability.  To this day I still replay MGS3: Snake Eater and the Tanker Mission in MGS2 to set myself challenges. Ground Zeros is better than both of them and because it's on PC it is better still. Playing with a Xbox 360 controller or with keyboard and mouse the controls are great. The only exception to this is the vehicle controls which I found hard with the keyboard but good with the controller.

On that point, I'm playing on a Dell Laptop (Windows 8.1 64 bit, 6gb RAM, i5 2.6 Ghz dual core processor, with Nvidia 650M 2gb GPU) which is listed at the lower end of capability by Steam. The game runs flawlessly with incredible graphics. If you have a higher power PC capable of the full 4K graphics your mind will be blown.

All that said if you're new to the Metal Gear series and have no experience with stealth action a games I’d only suggest buying this if you are absolutely sure that you will buy Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Ground Zeros is a good place to learn the basics and master the very difficult mechanics of avoiding contact and neutralizing threats without being seen. On the otehr hand if you're a Metal Gear fan with a PC (and haven't bought this for console already) I highly recommend this game!

I'd rate this as a 4 out of 5 due to its price point. 20 Euro full price is steep for a short story but that said Ground Zeros is about replayability.

review:
The optimization going on here is ridiculous... the game runs smooth on high settings on my HTPC that has a $60 video card in it. I read that apparently it utilizes every core in your CPU (tested w/ up to 12 cores in the article). The fact that the game looks so good and runs so serves as a demonstration that if developers actually try to optimize their games, they can acheive very Solid (!) results on minimal hardware.

Highly recommended just to see what can be done when developers give a shit about using resources available to them. Even more highly recommended as an additional installment in the MGS series, although it is really just a teaser for what is to come with The Phantom Pain...

review:
PORT
The port is excellent, can't argue with that.
Controls are suprisingly comftrable with keyboard and mouse. Alltho there is always option to play with controller.
Graphically wise, the game looks amazing. Framerate was steady 60+. You have all options to reduce the graphical settings.
 
Only con I can think of is that there is no mouse controls in the menu.

GAME
The game itself is short, if you want to learn more story in Phantom Pain from this Prologue. You will be disapointed. All the information you get from game, is allready given in trailers.

It takes roughly about an 45min-1 hour to beat the main story on the first try. The additional missions add more gameplay, but they do kinda feel forced. 

If you can't wait to Phantom Pain and want to experiance pure gameplay I would highly suggest getting "demo" game. It's definitly worth £10 in my opinion.

review:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UWNF8_-lKp8

Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is the tenth canonical Metal Gear game and the prologue to the upcoming The Phantom Pain.

In case you don't know it, the game takes place after the events of Peace Walker, and it is set in Omega Camp, an American military base in which are imprisoned Chico and Paz, and Snake has to save them.
 
The game contains a total of 7 missions, including Deja-Vu and Jamais-Vu. If you are a completionist and trial lover, this game has plenty of replay value: the main mission takes around 30 to 60 minutes to complete, while the side missions range from 10 to 40 minutes, with a total of at least 7 hours of gameplay, excluding collectables, different strategies, trials and 16 Steam achievements to unlock.

The game uses the Fox Engine, which revolves around realistic lighting and shadow casting. The gameplay is simply perfect: every gun handles really well, CQC is really fluid, driving vehicles is fun and beating the game without being spotted is incredibly rewarding.

The graphics have been greatly improved and look gorgeous on the highest settings. The game is also very well optimised, and even a small laptop can play it with a solid 60fps on Low.

There are, however, some problems with this port.[strike] First of all, the shell casings don't show up when you shoot, the reload animations of the handguns don't work properly and the infamous right arm glitch when carrying people is still present. This are, however, some small bugs that can easily be fixed in a future patch.[/strike] The worst feature that is absent in this version is the custom music for the helicopter: you can only use the music used in the game, not custom tracks on your computer. Again, I hope that this gets fixed in a future patch.

Overall, this is a technical marvel and the most replayable Metal Gear game. This is quite easily my Game of The Year, and a perfect game.

review:
- bought this game with the intent on playing stealthy
- found an armory and started lobbing grenades everywhere

10/10 great grenade physics

Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is the next installment in Hideo Kojima's long lasting Metal Gear/Metal Gear Solid series.

This entry into the series continues where the previous game, Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, left off. The strange part about this is it picks up after the secret unlockable ending from Peace Walker. However this one plot hole doesn't detract from the entire experience. The game is fluid, fast paced, and runs really smoothly. You don't have to have unlock the secret ending from Peace Walker to enjoy this game's story. The game's cutscenes and loading screens do a great job of explaining of what is going on.

When you first play this game you start off with the first mission Ground Zeroes. This is the prologue mission to Kojima's upcoming game Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Ground Zeroes is best described as a taste of what is to come from the Phantom Pain. After you complete the Ground Zeroes main mission you will unlock five other missions which tell the story leading up to the main Ground Zeroes mission. These extra missions all take place on the same map as the main Ground Zeroes mission. You will be very familiar with the base after playing each one of these missions, however each mission is varied and interesting enough to keep you playing.

Also this game has a deep ranking system and it is fun to challenge yourself to get rank S on each misison, as well as completing the various challenges such as marking all the enemies or completing a mission without using a weapon. Challenges like this keep the replay value high.

This game is a perfect buy on sale otherwise I feel like there isn't enough content to justify the purchase. It is a love letter to Metal Gear Solid fans. This game does take place at a later place in the time line so it isn't the best place to jump in if you are new to the series and are attempting to get into the lore. Other than that great buy and a lot of fun.
