{"recommendationid": "13480527", "author": {"steamid": "76561198006697626", "num_games_owned": 463, "num_reviews": 105, "playtime_forever": 232, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 232, "last_played": 1419113577}, "language": "english", "review": "We'll start off with what's obvious from the get-go: This is a drop dead gorgeous game. It's beautiful. There are some really neat lighting effects and water looks great. Solid textures and some nice depth of field effects as well. It also runs terrifically on my setup. It's probably the single best PC port I've played since Splinter Cell Blacklist. It's a refreshing change in an industry that's given us duds like Assassin's Creed Unity that are hardly playable at high settings even on a strong setup like mine.

That being said, I have a number of complaints about the game. I finished in 4 hours. It's absurdly short, more a demo than anything.

In a lot of ways this franchise hasn't changed much since the second game, which is admittedly fine in some areas. I consider myself a longtime fan of the franchise -- Metal Gear Solid is probably one of my single favorite games of all-time. Fans of the series love the exclamation points, the cardboard boxes, and the weird, preachy stories. I'm no different. I love all that stuff, I eat it up. And it's important that the series doesn't lose its identity for the sake of progress. But there are some features of the series in this game that just plain haven't aged well, and that's where most of my complaints come from.

My biggest issue with the game comes from the foolish way checkpointing is laid out. Imagine you carefully and meticulously move halfway across an open yard of tents, taking care not to be spotted, only to slip up near the end due to hitting the wrong button. Now your last checkpoint forces to restart a football field (about 100 meters for our European friends) away and retrace your own steps. You also get to hear the same introductory codec message every single time, too. Not good.

Checkpointing is a holdover from older games that really does a lot to damage the experience here. There's no reason a semi-open world stealth title shouldn't have a save anywhere feature. Hell, the option to save via a codec message isn't even present in this game, so why even have checkpoints at all? It doesn't make sense to use them over a manual save function. This isn't even a question of save scumming, it's just a matter of modern convenience that Konami seems to have forgotten. I have the same issue with the Far Cry series. It's 2014. There's no excuse for these games to use checkpointing when they'd be far better served by utilizing a dynamic save system. Bad checkpoints are some of the most frustrating things in gaming, and it puzzles me that developers still use them when there are obviously better systems available. Seriously, checkpoints are down there with escort missions. Game developers: Kill them immediately. Please. I despise them in games, especially in stealth games.

review: Overall, this is a pretty good game, but it feels like it's missing alot of content. The current price for the game on the PC is $19.99, which I feel like is ten dollars too much. But I'm glad they didn't release it full retail price, like they did earlier this year. If your a completionist, you can probably get your moneys worth out of this game, with all the side missions and such. But really it's an over priced demo. I'm not against the idea of paying for a little taste of a game, but this is not a good example.

review:
To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: Oh boy, the at one time "$40 demo" has found its way to Steam. Of course, this game isn't any different from the versions that were launched prior to this. This was actually my first time playing it, as I don't own an Xbox One or a PS4, so I was able to get in on it after the rage train had all but subsided. Now, I've had a bit of a history with stealth games, and they've not always been the best. I'm *really* bad at stealth. Like, really bad. I found Metal Gear Solid 1 to be a much more difficult and frustrating gaming experience on Normal than Ninja Gaiden Black was on Hard mode. I've matured about six years since then; I'm still rubbish at the genre, but I can more easily appreciate what's going on here in this game, and if this is the direction that Metal Gear Solid V is taking, I'm all the more excited because of it.

The Metal Gear Solid franchise (at least for 1-3) have always felt like a pseudo-non-linear kind of game. Stage design has been historically fairly linear, at least if my memory from six years ago hasn't failed me. Here in Ground Zeroes, the game is much more open-ended as far as the way to get to the objective goes, and it benefits from it all the more. Stealth, in my eyes, has always been about player creativity, and there's LOADS of room to get creative here, all while keeping the world feeling very organic and natural-feeling. There may be a conveniently placed storm drain for you to crawl through an otherwise very tricky area, but it makes sense for it to be there. Likewise, there may be a lot of concrete dividers all over the place, but it doesn't ever feel like they're put there just so that you can sneak around the area. All in all, the stage design is pretty darn fantastic with this game, and I am absolutely excited to see the huge sprawling world Kojima has planned for Phantom Pain.

Enemy AI seems to be a lot better this time around as well, if a bit slow on the uptake at times. While I can't say this for certain, it does seem like they've eschewed the "cone of vision" AI that has plagued the series for so long. They're pretty decent at tracking you down if they see you as well, but it never gets to the point where it feels unfair. I do kinda wish that when you rescue a certain character that was in a delusional state, the character's delusional ramblings caught the attention of the guards. I think that would've added a hell of a lot more tension to the game experience, but this is somewhat a minor complaint. The gunplay is good, but I hardly ever used it, as when I play a stealth game I try my best to go for zero casualties. 

Of course, the big factor on whether you decide to play this or not comes down to the cost per hour of gameplay. According to completionists, you can get about 6-8 hours out of this game if you go for 100% completion, but if you're just playing it for the main mission, you'll only get about an hour to an hour and a half out of it. Even being as bad at stealth as I am, it only took me 80 minutes. It was a damned good 80 minutes, but it was still 80 minutes. 9/10.

Story: I'm by no means an expert on the overall story of the Metal Gear games, so I'll just approach the game's story from what was presented. It's uh... something, all right. Again, the story does suffer a bit from the fact that the game is only ~80 minutes long, but it does a lot with that 80 minutes. Even though the character intros are brief and details as to these character's lives are vague at best (at least from an outsider's perspective), they do a really good job of fitting the scenarios realistically. Also, the cutscene at the end gets pretty darn grisly; a much unexpected turn from the usually (not always intentionally) silly standard of writing for the series. Kaz's has a silly line which you've no doubt heard by now, but apart from that, everything just worked and it just worked really well. Very enjoyable. 9/10.

Graphics: Metal Gear Rising impressed me with how good of a port it was to the PC, and Ground Zeroes absolutely blows my mind with how good of a port it is. You've got a good bit of graphical fidelity options (no Anti-aliasing options directly though, which I found rather weird), and Fox Engine is damn well optimized for PC. Steam lists the recommended GPU as a GTX 760 (which I've got) and I was able to run everything on Extra High settings at 1080p 60FPS with only a few frame dips here and there. It's stuff you've gotta really be watching for, though, and if you're not of the hawk-eyed variety, you may not even notice it at all. It does punish my GPU a bit though, causing temps to hover at around 65-70degC, but for a game that looks THIS amazing, I can't complain one bit. There are a few off textures here and there which may just have been me running out of VRAM or something, but it's once again stuff you've gotta be actively looking for. Impeccable. Simply impeccable. 5/5.

Sound: A lot of people got mad about Kiefer Sutherland replacing David Hayter as the voice actor in this game, and I've gotta be honest; I think Kiefer does a lot better job. He does a good job at coming across as a warrior who still has some empathy somewhere within his bullet-riddled heart. In fact, the only one who has kind of a not-so-great vocal performance was Kaz, but that may just be because of fiddle-related reasons. The OST is damned good as well. Then again, I suppose the Metal Gear Solid games have always had good OSTs, so this is something of a moot point. Sound design is great as well, with loads of minor details serving to both help you get through the game and enhance the immersion. Excellent stuff. 5/5.

Overall scores are: 9/9/5/5; cumulative score of 9.3/10. If Phantom Pain can keep this level of quality throughout the entire game, it may very well be Game of the Decade. Seriously.

review:
A shining example of how a PC port should be done. Top notch quality that doesn't even feel like a port. 

Amazing graphics, really shows the power of the PC. Plays on 3770k w/ 770 SLI with all settings maxed out at 60+ FPS, very smooth. No crashes, no issues here.

The story is short, but thats to be expected as this is a preview for Phantom Pain. However there are side missions, challenges and Steam achievements that keep replayability high. 

Controls can take a little getting used to if your playing with keyboard/mouse. Also has full gamepad support, but playing with the mouse is alot of fun and makes looking around and aiming alot more fun.

I own the PS4 version, and I much prefer the PC version. 

TL;DR = A Very solid game, Click Buy.

review:
Let me make this quick:

I've played the game extensively on my PS4 and just bought it to test the waters for MGSV on PC and support the MGS franchise and I hope to see more of it on PC.

What's astonishing is that a JAPANESE game developer - which is usually a big warning to any PC gamer expecting a decent performance - manages to SAVE the modern game industry. While the game runs and looks great on consoles, it manages to look EVEN BETTER on PC while still maintaining a CRISP 60 FPS. I know it's sad I'm getting so hyped about a game not running like trash on PC, but oh boy that's the point we currently are at.

I am fully convinced that MGSV is going to be a high contender for GOTYAY and even more so on PC. Kojima is a literal god for continuing to surprise me even after all these years where other former legends have fallen way way deep into the abyss (looking at you, Square)


11/10 would buy just to donate to Based God Kojima, saviour of Video Games

review:
A fantastic port that looks incredible and plays even better. My computer sometimes struggles to newer games on their highest settings, but Ground Zeroes not only looks better than most games, it easily runs over 60 fps and doesn't have a single hiccup.

In terms of the gameplay, this is Metal Gear Solid through-and-through, with updated (and customizable) controls. Classic Kojima cinematic storytelling, complete with dynamic, emergent gameplay.

The only complaint I have is that looking at Snake but hearing Keifer Sutherland talk is really disorienting. David Hayter should always be Snake; whether he's Naked, or Solid.

Was afraid of my PC running it.  Runs at 60 fps on lowest settings with my cheap 2010 GPU (GT 430). Definitely better than the console ports, however this game has VERY weird controlls. You will find yourself changing them within the first 10 minutes of gameplay.

The game is pretty short but It is worth the full price and It is way more than worth it at sale price.

review: My faith in Konami got even higher after this game. When I play MGRising, i was amazed of how great a PC port could be. I've been seen lazy ports coming to PC very often and i was beginning to lose faith, now i have Konami once again to thank. About the game, it is indeed very, very short. Campaign doesn't last, everyone knows this, my problem with this matter was the unfair cost in console version, but once again Steam brought justice. If you end the game in 1 hour or less, know that you'll take quite a time to play side missions, they are challenging and much fun.

review:
[h1]Great appetizer! - 8/10[/h1]

[b]Introduction:[/b]
All MGS and stealth action lovers are patiently waiting for 'The Phantom Pain' and now all PC gamer can finally get their hands on the prologue too to dawdle away. It was about time! As stated - it's only a short prologue, but it's well produced and will give you a brief look, what you can expect from the upcoming full price title. I won't start to talk about the story or objective this time, because it's only one area and one story mission and you wouldn't discover anything on your own anymore. Please check the pro and contra list and the conclusion to make sure, if it could be worth your money or not.


[b]Pro:[/b]
[list][*]it's a Metal Gear Solid!
[*]interesting story
[*]very good stealth action
[*]great port (enjoyable mouse+keyboard or controller navigation, no stupid 30 FPS lock, adjustable graphic settings)
[*]very well optimized performance
[*]great graphics
[*]great cinematics
[*]great voice actors
[*]great soundtrack
[*]ridable vehicles
[*]some replay value thanks to different side missions and collectable stuff
[*]no crashes (for me)[/list]


[b]Contra:[/b]
[list][*]very short story mission (only 50-90 minutes depending on playstyle)
[*]price tag (19,99 Euro) is too high for the delivered content  [the 13,39 Euro sale price tag is much more appropriate]
[*]some knocked out or sleeping enemies can be displayed as standing for a moment from time to time, when you're reentering a certain area and then they will fall back to the ground
[*]some knocked out or sleeping enemies can magically disappear and reappear (only happened once for me)
[*]you can't drag people while crawling
[*]ugly subtitle font[/list]


[b]Conclusion:[/b]
'Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes' is nothing more than a short appetizer for the upcoming 'The Phantom Pain', but it's a very good one for every MGS fan. It will satisfy your desire for the moment and make you hungry for more at the same time...I'm still not sure, if that's a good or a bad thing. This prologue is a must-have for every fan, but it's absolutely nothing for people, who haven't played a MGS before and/or have no clue about what the heck 'The Phantom Pain' is due to the minor content. And don't be afraid of (another) awful port, it's really well done and optimized.


[b]8/10[/b]   [i]...Snake? Snaaaaaaaaake![/i]

----------------------
[i]~ Do you want to add something to the review or do you want to share your opinion? Feel free to make a comment.[/i]

review:
idling on a ladder and accidentally killed a guard when he's going down, knocking enemy out with magazine, spear headbutting enemies. What could be better? lol. 
Amazing port of a beautiful prelude to the Phantom Pain. Also, full of easter eggs and fun stuffs to do. Always be a fan of MGS series.

10/10

I love the metal gear series and have always wished they would at least make PC versions to re-enjoy the magic. This on the otherhand is not just compatable with PCs, its exquisitly made for PC. However, I do feel that charging for a game with one level that takes roughly one hour to complete is a bit of a piss-take. 
Think of buying this Prequel as an investment in Konami completing and releasing The Phantom Pain, and you could justify the price for an hour of gameplay.

review:
Cool short little MGS game (WARNING: don't expect a full game).  I'm s big MGS fan and I've been waiting for Konami to release another game to the series.  So if you're a MGS fan I'd highly recommend this to you.  But this could still be fun for you even if you're new to the franchise and you like stealth/action games.  

Pros: You get to revisit the MGS franchise on PC, the game has great optimization (even some low end cards can max it out), great gameplay letting you choose different playstyles as in almost every stealth action game, gives you a bit of a challenge even on normal difficulty (if you're into that), the graphics are decent but not as good as some of the other games out there today (which I'm perfectly fine with if it runs well).

Cons: Story lasts one mission then basically tells you to go buy the Phantom Pain when it comes out (although there are some additional side missions you can play), game locks at 60 fps which I don't see as that bad of a problem since most people will be playing on 60hz monitors anyways.

But overall I'd rate this game 9/10 and I'd say it's well worth that $20.

review:
The Metal Gear franchise has been around for a long time. If you grew up playing Metal Gear Solid on the PS1 like myself then you will feel right at home here. I have to admit my review may be bias because I consider the first MGS to be my favorite game of all time. I played it during my teenage years and it made me fall in-love with video game story telling. 

With all that being said this is not a "FULL" game. This is a glorified tech-demo/prologue to the up-coming MGSV:Phantom Pain. This by all means isn't something that will keep you busy for 30+ hours. Not saying it won't keep you for awhile if you're into 100% completions like I am with this series. 

There is plenty to do if you're a die-hard MGS fan. So I'm only going suggest this game to fans of the series. If however you have an extra 13-20 dollars laying around and like the idea of a free-roam (in a smaller space) stealth/action with a decent starting point for a story then by all means BUY IT. Also if you plan on buying Phantom Pain, you will need to play this game to get the full scope of whats going on. 

Story: 9/10 (so far so good on Hideos part and looking good on the set-up to phantom pain, which will most likely being another amazing emotional ride)

Graphics/Visuals: 10/10 (some of the best looking lighting you will see in a game, aslong as you have a nice GPU/CPU combo you will be in for a visual treat un-matched by 99% of gaming has to offer.)

Gameplay: 9/10 (very rarely there are camera problems where it seems like the camera is too close and hindering your view, works great on a xbox 360 controller aswell as mouse/keyboard)

PC Optimization: 9/10 (lots of options and customization to get the most out of your hardware. Would like to see a better option for depth of field which I've found out turning it to "Low" stops the blur effects and makes the game look better. I don't know why turning an option down makes the game look better, but it does)

Overall: 9.5/10 Amazing game with very few to no flaws. Short maybe 10-20 hours of gameplay, longer only if you want to complete everything. Reports state that Phantom Pain will have over 200 hours of gameplay. So its fine with me if this one is short if PP is going to be insanly long and complex.

TL:DR: Buy this game if you are a MGS Fan boy or Want a short but sweet stealth/action thriller with a great story set-up to Phantom Pain. 

PS: Game Devs... stop using Depth of Field and Motion Blur it's a cheap tactic to make plebs think something looks great but really doesn't. I know this feature was probably added for low-tier hardware (consoles) to make it look good even on low settings. People with High-Tier hardware should have an option to turn it completly off without losing out on other features like reflections.

PC Optimization: 9/10 (lots of options and customization to get the most out of your hardware. Would like to see a better option for depth of field which I've found out turning it to "Low" stops the blur effects and makes the game look better. I don't know why turning an option down makes the game look better, but it does)

Overall: 9.5/10 Amazing game with very few to no flaws. Short maybe 10-20 hours of gameplay, longer only if you want to complete everything. Reports state that Phantom Pain will have over 200 hours of gameplay. So its fine with me if this one is short if PP is going to be insanly long and complex.

TL:DR: Buy this game if you are a MGS Fan boy or Want a short but sweet stealth/action thriller with a great story set-up to Phantom Pain. 

PS: Game Devs... stop using Depth of Field and Motion Blur it's a cheap tactic to make plebs think something looks great but really doesn't. I know this feature was probably added for low-tier hardware (consoles) to make it look good even on low settings. People with High-Tier hardware should have an option to turn it completly off without losing out on other features like reflections.", "timestamp_created": 1419098915, "timestamp_updated": 1419099132, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
This game looks gorgeous, runs amazing and plays great. I have absolutely nothing bad to say about this game. As a long time Metal Gear Solid fan I'm incredibly happy to finally have another game in the series on PC, especially this most recent entry in the series which introduces a level of detail and gameplay that has never before been in the series. Just in the first hour I attempted several ways of infiltrating the enemy compound and found each experience unique in and of itself, before finally settling in and making my way in as stealthily and deadly as possible. Which is so far proving just as an enjoyable as the other methods. I can't wait to get to the alternate mission objectives and camp layout types to explore the depth of this short taste of whats to come in The Phantom Pain. 

I 100% unequivocally recommend anyone that is a fan of the Metal Gear Solid series, or a fan of fun stealth/action games with a nice sense of humor to give this game a try. It's well worth the sale price and even at $19.99 it's still a worthwhile purchase. Not only will you get a stunning looking game, but a incredibly well directed and voice acted piece of gameplay dense with systems to toy with that runs spectacularly upon install. Which is sadly a rarity these days. I can't wait to put some more hours into this and anxiously await the release of The Phantom Pain next year.

review: This is a fine example of how a port should be. It is well optimized and so far, I've not encountered any bugs. I was amazed how well it runs on my i7-3610M and GTX660m laptop, getting 35 - 39 fps with most settings on high. Gameplay wise the game is rock solid though I'm not a fan of auto cover. Overall this is a magnificent PC port and Kojima never dissapoints! All aboard the hype train for Phantom Pain!

review:
Don't believe the system requirements, the game is very well optimized, and maxed out, it looks gorgeous.
Gameplay wise, it's the best in the series. If you dislike the timeslow gimmick when you got spotted, you can just turn it off in options. While the main scenario can be completed in 10 minutes, GZ offers amazing replayability with it's sandbox approach to Metal Gear gameplay, as well as several unlockable missions.
Definitely worth it at this pricetag.

review:
Honest review from life long Metal Gear fan.

  It's Japanese so it's weird, and it's by Hideo Kojima a weird Japanese guy so it's even weirder. All in all, Quite a feat of achievement, the game engine is super stable. It shows off some extremely life like features. It flows really well, moves really well, light acts like light, it's high texture high quality. It looks great and feels really responsive and seems very well thought out. The objective are simple and clear. And Kiefer Sutherland sticks out like a cock for a thumb. Ruined the whole fucking thing. Hayter being replaced is not the issue, Sutherland is. Unfortuantely It's one of the most immsersion breaking expereinces I've ever had in a game. I'm not me when I'm running around a Cuban military base, I'm Snake, I'm the last 20 years of game history badassdom. Now I'm just Kiefer Sutherland playing a pretty game that looks and feels scarily like MGS.

review: Great game buuuut... 19.99 (or around 13 on sale) is just too much for how little content there is. Had to revise my review, it isn't one repeatable mission, but its multiple missions lazily sharing the same map which makes it feel like you are just doing one long mission. I enjoyed myself, but I wouldn't willingly pay more than $10 for it and most of that is just based on the quality (obviously stemming from phantom pain). I'm satisfied with my purchase, but only because it was on sale for $13.

review: A great prologue for an even greater game. Mechanics are flawless, stunning visuals, well optimized, amazing story, what else can I say? It's a Metal Gear Solid game but in a lot smaller package - a tiny slice, 1/300 of what the Phantom Pain is gonna be. And if the length still concerns, there's also that replayability. Do all sneaky and carefully or go rampage and do everything fast the next time, every time's different, but the question is how well and how fast you can manage? In addition to the main mission there's several side missions, which are at least as fun to complete if not funnier. This game has more to it than you can imagine, and its worth every penny as long as it's under 20 euros.  -9/10. Astonishing.

review: Runs smoother than butter drippin' off a hot biscuit.  Some people call it a glorified demo.  I call it a glorious demo.  Get it cheap and you won't be disappointed.  Even modest rigs can manage a high frame rate (if you're having trouble getting there, turn SSAO and Screen Filtering off, and turn lighting down to high -- the visual quality barely changes but you get a huge frame rate boost).  Looks beautiful, plays great, and the environment is a lot bigger and more intricate than it seems at first glance.  If you don't go in expecting a full Metal Gear game, you won't have much to complain about.

review:
I first played Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes the day it launched on PS3. Leading into it's release I replayed the franchise, PeaceWalker included. I was shocked to fire up the PS3 and try Ground Zeroes out, it looked like trash.....

I found Ground Zeroes on the PS3 suffered from the same problem GTAV did, low framerate! After playing the silky smooth MGS4 I expected FoxEngine to be a step forward. Instead what I got was a chuggy, blurry, and jaggy mess. Once I beat the main mission I took the disk out and never wanted to try it again.

Fast forward to the PC re-release and I was getting nervous. My computer is a few years old now, a Phenom II x4 965be and a GTX570. I was worried I would be getting a similar experience with low framerates, jaggy  models, blurry textures. Even if it didn't run I was still going to be buying it to show support for Godjima, and all Japanese developers for that matter, to encourage future PC releases.

Well hot damn, does it run amazing. I'm running on High settings at 1920x1080 and the game went from being the uglyest MGS I've played to the most georgus. It runs silky smooth, the animations are great, the textures are detailed.... It's just damn beautiful.

As for the content I've put in 13 hours so far and am only at 18% unlocked, and that was from the main mission and two side missions on normal difficulty and B rank. If you were to JUST play the main mission the game can be short, like an hour the first time short, but you would be missing out. The side missions have enough variety in weather, spawns, items, costumes, and objecteves to keep things fresh and exciting well after the main course. I have many more hours to go as I finish each unique mission, S ranking them all, then doing it all over again on Hard.

Considering it's reputation as "a demo with little content" this would be one of the best PC games I've ever bought. It's so well programmed, it makes me happy I can run it at such high settings without it heating up or maxing out my PC. If you're like me and grew up with a PS1 and a PS2, support one of the best franchises in video game history. I am so excited now knowing I'll also be able to run silky smooth versions of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain AND Metal Gear Online 3.

Keyboard controls take some getting used to and there's no change to the on-screen icons so memorise that list otherwise, you might need to wait for controller support to be fixed cause that doesn't work. 

Other then those two complaints. I got nothing else bad to say about this...other than it being short but it's better than most indies selling for this games price [avatar related]

review: I use to be a fan of this game, cool cinematics, stealth missions whats not to like. But they turned this game into splinter cell, the iconic voice of snake gone, the radar is useless you have to play a guessing game as to where the enemy is and once you spot them no field of vision, you can no longer walk that fine line like a ninja just out of the enemey line of sight cos you just dont know where it is, whatever happened to knocking that use to be fun get a spot knock knock  ! Boom satisfaction. Its frustrating playing this game stealthy theres alot of missing info you just dont know where the enemy is or if he will see you peeking out that corner and somehow they can see you behind closed door you just picked nice, it should be easier to be stealthy and harder to just run round and kill everyone. its till a good game tho for the price.

review:
Having already played and beaten the game many times on PS4, I knew what I was getting when I bought this game on Steam.  While short if taken at face value, there's TONS of stuff here to keep you busy for hours and hours.  Tapes, Badges, missions and lots of other hidden secrets including the 2 console DLC missions.  Just learning to play the game and find different ways and methods of infiltrating Camp Omega provides lots of fun and entertainment.  If you are the type of gamer that likes to replay missions and try to beat your previous records, then this game will suit your interests well.

As the prelude to MGSV:The Phantom Pain, it serves as an introductory course into the games mechanics and storyline.  With backstory and context provided in a Graphic Novel style, you are able to learn of the events that lead up to the story of Ground Zeroes.  However, that is no substitute for actaully playing those games.  If you have the means, you should play MGS3:Subsistence(Snake Eater), MGS:Portable Ops, and MGS:Peace Walker...in that order.   Metal Gear is one of the best series in gaming, and Ground Zeroes/The Phantom Pain looks to continue the series high pedigree.

There's nothing more to say but buy this game RIGHT NOW!  Launching with a 33% discount makes this an even better proposition than it already is.  Infiltrate Camp Omega with Big Boss and discover the events that lead up to The Phantom Pain!

review:
What is going on here?. MGS V GZ can kick COD Advanced Warefare and BattleField series (please do not misunderstand me, I am a real COD and BF fan for years). 

Is MGS V using less system resources, and providing a great gaming experience for very less?. If so, what are the other gaming manufacturers selling us?? ...Just wondering, and confirming an old hunch I got.

Backing to MGS V GZ this is a great experience!!. Great graphics, great voices casting (Keifer Sutherland included), nice score by Enio Morricone, and all this on less than 3Gb including movie scenes??. I am in SHOCK here!.

I only want to say thanks to Kojima Productions and Konami for this real stunning high performance at very low cost consideration example for this gamer. 

I DO REALLY APPRECIATE AND RECOGNIZE YOUR JOB.

Thanks again guys.

review:
Runs brilliantly at 1080p on an older 3770k-OC (4.2Ghz)/ 660ti-OC SLI based rig, Full 60FPS with a rare judder on some transitions in cutscenes / to gameplay. Only noticed bad pop-in once, though any enemies over a certain distance won't be drawn until you zoom in on them. All settings maxed except for Shadows on High, which didn't actually seem to be the problem in the end, but I couldn't be bothered to change them back.

Graphical options could be a little better, too many things are bundled under special effects and the like, so you can't disable just DoF or anything like that, but everything else from resolution to shadows and lighting is controllable. 

Importantly the 30FPS limit is by default disabled, though it might be worth enabling on weaker machines, since gameplay is slow enough that looking better may be worth the sacrifice of responsiveness / smoothness.

Looks great, controls are good except for no mouse control in the menus (Otherwise all keys seem to be rebindable). Gameplay feels good though I've not really played the older games. If I have a complaint it's that enemies can respawn too easily, if you clear a route then return to take something with you, the further enemis are likely to have respawned.

Haven't done the extra side-missions, but the main mission is enjoyable, though short. Finishing it left me with a percentage of 7%, so theres definitely some time-killing stuff to do as well as the optional extra missions.

For £11.38, It's worth it for sure. Would not have been happy to have paid £40+ on the consoles, but I'm looking forward to the main game after playing this.

Heres hoping we get the older games collection refitted for modern PCs / the games we're missing.

9.5/10 Great port, pretty good game, left wanting more.

review:
Poured 10 hours to it (as of posting) and there is so much to do. It wasn't a short game at all. Whoever said that played us like a damn fiddle.

This is a game of skill like in a sense playing old school games, let's say, Pacman. Improving your scores, rank, time, and how efficiently you play is part of it.  Repeating the same thing in this game would not feel like a chore especially if you have played Peacewalker before.

And also, it doesn't feel like a port too. It's like the game was intended for the PC all along. Heck, I even prefer using my kb+mouse over my controller.

I was really surprised how badly this game was running with all the reviews saying how well optimised it was. I had to turn down everything and finally got it to run at a pretty good framerate.

Then I realised it was running on Intel Graphics.

review:
First of all, yes, it's not a particularly long game. Ground Zeroes consists of one main story mission, four missions that tie into the story, and two non-canon missions, all on the same map but set at different times of day with different atmospheric conditions and weather. You could probably experience every mission in around five to six hours, but the beauty of Ground Zeroes is in the replay value.

A total revamp of the controls and systems of Metal Gear Solid, Ground Zeroes takes a common sense approach to stealth and infiltration. Most stealth games have very arbitrary rules that are sometimes quite obtuse and don't always seem to be based in reality, but rather game logic. In Ground Zeroes, if you hide somewhere you would likely hide in real life, you will remain hidden. Guards no longer have cones of vision that spot you as soon as you're on the fringes of them, allowing you to either be spotted from a distance, or hide in the corners of their peripheral vision, depending entirely on your coverage, if you're in shadow, or what kind of movements you're making.

The controls are fluid, and the animations are smooth and quick. It plays like an absolute dream. Despite being a cross-gen title, Ground Zeroes still looks impressive and has a very clean look and natural balance of colours that few other games have. Despite some problems with those using AMD cards (driver related), Ground Zeroes is a great port that runs on a wide variety of systems, and eliminates the problem of poor level of detail managing at a distance the console versions had.

It's not a perfect port (the anti-aliasing leaves something to be desired, and the DOF effect doesn't seem correctly implemented in gameplay), or a perfect game (it's not particularly long if you're only wanting the main story), but I would say it is worth trying out. You might just end up liking it, and finding yourself getting many more hours out of replaying the game than you thought you would. Personally, I spent many hours on the PS3 version and at the time of writing I'm heading towards 15 hours on the PC version just through replaying either for fun, to discover secrets, or to improve my best times and get S-ranks.

review:
Beaten the main campaign in 43 min. and 05 sec. and did the following:

- No reflex mode
- Extracted all the prisoners
- No combat alerts
- No kills
- 4 retries

Got a S rank

Saw the epilogue. My Big Boss went Rising and now it's Solid.

10/10: Would replay again!

Port-wise it's really... Erm.. Solid. 
Tons of graphical options like:

- Custom resolution (Supports 4K)
- Shadows
- Lighting
- SSAO
- etc.

The only downside is that the DOF is combined with AA.
It plays well with a controller and M+K (M+K controls are rebindable!)
Overall, The new FOX engine looks beautiful and runs great on PC!

After you've beaten the main campaign you unlock additional side-ops.
There are also tapes and XOF-patches to find and collect (for those hardcore completionists out there).

PS.

Thank you based Kojima-san!
You played us like a damn fiddle~

review:
I would describe this as a short but sweet experience you can easily beat this on two hours but there are also many different side missions you can do.

The pc port of Ground Zeroes is excellent it runs just great  and if this port is any indication on what the phantom pain will be on pc when it releases then we are in for a treat :)

Did some comparing with the ps4 version and the lighting and textures look so much better they have really put a lot of effort in to this.

My only gripe is that it is a little pricey for a two hour experience but a hell of alot cheaper than it was when it first released on console.

Yes...Yes..This is a prologue to a main game, and you gonna get bonuses and special stuff to mother base in The Phantom Pain,because of having Ground Zeroes ? Ok..B-but it's not enough to buy-..The game has amazing replayability and you gonna play it again and again ? Someone don't know it yet ?Bad for them..Yes...Yes. Goodbye,[spoiler] Mr.Kojima	 [/spoiler]

review:
[h1]After years of deception, Metal Gear Solid series finally uncloaks before us PC Gamers. But how does the game perform?[/h1]

MGS: GZ is designed to be more of a prequel to the true next installment of the series: Phantom Pain (don't worry, that game is also coming to PC). This particular game was made just to quench our thirsts and make the waiting a bit easier. More importantly, because of the dramatic shift the game takes the series by introducing open world and very open-ended gameplay, it was a way for fans of the past installments to familiarize with the new structure of the game.  

Now I've seen many people claim this to be a glorified paid demo---I completely disagree however. The game offers a lot of side content, replayability with different approach to justify your purchase. 

If you decide to just breeze through the main mission without bothering anything else, it would take only about 2 hours to finish it. However, if you plan to investigate the entire camp, find intel, rescue POWs, gather collectibles and do some of the side missions, then it will take you around 10 hours at least. This sort of venturing out of your way and exploring is definitely new to the series, which fundamentally breaks the linear level design and objectives of the previous games and works remarkably well. The open world provides more tactical approaches in handling the missions:  provides more ways of infiltrating mission area and approaching objectives. However at the same time the open ended nature can work against you as enemies are more spread out, are generally a lot smarter and if they see you then you are in for a tough firefight --- In previous games, this often led to many players restarting to the last checkpoint as more than often once you were spotted, it was impossible to go hidden again and you would eventually die. This time, you have the flexibility to not engage in the firefight for long and quickly become a ghost again. Another important thing to note is that the enemy AI is very dynamic--- They don’t follow specific patrol patterns for long and if you ‘disrupt’ their patrol, they will react in unpredictable ways. So, less memorization and more reaction is the gameplay paradigm that is enforced into the design and I for one gladly welcome this change.

So how is the PC port? One word ---Solid (no pun intended). The game runs beautifully across a wide range of systems and looks pretty good as well. While there are odd low resolution textures and detail here and there, but I guess that is what happens when you make a cross console-generation game (also available on the PS3 and Xbox 360) but it hardly detracts from the overall visual experience. My only issue with the game’s graphics is the obsessive use of blur. At times I feel like the game uses blur in the wrong situations and not in the right amount. For example when you point the gun in first person, it for some reason blurs the crosshair. The game also have some problems finding the right intensity of the blur for the relative distance to the background. Also, the FXAA used is poorly implemented and it just looks like it blurs out a lot of textures in hopes of reducing jaggies. For consoles I understand as FXAA is cost efficient in GPU power, but for PC, please give us an option to turn it off and use some other form of AA that does not blur the image. Even if some other AA was not an option, I would gladly turn off the AA here and instead using DSR (down sampling) to render the game at a higher resolution and downsize it, which works better than any AA out there anyways. 

The controls of the previous games in the series always felt like one of the weakest areas, simply put--- they weren’t designed to be effective when you needed urgency in your movements and combat. Thankfully, the controls of this game is very well designed. While many would understandably want to play this game using a controller, I decided to try it with the mouse and keyboard as it was a PC Gamer thing to do! After playing for a few minutes, I changed some of the controls to better suit my needs: Making the most of the extra buttons on my Logitech G502 mouse, I mapped many of the controls to my mouse as I feel I am much faster using the mouse buttons than many of the keyboard buttons. Again, this is down to the preference of the player which will vary from person to person. It was a bit odd to find out that the extra mouse buttons other than the right and left click not bindable. Another thing to note, the game does not alternative buttons for each command. Also oddly enough, the menu navigation cannot be done with the mouse, instead the keyboard WASD is used and 1 and 3 to change the menu options which I find it weird. These rough edges shows Konami’s inexperience with PC game design but they can be easily solved in a future update. 

So that pretty much covers it. This is a small, yet delicious, slice of game that I have been waiting anxiously for. Like every delicious slice, it just makes you want more!

review:
ground zeroes is a very fun prologue to the phantom pain and i highly recommend getting this in the definitive collection bundle (its just not really worth it on its own unless you get it on a sale)

the gameplay is super enjoyable and is a very good teaser of whats to come in the main game
if you are a big fan of the big boss metal gear solid games I think its well worth a purchase if you want to know what happens next.

review:
A great sample of what we can expect from the full MGS V release! The port is excellent, with the game translating really well to PC. Highly recommended for all true MGS fans, especially those who had been eagerly anticipating the day the franchise makes a return to the PC platform! The mission where a certain Mr Kojima makes a cameo appearance is worth the price of admission alone!

If this is the entree, I simply can't wait for the main course! :)

review:
If you're anything like me, you probably looked at the minimum requirements and said "Oh god, my PC'll never be able to run this", I bought the Demo anyway and installed it, booted up into the game and to my surprise I found that I can run it at relatively high settings at 1600 x 1200 with over 30/40 FPS, But if you're like me and you play with a 360 Controller, the controls will mess themselves up and you'll just end up staring at the sky, though I can't really complain because the game plays quite well with a keyboard and mouse.

I loved every second of this game, I've got 5 Hours out of it so far, and I'm looking forward to The Phantom Pain, but I wish the game was longer, well worth the £11.38 I paid for it though.

Overall I'd give the game and gameplay itself a 10/10. this is an amazing port and plays amazingly well.
Value for money? I guess I'd give value for money about an 8/10, including all of the Side-Ops and Extra Ops. (You get both Deja Vu and Jamais Vu)

review:
It's Metal Gear! On PC! And in fine form, too.  There are a few technical issues (inability to bind mouse4 & mouse5 and sensitivity that does not adjust while zoomed, to name my two biggest ones), but overall the quality of the port is nearly peerless -- it runs great, looks great, and plays great.

If you hate waiting for the full version of The Phantom Pain next year and want a bite-sized taste now, you can't go wrong with Ground Zeroes.

review:
Ya know, after beating The Phantom Pain and being left pretty disappointed for the most part; I look back at GZ and think how this really felt like a true to heart MGS title.

In comparison to TPP it has the great Harry Gregson-Williams score, great pacing, focused and meticulous level design which TPP really lacked. Personally I think this game benefits being so minimalistic compared to TPP's open sandbox design.

Even my knowlege of MGS3 and Peace Walker actually mattering, giving some weight to the context of the story unlike TPP. Regardless, GZ is great. Short but sweet. However I suppose its subjective since I somehow managed 100 hours on this. Guess it was the hype for TPP ironically.

Graphics are beautiful and story is tense, altough from time to time character movements are a bit strange. 
Overall very good game.

review:
The best demo since the MGS1 PSX demo
Would pay for one level again
11/10

review:
Kojima, you magnificent bastard!

Lets say that this is probably the best game to be ported from a console release to the pc plattform. I can run this game at max, extra high graphic settings, smooth 60 FPS and sweet mother of GabeN this is the best port ever! I can only run Assassin's Creed Unity on medium to high graphics and that made me afraid to not being able to play Ground Zeroes or upcoming Phantom Pain. But someone at Konami must have said: "JUSTICE FOR ALL!" and then continued to crank up the quality.

I love your work Kojima-san and all of the awesome people at Konami and I can't wait to sneak away in The Phantom Pain.

The bad:

The textures are awful and low res (in game textures, cinematics look much better but not as good as they should be, also what the fuck is up with the obnoxious blur? I'm playing a fucking game not watching a fucking movie!) even on high and very high settings. Keyboard and Mouse controls are just utter shit, no mouse menu control, unresponsive and slugish controls. not enough options to turn off graphical settings, no raw mouse input, no FOV slider (even if it wasn't large I still feel in first and third person like I'm zoomed in). This was NOT worth the money, even on sale for 33% off. For a "game demo" being so short I don't know why they even put a price tag on this, fucking waste of 14$.

Now on to the good:

Game runs quite well... that's all...

review:
This game make something very impressive for me. Because at first. I think this game will be the same as many console games that port down to PC.

But what I think is wrong. The quality for game's model. the shader of model. Lighting, and the Detail around the map scene. It's quite almost the same as PS4. I can running on 60FPS without dropping. mostly detail in the game are rendered very well. Maybe a little bit glitch on the Level of Detail stuff. But that doesn't seems to be a big problem and not really taking you into trouble.

The controller for PC is quite good. Some is weird for me but it doesn't bother me much. Somehow you'll adjust as what you want instead. and the game mechanic quite good. maybe it's hard for many people to play. But I'd say this one is making you want to practice more and more.

9.5/10 that what I'd give to this game.

review:
Never thought I would play MGS game on PC in recent years, until I saw this and the Phantom Pain. Though this is a very short game, it has high replayability.
Best of all, I never thought the game would play so smoothly on PC. It's a great example of how to port a console game to PC, even though all games are made on PC initially anyway! 
The gaming experience is further enhaced thanks to full controller support and fluid, simple and intuitive keyboard and mouse support. Anyone who has never played this on console would think it is actually a PC game, ported to console.

Stay tuned for MGS Phantom Pain, and until that time, keep yourself busy playing this amazing short mission. Worth every penny.

//Besides, it's good to see Snake on PC/Steam.
Hope to see more future MGS games and old ones to be here as well.

This game is amazing. I'm somewhat of a noob to the series, having only experienced MGS 1-4 via Chip & Ironicus' excellent and informative [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eGUaz7CmOI0&list=PLrekaHLD2rhbekQxP_Pt1O_KVTcSgVVMU&index=1]Let's Play[/url] series of them, so I'm familiar with the gameplay and story, just never played them myself. 

Ground Zeroes is a playground. It gives you a bunch of tools and abilities and plops you down in a giant sandbox where you can use those things to your heart's content. This may only be a single prologue map, but the gameplay is deep enough that that's okay. You'll find yourself playing it over and over, doing things in different ways, trying out new things, or just goofing around. There are also alternate missions that change up the objectives as well as weather and time of day, creating a dramatically different looking and feeling game. 

On the technical side of things, the port is mostly excellent, especially considering it's a Japanese developer, some of whom are still learning how to make a proper PC port (See: Dark Souls 1, Deadly Premonition, Final Fantasy XIII at launch, etc.). But MGS5 has graphics options out the wazoo, arbitrary resolutions, and is incredibly well optimized. On my i7 4770k and HD 7950, I get a constant 60 FPS at 1080p with everything on Extra High except for Shadows and SSAO down a notch to just "High". It looks fantastic. The one mark against it is the 60 FPS cap - for someone as obsessed with framerate as Kojima, I would expect him to not artificially limit the framerate. 120 and 144 Hz monitors are becoming increasingly common. It's smooth enough at 60, but worth mentioning.

Some people malign this game as "just paying for a demo of Phantom Pain", but then this is the most feature-packed, most replayable, most awesome demo ever made, and (as you can see from my play time) I've gotten many hours of entertainment from it. Don't let the price throw you off - it's totally worth it.

review:
MGSV: Ground Zero is an exceedingly small chapter of a much larger picture. A painting so encompassing that parts of it dates back to the 60s. This series, is no less than an artistic masterpiece. This portion of the painting, enthralls no less in magnitude...The problem is that sensation, that a masterful piece of art provokes from you, is short lived. Although there is much to rethink about. New and different ways to see, even if it is small, the beautiful part of this large picture.

Do yourself a favor. Buy this game, because the creators for it deserve the money irrespective of anything else. Then go and purchase the entire series. Play it in chronological order and then prepare to be engrossed and enthralled like never before. 

Take your time when you extrapolate from this game, I say that because when the following game comes out. It is essentially taking place in our current time. In a presumably parallel universe...

Is this prologue worth $30? I don't think so. Paying less than $10 would be fair considering the amount of content it brings. Most people will say the campaing is short, and it is, but the game offers more content after the main mission is completed. Easily you can get around 6 hours of total gameplay, a little more if you are not that good in these kind of games that require patience. 

Leaving that behind, the game looks outstanding on budget based computers, I enjoyed it with 8 GB of RAM, ATI Radeon 5870 and a Core 2 Quad Q8400 at a stable framerate, the cutscenes are all real time like I would expect from a Kojima directed metal gear game, no pre-rendered crap like MG: Rising. The gameplay is fluid and intuitive, the music is outstanding and the enemy AI is pretty descent.

The story continues right after the events of Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, if you are new to the series, everything won't make much sense, there are some tapes and texts in the game that try to explain the events in the past games since MGS3: Snake Eater, but I would recommend playing or atleast watching a few videos about the story of Big Boss and his crew. 

I still don't understand why this was not included in the main game, just like in Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty, where you play the first part (prologue) with Snake and then you play the real game with Raiden. But still, it's a nice addition to the PC library of games, and a must have if you are a Metal Gear fan like myself.

Enjoy!

review:
As a huge MGS fan it's obvious I like this game. But what about those who never even touched an MGS game?

First off, this main game is short. Your first run on the main mission should take anywhere between 90 minutes or 3 hours at most. If you play just the main story and that's it, you'll be dissapointed. But if you like to complete side missions and have OCD, I feel you'll get your moneys worth with collecting all those XOF patches/cassette tapes, getting higher ranks, and finding new ways to complete missions.

As the for the gameplay, it's MGS at it's finest. Switching from crouching to crawling has never felt smoother, and it's actually hard to go back to something like MGS4 after playing this. And gunplay is great, especially with the new bullet drop effects, which makes you rethink about sniping someone across the map. My only complaint would have to be the cover mechanics. They're... quite awful to be honest. Hope they fix this in The Phantom Pain. Also no cardboard box. WTF?

The AI is pretty good as well. If you stand in broad daylight, it's obvious they'll see you 20 meters away, even on normal. And if you think reflex mode makes this game too easy, you're very mistaken. Especially when you get spotted by 3 guards and all you just shot a single shot tranq. Also, don't rely on regen health. Take too much damage, and you'll have to manually heal yourself with the marijuana health spray from Resident Evil. Realistic? No. But neither is eating rations that magically heal you after a point blank rocket launcher blast.

tl;dr version:

Pros are great replayability, lots of stuff to collect, gameplay, graphics, Hideo Kojima, and marijuana health spray.

Cons are short main mission, cover mechanics, no cardboard box, and too much water.

Overall I'd recommend this those who like to do everything in the game, have OCD, and want a great stealth experience.

Don't recommend if all you're here for is the main story. You'll feel ripped off. And hate water.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm off to attemp an S rank on the main mission. But killing the guards is so tempting after collecting all the tapes...

As the for the gameplay, it's MGS at it's finest. Switching from crouching to crawling has never felt smoother, and it's actually hard to go back to something like MGS4 after playing this. And gunplay is great, especially with the new bullet drop effects, which makes you rethink about sniping someone across the map. My only complaint would have to be the cover mechanics. They're... quite awful to be honest. Hope they fix this in The Phantom Pain. Also no cardboard box. WTF?

The AI is pretty good as well. If you stand in broad daylight, it's obvious they'll see you 20 meters away, even on normal. And if you think reflex mode makes this game too easy, you're very mistaken. Especially when you get spotted by 3 guards and all you just shot a single shot tranq. Also, don't rely on regen health. Take too much damage, and you'll have to manually heal yourself with the marijuana health spray from Resident Evil. Realistic? No. But neither is eating rations that magically heal you after a point blank rocket launcher blast.

tl;dr version:

Pros are great replayability, lots of stuff to collect, gameplay, graphics, Hideo Kojima, and marijuana health spray.

Cons are short main mission, cover mechanics, no cardboard box, and too much water.

Overall I'd recommend this those who like to do everything in the game, have OCD, and want a great stealth experience.

Don't recommend if all you're here for is the main story. You'll feel ripped off. And hate water.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm off to attemp an S rank on the main mission. But killing the guards is so tempting after collecting all the tapes...", "timestamp_created": 1419063981, "timestamp_updated": 1419063981, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 30, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.723841369152069092", "comment_count": 1, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
A worthy prequel to the upcoming sequel to Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.
This take place right after Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, if you haven't played it, I suggest you go get it on Playstation Network for Playstation 3 to catch up on the story.

Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, is the prequel to Metal Gear Solid.
Both Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes & The Phantom Pain, is worthy successors to the previous installment of Metal Gear Solid 4.

With Ground Zeroes first & The Phantom Pain after, the Metal Gear Solid franchise will come to a close and close the gab that has been left behind by Hideo Kojima for so many years. Prepare yourselves for awesomeness!

review:
I understand why a lot of people were let down when this game was not 20+ hours long and seemed 'like a demo'. I came in with that expectation, and I felt so much better about this after actually playing it.

This is a really succinct, focused microcosm of the best parts of Metal Gear series. It's meant to be replayed, explored, dissected, and fine-tooth-combed. Just like any of the longer entries. I have a feeling I'll be playing this one into the ground since there's a lot of variation in the small setting, but not an overwhelming amount of detail.

I have a feeling that Ground Zeroes is the "Tanker Chapter Prologue" to The Phantom Pain.
If you let friends convince you it's too short or not worth the price, you got played.

review:
I remember walking into a Babbages and buying Metal Gear Solid for Playstation in, what was it, 1998, and what an amazing game that was! Amazing how it brought a cinema experience to home consoles. MGS3 Snake Eater for PS2 is still one of the best games I've ever played, and MGSV looks to continue the full Metal Gear saga. 

On a PC specific note: This demo works fantasically on a PC, with PC adapted menus and controls. Its Hideo Kojima folks so expect nothing less than perfection. I use an Xbox 360 wired controller and the integration is excellent. You do not get any sense of "a port".

Lastly, I've been playing with V-Sync on and the 30fps lock option for the full Kojima experience. Even though my PC could run this game at much higher fps at max settings, I feel its best to use to fps limiter to maximize the tiny details which are in every MGS game! Let everyone here know what you think!

Heres the base for this game. theres a loving fan base for the metal gear solid series. we want the phantom pain now. so what does kojima do? they release a teaser game for the phantom pain. this game was meant as a way for the players to get a feel for the fox engine. the combat flow and play stayle of ground zeros will largly be the same in the phantom pain. so if you want to know how the phantom pain will play? get this. ull get an idea for a few new features like the reflex mode and the controls.

story wise this game is also suposed to take place between peace walker and the phantom pain. kinda be the transition between mother base being detroyed and snake being put into a coma waking up 9 years later. the main story being only one mission long

but there is also extra ops and side ops. which are really fun to mess with esspecially the extra ops. you can unlock mg1 one snake and cyber ninja skins in one mission, while in the other extra ops mission you get extra skins for raiden. and over all I found enjoymeant in just screwing around while going after a few achivments. 

 yes i guess you could just watch it all on youtube. but that takes the fun out of it. you also get some goodies in the phantom pain for owening this game as well. for 13$ or even 20 off sale, this game was well worth the money.

review:
I've been a fan of the Metal gear franchise ever since Metal gear Solid on the PS1, and I thought the franchise was finished after Peace Walker. I didn't have much hope for Metal Gear Solid V, and decided to buy Ground Zeroes with low expectations. What I expected was a mediocre console-to-PC port with similar gameplay to MGS4, which I had mixed opinions of.

I'm extremely pleased to say that any pessimism I had about the game has been blown out of the water. The PC version has a few technical issues, but it's nowhere near the copy-paste port that I've come to expect.

What really shines for this game is it's clean engine. Gameplay is fluid, non-stop, exciting and tese. The story is soaked with atmosphere and excellent voice acting accompanied by music from Harry Gregson-Williams, who has always produced top quality soundtracks for the series since he started with MGS2.  The graphics look phenomonal, and I have been playing on the default settings which were mostly set to high, and FPS was exceptional as well as looking great.

My only criticism is the decision to introduce Kiefer Sutherland as the voice actor for Big Boss, when previously in the series he was voiced by David Hayter. He fits the role well, and is a good choice, but for long standing fans, David Hayter will always be Snake.

I was also expecting it to be a demo with no content, but I have been pleasantly surprised and I'm going to be extremely entertained for hours, which will hopefully stave off the hype for Phantom Pain arriving.

review:
THEY NEED TO ADD ON THE DESCRIPTION: 1 actual mission, and 4 side missions.

There is no replay value. The actual mission is greatly limited in length. Also all the missions are based out of the same map. You can expect 5 hours of gameplay.

You are basically buying 1 episode. Although very short, the gameplay/quality is great. Still miss PS3 metal gear solid. 

I don't think a single episode is worth $20, I think it is worth $5, and for that reason I am not recommending anyone buy this game at it's current price.

review:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a kind of prologue to Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Kind of like how the tanker chapter in MGS2 was a prequel to that game. Even though it's just a prologue this game is amazing.
I've heard complaints from crybabys like Angry Joe that the game was too expensive at release. I think it was about 40-50 dollars at release. Paying that amount of money for a game with an hour long campaign is kind of crazy. But this game is not meant to be played just once and be done with it, there are a lot of side-missions and some hidden collectibles that actually are difficult to find.

I'm going to start with the story and if you haven't played every other Metal Gear game before this, get out. Go out of here, find MGS HD collection for PS3 (I choose PS3 because reasons later), play Metal Gear 1 and 2, download and play Metal Gear Solid from PSN, go back to HD Collection, play MGS2 and MGS3, find a PSP, play MGS Portable Ops, go back to HD Collections play MGS Peace Walker, get a PS3 play MGS4, you can skip MGR:R because it's not important.
If you play this game as your first Metal Gear, you are a stupid cúnt just like Angry Joe.

Now, the story takes place 10 years after Snake Eater, following the Groznyj Grad incident with The Boss' death, and only a year after the Peace Walker incident.
After he fulfilled his mission he was awarded the title of Big Boss. Now he his still sad about The Boss' death, which is understandable because The Boss was the only woman who he ever loved. Big Boss has met with Kazuhira Miller, commonly known as Master Miller or just Master. Big Boss and Miller has started a private military company called Militaires Sans Frontières, translated Soldiers Without Borders. They got a mission to go to Cuba and drive out an unknown well-armed army. Yadayadayadayada. Big Boss finds out about a nuclear deterrant called Peace Walker, skip lots of story, it turns out the AI of Peace Walker is based on The Boss. At the end of the game is turns out the ghost of The Boss took over The Boss AI and drowned Peace Walker. The credits roll, but there are more story stuff after the game is done.
Turns out Paz is not a 16-year-old Costa Rican high school student, but a Cipher agent, she hijacks MSF's  Metal Gear ZEKE. Big Boss destroys it, she flees, gets captured by XOF, then this worthless kid Chico goes after her and he too gets captured. It's up to Big Boss to rescue them and the story is now in MGSV: GZ.
I'm cutting the story here, there's too much shít.

The gameplay is really good, if you play one of the newer MGS games you will have some serious problems playing MGS1, 2 and 3.
The stealth is more realistic in this one compared to the other ones, you don't get to change your camo to decrease your chances of getting spotted.
In the main mission it's at night and it's raining, it's pretty easy to not get spotted, but all of the side-missions play during daytime. It's sweet.

The music is pretty good, sound effects are also pretty good. Even the random conversations between soldiers are interesting. Not much more to say about that.

The game also looks fúcking gorgeous.

My final score for this game is actually 10/10 because it's a Hideo Freaking Kojima game, and as we all know Hideo Kojima is the biggest díck G ever. There are also multiple ways of beating this game, like sneaking onto a truck to get into the Admin Building.
I can't stretch it enough how much you shouldn't play this game if you haven't played all of the other Metal Gear games.
This game is short and sweet.
Even the bonus missions you unlock after collection all of the XOF patches are great. First one was originally a Playstation exclusive called Déjà Vu where you play as Big Boss, where you have to recreate scenes from Metal Gear Solid 1. Easily the best part of the game.
The second mission was a Xbox exclusive and is called Jamais Vu where you play as 2018 Raiden, it's lame.

If you are still here, reading this I've got to give you credit. This game is like the best game on Steam right now.
Later, fúckers.
raw_json:
{"recommendationid": "13466037", "author": {"steamid": "76561198021827061", "num_games_owned": 490, "num_reviews": 55, "playtime_forever": 3460, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 1348, "last_played": 1447434401}, "language": "english", "review": "Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a kind of prologue to Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. Kind of like how the tanker chapter in MGS2 was a prequel to that game. Even though it's just a prologue this game is amazing.
I've heard complaints from crybabys like Angry Joe that the game was too expensive at release. I think it was about 40-50 dollars at release. Paying that amount of money for a game with an hour long campaign is kind of crazy. But this game is not meant to be played just once and be done with it, there are a lot of side-missions and some hidden collectibles that actually are difficult to find.

I'm going to start with the story and if you haven't played every other Metal Gear game before this, get out. Go out of here, find MGS HD collection for PS3 (I choose PS3 because reasons later), play Metal Gear 1 and 2, download and play Metal Gear Solid from PSN, go back to HD Collection, play MGS2 and MGS3, find a PSP, play MGS Portable Ops, go back to HD Collections play MGS Peace Walker, get a PS3 play MGS4, you can skip MGR:R because it's not important.
If you play this game as your first Metal Gear, you are a stupid cúnt just like Angry Joe.

Now, the story takes place 10 years after Snake Eater, following the Groznyj Grad incident with The Boss' death, and only a year after the Peace Walker incident.
After he fulfilled his mission he was awarded the title of Big Boss. Now he his still sad about The Boss' death, which is understandable because The Boss was the only woman who he ever loved. Big Boss has met with Kazuhira Miller, commonly known as Master Miller or just Master. Big Boss and Miller has started a private military company called Militaires Sans Frontières, translated Soldiers Without Borders. They got a mission to go to Cuba and drive out an unknown well-armed army. Yadayadayadayada. Big Boss finds out about a nuclear deterrant called Peace Walker, skip lots of story, it turns out the AI of Peace Walker is based on The Boss. At the end of the game is turns out the ghost of The Boss took over The Boss AI and drowned Peace Walker. The credits roll, but there are more story stuff after the game is done.
Turns out Paz is not a 16-year-old Costa Rican high school student, but a Cipher agent, she hijacks MSF's  Metal Gear ZEKE. Big Boss destroys it, she flees, gets captured by XOF, then this worthless kid Chico goes after her and he too gets captured. It's up to Big Boss to rescue them and the story is now in MGSV: GZ.
I'm cutting the story here, there's too much shít.

The gameplay is really good, if you play one of the newer MGS games you will have some serious problems playing MGS1, 2 and 3.
The stealth is more realistic in this one compared to the other ones, you don't get to change your camo to decrease your chances of getting spotted.
In the main mission it's at night and it's raining, it's pretty easy to not get spotted, but all of the side-missions play during daytime. It's sweet.

The music is pretty good, sound effects are also pretty good. Even the random conversations between soldiers are interesting. Not much more to say about that.

The game also looks fúcking gorgeous.

My final score for this game is actually 10/10 because it's a Hideo Freaking Kojima game, and as we all know Hideo Kojima is the biggest díck G ever. There are also multiple ways of beating this game, like sneaking onto a truck to get into the Admin Building.
I can't stretch it enough how much you shouldn't play this game if you haven't played all of the other Metal Gear games.
This game is short and sweet.
Even the bonus missions you unlock after collection all of the XOF patches are great. First one was originally a Playstation exclusive called Déjà Vu where you play as Big Boss, where you have to recreate scenes from Metal Gear Solid 1. Easily the best part of the game.
The second mission was a Xbox exclusive and is called Jamais Vu where you play as 2018 Raiden, it's lame.

If you are still here, reading this I've got to give you credit. This game is like the best game on Steam right now.
Later, fúckers.", "timestamp_created": 1419057714, "timestamp_updated": 1419072775, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: A great port from the console version. The game runs smooth as butter. On my 780 I was playing with everything turned on very high and never had a single slow down. The gameplay is a more refined version of MGSIV. This "game" is very very very short. There is some replay value to it. But most will finish the single mission story mode in less than 2 hours. I knew this going in and with the $13 price tag I felt ok with that because I am a huge MGS fan, and mostly was hoping by showing patronage to this game we will eventually see the older games ported over (Phantom Pain has already been announced for PC). Also no stupid DRM or other nonsense. This is an excellent port from Konami. Keep up the good work and bring us Peace Walker, MGS2, and MGS3.

review: Ive been a long time fan of mgs and I at first thought this was great. It's a pos. Yeah the engine is great, but the missions are crap. Only one of them is fun, the one other one that I'd like to play is too much of a pain in the ass to unlock. I have to get a perfect rank on a bunch of daylight missions... because it's a good idea to make the missions during the day? It's annnnnoying. I don't have the patience. Half the time youll just end up restarting the mission and doing what you just did 15 times till you finally undetected through most of the mission. It's broad daylight and so tedious with no good reason for the mission to be happening then. The game is short, the only thing they have going for it is unlocking the one mission where you play as the psx snake... plus... keifer... great... I've always loved his movies like...? idk that vampire one? crap. Even on sale, it's just a slap in the face. If you wanted to give me a taste of stealth, (specifically the stealth only missions) how bout you make them not take place during broad daylight? The main mission is the only one that is fun and its screwed up by millers constant chatter and tutorials.

review:
I should have spend 1 minute online reading about this game before i bought or at least be more suspicous that it's only 3 GB in size, so I can't blame anyone but myself for this...

But the main storyline of the game can be finished in about 40 minutes, and that's taking the cutscenes.

***SPOILERS****

you collect 2 hostages and leave the island. 

***kind of***


Even though the game reminds me to be stealthy there is no punishment for not doing that. After i accidentally got spotted in the first 10 seconds of the game and made my first kill I decided to go on a rampage just to see what happens.

and guess what? I ended up beating the game... I killed everyone in my sight and the game, after sending 2 waves of easily dispachable opponents, declared the area to be "clear, and suspect lost" so i just ran to the next spot and repeated.

at one point i was in a tank in the middle of base shooting all the waves of enemies game threw at me till they stopped coming. and again the area was declared "safe".... all while the hostage i was supposed to prottect was safely chilling next to my tank as i proceeded to slaugher innocent navy seals...

so basically, if you take away the cutscenes, and go in guns blazing, you can finish the game in something like 25 minutes... as a veteral splinter cell player I would call Bulls*it on "stealth gameplay" element of this game...

perhaps that is harder to do on "hard", however that doesn't really add to the replayability of the damn thing.
Thank god there are extra side missions to play after that so it's not a complete waste of money (even with the discount)
but as far as the main story goes it looks more like a demo of a game. You are better off investing 4 pounds in MG revengeance which is on sale now too. At least you get a real game not just a mission.

review:
I've never played an MGS game before, -(except MGS 4 at my mates house for about 15 minutes)- but besides that, I had never known what MGS was about. I wish I had played it from the start, I wish I had gotten to know these characters and love them, and want to have that experience that Playstation gamers had. From the time I saw MGS V: The Phantom Pain's E3 trailer I knew this game was on my 'most wanted list'.

Although I never bought this game when it first came out, -reason being it was $39 on Xbox One and I hadn't built my PC yet,- I always wanted to buy it. Now that I finally got to experience a small taste of MGS V I'm completely blown away.

The mechanics of this game, the graphics, the characters, the voice acting, story, everything, was absolutely spot on. I would agree that even still buying the game at $19 still is not that good of a value for money. Even thought I bought it during the Steam Winter Sale, it was money well spent either way.

10/10 would recommend!

review:
A Kojima game on Steam? A beautiful moment for us all and not to mention it's Metal Gear Solid. A fantastic port that was done more than well with no issues whatsoever. As for the game itself? It's brilliant. It requires tactical thinking and offers so much that you'll just want to do more than one playthrough of every mission. 
Prepare your snake to get solid for a long time because this is a good one.

review:
Great hardaware support, good engine, good "demo". Ive waited a long time to see MGS on steam and this was worth the wait. It going on sale the day it comes out is just another nod to the PC community by the lord our god Kojima. 

To those who claim this game is "too short" and it lasts "12 minutes" you didnt get 100% and youre just not a fan. The unlocks and collectables are all fan service that show off Kojima's sense of humor. If youve been on MGS since '98 then youll find this well worth the price to get your feet wet on the fox engine.

review:
Gorgeous game. Kiefer is alright as Snake. Best playing MGS game in the series, without a doubt, but, It could be considered light on content. It is a sandbox to play in. One map, seven or so missions on that map with different weather and times of day. Play stealthy or murder fools, it's your choice. Hold guys up and show off the egregious lack of NPC voice acting. 

I WANT TO KNOW WHO THE SURGEON IS DAMMIT.
