review: Great re playability, got months of enjoyment out of the PS3 version and will get months out of this Steam copy. If you are the type of gamer that rushes to the end once and moves on to the next best thing this game will only disappoint you, but if you enjoy mastering games and getting all the achievements you'll get much more out of this.  Graphics and controls in this port are also excellent, this really is the definitive version of Ground Zeros. Hats off to Kojima and his team and I eagerly await Phantom Pain next year.

review:
TLDR: A good port of new MGS game-demo-thing. If you're a fan of the series buy it, if not wait for a sale because the content is limited.

GOOD:

+Looks good and runs smoothly on my mid-range machine.
+Plays well with KB+M but is definitely better with a gamepad.
+The one area available has several missions that play pretty differently and have plenty of challenges/acheivements.
+Both console exclusive extra missions are included (a nostalgia trip for MGS1 and a Snatchers-mission starring Raiden from Rising)

BAD:

-One map which is well designed but monotonous after a while.
-Limited gear/items
-It's basically a demo you're paying for.
-They're playing you like a fiddle.

review:
As a very hardcore fan of the Metal Gear Solid Franchise, I was at first dissapointed in Ground Zeroes when it was announced for the consoles due to the pricing and the content of it. However, i never actually played the game. Now, after playing the PC version of this game, here is what i have to say:

Pros:
-Beautifully Optimized, probably of the best optimized game ever (Ubisoft needs to learn from Kojima Productions)
-Gameplay is wicked awesome, ALOT better than all the previous Metal Gear games.
-Graphics are top notch!
-Game doesn't lag one bit
-Emphasis on Stealth. Alert=Death.


Cons:
-Gameplay is short, only about 1 hour 15 mins long. U can finish the game in 30 mins if you are fast (However, I feel that the Side Operations make up for this)
-Game is a little bit buggy (Problem where the game won't open when u plug a game-pad in. I gave up and used Keyboard and Mouse instead)
-NO DAVID HAYTER!! I WANT THE ORIGINAL SNAKE!

All in all i rate this game a 9/10 in terms of gameplay and 7/10 Overall.

review:
MY rig is just a bit below the recommended specs for the game (mainly on the proccesor area, i have a Phenom quad-core 2.2Ghz proccesor) 
and the game runs incredibly smooth, around the 40 to 50-something frames, and sometimes even up to 60, on all setting in high. 
If that isnt a sign of good optimization on the FOX engine then i really dont know what could be.

All fanboyism aside, the game still has a couple of minor bugs, many people are having problems even launching the game, others are having problems with the game not recognizing correctly their 360 gamepads. But overall still very good game for just being a priced prologue.

PRAISE KOJIMA-SAMA!!!

review:
Why is my controller not working? With something that came out on console first, I feel a 360 controller to be most appropriate.. This port's great says the comments.. i'd love to play as i'm a long time solid snake fan. Everytime I try and play this with controller it glitches and inverts the verticle axis so all I can see is the ground or the sky, if I change axis orientation. I can play mouse and keyboard but I want what I paid for, and that means letting me play on my big screen a comfortable distance away with me conroller. PLEASE FIX THIS!
Long Live Kojima

review:
this is a review from a MGS snake eater player i have not played the later installments due to console issues

that said, i enoyed the feel, controls, look, voice acting, and story. this is why mgs 3 was my favorite. Coming into this game and seeing all the changes threw me off. but i quickly learned that it was the same basic design only improved. no more sloppy aiming, no more vague CQC (close quarters combat), and very easy to learn stealth mechanics.

there are a few things that have been added that drasticly change the way mgs is played. the marking system, and the spotted system.

once spotted the game goes into slow motion, and shows the enemy that saw you. i both like and hate this, it creates a weird disconnect between normal exploration and sneaking into a slow motion quicktime. im not saying thats bad but in my opinion it makes it very different and jarring at first but extremely useful.

At the beggining of the game you are introduced to your binoculars which can help you scope out the area but it can also mark enemies. the marking of enemies has been in many games such as deus ex, farcry 3, splinter cell, and hitman.
its such an old and used concept that its strange to see it in a metal gear game especially when its never helped you keep track of enemies. like i said before i like and hate this, it makes it feel less like metal gear and more like splintercell.
on the otherhand this helps greatly since the areas are massive and expansive, no longer is it small areas with a set number of enemies not its a huge field of things to keep track of. 

so play with them on, or off your choice

as a game and as a metal gear game i strongly recommend this game to the old and newbs to the series.

review: Albeit a very short game, Kojima's work definitely shows in MGSV. Graphics are stunning along with this being the best PC port I have ever played. Runs as smooth as silk even on Extra High settings (GTX 760). Kiefer Sutherland nails it as Naked Snake in this one. I recommend Ground Zeros IF it is on sale! I hope that those buying are aware of Ground Zeros being a Prologue to MGSV Phantom Pain, and not a full game. I am looking forward to Phantom Pain and hope to pick it up the day it comes out. Ground Zeros gives old fans and new ones a small, yet great taste of a perfect game to come.

review:
Ran real well on my medium-high end craptop (settings mostly set to high and still ran great without any problems) and just downright played great on keyboard & mouse (except for the movement when trying to turn around and when you try to choose some options while you have someone in a chokehold. You have to hold one key to enter interrogation [default: Q] and while you're holding said key you have to press another key with the same hand to choose a dialogue option [default: 1, 2, 3] which can be straining to many).
When trying to lean against some small cover (while crouching especially) Snake tends to put his head out just enough for anything on the other side to see which can be highly detremental for those just attempting to touch a surface of, for example, a small box. When that happens even trying to back your body out of sight can be difficult as Snake also tends to get his whole body out of cover.
The sensitivy for aiming in first person mode is way too high even when set to the lowest it can go in the options menu, which can highly affect perfect shots with snipers when looking through the lense or even just using the binoculars without looking too far off somewhere. A controller is much more recommended for these moments.

It's a third-person shooter when you let it become a shooter (which is unrecommended and isn't the initial point but that's the player's choice).
The guns work really well here; they spread quite a bit if you hold down the trigger too long (as with most other shooters) and there's bullet drop which is much more noticeable with the sniper and the tranquilizer gun.
It's a wonderful stealth game with incredible AI where the enemy can spot you immediately if you're seen close enough to them, though if you're far enough from view they'll just check out whatever unusual thing that was in the distance. If you're in view for too long too far away they'll "check out a suspected individual" or "check out something suspicious going on." Close enough to them and you're in view for too long they'll recognize you, set the whole area to combat status, and start engaging immediately (unless you neutralize them fast enough and if they're alone before they set the entire island into combat status) which you can then run and hide until the heat wears off or shoot back until you're in the clear, though reinforcements usually keep coming if they [i]notice[/i] that their live soldier count is dwindling. You can also experiment with how you can be sneaky in this game (ie: get most of the solders's attention away from your goal by detonating a C4 to destroy an AA gun that was placed really far away from where you're going).

[b]There are just so many great things in this game that I most likely still haven't even squeezed out despite my tons of hours and completion rate into it. This is one of those games I think where learning on your own what you can do with what you have to help get you from A to B is part of the joy and fun. As stated many times in many other places though, the only big negative thing about this is that it's pretty much a demo: it's too short for a full priced game. For fans and just the right people this is an incredible piece to have and play.[/b]

{"recommendationid": "13463079", "author": {"steamid": "76561198034306697", "num_games_owned": 1445, "num_reviews": 636, "playtime_forever": 6658, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 4149, "last_played": 1444219559}, "language": "english", "review": "Ran real well on my medium-high end craptop (settings mostly set to high and still ran great without any problems) and just downright played great on keyboard & mouse (except for the movement when trying to turn around and when you try to choose some options while you have someone in a chokehold. You have to hold one key to enter interrogation [default: Q] and while you're holding said key you have to press another key with the same hand to choose a dialogue option [default: 1, 2, 3] which can be straining to many).
When trying to lean against some small cover (while crouching especially) Snake tends to put his head out just enough for anything on the other side to see which can be highly detremental for those just attempting to touch a surface of, for example, a small box. When that happens even trying to back your body out of sight can be difficult as Snake also tends to get his whole body out of cover.
The sensitivy for aiming in first person mode is way too high even when set to the lowest it can go in the options menu, which can highly affect perfect shots with snipers when looking through the lense or even just using the binoculars without looking too far off somewhere. A controller is much more recommended for these moments.

It's a third-person shooter when you let it become a shooter (which is unrecommended and isn't the initial point but that's the player's choice).
The guns work really well here; they spread quite a bit if you hold down the trigger too long (as with most other shooters) and there's bullet drop which is much more noticeable with the sniper and the tranquilizer gun.
It's a wonderful stealth game with incredible AI where the enemy can spot you immediately if you're seen close enough to them, though if you're far enough from view they'll just check out whatever unusual thing that was in the distance. If you're in view for too long too far away they'll "check out a suspected individual" or "check out something suspicious going on." Close enough to them and you're in view for too long they'll recognize you, set the whole area to combat status, and start engaging immediately (unless you neutralize them fast enough and if they're alone before they set the entire island into combat status) which you can then run and hide until the heat wears off or shoot back until you're in the clear, though reinforcements usually keep coming if they [i]notice[/i] that their live soldier count is dwindling. You can also experiment with how you can be sneaky in this game (ie: get most of the solders's attention away from your goal by detonating a C4 to destroy an AA gun that was placed really far away from where you're going).

[b]There are just so many great things in this game that I most likely still haven't even squeezed out despite my tons of hours and completion rate into it. This is one of those games I think where learning on your own what you can do with what you have to help get you from A to B is part of the joy and fun. As stated many times in many other places though, the only big negative thing about this is that it's pretty much a demo: it's too short for a full priced game. For fans and just the right people this is an incredible piece to have and play.[/b]", "timestamp_created": 1419043674, "timestamp_updated": 1433678884, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 2, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.523809552192687988", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: Ok this is a tough one for me. I love the MGS. All the games. And I would rebuy them all if available on PC. That said this game doesnt feel too metal gear-ish. Maybe it might change for PP. The port is exellent/ runs like butter on my machine as it  should. One problem(s): Keyboard control for this game kinda sucks. And there's intances of mouse acceleration when using minoculars and other things. Another problem is the game doesnt explain a lot of the actions u can do.  I have to constantly look the key bindings to figure what does what because it aint intuative. Like I had to look how to 1st person mode. I knew i could do it from previos games. Also you are gonna have to remap keys like crazy cause by the default they suck. Also u cant use mouse wheel to scroll weapons. Although 124 button on keyboard works well enough. Menu navigation is also a problem. Have to use arrows key. Lame. Anyway solid port, just wish keyboard/mouse control where better thought out.

review:
I like and dislike this game. I dislike it because its a waste of money. It only has 1 map and 6 or 8 missions I forget which to me is a waste however so far I have really enjoy this playing this game. It looks amazing, it runs super soomthly and its alot of fun. But this is like a demo of the actual game that is going to be released whenever and I feel dissapointed to £12 for a demo. 

If you have lots of money or don't mind wasting money then by all means get it GET IT NOW. If your like me I suggest you wait till they release a full game rather than a tenth of a game.
Nice graphics, but very short gameplay

review: if you're a fan of mgs don't miss out, the game is great, it run great and look so good. don't fool yourself into thinking this is a full mgs game though. this is a prologue and an introduction to some of the new mechanic of phantom pain,the game is short, but that's if you do the main missions only. take your time with it, there's other mission to do after you did the main mission (on one map only though) and you can transfer your save file to mgs phantom pain when it's out. if you're new to this franchise there is a short introduction to snake's story (a.k.a big boss the original snake) in the other games he was in (mgs 3 and peace walker). for 33% right now, it's worth it (it was 30$ on psn).

review:
So here's the thing about Ground Zeroes. The gameplay? Fantastic. The graphics? Gorgeous. The story? Phenomenal. The controls? Well we need to talk. I played the game with my keyboard and mouse, but there are a few issues here and there. This game somewhat suffers from, "Let's use every button!" syndrome, though it's not that bad. For the most part, things make sense. WASD to move, shift is run, ctrl is tip-toe (I changed it to alt for personal reasons,) C is crouch, Space is a quick dodge dive thing, E is the action button, making you quickly climb up stuff when necessary, M1 is attack, M2 is aim, M3 switches brings the camera to the opposite shoulder, F looks through the goggles, R reloads... And then there's a mess of other stuff on random buttons.

Here's two fun examples of how this hurt the game:
 1 = Main Weapon, 2 = Sidearm, 3 = Throw Item, 4 = Night Vision Goggles. Holding 1 will let you change some addons for the main weapon, being its supressor and it's light. So your left hand is on 1. The buttons to change these things are X and Y, the same buttons used on the 360 controller. This can be a hassle when you're switching quickly.
Another example involves hold ups. If you get close to an enemy and then stick your gun to their back or in their face, they'll go arms up. You can then interrogate them by holding Q. So your right hand is holding M2 to bring your gun up, and your left hand is on Q. Then three options appear for talking, which are in a pattern indicating you control them with a direction. You try moving the mouse up, nothing happens. You press W, nothing happens. Turns out it's the arrow keys. First time I encountered this, I had to use my nose to tell this guy what to do, because Q needed to be pressed, and I needed to keep this guy in a stick-up with M2. I later discovered that using M2 was unnecessary when he was holding his arms up, although this was only from behind. My assumption is that they'll strike if you're in front of them when your weapon goes down.

So obviously the game has rebindable keys for the keyboard and mouse which is great, but what about the other options? There are graphics options a plenty, although one in particular, screen filter, I couldn't figure out what it actually did, so I left it turned off because I saw no difference. The game has no audio options, and although that's disappointing, if you're not wearing head phones while playing this, you're not using the game's well tuned audio to your advantage. Multiple times being able to hear where a vehicle was coming from saved me from getting caught by it. There is no FOV slider, although I don't believe it's necessary for a third person game. The field of view is analagous to reality, and the only time you got into first person is in first person gun aiming, and when using both the binoculars and the i-Droid.

In getting this game to work for me, I had to do multiple rebinds, but once I did, the game play was smooth as butter. It helped that I own an MMO mouse though, so I was able to map a few things to five through nine. The gameplay is phenomenal too. If you're a fan of the series and you're reading this, wondering if you should get the game, yes, you should. If you're a fan of stealth, you should still get the game, although if you're unfamiliar with the series, a few things might not make sense to you. It is true, the official single mission is short. It's about 2 hours to complete for the first time, although if you enjoy this game play, there's plenty more to do. There are multiple side ops, some being stealth, some being assassinations, and one even being a fly in and rescue battle, with a very amusing ending for fans of the series. There's also a secret side mission which unlocks once you collect all the XOF patches, which I'll let you discover for yourself.

The bottom line is, this game is fantastic, despite it's control flaws and short length, if you like stealth, this game is beyond worth it. There is plenty to explore and do, despite everything taking place in the same military compound, and you will have loads of fun playing it.

Oh, one last thing. If you're here expecting gameplay like Metal Gear Rising, then you're in the wrong place. This is a stealth game, not an action game.

review:
AAA devs like Ubishit and EA with years of development : Shit ports that won't run on a NASA computer

Japanese dudes who mostly don't know english porting a game that came out earlier this year : Can run at 60 on toasters way below the recommended specs and has controls that actually compensate for the switch to K+M

Kojima is the perfect mix between a Gaben who still does games , and a Ken Levine who didn't sell his soul to the devil
The Big Boss arrives to entertain the PC master race......this is no cheap port.......stunning from Kojima and go.

review:

review:
This is a demo serving to tie in the events of peacewalker to the begining of the phantom pain, if you have never played peacewalker which I don't think many have considering it was on the psp, I would definetely not recomend buying this game. 

Even then if you have played peacewalker there I would advise you to be patient and just wait till there is a phantom pain collectors addition that bundles this with the main game.

To be honest I also don't quite think this  is a good reflection of how the phantom pain will be set up, Ground Zeroes feels like a sequel to peace walker, which is weird because peace walker felt very unique, and I don't quite know how the mechanics in this demo will relate to the full release of the game.

Considering the side missions and main mission take 2 hours total to complete, and that this is the buggiest demo I have had to pay for (can't start the game without unplugging all of my peripherals on my computer and then plugging them in after the game launched), I can not recommend this game

review: Great prolouge. yes it is short. around 4 hours with side missions. but the gameplay here is the best its ever been in a metal gear solid game. its fast fluid, designed from the ground up in 60fps. and the pc port is very well optimised. running 4k max settings 60fps on dual 980s without a single dip. lots of replay value, lots of hidden gems in the game. a good taste of whats to come. if you see this on sale for a reasnoble price then its worth getting.

review:
First of all, this is mostly a demo of Phantom Pain, so don't exepect it to be a long game. It's graphically amazing, the atmosphere of the game is fantastic. Stealth at his best. 

It's hard, it's open world and how you succeed in the missions is compleatly up to you! I'm trully happy to see this game on PC again. 

Although, i've been playing a bit and i've encountered an annoying bug. If you play with keyboard + mouse, sometimes one of your direcction keys gets "stuck" and Snake just moves around in circles until you exit the mission - hoping that gets fixed!-

A fun, attractive and entertaining game (with some easter eggs).

review:
Quick review for 1 Hour playtime:

+Pretty decent port to PC.
    I.  steady 50-60 fps, 1080p [high settings] on mobile GPU GTX860M.
    II. no missing textures/glitches popup or NPC's random spawn. 
+Gorgeous FOX engine graphics:
    I.  no unneccessary 'overlighting' features on Battlefield 4 & AC Unity.
    II. texture models & Player movements much more grip to the land/plane field.
+Stealth redefined:
    I.  Running to prone position, prone to running position more efficient.
    II. Quick action [slow-mo] when being detected by enemy. [Adrenaline rush mode]
+Make radio call on the go. [unlike it's predeccessor, navigate to radio menu > make call {frequency}]



-watching cutscences running on 60FPS, get the feeling of watching 'Charlie Chaplin', 
-no more David Hayter's voice.
-Game failed to launch on Win8.1 x64 with gamepad attached on PC. [ had to unplug > start game > reattach ]
-It's prequel TPP, don't expect full game.


"A delayed game is eventually good, but a rushed game is forever bad." - Shigeru Miyamoto

review:
After a frightning 5 seconds when my logitech extreme 3D pro joystick decided to say to me, 'No you will not play this game' and MGSV:GZ failed to start at all on first attempt, I unplugged that sucker and was playing the game in about 15 seconds.

Beautiful... Just Beautiful.

I think Phantom pain is an instant preorder once it's available. I was gonna get it for PS4. But now PC all the way.

Small issue of the Y Axis setting in camera settings not functioning at all and stuck at Normal orientation. But they'll fix that I'm sure. Also you may run into problems running the game at all SO BE WARNED! Only problem I had was my logitech joystick caused the game to not start. When unplugged, it worked fine but this might not work for everyone.

But other than that. Awesome Port.

review: Although it has already been said, I too will say that this game is a bit too short but since it is a prologue to Phantom Pain I find its length somewhat reasonable. As a person who has played Metal Gear Solid 1, 2, 3 and Peacewalker I can say that I thoroughly enjoy this game and even after so many games it pleases me to see that Metal Gear still keeps getting better while still paying tribute to the basics. I have yet to play the side missions but already at this point I can say that I am extremely hyped for Phantom Pain.

review:
Boring game that plays nothing like Rising. Instead of playing as a cool Ninja Cyborg battling cyborg samurais and robot wolves with great combat and rich story you play as a weak bland army man vs a mutant on alcatraz? 
You dont have a sword, There is no blade mode. Barebones combo system. You cant even jump.
So instead of making a good game about classic good characters like Raiden, Jetstream Sam and Blade Wolf we get a garbage fanfic spin off of some doofus.
SKIP THIS TRAVESTY!

review:
I've spent over 20 hours on this game on my PS4 and bought this on PC just to get a chance at listening to the original voice acting.


First, let me comment on playing this with Japanese voice.
To play this with Japanese audio, you'll have to set the game's language to Japanese through Steam; Steam will then proceed to download an additional 1.8 GB of data (presumably the Japanese audio files).
If you configured the game prior to changing the audio, such as tweaking the graphics or controls, you'll have to configure the game again.

You'll know if the game uses Japanese audio if it asks you to choose between 日本語 (Japanese) or English, and no other language. This ingame language selection only affects text, so don't choose Japanese unless you can read it, or changing the language will be a pain. If you can choose any other language, you are playing the international version with English voice acting.


Now to the actual game.
This is what games should be like: Solid performance (no pun intended) and hardly any noticeable bugs or issues without the need to install 3 day-one patches (looking at you, Ubisoft).

The main mission is unfortunately way too short and can be finished in half an hour if you know what to do and where to go, or less than 3 hours if you take your time.
If you're aiming for completion, however, you could easily be playing this game for over 20 hours, like I did on the PS4.

Gameplay-wise [i]Ground Zeroes[/i] might be a bit underwhelming for MGS veterans. The shift from Stealth to Action is very noticeable.
[list]
[*]It is no longer possible to knock on walls to attract guards; we do get an infinite amount of empty magazines to throw around, however.
[*]There is only one crawling speed; no more super-slow crawling. At least we can still roll around...
[*]Playing dead is also no longer possible, and there are no containers to hide in (no lockers or trash bins or similar).
[*]There's no camo; It's always weird to see a guard standing in front of a door, not noticing an old man dressed in a dark-blue skinsuit lying around in front of him while he's pointing a flashlight at said old man.
[*]And there's no cardboard box. Yes, I wasn't kidding when I said there were no containers to hide in.
[/list]

Despite all, this game is still pretty good and deserving recommendation.
I spent a lot of time exploring all kinds of ways to get into Camp Omega, I spent a lot of time exploring all kinds of ways to get out again, and I'm going to do it all over again. On PC this time.

review:
The definition of the absolute masterpiece.Great story,great cut scenes,great ingame graphics,great voice overs and soundtrack,amazing optimization for old hardware and overall simply perfect.I know the game is very short but it doesn't matter,buying this game means you buy quality and not quantity.I never buy new games so early after their release but i bought Ground Zeroes in its 1st day because i wanted to show my support to Konami for bringing MGS V to us pc gamers.Let's hope they will release also Silent hills for pc.

10/10 from me

review:
Just amazingly stable pc port i was afraid how it would run with my pc, but it just runs so smooth. 
However keep in mind that this is a prologue to Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain so game might feel expectedly short... Unless you are like me and want to spend extra time exploring every corner of map, have a nice little chat with the guards every now and then and then drag some bodies down to edge of cliff just to hear the seawater splash, or maybe just wreak some random havoc with all of the arsenal available or maybe you want to hone your espionage skills in advance before the real game comes out with also including Metal Gear Online - Tactical team Operations! 
Kojima and Snake surely kept us waiting, but the wait was really worth it. And as hard as it was to resist buying this for ps3 for nearly a year i am glad that i waited and supported pc port instead.  Welcome back to home Snake!

I give this game 9/9 XOF patches

review:
Fan of the Metal Gear series, im glad that Komami and Kojima still have a heart for a pc version of the game.  And boy does this game look real pretty with its new Fox engine!  The game is ported to the pc and runs fine. Has gamepad support and plays great.  This is a short game, however you can Replay to earn acheivements and unlock modes, ect. It really shows what the fox engine can do and can't wait for Metal Gear Phantom, a full proper Metal Gear game on Pc!  Metal Gear Ground Zeroes is a prequel of what is to come and boy I can't wait.  I started guns a blazing and finished by hopping into an APC and cleared the base.  Next time i'll try a sneaky approach and try not to get spotted or set an alarm off, probably will make the game a lot longer to play.

I would recommend buying this on sale, since its short play through. But has replayability though.   I bought this for $13.39 / 33% off and I thought it was a fair price to pay for the content in this game in my opinion.  However, if you want to support this game and more to come paying full retail is not so bad.  I enjoyed the gameplay and would  highly recommend!

review:
This game runs so incredibly well! I wasn't even afraid it wouldn't, I watched a tech video about the FOX Engine and they touted it to be incredibly flexible and powerful, with scaling options for every format (PS3/4, Xbox 360/One, and PC) We can look forward to The Phantom Pain on PC, and hopefully the new "Silent Hills" as well since that too is being crafted with the FOX Engine.

In 4k, I get a Solid 60FPS with every graphical option turned up all the way (playing with two 980 GTX in SLI). In 1080p on my laptop with a 765 GTX I too get nearly 60FPS with some options turned slightly down, but never to the low settings. It is simply amazing to see this game so well optimized. I wish more were like it!

The game itself is short, but with a lot of replay value, so the price of $20 is very well worth it. If you're lucky, you can get it for less (I got it for $13.39 Steam Holiday Sale, and I heard Green Man Gaming may have it cheaper).

Highly recommened! I love the Metal Gear Series and am so happy to begin to enjoy it on PC in 4k with the best graphics.

review:
Great game!  I don't know what the QA department was smoking for minimum system reqs but mine are pretty far below it and the game plays at 60fps on High settings @ 1600x900

Remember: This is a laptop that is from 2011
i7-2630m @ 2.0Ghz - 2.8Ghz turbo
8GB DDR3 1066
2GB GDDR5 nVidia 560m GTX

Now, I don't have the bandwidth to show 720p or better, but here is my first time playthrough recorded at 720p but converted to 480p for bandwidth sakes.  The game played at 60fps, but I recorded at 30fps since it was live on twitch.tv

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5HIXlzc_Lng

review: Love the series, and this installment is no different.  It's a great port, lots of features and options..the only issue I have is that many of the visual improvements involve bluring (depth of field and whatnot)...this is sometimes too previlant when using the binocs, and also Snake/Big Boss is far too often out of focus. I get that it is technially an imersion improvement (amung other things), but I used to love seeing the high detail of the main character while I waited to pounce on the enemy...no he is just a fuzzy remnant of what was on the ps4. I really hope this isnt the case with TPP...I like to play with my settings on max (so I play on PC) and don't want to have to lose out a feature to the PS4. Other than that, awesome port, can't wait for more Metal Gear next year.

review:
If you are a fan, and cant get enough of MGS. Buy this on sale now and get an ace insight into what good things there are to come from MGS yet. 

It is a short short "game," honestly, it only took 60mins to finsish the Ground Zeros story driven section. And that was me taking my time, guessing where to go and just having fun. 

Gameplay is pretty flawless, really intuative. And some great features added (though I was dissapointed that I couldnt throw bodies over the cliff face to hide them, that is just stupid.)

Have moved onto the side missions, they are cool. Again, really feels like a testing ground for the mechanics really, and they are good fun. 

Graphically, amazing. And frame rate was a perfect 60, I didnt see even the slightest micro stutter from the game (970, 16gb ram with 2750k)

I miss David Hayter, but the 24 chap did a pretty decent job. 


So all in all, yeah. Very pleased - Short and sweet, and a good evening atleast of fresh MGS joy! :)

review:
While the game is a solid port and a technological marvel, the content is lacking. I'm not going to discuss the length and depth of the storyline since that has been pointed out again and again.

Instead, my biggest disappointment is with the mechanics. Compared to Metal Gear Solid 4, the game has been heavily simplified. In 4, you could crawl like a catterpillar, play dead, search enemies during hold-ups, pin enemies to the floor during grabs etc. You can do none of these here.

There are also some issue with the KBM controls for grabs and interrogations, but I'm betting they'll be fixed soon. While I am a controller user (I have an Xbox 360 one and an Xbox One one), I prefer playing aiming games with a mouse.

That said, I still recommend the game, mostly because I'm a sucker for Metal Gear, but it does not hold a candle to 4.

review:
As a die hard metal gear fan (own them all) I am quite happy to say ground zeroes is really really good, Game play wise. As for the story it is lacking, (I know this is a only a opening to mgs v). Also unless you have played peace walker you will not know very much beyond the small backstory section on the main menu.

Right the pc port = Fantastic no frame stuttering at all for me, And good graphics settings options, Maxed out with me. (GTX 770). The only problem i have had is the mouse will show up frome time to time when using a pad.

Now i would recomend this to Metal Gear fans and to non fans as the gameplay is soo good, It took me 2 hours to finish the main story (not rushing too much but not exploring really) I am now doing the side quests which seem quite engaging some with more story elements at the end of them and more unlockable audio logs.

Right now go play it. Have fun.

review:
Well, 

I recommend this, but buy it ASAP while it's on sale as it's one mission and a few hit missions after you finish the story line. 
It's a paid Prologue, and sort of a tech demo. 

The story, the little there is, is tradicional MGS. Corny sob-story with over-the-top elements and a plot that only makes sense if you are Japanese ( so I am told ) or you are high on LSD. Or both. That will make it better, I guess. Regardless of the story, it is enjoyable, as pretty much all Western games don't have such an original approach to story telling, plot and setting.  

Even though it's a port, maybe it's one of the best PC ports out there. It is capped at 60 fps, however, the cinematic filters employed make it that a 30fps experience is pleasant, even though this statement is an anithesis of what I have learned since the first 3dfx card came out. 
It's a well done and well optimized port.

Graphics are amazing! 

Controls are weird. After a while they become more natural, but still, it's noticeably done for console and then tweaked a bit for PC. 

Animations, sound design and attention to detail, wow, top-notch. 

It's a demo. It's small. Buy it now while on sale.

review:
What can I say? It's a Metal Gear Solid game, and one of the most beautiful, at that. This may not be a full game, but you're not buying it at a full game's price. This is a fantastic prologue, and I can't wait for Phantom Pain!

What has been put into this game is WELL worth the $13-20 dollars. There are SEVEN missions (not one like most people say) with both normal and hard difficulties for all of them.

review:
This seems to be more of a tech demo of the fox engine then a full Metal Gear game, but that doesn't mean it's not good.

Ground Zeroes gives you a taste of what is to come in Phantom Pain. 

Everything you like about MGS is still there, sneaking and stealth, but you can also go guns blazing.
AI is still not very smart. But the huge open make up for it. 

Performance wise it also runs very well, and looks good too.

For 13€ on steam it's a steal.

review:
If you are a fan of the franchise...get this game. This is done in very much the same spirit as the Silent Hills P.T, only in a very different setting (obviously) and with much more content (side missions and such). It is chock full of Kojima brilliance as you might expect and is sure to whet your appetite for The Phantom Pain. 

 The main mission for me only happened to only be about an hour long of solid game play, but that's because I somehow managed to breezily stumble through it like some drunken spy. I didn't do much in the way of exploration or score hunting, but there is plenty of that if you feel up to the challenge. It is certainly replayable, to say the least. A couple of things that didn't feel right to me, though, were the items and item cycling system, as well as the cover system. As far as items go, I didn't seem to find many things I could use or wanted to use and the cycling system didn't work well for me because, for one, it was 'different' than past installments, and, secondly, it was actually hard to move through it (I either couldn't figure out how to keep it "still" or it just wasn't possible to do so). For the cover system, my complaints aren't that it was difficult to get into cover, as I felt that I was able to very fluidly posistion myself up against whatever objectI was using as cover. The difficulties I experienced were related to sticking/posistioning and moving whilst in cover already. I constantly found myself "falling off" of objects and had a hard time navigating when pressed against something. I should mention I played with an Xbox controller (controls were "confusing" at first, but I got used to it) and that may have had an effect on my abilty to traverse cover.

That being said, I don't feel like you'll miss out if you chose to not play GROUND ZEROES and opt to go right into The Phantom Pain. It's nice if you're a fan and love the MG franchise (like myself), but you're likely to be dissapointed if you're new to the series and are looking for a game to play. Wait for The Phantom Pain if you're in the latter category. In fact, if you're new, brace yourself...because you're late as hell to an expansive and story rich game series.

Enjoy!


Edit: I should also mention that this game, from a technical standpoint, is gorgeous and plays very very smoothly. I don't have the best PC in the world and was worried I'd have performance issues (heh) but was pleasantly surprised that I experienced nothing of the sort. This was run on a mix of medium/high settings and I run a GeForce 650 (don't laugh). Excellence from Kojima as always.

Edit 2:
So, I've played a lot more since I wrote the review. I have to say, all the bonus content and awesome Kojima easter eggs are so so satisfying. I have, at about the 5-6 hour mark, beaten all the missions (not unlocked everything). This is still definitely a must for MGS fans. Do yourself a favor and play this. It's a very satisfying experience.

review:
My Metal Gear is done Rising, now its Solid. 

Also, the differance between "Model Detail High and Very High" is Snake's crack is more defined.

Really though, its great. I mean, the port is one of the best i've seen, it plays like a dream, and to all the people who said "Its too short", well, I've logged 30Hours on it, and I beat each mission, once. Jesus Christ, I really am bad at MGS

Reminds me why i say metal gear when people ask me my favourite game.

10/10 would play like a fiddle again

review: THANK YOU KOJIMA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This game is pretty fun and I have been waiting for a MGS to come to PC that wasnt a spin off. No offense to MGS:R, just I love snake and I really like the intuitive stealth. Regardless, the reason I am writing this review is to help some people who might have problems launching. I certaintly did. A fix I found to work the most was going to my steam follder and navigating to SteamApps\common\Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes. Once there I created a shortcut to my desktop of the MgsGroundZeroes.exe and then ran it as admin from my desktop. Before if I launched through Steam my desktop would sit blank and no hint of launch was there except, my portrait was green and said I was playing which I wasnt. Gameplay is pretty fun and I must admit even for a short intro they really did have a lot of content for 19.99 or if you were like me and snagged this at 13 and some change. Anyhow I reccomend this to anyone who loves stealth games. Story can be confusing, but they do have a backstory in this to catch you up!

review: A phanomenal PC port that looks better on my PC than it does on a PS4. A great game, too, especially for any fans of the series. The game takes place almost immediately after Peace Walker, so you need to at least know what happens to appreciate the story. Whilst the main story is only around 2 hours, there's quite a lot more to do afterwards. As a prologue to Phantom Pain, I'm beyond excited; Kojima seems to have a masterpiece on his hands here.

review:
With Japanese devlopers having bad PC ports this was a surprise to see.
With a single GTX970 I was able to have all settings at max and only once was below 60FPS which was in the opening cut-scene.
As for the game itself what you see is what you get an open world MGS game which means sneaking around and [strike]nanomachines[/strike] holding up people its what you expect however as you should know it is a short game as it is the prequel to Phantom Pain and acts like the Tanker Chapter in Metal Gear Solid 2.  However with its side-ops you may get some replay value out of it but just be aware it is possible to complete the main story in an hour (Without cut-scenes so add on an extra hour there).

review:
Short but sweet, Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a great prologue for Kojima's next full entry to the series. While it requires playing the PSP game Peace Walker for the story to make much sense, the gameplay is simple and deep enough for players new to the franchise to jump in. The port itself runs extremely well and shows that it has been carefully optimized for PC, with all sorts of settings for high end machines to take advantage of. The Fox Engine shines on PC, creating an absolutely gorgeous gaming experience. While the main campaign can be beaten in about 30 minutes, the extra missions, unlocks, and secrets keep you coming back for more.

Absolutely worth the purchase.

review: I don't usually review games here but feel I can do a service for all other PC-only gamers who, like me, might have heard of this franchise but never played it.  Ground Zeroes is an absolutely superb stealth game, quite obviously the work of a brilliant designer and the result of all that has gone before it in the series.  Obviously the key comparison is with Splinter Cell, but whereas I liked Blacklist a lot, GROUND ZEROES is an [i]open world[/i] stealth game, which means there is none of the heavy scripting and funneling that dominate the SC series.  In this game, you can make choices, like which LZ to use for helicopter exfil and which routes to take to any objective.  The controls, even on a PC port, are really well harmonised for KB/M and both the stealth and the combat dynamics are superb.  Great ambience, design and production values too.  It can be very unforgiving, as the AI feels very human and very sharp and, unlike in Splinter Cell, the game wants you to feel like one operative up against an army rather than an all-conquering specops ninja with a dozen gadgets; in this game you have your wits, an assault rifle with a silencer that will degrade through over use, a tranq gun and anything you can find.  Not only is it a superb game, it is a fine example of the art of game design and a slap in the face to Ubi and other corporate game publishers who dumb down tactical games in order to make the player feel like a bada$$.  For those who fear interminable cut-scenes, there are only a few and they are skippable.  It's not for everyone, as you need patience both to play the game and understand the remarkably convoluted story but highly recommended.
raw_json: {"recommendationid": "13457664", "author": {"steamid": "76561197970513346", "num_games_owned": 0, "num_reviews": 5, "playtime_forever": 1444, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 400, "last_played": 1527041496}, "language": "english", "review": "I don't usually review games here but feel I can do a service for all other PC-only gamers who, like me, might have heard of this franchise but never played it.  Ground Zeroes is an absolutely superb stealth game, quite obviously the work of a brilliant designer and the result of all that has gone before it in the series.  Obviously the key comparison is with Splinter Cell, but whereas I liked Blacklist a lot, GROUND ZEROES is an [i]open world[/i] stealth game, which means there is none of the heavy scripting and funneling that dominate the SC series.  In this game, you can make choices, like which LZ to use for helicopter exfil and which routes to take to any objective.  The controls, even on a PC port, are really well harmonised for KB/M and both the stealth and the combat dynamics are superb.  Great ambience, design and production values too.  It can be very unforgiving, as the AI feels very human and very sharp and, unlike in Splinter Cell, the game wants you to feel like one operative up against an army rather than an all-conquering specops ninja with a dozen gadgets; in this game you have your wits, an assault rifle with a silencer that will degrade through over use, a tranq gun and anything you can find.  Not only is it a superb game, it is a fine example of the art of game design and a slap in the face to Ubi and other corporate game publishers who dumb down tactical games in order to make the player feel like a bada$$.  For those who fear interminable cut-scenes, there are only a few and they are skippable.  It's not for everyone, as you need patience both to play the game and understand the remarkably convoluted story but highly recommended.", "timestamp_created": 1419023360, "timestamp_updated": 1419023360, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 4, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.545454561710357666", "comment_count": 1, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: I had some trouble getting my controller to work at first, but after I figured out the problem it was smooth sailing. It's a very well optimized port, I get a constant 60 frames per second at the highest settings possible at 1080p with a i5-4670k CPU and GTX 760 card. It looks amazing, too, definitely some of the best graphics I've seen from a console port. As for the game itself, the main mission is pretty short, but there are a few more missions to do afterwards. The gameplay is amazing, by far the best in the series. Overall if you're a big Metal Gear Solid fan, this is an absolute must play game if you want even a taste of next year's Phantom Pain.

review:
The game has more than one mission. Anyone who says otherwise isn't paying attention. Each mission takes about 15 minutes or so to complete unless you suck at stealth like me then you'll get about an hour playtime each mission.

Game is well optimised, plays like a damn fiddle.
Nanomachine free and is all round fun like all the previous Metal Gear Solid games.

Would reccomend. Only issue is that the game hates controllers. Often times it will not work, buttons are switched and I can't seem to work out why.

review:
Just a demo version of Phantom Pain that you have to pay for.
But a great demo at that.
All you get is a small area that you can treat like a sandbox. Main objective lasts for about 30 minutes, but there are other objectives after that and achievements you can unlock. Cool way to wait for Phantom Pain. Affordable at a discount, not really worth it for the full initial price though.
The content is good. PC version has all the stuff that consoles had released, so overall, It can suffice for quite few hours altoghether. 
It doesn't FEEL like a full game though. Grapics are quite decent at max, but not overly spectacular.
The biggest shortcoming I would notice, is that it looks very similiar to Splinter Cell at this point, but it didn't loose all the MGS feel yet.

It makes me want to get my hands on Phantom Pain even more though. I'd rate this 8/10, 9/10 If you liked to follow the (twisted) MGS storylines... AND 7/10 if you include how much time you actually get to spend with the title, over a small military base.

Oh, and it loads surprisingly fast. Seriously, seconds.

I recommend getting this demo, but at  discount. :)

review:
It's really a welcome sight to see the latest MGS game by Hideo Kojima on PC and on steam.
I have to say the game engine s really paying off, specially for graphics which runs smooth on ultra high options on my N56VZ.
But for what I'm experiencing the gameplay controls aren't feeling as smooth as MGS4. I also played it on PS3 & PS4 (hands up for the mouse aiming). So I have to say it requires some more tweeking and also some bug fixes.
In the end I have to say it's a good start, but lots of features are to be presented in the Phantom Pain, so we play while we wait...

review:
A very well done port though very short game.

Pros: 
[list]
[*]Everything you love about MGS franchise, the sneaking and stealth is nicely done.
[*]Voice acting, narrative, the drama, back story.
[*]Well done port ( runs smooth for me in High settings )
[*]See snake's shiny 4ss in 1080p
[/list]
Cons: 
[list]
[*] 1/single map
[*] Short game ( you can finish the game in 30 mins or less for the main mission )
[/list]

Bought the game on sale and you should too as this is just an introduction for the Phantom Pain.

review:
Don't let the ridiculously semi-high minimum system requirements scare you from getting this game. As a long-time Metal Gear fan, I took the risk of getting this even when my desktop was below the minimum reqs (Except RAM. hue)

My specs as of this writing:

OS: Windows 7 Ultimate x64
Processor: AMD A8-3850 Quad (~2.9GHz)
Video card: Radeon HD-6570 2GB
RAM: 4GB DDR3

I can run the game on High while still making the FPS managable (As in I can still move, aim, and fire properly)

For the game. To make things short.
Buy it. Play it. Love it. It cost quite a bit, but it's worth it, possibly more. The ONLY thing I didn't like about GZ is only one main mission, but as we all know, GZ is more a demo than a full game, so we can expect more, a lot more, when Phantom Pain comes out.

Overall. Great game/demo. Great graphics. Great mechanics. Long main mission (Takes from an hour or more, depending on the player) and a lot of fun Side Missions (Ops) to mess around with after the main mission.

11/10

Buy it. Play it. Love it. It cost quite a bit, but it's worth it, possibly more. The ONLY thing I didn't like about GZ is only one main mission, but as we all know, GZ is more a demo than a full game, so we can expect more, a lot more, when Phantom Pain comes out.

Overall. Great game/demo. Great graphics. Great mechanics. Long main mission (Takes from an hour or more, depending on the player) and a lot of fun Side Missions (Ops) to mess around with after the main mission.

review: It is so nice to be able to play a pc port that actually feels like it was intended to be played on the pc. This game runs so smooth and includes a wide variety of graphics options to fit many different pc setups. And it looks amazing. I have already mastered this game on the PS4, but I got it again on PC mostly to see how well the Fox Engine handles pc. It runs like a dream. I was able to get about 45 FPS at 4K on my GTX 980, but I could barely notice a difference. So running it at 1080p with 60 FPS was the best solution for me. All settings maxed out, of course. Combine all of that with the fact that this game launched at $13, and you have an amazing deal.

review:
FAIR WARNING: There is only one level you play on. It's basically a Demo

While I was upset at first; I really did enjoy it. But here is the issue; we shouldn't be paying for demos. If anything; this should have been free. What I do hope for is that Konami gives some sort of 'Bonus' to everyone who purchased this or at least the funding will go to developing the upcoming game; making it that much more amazing.

Overall; from what I have seen; the upcoming game will be a Game Of The Year hands down.

It makes me wish Splinter Cell had Prone like this game.

review:
This is an amazing port from the console versions of the game with enhanced visuals such as screen based reflections and an increased number of simultaneous lights on screen at once. I only have a medium spec gaming rig, but this game runs very well on maximum settings. Despite the length of the main mission, this game has loads of replay value with the side missions and all the collectible story tapes and unlocks. 

This game also serves as an amazing prologue for The Phantom Pain, creating an enticing transition into the larger game set to come out next year.

Explosions everywhere when gunfire starts like a badass movie, Enemys have diffrint patterns in response to what happens or there suroundings, Dramtic short story line, Good Pc Port. A lot of effort is put into this small packed demo with some replay ablity for side-ops. For this games play time length is not long, but is a well exucted part demo of the game. Wait untill theres a Sale or a price drop for the demo. at it's price of $20 is not worth it compared to other tiles on Steam, but this is well worth it for whats to come in the full game when it comes out.

Update:
There seems to be some sort of glitch error with the controller mapping like the A button Becomes the B Button for some reason, Try disabling your Steam sync cloud and that should fix your controller mapping and check  the intergrity of steam files in propertys just to be sure.

Looking at the minimum requirements, you'd think this game will never run fine on anything but the top PC gear. However, the good news is that it turns out not to be the case. Mine is a reliable but old setup: AMD HD6950 2GB GPU, with an Intel i5-3570K OC'd to a safe 4.2GHz and 8GB DDR3 RAM. 

The game looks gorgeous and still runs at a smooth 60FPS on 1080p, with most settings on Extra High, except for the various Filters and Shadows, which I left on High, as they seemed to cause occasional drops. Not a big problem, but if you have a better and newer GPU than mine, I believe you won't encounter the slightest issue at this resolution, as the stress definitely isn't on the CPU.

Speaking of another aspect of the port, the mouse+keyboard controls are—for the most part—done really well. If you can get past having to use exclusively your keyboard on the various menu screens, I'd say the controls are pretty intuitive once you have spent a few minutes on them. I also must say I've never expected to enjoy playing a MGS game using anything other than a gamepad, but I've been proven wrong.

The other advantage of having this game on PC seems to be given by the versatility and overall quality of the Fox Engine, which people have taken very little time to exploit in forms of texture and/or model replacements that yield results such as being able to play as Chico or Kaz against soldiers resembling Big Boss, or something as absurd as replacing the crows' model for a human one, which looks as funny as it sounds. Before long, we may have fully fledged mods that add up to the game or even become games of their own, one baby step at a time. 

As for the game itself, it has one main mission which will take you anything from 20 minutes to 2 hours to complete, depending on your approach and expertise. Its function is to set the stage for the upcoming Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain, and it's the only mission with relevance to the plot. Of course, there are side and extra missions which will keep you busy for a few more hours if gameplay is what you're mainly looking for.

I would recommend this technically very good port to any long-standing fan of the Metal Gear Solid franchise who doesn't mind a bit of redundancy in terms of overall setting on the way of some nice fan service extras. I can't particularly recommend it to newcomers, as it doesn't really give the best of ideas of what the franchise is about, and it might be a tad confusing for someone who hasn't followed the storyline. 

To those, I would definitely recommend looking back to the older titles, most of which (excluding the rather important original Metal Gear Solid, in fact) can be found in the HD collection for PS3, PSVita and Xbox 360, if you have a console. Special mention goes to Metal Gear Solid 3 (originally released on PS2), which is a masterfully crafted installment that narrates the story of how Big Boss came to be.

A final aspect I would reflect upon is whether the current price tag is worth it for the average consumer. If you have slight doubts, I'd in fact hold off and wait for a sale, as the upcoming title will definitely steal the show and provide much more valuable content than this. [b]Edit:[/b] I was quite wrong. This chapter remains a good instalment, however.

review:
Awesome PC port, it runs at a constant 60 FPS with no drops with most settings on extra high and every other setting on high on my 750ti. It is locked at 60FPS, which isn't a problem for most people with a 60hz monitor, but it is a tad disapointing for people like me that have a 144hz monitor, but it's by no means a dealbreaker.

As for the game itself, it's awesome! Obviously the main mission is short but it really does have lots of replay value. It's actually incredibly fun to just screw around in the open world on some of the side missions. The animations are some of the best I've seen in any game, and there's an incredible amount of detail in Snake's movements that you won't see in any other 3rd person game.

This game definitely exceeded in getting me excited for The Phantom Pain, and you're crazy to not get it for 20$, let alone the 13$ sale price.

Runs great, plays great, can even run on my laptop.
If you are a Metal Gear Fan, you will want this game.


Only two caveats I could think of: David Hayter is gone (tears, so many tears), and the game is really short.

Also note: They added a slow motion ability when you get caught which makes it very easy to shoot everyone in the head - this could be considered dumbing down the game, but I personally like this feature.

review:
An absolutely incredible experience for an incredible price. There's no doubt that most people will feel shunned at the fact that this is a prologue to the main game "The Phantom Pain", but I think it's well worth the money. 

You get a large map with various missions, trials, collectibles and hidden extras that MGS fans have come to love. There's also some very nice cutscenes to introduce you to some of the characters that will feature in the main game. Even if you aren't an MGS fan this game is a very nice introduction to the series and allows you to really understand the mechanics of the games. I've completed all 6 missions after 7 hours but I'm only 43% complete. 

The graphics are incredible and the performance is incredible (it's very well optimised). There's actually very little I can criticize apart from the fact that it ends.

It's Metal Gear. By this point, you'll know if you'll love it or not.

My opinion on this one: Great controls, Graphics, Story and much fun to be had.

Definately around 50-100 hours of content for me to enjoy here - So many different ways to approach scenarios.

Being able to unlock PS1 Snake and Grey Fox?

Kiefer Sutherland playing Snake? At first I thought this would be terrible but after giving it a go? You can definately see why this became a thing.

Great price for a great game.

It's not a demo, even though it gives you just enough content to be dying for more.

Glad to see PC finally getting some love after MGS2.

Hopefully Konami will port over Peace Walker and MGS3 so that we can enjoy them (Even if they were straight ports).

11/10 would lemongrab again.

review:
Metal Gear Solid. 'Nuff Said.

However...

Metal Gear Solid 4 was a system seller for me. It's WHY I bought a Playstation 3. However there's literally nothing Sony can do to sell me a Playstation product anymore so even this near demo coming out on Steam is amazing for me.
Currently running a core 2 duo with 6 GB of DDR2 & a GeForce GTX 650 TI I wasn't actually expecting this game to run. However it runs... it runs very well in fact. With the game chosen settings of mostly medium settings with a couple high settings the game has demonstrated no lag what so ever so far. 
Running better then any other action military game has for awhile on my system I'm very pleased. It runs MUCH better than Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon: Future Soldier does & Call Of Duty: Advanced Warfare on this system is just a bad joke.
Even runs better then Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist but not amazingly better.
So far it feels & controls exactly like I expect a Metal Gear Solid game to do. The back story option on the menu is also very welcome since I have not finished Snake Eater at all (seriously screw escort missions in a military combat action game...). Also I have hardly played any of the newer Metal Gear products... just a bit of time (not even 1/4 of the game) in the PS3 HD collection meaning I've lost track of the story line long ago.
This is the right product for the price (including the -33% daily deal on that is... full $20 is pushing it but I would have bought anyways since it's MGS) however it is a limited scope; I haven't explored too far yet however the map does seem a bit small.
Over all... 9/10 stars but only because it's basically a demo with a small map. 
And Kojima? Make MGS 4 & HD collection for PC please... I'll give you my first born child (Note: I do not & probably will never have children).

You have set the bar for PC ports.
This runs amazingly and in my opinion has some of the best graphics I have seen yet.

And there was me thinking a Japanese company was going to deliver us a shoddy port, shame on me!

review:
I'm pleasantly surprised to find that there is much more content here than what the internet has been claiming since it's release. $30 is certainly too much for it, but the price now is more than fair for what you get.

There is one main story mission, but there are other side missions with story sprinkled in. It sort of reminds me of the VR missions from the old games, or the post-finale missions from Peace Walker.

According to my completion percentage, I'm 5 hours in and only 25% done. If you are interested in the Metal Gear series, this is worth your time.

I had to ask myself the question, 'Is this a PC game?' when I enter the main menu and attempted to navigate to the options menu only to find the cursor unavailable to use. Luckily, I did get a proper response using the arrow keys which I then use to navigate to the control type submenu, thinking I would be able to fix the mouse problem there. However all it revealed was a controller map with its function legends, and the other submenus had nothing revelant to do about the use of a fucking basic PC input device: The Mouse. Also I shouldn't need to know about controller instructions when I don't have one plugged in.

Anyway I began the game with no knowlegde of its backstory; I didn't play any of the MGS games nor do I want to read the backstory text in a video game, because I assume that a 95% positively rated game with a Story Rich tag and seemingly high production budget will provide an in-game cinematic storytelling. Nope. I was horribly offended when the credits began to roll because I have no clue who the protagonist 'Boss' was and why he was tasked with the mission on the island and how he was relevant to Scarface and his entourage and to the 'plot'. No I don't want to read Wikipedia or listen to tapes or read in game text, also for 11 pounds I want a story not a crappily stitched draft or island sandbox demo. Since the game did not tell a story I did not care for the characters and the franchise itself. 1/10 - waste of money and time. Play the last splinter cell game if you actually want a comprehensive story, dialog, animation and stealth/tatical shooter.

review:
I haven't completed the main mission yet, but good lord I am astonished. The game engine must be running on witchcraft, because even on high settings this game runs as smooth as silk. As for the gameplay, it's quite interesting so far. The last MGS game I played was MGS2, so understandably this is completely different to what i'm used to, but it actually does a good job of introducing you to the open world gameplay before letting you go off on your own.

Oh, and yeah, I miss David Hayter as Snake, but fortunately Keifer Sutherland does a good enough job. Admittedly I was quite worried that, being a screen actor, he would end up phoning it in (like most other screen actors do when attempting voiceover work). But no, he commits to the part and does a good job, so thank god for that.

To end this review, so far I would highly recommend getting this, if only in the hopes that it would convince Konami to release more MGS games on the PC (or at the least re-release the PC ports of MGS1 and MGS2).
F5ing dudes off guard towers to their death.

It's actually a good port too, loads of options for da grafx and fully rebindable keys if you're not using a gamepad which you should be using.

To conclude, get hyped for phantom pain.

review:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is a prologue to The Phantom Pain, and it gives a taste of what we should expect from it. It's a short game with only a handful of missions, but if you're a perfectionist, you're gonna spend more than a few hours playing it.

So, what can I say about Ground Zeroes? First and foremost, I'm really impressed with the production quality. The visuals are well detailed and beautiful, the VA is top notch (huge fan of Kiefer Sutherland), gameplay is excellent, animations are really well done and don't feel choppy like the ones in Splinter Cell: Blacklist. Level design is really good and allow multiple ways of completing mission objectives.

The enemy AI is quite good and the enemies don't feel like dumb robots that can't see you moving right in front of their eyes. They will perform searches and communicate with each other to some degree, like when the spotlight guy detects you and ask nearby soldiers to investigate. When you get spotted and they raise the alert level, you'll see lots of enemies converging to your last known position and start looking for you, and that's something I like to see in this kind of game.

On a technical level, this is a really good port. It runs silky smooth at 60fps with all the bells and whistles on my average rig - i5 3570k, 16GB RAM, GTX 760. The mouse/keyboard controls are surprisingly good and the default mapping is efficient and comfortable. It's not perfect tho: you can't use the mouse pointer to navigate menus, you must use your keyboard.

Overall, it's worth every penny I paid for it, and I can't wait for The Phantom Pain!

Pros:
- fantastic port
- very well optimized
- very good keyboard/mouse controls
- it's a major MGS game on PC!!

Cons:
- lack of mouse input to navigate menus

review:
Runs surprisingly well even with such great graphic fidelity. System Requirements on the store page is hugely overblown as a 6 year old rig could probably run it well enough. For reference, I can run this on my i7 860 and HD7850 on High at 60 fps with no frame drop or stuttering whatsoever.

Story is very short and will leave you craving for TPP. 


..And the Paz's Diary section will make you want to beat Chico repeatedly in the face with a mallet.

A truly next generation game for the PC. If you are any kind fan of stealth games, sneaking games or just Metal Gear Solid, then this is a definite "must buy" for you. Although, this MGSV Prologue is short, it's a taste for what's to come. Do yourself a favor.... play this game. 10/10

review:
It's a good port, BUT like every port, and every game, it has it's pros and cons.
PROS:
It's becautiful, compared to some AAA games of recent
It runs well, on a 3 year old PC I managed to get 60FPS with a mix of high and medium settings
Mouse controls are good
As an MGS fan, my snake was solid, 10/10 would Fission mail again

CONS:
It's obviously a console port, the menus are almost entirely keyboard controlled
This is like paying £12 for a DLC, it's just one mission.
Ai is a bit thick, and there's no real indicator of what they are doing, so you're stuck guessing

Overall, I'm not unhappy that I bought this, though I'd much rather have saved this money for the full release, Phantom Pain. Get it if you are in need of something to hold you over till the real MGS V comes out.

review:
The performance in this game is fantastic. 60fps with high settings is not a problem, even with budget builds. However, the controls in this game SUCKS. But by controls, I don't mean the actual gameplay (IT'S GREAT), the port just doesn't support 5+ button mouses and X1 controllers. The camera keeps zooming upwards with the X1 controller and I can't seem to find a fix for that. The 360 controller seems to run just fine, but the button prompts seems to be in Japanese (using B instead of A and X means going back). It's pretty confusing I just gave up after about half an hour. 

Overall, if you're a M&K guy who doesn't use 5+ button mouses, you should be fine because you can rebind your keys and the game runs brilliantly. But, if you're like me, and prefers to make use of the controllers or 5+ button mouses, you're going to be a frustrated.

Gameplay is smooth as butter and has the freedom we've come to expect from a MGS with all the added depth of an open world. It's short (although replayable) and rather lacking in story or plot but it's reasonably priced.

A shame though it could not be just a demo, if it was this would have been one of the best demos in the history of gaming.

review:
As a lifetime MGS fan i gotta say, this game is all i have hoped for.
Biggest surprise: This game controls beautifully with KB and Mouse. The MGS Series was one of the few I'd always considered to better be played with a controller, this game proved me wrong. 
Everything about this game feels premium, unlike the shallow Triple A titles Ubisoft likes to pump out.
I finished my first playthrough with 8%, can't wait to dive back in.
Only downside will be, after finishing this, waiting for Phantom Pain will be even harder.
(Oh, I actually found a flaw, I miss Snakes old voice actor.)

review:
For MGS Fan, its worth it. 

And its included the exclusive xbox and playstation mission, the Deja Vu and Jamais Vu by collection the XOF badge. So yea. 

Great port, run great on my 2012 system with high setting. Only control got a bit cluncky when I'm trying to put down a body. Maybe because I'm using controller or idk. Oh well, still a great game.

GROUND ZEROES is a fantastic achievement from Kojima Productions, not just in regards to its excellent world buliding, game mechanics and storytelling, but also with respect to the excellent PC release.  Regarding the game itself, it's excellent albeit brief.  If the idea of replaying missions to try alternate strategies or to beat your score, it's probably best to hold off for the main dish when PHANTOM PAIN is released next year.  If you enjoy replaying missions, self-improvement and pushing at the seams of open world gameplay, then GROUND ZEROES is an absolute must-play. The only point of contention I experienced in my first play-through of the main mission – which took around 80 minutes, but I plan on doing it at least 3 or 4 more times, not to mention the 6 or so side missions you can unlock – were some aspects of the storytelling. I won't go into it too much here, but there's reason for healthy discussion on the game's treatment of its sole female character.

The PC version of the game is rock solid.  I'm not sure why they released the minimum requirements they did; I'm a mix of above and below and the game ran at nearly 60FPS at 900P (2013 rMBP w/GeForce 750m, 16GB RAM, Core i7 2.3GHz). Controls are excellent and the game has a healthy selection of graphics options.

Overall I can see myself returning to this small but exquisitely crafted game many, many times.  It's a ton of fun and easily the best controlling Metal Gear Solid ever released. I don't regret splittling with $15 for the experience and I simply can't wait until I get my hands on THE PHANTOM PAIN next year (Note to the developers: *please* release the PC version at the same time as the consoles).

review:
Let's get the popular opinion out of the way first, the game is shorter than the old MGS1 demo from demo disk in a PC Gamer magazine. Pretty disappointing, seriously. Dropped the ball hard.

That aside, it keeps the same feel as Metal Gear games historically have. In my 57 minute playthrough, the story flows nicely and is exciting to follow. Controls are decent and the game looks fantastic (aside from Depth of Field focusing being jacked up). My biggest complaint (aside from the game being short as balls) is the loss of David Hayter as Snake's rugged voice actor and will take some getting used to in Phantom Pain. 

Do I recommend this game? Yes-- if you're a Metal Gear fan. If you've never played a Metal Gear, I would recommend skipping on this until it's no less than 75% off and either going back to the old games (which have aged quite nicely aside from MGS1-- yet still good) or jumping straight into Phantom Pain when it becomes available.

Amazing!! Kojima team optimized very well the game for pc. Is working perfectly. And of course is an excelent game.

I'm very happy and I truly recommend.

Thank you Hideo Kojima!

review:
Amazingly optimized PC version, there's a few control gripes with mouse and keyboard and I wish there were more Anti-Aliasing options, and worst of all you can't import your own music onto your helicopter like you can with the PS3 and PS4 versions (That's such a fucking bummer, seriously) but that is the extent of my complaints with the port. I'm so glad I waited out this PC version instead of buying it for my PS3.

The game's [i]main story mission[/i] is rather short and yet I don't feel ripped off, the kind of people who say you can "Beat this" in 2 hours don't know what they're talking about; Sure that's the time it takes to complete the main mission in this, but after you complete that you're only 7% finished with this game. It's like how the real meat of Platinum games isn't "Finishing them" but S ranking everything. And besides, the best shit in the game is when you find all of the XOF badges and get Jamais Vu and Deja Vu. Deja Vu is a trip down nostalgia lane for sure, and even has a quiz that only MGS fans would be able to complete. When you get all of the answers right, you get to use the classic solid snake skin and it's awesome; Complete it on hard difficulty and you get tougher, more obscure questions that if you answer correctly you get the Gray Fox skin.

After playing this, my hype for TPP increased 7 fold, and I hope that the success of this game on PC will eventually lead to MGS HD collection making it's way to steam. (Please Konami, nothing would make me happier than being able to play Peace Walker cooperative play with my steam friends, and you've already proved you can publish a good PC port.)
