review:
Alright, so it's finally here, and we PC gamers have been waiting for this - a solid MGS port. Now's our shot to show Kojima's efforts to make this (very polished) port was not in vain and to continue looking to PC gaming as a viable market for the series.

Onto the game:

So it's short. It's meant to be a prologue to the upcoming MGS V: The Phantom Pain, so don't expect a full-fledged game. This takes place after MGS Peacewalker, but it does have a decent little backstory section to catch you up to speed since MGS3. 

It's a AAA series, and the pricetag should reflect that it's really more of a teaser. The pricetag might be a little steep for some considering the lack of content, but don't let that scare you off if you're a fan of the series. It's got a lot of replay value and tons of little side missions to keep you entertained. If you've never played an MGS game before,  might not want to jump right into this one, so if you've got the option to do so, go ahead and play the series. It's a great one, I promise. This series was my childhood right here.

So it's short but replayable, and currently on sale for $13.39. What makes it worth it?

For starters, it's optimized perfectly. I can run this totally maxed on my rig (which isn't the best, but it's certainly pretty good) at 45-60fps stable, and the graphics look absolutely phenomenal. It's very cutting-edge, especially when you see how the cutscenes are rendered in the game engine. No pre-rendered garbage here - it's all done in Kojima's shiny new Fox Engine. Tacking onto that, it has 4k support, for those with the hardware. That might be of interest to people who have that capability, but even on my 1080 monitor, this game looks just gorgeous. The screenshots I'm sure you'll see on the store page and by other users don't lie - it's great. The graphics options are there, no worries. We've got a good array of choices to tweak how this game looks, so Kojima certainly delivered there.

Other than that, the controls are a concern for many, I'm sure. A keyboard and mouse might seem a little odd for an MGS game, but take my word for it PLEASE - it works so well here. It all feels smooth and very natural - the keys are right where you'd expect them to be and you can easily rebind them to your liking. The game also has controller support for those who fancy that, but I can't say I've personally tried it. Basically: the controls wil work for you no matter what medium you choose.

So the main story may be short and easy to burn through, the side ops aren't extremely plentiful (Although they're fun as hell, seriously), but the game is extremely well-done all around. At a sale like the one currently, it's a steal for anyone looking to enjoy the game on a new medium. This is how PC ports should be done. Kojima Productions set a high standard for any company looking to port a console game to PC.

I did have an issue, by the way, launching the game where it would never open when I'd launch it. Some say removing gaming peripherals fixed this, others say running it at 800x600 to start it up helped, others had to install the redistributed files and reboot. For me, a simple reboot fixed my issues and I'm currently enjoying the game just fine.

I'm sure those will be patched ASAP, but there's that for those who run into any of those issues. Check the forums, lots of people are listing many fixes for these launch bugs. Little disappointing, but I think the game itself makes up for the small hiccups (Maybe it was just rushed a little to get it out for day one of the winter sales?)

Anyway, long story short: Here's our shot to show Kojima his work to bring this game to PC is a smart one. If you're a fan of the series and want to show Kojima that we're a viable market, don't hesitate. Even if you own it on another platform, it's worth having this gem in your library. You won't regret it. It runs like a dream and keeps you entertained for a good while. I spend most of my time taking great eye-candy screenshots, and with a game like this, I'm sure you will, too.

It's not without some launch flaws and it's certainly not a massive MGS title (And the pricetag may look a little steep for what you're getting) but I have to say, I don't regret it. It feels like MGS has found a new home: my PC library where it belongs.

For starters, it's optimized perfectly. I can run this totally maxed on my rig (which isn't the best, but it's certainly pretty good) at 45-60fps stable, and the graphics look absolutely phenomenal. It's very cutting-edge, especially when you see how the cutscenes are rendered in the game engine. No pre-rendered garbage here - it's all done in Kojima's shiny new Fox Engine. Tacking onto that, it has 4k support, for those with the hardware. That might be of interest to people who have that capability, but even on my 1080 monitor, this game looks just gorgeous. The screenshots I'm sure you'll see on the store page and by other users don't lie - it's great. The graphics options are there, no worries. We've got a good array of choices to tweak how this game looks, so Kojima certainly delivered there.

Other than that, the controls are a concern for many, I'm sure. A keyboard and mouse might seem a little odd for an MGS game, but take my word for it PLEASE - it works so well here. It all feels smooth and very natural - the keys are right where you'd expect them to be and you can easily rebind them to your liking. The game also has controller support for those who fancy that, but I can't say I've personally tried it. Basically: the controls wil work for you no matter what medium you choose.

So the main story may be short and easy to burn through, the side ops aren't extremely plentiful (Although they're fun as hell, seriously), but the game is extremely well-done all around. At a sale like the one currently, it's a steal for anyone looking to enjoy the game on a new medium. This is how PC ports should be done. Kojima Productions set a high standard for any company looking to port a console game to PC.

I did have an issue, by the way, launching the game where it would never open when I'd launch it. Some say removing gaming peripherals fixed this, others say running it at 800x600 to start it up helped, others had to install the redistributed files and reboot. For me, a simple reboot fixed my issues and I'm currently enjoying the game just fine.

I'm sure those will be patched ASAP, but there's that for those who run into any of those issues. Check the forums, lots of people are listing many fixes for these launch bugs. Little disappointing, but I think the game itself makes up for the small hiccups (Maybe it was just rushed a little to get it out for day one of the winter sales?)

Anyway, long story short: Here's our shot to show Kojima his work to bring this game to PC is a smart one. If you're a fan of the series and want to show Kojima that we're a viable market, don't hesitate. Even if you own it on another platform, it's worth having this gem in your library. You won't regret it. It runs like a dream and keeps you entertained for a good while. I spend most of my time taking great eye-candy screenshots, and with a game like this, I'm sure you will, too.

It's not without some launch flaws and it's certainly not a massive MGS title (And the pricetag may look a little steep for what you're getting) but I have to say, I don't regret it. It feels like MGS has found a new home: my PC library where it belongs.", "timestamp_created": 1419001755, "timestamp_updated": 1419001755, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
This review might be biased because I consider $13 a good deal. Please ignore if you think $13 is a lot.
 
About 2 hrs for the main mission but still an enjoyable one. This game, Ground Zeroes, is just a teaser/intro to The Phantom Pain, but that doesn't mean it's not worth the time. It brings a whole new aspect to MGS where you get to play like a maniac without getting killed so easily, which will be a negative to the die-hard MGS fans. The game has a mixed bag of feelings to that of FPS shooters and uncharted/tomb raider, which may or may not be a good thing for some people - in my opinion, it's a bad thing. 

It feels like the peak of the franchise was somewhere between MGS3 and MGS4, and MGS5 (at least for Ground Zeroes) was a step down in game mechanics. Even for a short game, the story is actually good and I'm happy the game didn't stray away from this aspect. Since this game is a 1 mission prologue to MGS:TPP, I'm hoping TPP brings back things like food gathering and collection kits for weapons/first aid.

Graphics are ok, not great; a single GTX670 with a slight overclock can max this game at 1080p 60FPS. Even so, the game still looks nice enough to pass.

I'm still trying to 100% the game so this review will be edited when it's done. For now, even with only the main game completed, I'd still recommend it; especially at the low cost of ~$13 on release.

review: Spent a good few hours on this for the PS4, but not really a swell idea as a re-purchase. Game is a fantastic port, but does feel clunky with a keyboard and mouse, which is gonna happen with 3rd person shooters. Although short, it offers a grand amount of playtime but requires patience and none of that guns a' blazing crap. I'd hold off 'til the Phantom Pain for your stealth fix if you've bought this game for the consoles, but I'd say it's a good amount of hours spent at least trying the game so you know what to expect in the new game.

review:
Pros:

-Amazing visuals. This is what a 'next-gen' game is supposed to look like. Hats off to Kojima's artists, they really earned their paychecks here. From the modelling, animations, texturing, etc. It all comes together beautifully.

-Tight controls. Gone are the days from older games where you had to check a menu just to figure out all sorts of button press combinations just to do semi-secret moves regarding CQC and such. It's been streamlined in a manner that's much more quick to pull off, without feeling overly trivialized.

-Solid gameplay. At no point did it ever feel janky or 'cheap'. Everything behaves in ways you ought to expect it, from how your character interacts with the environment, to the handling of weapons and the behaviour of your enemy.

-A couple of new tricks up Snake's sleeve. Interrogations and such are now a neat little thing.

-Lots of side-content. I didn't realize until I beat the game that you end up unlocking tons of side missions after the fact that you can play after, which is a good thing, because of a point I'll be getting to in the cons.


Cons:
-It's short. Like. SUPER short. Way shorter than you'd think, even for a 15 dollar AAA game. If you knew what you were doing and didn't mind shooting your way through objectives, you could beat the entire 'main' game in 15-20 minutes easily. It took me roughly an hour and a half on my first playthrough, and that's because I went the wrong way initially and had to double back through the entire map.

-Stealth is kind of a joke. There isn't much punishment for getting spotted, and if you've ever played a third person shooter before, you can go guns blazing through this no problem. It's steath elements are merely a suggestion for the sake of challenge, rather than necessity, and thus, this isn't a real stealth game. This is action-adventure.

-Easy difficulty in general. There just isn't much in the way of punishment in this game, and it gives you too many means of just rambo'ing your way through should you mess up. Reflex time is a dumb addition clearly meant to hold the hands of newer players, but when you make such concessions, how do you expect new players to ever learn and improve? This little 'feature' can be turned off in options, but unfortunately it's on by default and you must go looking for it. Oh, did I also mention 'regenerating health' is now a thing? You can already bet your boots that Phantom Pain's online component is going to have unlock progression at this rate. Too many 'modern gaming industry' gimmicks sour the gameplay experience by removing all tension from stealth and combat.

-Ending cutscenes deprive you of interaction at some really cool segments. I wont drop any spoilers, but there will be points at the end when you scratch your head and ask yourself "Why don't I get to play this part? Why am I watching the game have it's own fun?"

-Story wise, the game assumes you've played the more obscure titles on the PSP, a handheld that, frankly, not many people even owned in the first place. If games like Peacewalker were made available on consoles and PC, it would serve rather well to dispel some of the confusion of the plot that is loosely explained in text snippets that you have to look up on your own in the main menu outside of the in-game experience.

Overall:

I had a great deal of fun with this, even with some of it's shortcomings, they paled in comparison to the overall potential of the game. With only 8% completion after beating the 'main course', I've got a decent amount of replayability to knock out before I can truly write this game off as 'done'. While I'm not completely sold on this model of game distribution just yet due to how long it's taking to get Phantom Pain out, I can honestly say this game is worth the $14 dollar price tag it's asking for while on sale at the moment. On it's surface, it's got a 'demo' feel to it, but once you dive into some of the offered extra content, you're getting more bang for your buck than the typical 15 dollar indie zombie survival minecraft rip-off trite that gets regurgitated out of Greenlight at around this price range. I know one thing though: This game is a quantum-powered hype train for Phantom Pain. Once you make your way through this, the wait for the next stage of the franchise will be nearly unbearable, and thus, I have to fully recommend this game.

review:
Got this last night and played it for a few hours. It's fun as hell. I can tell it's going to be very short, but for $13-something on sale, I can't complain. The gameplay is solid, the backstory is good, the voice acting is pretty good.

And...those graphics! During that opening sequence I was thinking "Witchcraft!"

I don't know how this game is able to run so smoothly on my meager 660 Ti with EVERYTHING maxed and look this good, but it does.

First off the bad. IF YOUR GAME WON'T STAY OPEN ON INITAL STARTUP, UNPLUG ANY CONTROLLER OR JOYSTICK YOU MAY HAVE PLUGGED IN. If using for the game plug back in after game has launched.

 The mouse and keyboard work in the menu could have used a bit more work. Sometimes it functions a bit odd. 

Seems to be missing any sound option in the game, or am I just missing it? I don't see one in options. Had to alt/tab and change in the mixer. Game didn't want to minimize quite right on Win 8.1 so, I had to do it real fast as the game closed. 

Mostly small BS stuff like that, nothing major and running very well overall on launch day.

This 24 guy... Not Snake, Not Big Boss, Not Meal Gear.  Bring back the real Snake. 

Some good stuff. 

It's Metal Gear, and it looks bad ass. 

It's short so if you're not a big Metal Gear fan, you might wait for it to come down, or for the full game.

The graphics on this game are amazing, and the controls feel the same way; you would not thing that this game is a console port at all.
Just like previous Metal Gear games, you can go full stealth or you can go fully loud on the missions. You unlock different weapons depending on the ranking that you receive for the missions.
The story is just like what Hideo does best, can't wait for the Phantom Pain.

review:
Hideo Kojima and his utter genius.
I played the Japanese version first so everything was as expected.
But man I did not expect to be blown away by Kiefer Sutherland in the English version.
It's a short game being the prologue to TPP,but every second is worth it.

A good practice for the stealth mechanics to come in TPP,the AI aren't as dumwitted like other stealth games.
秀夫氏、毎回ありがとうございます！！

review:
Really good prologue for "The Phantom Pain", some people think this game is too short... Well, the campaign is short, that's true. BUT! It includes a lot of extra missions so you can play it for hours to complete the 100% of the game.

If you like the saga, you will like this game.

Amazing port! The game runs perfect at 60 fps on my rig with all the graphics options maxed out.

My rig:

- i7 3770 3,4 GHZ
- GTX 970 4GB
- 8 GB DDR3 1600
- ASROCK Z77 EXTREME 6

Regards.

review:
It's interesting how the Metal Gear Solid games went from a series with tank-like, often unintuitive controls, to one of the smoothest and best controlling 3rd person games I've ever played. However, it is hampered by some strange default key cofigurations.

After playing all of the previous games on consoles, playing with the keyboard is a little strange at first, but I eventually got used to it after just a little bit. Although, I did go through and adjust some of the default controls because they didn't make any sense to me. For instance, when you're using your binoculars (by holding F) and you want to zoom in you have to press 'V'. How they expect someone to do this, I'm not exactly sure since the 'v' key is right below the ' f ' key that you're holding. Also, it's a good idea to change your slow-walk button to shift, and set sprint to ctrl since you're gonna be spending a lot more time walking slowly than sprinting.

In total, I changed my controls to:

slow-walk: shift
sprint: ctrl
switch shoulder: f
First-person aiming: v
binoculars: t
binocular-zoom: right-click

besides that, everything was comfy.

My first time through the main mission was awesome. I got caught a couple of times and had to fight my way out which was a little embarrassing. I'm actually pretty excited to play through it again and see how quickly I can get past everyone without being spotted.

If I had to give it a numerical score it would be a 9/10.

review: After a string of poorly optimized pc ports this is a breath of fresh air! runs smoothly at all times and looks astounding. The gameplay is a mixup of all the greatest mechanics that have existed in the metal gear universe and all of it has been brougth together in this tight package. There isnt much of a story or a campaign, it seems this product is a giant showcase for the gameplay mechancics and the graphics. As long as you know what you are getting for your money this game gets a solid thumbs up from me!

review:
Yes, yes, yes. It's just...wow. Take in mind is short, very short but with plenty side ops to keep you busy for a couple of hours. The controls are great, aside from crawling that seems to be a little... weird sometimes to move around. The graphics are just stunning, running a solid 1080p 60fps on ultura high (with a GTX 770). For 14 bucks is more than great for a demo of this quality. 

Buy, get some popcorn, and sit and enjoy the display case of the Fox Engine that this "game" is.

review:
Wonderfull port, masterly optimized, great gameplay with a HUGE toolbox of things to do.

Hideo Kojima, welcome home to the PC.

Would stealth murder again. 12/10

Pros: 
- Surprisingly well-optimized
- Some replayability to be had

Cons: 
- Even with the potential replayability, the story mission is quite short

Other thoughts: 
In the steam sale that is currently going on at the time of writing this at -33%, I'd recommend buying it. At the normal price, I can't be sure. But none the less, you'd be supporting the developers, and would be letting them know that the risk of delving into the PC market as well as the hard work, was worth it. There's a line Snake says, which goes "kept you waiting, huh?". Yes, and it was worth the wait to finally see another MGS come to the PC, and a well-optimized one at that after the fiasco of Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance oh-so-many years ago. This is finely polished.

I cannot comment on the mouse and keyboard layout, as from the get-go I decided to opt to use a Xbox 360 controller.

review:
Pretty good port! The optimisation is really good. Running everything at maximum settings with 2 GTX 770 in SLI and an i7-4770k and getting constant 60fps. Could even use only one card, as the two are running at 50% and the game doesn't seem to need more than ~500MB of VRAM! There's not much changes from the PS4 version, just a little extra detail here and there; view distance slightly increased, lights distance increased, some little effects, like rain running on clothes, more detailed... 
Now for the content, the main mission is quite short as every one has propably heard since the console release, but astonishing in it's replayability, as there is many ways to complete this mission. The rest of the content is interesting as well, but seeing the same map over and over again is a bit dissapointing... 
It's not a big game, more of a big demo, but as the price is more reasonable on steam than it was on the consoles releases, it's pretty interesting. If you already own a PS4 or XBOX ONE copy, it doesn't add anything, so don't bother, (unless you absolutly want to see it run on your computer, then who am I to give you orders XD ).

review:
The game is fun to play and challenging. If you like stealth-based gameplay you can't be wrong with that one.

The only main mission is short but if you like exploring and doing the side missions, or improving the way you play to achieve s-ranks, I assume it can last more than 20-30 hours, which is way more than some games sold at $40 or $50.

The scenario is good. Since the game is short there's not too much material to base my judgment on but it seems to efficiently link Peace Walker, which I recommend playing, to the upcoming The Phantom Pain.

Sound effects, voices and music are once again flawless as in every MGS game. I miss David Hayter's acting a lot but Kiefer Sutherland does a good job too.

Controls are logic and easy to learn, Big Boss' movements are slick and responsive. I still haven't figured how to dive/dash despite of the prompts but I'll eventually understand.

Aim assistance and "reflex mode" - which slows time when you're spotted - can be deactivated.

The Fox Engine is gorgeous and the game is amazingly well optimized. Note the fact that it's a developper that doesn't usually develop for PC, yet does a better job at it that a lot of other companies.


If you want to fully enjoy it I recommend playing the other Metal Gear games, or [b]at least[/b] MGS3 : Snake Eater and MGS : Peace Walker.

Controls with a Xbox360 controller are comfortable and accurate so I recommend using one. Maybe aiming is better with a mouse but the rest just feels better with the controller.

review:
It runs...so damn smoothly.  1080p, 60fps, high settings...it's just...beautiful.

This is my first Metal Gear game on PC, so the switch to mouse and keyboard was an adjustment, but being able to aim with the mouse is very well worth it.  

However, I did try playing with my XBox 360 pad and got some VERY weird control issues.  These could be unique to my system, but they were like this:

- The buttons were all mapped incorrectly, and there's not many options to change it
- The right analog stick was completely unresponsive
- I couldn't swap back to keyboard controls without first unplugging the Xbox pad, then restarting the game

But, as far as I can tell, I'm the only one who seems to have this problem.  Everything else though runs perfectly, and I don't really miss game pad controls anyway so it still comes recommended.

review:
Fantastic Port. Fantastic Game.

At a technical level it's absolutely mind blowing that it runs as well as it does. I'm maxing out the game at 1080p and I'm hitting a stable 60FPS while only using 35% of my GPU (GTX970). I have never seen my GPU usage so low while maintaining such a high framerate. Not even one dip below. I did run into 2 issues with the port however. First one is that V-Sync is a must, the amount of screen tearing without it is beyond words. I haven't seen tearing this bad in a very long time. The other issue is that the game seems to hate multi-monitor software such as DisplayFusion and Vertical Taskbars. If you have either of those (or both like me) you may need to close the software and hide the taskbar. If not the game will either give you a lovely 640x480 window (http://i.imgur.com/e2GLCke.jpg) that can't be changed or it will give you a taskbar that is permanently on screen (http://i.imgur.com/SmxQNCs.jpg).  outside of these 2 issues the port is perfect.

The game itself is a blast to play. It's a great taste of things to come in "The Phantom Pain". The main mission itself took me 61 minutes first go and while I found it to be a bit too easy (1 retry, 0 kills, 0 alerts) the experience that it gave me overall was spectacular. If Phantom Pain is basically a 20+ hour version of this I'm so down. Also, while the main mission only clocks in at an hour first go around that only accounted for 8% of the game completition according to my stats. There are a fair amount of side missions you can do and a few hidden things to collect along with another difficulty. There is content here beyond the main story. 

Overall, it's a great game and while the name "Demo Gear Solid" is true to an extent, this is most definitely worth a purchase if you just can't wait any longer for Phantom Pain. The stealth is solid, the game is smooth and why wouldn't you want to support PC MGS?

review:
"Here's to you Nicola and Bart.
Rest forever here in our hearts
The last and final moment is yours
That agony is your triumph"

The next chapter in the amazing Metal Gear Series, and first to come to Steam, lives up to the hype and delivers a powerful story with much improved gameplay.
Being on the new 'Fox' engine, Metal Gear Solid feels more realistic with not only looks but the way the world is. Enemies react better and move more natrually as well as fight with a better understanding of how to hide and survive a battle. Vehicles move around and people talk to each other in normal conversation. All in all, the game looks and feels great with the addition of graphic options to suits your PC's needs.
The story is a lot darker and there are a couple grim scenes that I winced at slightly. But this just goes to show how far people are willing to go in their own personal agenda's.
For the price is also the addition of the DLC packs, jamais vu and deju vu, achievements and things that will be unlocked in The Phantom Pain upon release.

(I am not counting the playtime and the game's short length because by now, if they had looked into the console releases, people would have known about the games short length and therefore saved themselves the complaining for when it came out on Steam.)

Highly reccomended if you are a big fan of Metal Gear Solid. If you're not you may have a hard time understanding everything that is going on without playing all the others first.

review: I never played thE prior MGS games because of two reasons. One of which is I never owned a Playstation 3 because of the controler and the other reason is I never cared for it. But with the hype that is going around for MGS V Phantom Pain like STD's at a fraternity. I decieded to take a wack at it. This small game was indeed amazing and quite frankly I sorta wish I can go back in time and kick my younger version to play the MGS series just so I don't have to go wiki everything. During this year most of the games that came out have been nothing but dissapointments but playing this put me in the X-Mas spirit by going around Gitmo and kidnapping nearly every guard just for the laughs. The game runs unblievebly smooth at 60fps and the enivroment was outstanding visually appealing on my PC.  The only cons with this game is I don't believe the price tag for $20 dollars is right but since it went on sale for $13 dollars I don't care really anymore about the price since it is better than other the other AAA game's that have been shown this year. Overall if you want a game that raises the bar on both story telling, visual appearence, and mechanics while actually having fun with it then this is your game.

review: My least favorite out of the series so far, enemy AI is pretty bad, graphics are over hyped for what they are. It's great that MGS is finially coming to PC, however id rather have an HD version of Snake Eater or the original any day of the  week. This demo is boring, and the soldiers are kinda just anywhere, no real posts or formations even when you are detected, they just run around aimlessly.

review:
Nice and smooth controls. Driving vehicles was a little on the akward side, a little too senestive. Interrogating gaurds is a little awkard as well, having to press like 3 keys but other than that  it's great demo. Can't wait to see what Kojima cooks up for phantom pain.

Also be warned, the game itself is like a demo. Very short.

review: Even though this is meant to be just a demo of the main game, it i so much more than that. This is one of the best metal gear solid games i think i have ever played and really captures the things people loved from the older series. The graphics are amazing, the gameplay is outstanding and overall just beautiful. The game relies on the player more than the player relying on the game, something not seen in so many other games, giving a strong sense of control and realism to it. Speaking of realism, the enemy AI are programmed to reflect what any well trained soldier would do. when i first started playing i though i could let them see me for a second , in order to lure them to me, but instead they reported in which lead to the others enemys being more catious. This is the perfect metal gear solid and I hope that the main reflects the brilliance of this demo. wouldn't say this a 10/10. Closer to 20/10.

A must-have for fans of the franchise and highly recommended for people who like stealth games. Also way better port than most console ports I've seen/heard about (I look at you Dark Souls, Deadly Premonition and Final Fantasy XIII).

review:
เป็นเกมที่พอร์ทมา PC แล้วสมบรูณ์แบบมากเรียกว่าการบังคับการจัดวางปุ่มนั้น

เข้ามือผู้เล่น PC สุดๆ ไม่จำเป็นต้องใช้คอนโทรลเลอร์แต่อย่างใด 

กินสเปคต่ำมากเล่นได้ลื่นไหล ข้อเสียอย่างเดียวของภาคนี้ที่แฟนเมทัลเกียร์คงทราบกันดี

คือมันสั้นมากเล่นอยู่บนเกาะเล็กๆ เหมือนเดโม่ ภาคปฐมบทที่ปูเรื่องไปสู่ phantom pain

แต่ถ้าคุณรักซีรีย์นี้ ซื้อเถอะครับไม่ผิดหวัง ซ้อมมือไว้ก่อนไปบู้จริงในภาคหลักกับ MGS online

9/10

review: I highly recommend this, if your a fan of the Metal Gear Solid series and would like to enjoy an extremely polished game this is for you! Many complain that this is a glorified demo, but this is simply a prologue and example of what is to come. If you take the time to complete all the missions and side quests you would more than get your money out of it. Also this is a FANTASTIC port with little to no performance issues if you have a decent pc. It does have its faults such as having to plug in the controller after launching the game and a few glitches here and there which im sure will be patched soon. If your a fan of Metal Gear Solid and Hideo Kojima buy this right now, you will not regret it.

review:
[h1]Fox Engine[/h1]
Kojima Productions brings you the sexy [b]Fox Engine[/b] the inhouse nextgen engine that will is used in MGS GZ and the upcoming MGS 5. From the stunning cinematic features to the rich graphics the fox engine (thankfully) has been ported over to PC. Like many modern engines, much of Fox Engine's image quality comes courtesy of Physically-Based Rendering (PBR), which in short enables materials, surfaces and objects to react realistically to lighting and shading in real-time, accurately reflecting their appearance in the real world.
[h1]Ground Zeros[/h1]
Tasked with rescuing Paz and Chico Snake must infiltrate the area they are being held and get them out in time for lunch at motherbase. Ground Zeros is basically the cherry on cake, it gives us a taste of what to expect for Metal Gear Solid 5. Yes its short however well worth its price, if you're new to the series or a returning fan you must check out this title!

review:
10/10 it's an MGS Game.

Compared to the prior, more linear MGS games, you have an open world to play the mission in any way you like.
Guards also aren't as predictable anymore, you have to change your tactics on the fly and it makes for great replayability.

The only downside is that this is just a prologue for the Phantom Pain and therefore the main mission is a bit short.
But they make up for it with great gameplay, an amazing story and side missions that will get you a few more hours out of the game.
It also is an amazing port that runs incredibly well. It's overall a really polished game and for the current price, you can't go wrong with it.

I personally really miss David Hayter's voice for Snake. Kiefer Sutherland does a good job as well and i'll get used to it, but Hayter has been voicing Snake since my childhood and will always be my Number 1 Snake voice.


Praise Kojima.

review:
Remade since I've finally gotten 100% on the game.

Absolutely gorgeous, missions are all pretty interesting and fun. Hard mode is fucking hard, as expected.

The only bullshit part is the whole collectables and trials nonsense to get to 100%. That was pretty annoying.

I luckily got the game for only 13 bucks, which is very good pricing for the amount of gameplay I got out of it. The original 30 dollars might seem a big high, but if you look at my hours, this is what your above-average player will take to get 100% completion, assuming you follow guides for some of the other nonsense like I did, and don't bother with the trials besides just the neccessary parts to unlock them all. Not to mention you can upload your data and new stuff will be in TPP once it comes out. Definitely worth it if you can snag it to 100% it before TPP comes out.

I played this game like a damn fiddle.

review:
Satisfying, Enticing, and ultimately a massive teaser for things to come. 

This game seems to function like a large and well put together DLC pack that works as a prologue connection between PeaceWalker and the upcoming Phantom Pain. This is both a positive and negative given the massive cliffhanger it establishes as far as wanting more to this brief snippet of a much larger story.

The controls are excellent, but are clearly intended for gamepad analog controls. Animations are as smooth as ever. Everything from shooting guards to knocking out guards to sneaking around feels both satisfying and rewarding on many levels.

Overall the game is well worth the purchase if you are any kind of fan of the metal gear series or are simply interested in getting a bit of backstory buildup for the upcoming major release.

At all maxxed out settings the game is probably one of the best looking games ever released (yes even compared to something like inquisition) and runs very smoothly on a single GTX 970. 

Cannot. Wait. For. More.

review:
At first, I used my Xbox Controller. Since the last MGS game I played was the original PS1 version, it was very awkward and clumsy at first. I was getting frustrated with the controls. It was then I was near Chico that I accidentally moved the mouse, and realised I can use the Mouse and Keyboard. After that, it was headshot after headshot, silently sniping everyone from afar
10/10 would kill mouse again

review:
Great game. Runs perfectly on my system. Constant 60FPS, everything maxed out on a 780 Ti. I heard that this game was really short, and I'm surprised to see that it actually has a fair amount of content. The main 'Ground Zeroes' mission took about 2 hours for me, and since then I've been playing the side-ops.  If you're a big Metal Gear fan you're gonna want to unlock all the cassette tapes to learn more about the crazy MGS story, and that should take a good amount of time. Along with collecting the XOF patches that unlock two extra missions I believe. So I think I'll be playing the game for awhile.

One thing I've noticed about this iteration of MGS is that it has gotten a lot darker. There is still some wacky sh*t like a Hideo Kojima cameo, but it deals with some pretty grim subject matter such as pedophilia and rape. Makes you feel pretty uncomfortable. The gameplay is the best it has ever been. It's just fun running around, sneaking up on people and smacking them around with CQC. And the non-linear progression allows you to tackle your mission in various ways, with various opening to exploit which is great.

They also added vehicles which I didn't use that often because I tried to remain undetected and It seems like you're screwing yourself over by driving around in clear view. Also, I thought I was going to be pissed off because of the lack of David Hayter, but I honestly think it's an improvement. I don't know that much about Kiefer Sutherland so his voice didn't seem out of place or weird to me, and it's a lot more professional and less cheesy.

Overall, I really have no complaints about this game. It's fantastic and I highly recommend it. Can't wait for Phantom Pain.

review:
Welcome to PC BigBoss! 

This game plays like a damn fiddle! SO AMAZING. I'm shocked I was able to run it MAX with stable 60fps even when my PC doesn't meet the requirment settings.

The game is amazing. The gameplay is flawless and so smooth in ways you can't find in other games. Its like Perfection. Once you finish it, you'd want more! The Story is short just like the game but trust me on this, the amount of quality in this 1hour story mode beats maybe all other games to-date. Like really. 

The game is meant to be short. It was made to introduce people to the FOX ENGINE and the new style of the game and to give us a DAMN FIDDLE CLIFFHANGER!

People asked for MGSV:GZ for PC, Kojima listened, Kojima delivered. This game is worth supporting to show the world that PC gamers exist and to show the awesomeness of Kojima Sama!

VIC BOSS!

review: I'm not sure how to feel. This game is essentially a demo for the Phantom pain, BUT it's quite expansive and quite fun to experiment with.  all in all it's a short teaser that is worth about $10-$13, so buy it on sale if you want to try it. it will also serve as a good way to tell if you want the more expensive Phantom Pain later down the line.

review:
I wish Merry Christmas to Hideo Kojima and big Thanks for giving us this game on PC.

Now about game itself.

Story:
 Many people have problem understanding why Big Boss is snake and how he is connected to Solid Snake but that will occur with young player who most probably were not even born when i played MGS 1. So you should play entire 
franchise of MGS series to understand compex sotry behind Snake who is cloned from Big Boss, governments, cold war and what nobody likes to talk is what happens to people on battlefield and after they survive it. What is left of man when he fights between two storms and none is good, only difference is what kind of evil will replace different kind of evil. There is no victory for humanity in the end of day only domination of one force above other and special interest shifting between them which is mercenaries like Big Boss. As we can see in prologe American base (black site) is on communistic soil in Cuba fighting against communistic Russia or SSSR doing to prisoners same things as SSSR which is hypocrite of hypocrisy.
 So for young players I recommend this game as one of best games with story, gameplay and Hideo Kojima even says on his site KONAMI that this is result of deep reasearch so most parts from game are made by real events or inspired by real events.

I will finish my review on graphic and gameplay later.

review:
Ok ladies and gents.... this is a visual orgasm, a long with an awesome intreo story to the phantom pain, runing my MSI Gaming 780TI and upscaling this little monster to 4k with DSR, will make me hate all other games because after seeing the fox engine in action.... not even real life will look so beautiful.... i do recomend this game, it has replay value, its hard if you dont plan things you will learn to be patient, before going guns blazing and starting your rambo crap.


No issues runing this game on very high even with the 4k upscale. looking forward for the phantom pain.

review: I get shit framerates? My buddy in the next room over has the same 7870 as me, and I have a better cpu. He gets 30 + fps maxed out while i get unplayable framerates? WTF?  And my Xbox controller is all fucked up in the controls too while his stuff works fine. I have reinstalled the game, installed updates, amd driver updates, still plays like shit. It does run great at all high settings, but maxed I get 15 to 20 frames. I'm a Huge ass metal gear solid fan and this really sucks. I still recommend the game becuase it seems hardly anybody else is having these problems. And Metal gear needs all the support it can get on pc! If anybody knows if there is a way to get the game running properly could you please help a brother out?

review:
Been a Metal Gear fan for years, and I'd never imagine the evolution of the series would take it to here on PC with Ground Zeroes.

And that's a good thing, because I was getting worried for a bit....

It's a fantastic PC port with nothing trimmed or dumbed down away from the console version, if anything it's far superior with the lighting and draw distance improvements. 

Thank you Hideo Kojima you amazing bastard, now go make Phantom Pain please. 

I. Can't. Wait.

review:
I'm not too far into it, but holy shit is it nice to buy a PC port and have it work just fine day one.  Smooth framerate, absolutely no screen tearing so far-I'm very pleased with the job they did on bringing the title over.

The gameplay is excellent so far-the base is small, but it feels very dense and alive, and the controls work decently even just using the keyboard.  It's really looking like MGS 5 will be a masterpiece,given how solid this weird little demo-game works.

review:
This game was a blast to play, and very well optimized, yet I still feel dissapointed. It's like going to a 5 star restaurant, paying for a quality meal, but the portion size isn't enough to fart out later. There's only one map on this game that gets regurgitated into multiple 'mini' missions. It's alot like playing a demo, but paying for it. If you're a fan of the series, you'll like it. But, just keep in mind, that it leaves very much to be desired in duration.



***EDIT*** 12/20/14

I made the game 'not recommended' for a reason people. It's short. I knew it was short to begin with and that it's a prolgue to Phantom Pain, but it's not worth buying. I recommend looking the game up on youtube, rather than buying it.

If anyone is looking to play a new game on your gaming PC try this out. Its fairly priced and a lot of people are saying it is the most optimized game of all time. It runs really well on a wide variety of PC configurations. Just make sure your PC meets the minimum requirements. I played the game with my mouse and keyboard and the controls work well.  It make take you a little while to get used to but once you understand them you'll be ready to go.  Just take a look at the key bindings in the options menu.  Its the best looking game I've played on my PC. Buy the full game when it's out!  I have gameplay of the game on my YouTube channel!  Link:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dd0ZCstbpJw

My PC specs:
CPU: Intel Core i7-4790K 4.0GHz 
CPU Cooler:  Silverstone AR01 
Motherboard: Gigabyte GA-Z97X-Gaming GT ATX LGA1150
Memory: G.Skill Ripjaws X Series 16GB (2 x 8GB) DDR3-1866

review:
Fantastic, polished performance, excatly what Pc gamers deserve! 

Thank you Mr. Kojima for supporting the platform and the technical team for their awesome work!

After my huge disappointment in nextgen console hardware performance and quality, i'am very happy and relieved, that i will be able to enjoy my favorite franchise in the highest quality possible.

As a Die-hard Metal Gear fan, this game lives up to the name in all aspects but one : David Hayter. The scenario is complementary to the rest of the series, the humour is still the same, the little "insider" quotes, the stealth action (even if they now call it operations) everything is there... although I still need to find Johnny (for those of you who know who I mean ;P)

The graphics are beautiful, sounds are great, AI was good even on easy (sadly I couldn't jump straight to hard difficulty, having played nearly all others* , I believe I could've went on at extreme difficulty right off the bat), cutscenes were still as awesome, cutscene transition to in-game nearly non-existant, all in all it's just plain amazing and the title I've been waiting for as a fan of the series and universe.

My only disapointment with the game is the fact that they changed Snake's voice actor. 
Will definitely do another playthrough at hard and try a few things out.


*( MG 1+2, MGS 1+2+3+4, Peace Walker, Portable Ops +(storyless version of Portable Ops) , tried Acid but it's not as good, and spent HOURS reading the MGS database add-on for MGS4. The only ones I didn't try are Portable Ops (sadly), Snakes revenge (not written by Kojima), Acid 2 (since I didn't finish Acid) and the one for the phone which I never remember the title that came out around the same time as peace walker)

Edit: forgot also played MG Rising : Revengence

review: This entire series has had a special place in my heart since Metal Gear Solid 1 for PS1.  I'm somewhat biased towards loving these titles and going total fanboy blind as a bat at just the mention of being able to control Snake again.   But approaching this game from a logical standpoint and as a consumer, i'd say it's a *decent* price to pay for a short prequel before we get to actually get our hands on The Phantom Pain.  I paid 13 for it and i was willing to pay 25 without batting an eye.  The game runs pretty damned well on my pc which i'll admit is showing its age now.  2.9 ghz cpu with a 2 gig nvidia graphics card and 8 gigs of ram and i've got everything maxed out except SSAO , which is still at high and i'm getting around 40-50 fps.  Kojima's staff should be teaching seminars for the devs out there that love to push products out and give everybody a playable experience with a 3 gig patch 3 weeks after release.  Mechanics, abilities, gameplay all are top notch in my book, and as someone that goes nuts for stealth/action/espionage, this has put a smile on my face.  Totally recommend this title, and if someone complains about the pricetag being around 20 dollars or so, I couldn't care less.  This is one developer i'd gladly pay to keep in business.

review:
Metal Gear Solid: Ground Zeroes

Gee, what can I say, honestly this game is like an art form of it's own, a prelude to the game that will follow, A.K.A. The Phantom Pain

Let's talk about the game a little

-------------------------------
GAMEPLAY
-------------------------------

You play as Big Boss, one of the most elite soldiers during the cold war era, and as such he comes with his own unique skillset. Boss is a master of sneaking, and as such he is instructed to complete all his missions stealthily, and with no backup. 

Equipment is procured on site, and you have to rely on your own wits and good luck.  The controls are perfectly optimized for keyboard and mouse, although it is playable and quite enjoyable with a controller. 

The enemy AI is amazing, enemies act according to the situation which is going on, and their eyesight is sharp, meaning you have to be really careful when sneaking around

-----------------------
STORY
-----------------------
Metal Gear Solid: Ground Zeroes is a prelude to Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. It begins with Big Boss infiltrating a black site in Cuba, or as Kaz would call it "A little slice of American pie on commie soil"

There, he is instructed to exfil two members of Big Boss' "Army Without Borders", Paz Ortega Andrade and Ricardo Valenciano Libre (also known as Chico). Paz was captured, and Chico went in after her because he loves her. I really cannot reveal much, you have to find out most of it for yourself. 

-----------------------------------
OVERALL
-----------------------------------

A very good port, excellently optimized, and with a great story and gameplay. I believe this game is just a stepping stone for Metal Gear games to finally appear on PC, and we might actually witness this in the near future.

Game is a 10/10, I would definitely recommend it.

Bravo Kojima, you did it again.

review: Good lord, this short game (a taste of the upcoming MGS 5) is perhaps one of the best ports I've seen on PC. It's gorgeous, optimized as hell, and it's full of Kojima's taste for both the macabre and humorous. If you enjoy the Metal Gear universe or want to experience stealth or action that the Splinter Cell series always dreamed of emulating, this is the best taster you can get. Good luck hanging in there until 2015. Kojima, you've kept us waiting!

review:
Metal Gear Sold V: Ground Zeroes is a fantastic game. Though there's only a single map that's honestly not very large, the map itself and the NPCs populating it are so wonderfully crafted that each of the 7 missions you can play on it all feel like a new experience. 

But there're loads of sites and other reviews you can look at if you're interested in whether or not the game itself is good, as it's been out for around 9 months now on consoles.

I will however talk about it's port (may or may not be an actual port) quality, which everyone and their dog's mom is saying is the best of the year.

While it is a fantastic "port", it's only a fantastic "port" in terms of performance. In other areas like graphics options, audio options and key rebinding, it has a lot of problems. 

Key rebinding is pretty good for the most part, unless of course you're left handed or if you're someone who binds to the right side of the keyboard. Be prepared to use a controller because you can't bind ANYTHING to the numpad or any other keys on the right side besides "Page Up" "Page Down" and the cursor keys. This is a major problem for those of us who don't or can't use the left side of the keyboard due to physical disabilities or simply being left handed.

I've been forced to use a controller to play it since I use the mouse with my left hand. And I certainly won't be buying MGSV Phantom Pain unless the problems this game has aren't present in it.

The audio options menu is non existent. There are no ways whatsoever to adjust the volume of different sounds, no way to change the audio output device while in-game. There's not even a menu for audio options.

The graphics options menu has a decent amount of options, but they're all very poorly presented. The game is locked to 60hz, Vsync is always on, AA and DOF are wrapped up into a single "Low" "High" "Extra High" or "Off" option, and other options like Texture Filtering are restricted to the same "Low" "High" "Off" method.

All in all you'll probably be able to get this to a playable framerate on just about any peice of modern hardware, but other than that, it's an okay port at best.

review:
I would like to know how many babies were sacrificed to optimize this game, because this is beautiful. I have an I5 4650 and GTX 660 2GB. Not amazing specs but I can run everything but Shadows on high. Shadows is on medium. The performance is great at a steady 60 fps for me. 

Now, I knew what I was buying. I knew the main game is short, but it has a few side missions. Since I like to S Rank all missions, this game will keep me busy. The main mission took me 45 minutes but that is because I rushed through and didn't collect the XOF patches or do anything else. As of now, I am trying to get an S rank on all the missions on Hard. I am not having an easy time. This game, for me, will take up a lot of time since I like Metal Gear. If you prefer something like COD with instant gratification, this game will dissapoint you, but at $13.39 (at this moment) I feel I am getting my monies worth. If this is your first Metal Gear Game, it may leave a bad impression for you as this is just a taste of what The Phantom Pain will showcase. I would wait for TPP to come out and then maybe buy Ground Zeroes, if you are new to the series. That way you can take the time to catch up on the older games.

review:
Arigatou gozaimasu Hideo Kojima Sensei!

Superior port. No bugs, crashes, works like a charm. Maxed out on i5-4670k, 8gb ram and gtx970, rock solid 60 fps. It's  beautifull game, fox engine can do wonders, great atention to details.

Game is quite short, but has a little bit of replayability, after the main mission you can go back and do a couple of extra missions, rescue hostages, kill some high value targets etc. Also, it's quite cheap atm, so go and get it while it's still hot!

Snake, welcome back on PC, we hope you'll stay a while longer :)

Now i really can't wait for Phantom Pain......

review:
Great port! Glad to see Kojima is looking towards the master race! Lets all show him we like this change. Few tweaks here and there and the game will be perfect! I am suprised how well the port is.
New players need to get a Metal Gear Lore update and possibly watch playthroughs or "movies" from YouTube to catch up. If you own a Playstation 3, look into getting "Metal Gear Solid: The Legacy Collection." Its well worth a playthrough of each game!

"Kept you waiting huh?"
Yeah, you did keep us waiting Kojima!

review:
In short: Amazing!

I was really impressed with the port, played smoothly and looked stunning. 

The first mission does end quite fast, but only if you let it. I found it quite engaging to sneak around and interrogate the enemies to reveal their secrets. 

Price wise, it was well worth £11.38. I was expecting to pay more than that, and I would have been happy to, to show Japanese devs that there is a market on PC.

All in all, if this is a taster of Phantom Pain, I truly can't wait! 

Thank you Kojima Productions!

review:
So, I hadn't played Ground Zeroes at all before getting this.  I knew it was short (well, main mission was short) and I knew it was basically a prequel for when Phantom Pain comes out, but I must say it's a solid experience (didn't really intend for the pun, but there you go)

My current setup is bellow the minimum specs they list, and I was able to play the game smoothly with most settings on high, save for 2 that were on medium.  For under minimum specs, that's impressive (I think they just really want people to play with the most highest settings, so higher specs)

The gameplay is smooth, the controls work well with the keyboard & mouse, and it's an interesting little mission that goes between peace walker and the game to come.

I'm nowhere near completing the game, but I think it'll be fun finding all the extra little things, and doing the side missions, as even though they're all in the same area, they'll put emphasis on diferent styles of gameplay.

With the starting price of 13.39, I'm satisfied with my purchase, and I've only scratched the surface of this game.

And, for those wondering about specs and everything, I'm running with an i52500k (stock) 8gb ram and a pair of GTX 590's.  It's only really in the processor category that I'm below min specs, but still, if splitting the average makes the game run the way I experienced it, someone did some awesome coding on the backend of this thing.

review:
Hello, I am currently 22 years old and I want to become a Big Boss. I know there's a million people just like me, but I promise you I'm different. On December 20th, I'm moving to Mother Base; home of the biggest Boss. I've already gauged my eye out, and now hide in my cardboard box everywhere I go as training. I may not be a Big Boss, but I promise you if you give me a chance and the support I need, I will become the biggest Boss ever. If you have any questions or maybe advice, just inbox me. Thank you all so much~

also 10/10 great port and game.

review:
When I was 7, my father bought home a PlayStation One along with a copy of Metal Gear Solid 1. I spent hours, months beating that game, I remember every moment of it, from the epic intro to crapping my pants when Psycho Mantis did his voodoo shit and I've been hooked to this series ever since. 

I've moved on from consoles, I built a PC and one of my biggest regrets was not getting to play Metal Gear Solid, the game that shaped my world view, the game that taught me how bad a war is. 

And now, it's here. I cannot explain the multitude of emotions I'm feeling at this moment. 

The game itself is just one mission in an open area, and now to add to Metal Gear Solid's fantastic stealth mechanics, you have multliple options and multiple paths to finish your objective. 

The only con is that it's too short, and it will make you desperate for The Phantom Pain. 

You have been warned.

{"recommendationid": "13444455", "author": {"steamid": "76561198047318813", "num_games_owned": 496, "num_reviews": 61, "playtime_forever": 723, "playtime_last_two_weeks": 0, "playtime_at_review": 152, "last_played": 1443800509}, "language": "english", "review": "When I was 7, my father bought home a PlayStation One along with a copy of Metal Gear Solid 1. I spent hours, months beating that game, I remember every moment of it, from the epic intro to crapping my pants when Psycho Mantis did his voodoo shit and I've been hooked to this series ever since. 

I've moved on from consoles, I built a PC and one of my biggest regrets was not getting to play Metal Gear Solid, the game that shaped my world view, the game that taught me how bad a war is. 

And now, it's here. I cannot explain the multitude of emotions I'm feeling at this moment. 

The game itself is just one mission in an open area, and now to add to Metal Gear Solid's fantastic stealth mechanics, you have multliple options and multiple paths to finish your objective. 

The only con is that it's too short, and it will make you desperate for The Phantom Pain. 

You have been warned.", "timestamp_created": 1418973497, "timestamp_updated": 1418973497, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 41, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": "0.710771024227142334", "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": false, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
Runs great, LOOKS AMAZING, and controls very well on PC. If you love MGS and care about enjoying this little sandbox, not just completing the missions as fast as possible, Ground Zeroes is definitely worth it, especially with a discount.

For those curious about performance, I have an i5-3570k, a GTX 660Ti with 2GB VRAM, and 16GB RAM, and I'm not even sure the FPS dropped below 60 even once, on the default medium/high settings.

review: These games left behind a legacy on the Playstation consoles and now it's out for PC and Xbox as well. I'm happy to see this game expand and grow and even happier to see it featured on Steam! Aside from that the game designers made a fantastic PC port that runs smoothly even if you don't quite meet the minimum requirements (I don't). Yes, this game is short and features one map but it serves as a sample for the upcoming game Metal Gear Solid V: Phantom Pain and to say the least I'm pretty excited about it. All in all, it's a very good experience for any die hard stealth fan and I am definitely recommending it to anyone that fits the aforementioned description.

review:
Has good performance on even weaker machines (Thinkpad W520 with Quadro), but has a critical flaw in that the mouse sensitivity is not set proportionally to the zoom level, which means aiming with guns is very hard and inaccurate, and trying to use the binoculars is hilariously broken when zoomed all the way in.

There is also a whole gaggle of issues around multi-screen setup, alt-tabbing, screens with non 16:9 ratios, the lack of integration of mouse into ui (all the menus are controllable only with wasd) and the lack of mouse cursor limiting (it'll happily let the mouse go out the window and alt-tab you out for right-clicking).

review:
Way more than a demo, this pre-quel to MGS:V is definitely worth the current $14 sale. Along with the main mission of rescuing Chico and Paz, there will be an assortment of lore to go over, side ops to partake in after the main mission, and overall prepare the massive hype train for MGS:V coming mid-2015.

I never actually played any MGS myself excluding Metal Gear Rising if you can count that, and all I can say is that I am overwhelmingly impressed by both the port itself and the game. It's fun in so many regards, and at the base $20 price tag I would definitely recommend this game.

review:
SUPER SHORT. Yeah most Metal Gear games are short, but this takes the cake on the SHORTEST Metal Gear. It's such a tease too because when you beat the game, the game makes you think there's more, but instead it gives you a split glimse of the Real Game "The Phantom Pain" and even tells you that the story will continue in it. 

The Gameplay is tight, it took everything from Metal Gear Solid 3 and 4 and just went to town on it, Gameplay wise it's the best in the Metal Gear Franchise. 

Despite the Game being short it's Map is fairly big and you can do a lot of things in it with gathering XOF tags or saving POWs, etc It's actually a neat game to power through. 

Overall, This game is just a BIG OL' TEASER for the Real Game MGSV: The Phantom Pain, I recommend you get it while it's on Sale, but I wouldn't recommend you getting it for the Full Price of $20.

review:
I grabbed a hostage, ran her through the prison very quietly. Came upon a big troop transporter and put her in the passangers seat. Drove through the front gate and was spotted. The whole army came after me, I drove to the evac spot but crashed and caught fire shortly before I reached it. I scrambled out of the truck, pulled my hostage out just before the truck exploded. Picked up a gun off the ground and mowed down 4 soldiers. I picked her back up, threw a helicopter signel flare and hid in the mountains until the chopper arrived. By that time the enemy had caught up to my position. They started shooting my chopper, I loaded my hostage on and climbed aboard. Pulled out an SMG and once again let a rip as the chopper made its way from the island. 

That was one hostage, one play and one time. I will play the shit out of this. 10/10

review:
I had it for the playstation, and now that it's on the pc I'm liking it a lot more--got my headset so I can hear directional audio, actual 1080p resolution and good lighting effects. I'm definirtely going to buy Phantom Pain for PC.

It is a big demo though,  and apparently they've added a lot more gameplay features since to the tech demos they showed for Pain. Howeevr, as someone who played the Tanker demo scene in the Zone of Enders game extensively, I will get more hours than the expected playtime just because Kojima and his team put so much stuff into their enviroments. I hope this is a moddable experience too.


There's this assumption that Pc gamers havent played MGS games before, and I believe they have. I did. Most of my hundred person+ friends list did.  Hope they dont delay the PC release of Pain now.

Awesome game, the graphics are really on par with todays standards. Runs really well on my setup: I3-3240, 8gb ram, 1gb galaxy 640. Kind of a short game but completing it awards more sub missions to play. Definately worth the replay!

:::EDIT:::
I recently updated my GPU from the 640 to an EVGA GTX 960 and Ground Zeros runs on ultra flawlessly. Still a great game!
An absolutely fantastic port.

review:
Considering this is my first MGS game on PC and the Phantom Pain will be my next, I must say I been a huge MGS fan and I essentially own every MG game as a physical copy with some LE versions. The reason I bought this version of the game is because obviously, I am a huge fan but the main factor is I do not have a proper next gen console so I bought the PS3 version. Let me take the PS3 and PC versions and lets compare in simple terms.

PS3
-Limited FOV
-Pixelated Enviro
-Chopping Framrate

PC
-Further FOV
-Better and cleaner "lines" and "textures"
-60fps and possibly higher.
-Runs really well on my pc and it seems optimized.
-Controller Enabled (PS3 or PS4 controller through 3rd party means)

Similiar Aspects
-Same Story
-Same Gameplay
-Same Content
-Same Side Missions

If anything I would buy either one because really any version of the game would do. I am no graphics peasant nor specific fan of either pc or console but as a huge fan of MGS and the development teams I am happy I can play this without problem.

review:
F I D D L E B O Y S

It's a good port. It ran well with high/ultra graphics on my ok rig, has a lot of graphical options, mouse and kb controls work, etc. Only things I was annoyed by was a lack of keys shown in the interrogate UI and a lack of zoom sensitivity slider. The actual time it took to complete the main story was only 90min for me, but then again it was expected. The gameplay is solid and open enough to keep me interested in side ops and harder difficulties. It might be a bigger deterance to some people though.

review:
NANOMACHINES, SON/10

Game runs flawlessly and as smooth as butter.  Not a single hiccup or glitch.  This FOX Engine is so amazing it's stupid.  Tried playing with a keyboard and mouse instead of my controller since it's broken, and I was destroying everything in my path.  Headshots fo' DAYS.

I loved it.  What a dark and sad start to the final chapter in Snake's story...  Jack Bauer is... BIG BOSS.  Game plays like a fiddle.  There's another in my...
Very difficult but fantastic port. For $13, you get your money's worth

review:
UPDATE: Playing on new GTX 750Ti -  60 Fps at the same settings as the 650 (All High shadows med 40fps) but only at 70% LOAD!!!!! God I love this card and PC 4 LIFE. <3 

I just played it on my PNY Gtx 650 stock clock, I have everything on HIGH but shadows MED and Lighting MED and im getting 40 fps Minimum at 1080P This card is the 'minimum" requirement and runs like a beast. Kojima I knew you would not let us PC gamers down. When I heard that MGS5 was coming out for PC; I built my PC. Thank you for releasing an incredibly well optimized port on day 1 and for taking care of us on PC. Ubisoft and EA could learn from this. But they wont. I will gladly give Kojima my money any day for his incredible games and pride in his work. I CANT EFFING WAIT FOR MGS5. 

Kojima 11/10

review:
Incredibly short, and probably not going to be worth anything once Phantom Pain releases. Considering all that, if you are a Metal Gear Solid fan, especially of Big Boss' story, you'll really enjoy it if you can find it on sale. It feels like the next step in the natural progression of Metal Gear Solid. Also other challenges to do, and fun mechanics to mess around with to add extra time to the game.

P.S. Probably the best PC port this year, performance wise.

review:
Seriously, would recommend to anyone who likes Metal Gear Solid games, likes stealth based games, and or is a completionist.
BEWARE THOUGH: This game is very short. If you only play the main mission one time and nothing else, you'll probably get 2 hours of gameplay. 
However, if you enjoy messing around and exploring the base and trying to get S ranks in all the missions, the collectible patches, casettes, and completing all the side missions you will get much more than 2 hours out of this game.
The gameplay here is SUPERB, best in the series, however, the amount of it is very minute depending on what you hope to do with this game. 
Consider what exactly you are looking for with this game before buying. If all you want to see is the small story bit and dont care about playing the missions over and over, just watch a let's play.

review:
Fantastic port, sets a great precedent for future Metal Gear titles coming to PC. Visually the game is incredible, even in 4k the textures are sharp and clear (aside fom the character models in places). The game itself is one really well put together stealth level, really love how it plays out.

The game is, of course, short, but everyone already knew that going in. For the price though, I would say it's worth it (I say this during a sale).

A word of caution: Even though the game runs incredibly well, the options in the options menu have negligible performance benefit. Either it runs or it doesn't, changing settings won't take it from 20 to 60 no matter what you do. Maybe that will be fixed with future patches, but if you want to see some numbers, look at the tweaking guide Nvidia put out for the game.
Wanna try out MGS for the first time? Buy this demo.

review:
This is a fantastic port of the game that runs like a dream for me. I don't know if it's Konami finally has their act together or the Fox Engine used in this game was designed with PC support since the beginning. Whichever the case, they've done an excellent job bringing Ground Zeroes to the PC.

If you're a Metal Gear Solid fan, pick this up! Yes, it's short. This is only a taste of what's to come. But at the cheaper price for PC versus when it came out for consoles plus 33% off in the Steam sale, it's a must pick up. If you're not a Metal Gear Solid fan, give it a try anyway. It's a solid step into the stealth gameplay that Metal Gear is known for, a gorgeous PC game, and a AAA experience that isn't breaking the wallet. Ground Zeroes will let you know if you'll enjoy The Phantom Pain's gameplay style and also if your PC is ready to handle it.

review:
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes is one of those games that you can't pass up, especially if your a Metal Gear fan.

---Firstly, I'd like to thank the developers for making the game run smoothly, especially for what it is offering. These days you see lazy ports and developers often blame others.---

Now onto my review and some information ( for those who might be wondering ) about the game.
The game is well optimized for the PC and offers several options to adjust visual settings, easily making it the definitive version. The options menu also has key assigning, so you can easily switch what key does what to conform to your liking. Mouse movement is amazingly responsive. Movement is smooth and there are options to adjust your mouse sensitivity, so you don't worry about having to use a controller.
Currently using an i5 4670 and a GTX 770, I am able to max the games settings with a stable 60 FPS.

The game has stunning visuals sounds, and effects. 
Gameplay wise it runs nice, combat is good as well, stealth works well. The AI seems good so far, I haven't run into any issues with them yet. The game is somewhat short, but it does offer some replayability by giving you extra missions once you complete the main one. You will definitely have hours worth of play when trying to complete the game at 100%.

For $20 you'll be enjoying yourself for a long time.

review: Take notes EbolaSoft aka Ubisoft!  Fox Engine runs amazing on PC and this game has no stuttering issues that I have came across yet.  I play it on Ultra 1080p and I don't even have to OC my I7 4770K or 970 to keep at 60fps!!!!    The game scales very well from lowest settings too Ultra as well so I am sure even a 650ti will be able to play this game with no problems at 1080p.  Konami has done me Proud!

review:
Having played the game on PS4 with a 100% completion, I can tell you from loading this version today that it is a great port. I run a 5 year old i7 with a nvidia gtx 680 and the game plays smoothly 55-60fps with everything maxed out (except lighting on high) on 1200p. The game looks great even on high.

remember this is not a game, rather a demo-prequel

+ graphics are top notch
+ story is great
+ voice acting is superb
+ gameplay/combat/controls are also very well executed
+- challenges are fun but a bit repetitive and getting 100% could take a bit of time

review: Runs like a dream. Goes to show Hideo Kojima has kept his sense of quality and values of fine execution well into the new generation. This product really exposes the flaws in the development cycles of other developers, especially in this christmas release period. Extraordinarily high detail squeezed into a 3GB download. Good replayability and lots of extras\easter eggs to find.  Promotes high expectations for the full MGSV release early next year.

review:
10/10, would hide under cardboard box again.

This game is shorter than you might expect, but it comes with a wealth of gameplay that keeps you entertained for many hours. The game looks absolutely beautiful on PC. If you're new to the MGS franchise or a hardcore veteran, you need this title in your library.

Ground Zeroes is more of a showcase of the new Fox engine and a teaser to get people pumped for The Phantom Pain than a complete standalone game. The map isn't huge, but there are so many different ways that you can infiltrate the base and accomplish your mission that it makes up for the short story. The stealth mechanics are fluid and very responsive, and in many ways this is the best Metal Gear Solid game ever created. When this game was first released, some people were upset with how short the actual mission is. However, it's priced accordingly and worth every penny you'll pay for it. I've played over a hundred hours on my PS3 and still didn't complete all the challenges.

The main mission is Ground Zeroes, but once you beat that it unlocks several other missions (some during daytime) that show just how much fun you can have on a single map. If you enjoy the stealth gameplay, you'll be delighted to run back through the missions multiple times, trying to infiltrate from different angles, and trying to complete each one without killing anybody or being seen at all. It's much more challenging than you might expect, but extremely rewarding. I've yet to find another game that gives you that same stealth feeling as Metal Gear Solid.

review:
Completed the main mission in about 2.5 hours and told that I was only 7% done with the game. I think there is more than enough content to justify purchasing this game, especially at a sale price.

The gameplay is a huge improvement from the older Metal Gear Solid games, blending what I love about those with more modern controls and mechanics. I can see this game having a ton of replay value just because I want to perfect my stealth skills. The game is also extremely cinematic even though there are fewer cutscenes. The cutscenes don't intrude or drag out like they have in the past, they were concise, interesting, and well directed.

review:
Two things about this game:

1: It's so short that it's a terrible value for money.
2: I've never wanted extra MGS content more than right now.

I got this game for $9.50 from a Brazilian site, and it barely broke even on actual gameplay time; that said, it's solid proof that I absolutely must have MGS 5. Some of the MGS'es as of late have been less than fantastic, in particular MGS4 and Peace Walker; MG Revengeance was a Bayonetta game in disguise. MGS: GZ is the best gameplay that an MGS game has ever had, and I'm so thrilled with the plotline. I'll be less excited when the inevitable happens and events play out like they did way back on the MSX, but that's how it goes, I guess.

BUY IT if it's cheap. You're paying money for a game demo, but there's no better game demo to be paying money for.

review:
tl;dr
Game is buggy.
Buy now, play later.

I haven't been able to play it all that much because the option to invert the Y-axis, simply doesn't. I've looked around for a solution that doesn't require me to install another program. I found that this game is really buggy. From small things like no audible voice audio in the opening scenes(thats as far as i got) to simply not starting.
Don't get me wrong, the game is magnificent. Despite all the bugs for keyboard/mouse the controller works for most people.
I'd tell you to buy it, it's on sale currently for nearly $13.50.
Buy it and then sit on it till the bugs are worked out. Or if you don't really care about money, wait till it's fixed and play it then. Im frustrated I can't play this game comfortably.
and just for fun... theres a xof patch near the edge of the cliff at the beginning! 
muahahhaha

review:
This game is dope. I'm familiar with the MGS series and have played all the other games in the series - with Rising and the one for Game Boy Advance being the expections - I have been waiting for this - overjoyed it came to PC.

The system requirements seem like an overshot so people do not attempt to run this on old builds and get the right sort of experience while playing. If you read the other reviews - you'll see there are people using Core 2 Duos that had no problem playing. With that out the way - with any decent card - you can turn up on this game and get nothing but smooth, solid gameplay.

(i5 2500k overclocked to 4.3, 8 GB, GTX 770 2 GB - so above average build)

Being burned on AAA titles this year that played like crap - I hesitated to test my system - moved to extra high on all levels and it didn't break a sweat. The game looks amazing and sound quality really sells the world.
 
This PC move has been done with attention and care

Even if you're new or do not follow the MGS series - this game could be the start of just that - give it a shot!

review:
People will tell you this game is horrible because it's so short, and to a certain extend they are right. If a person isn't a Metal Gear fan, I can't recommend this game. The true value of this game is the replayability and the Side Ops, both of which would not be attractive to your average gamer. I, however, love Metal Gear to the extent where I have played each game multiple times and I actually own Ground Zeroes on PS3, PS4, and now PC and I can honestly say if you're willing to devote the effort to learning how to git gud, this game is an amazing value.

Another things that may be a turn off is the story. In order to enjoy the story to it's fullest extend, you should play all the other Metal Gear Solid games, although only MGS3 and MGS:PW are truly "required" to understand the story. If you don't care for story though, the gameplay is so refined it's just an amazing game. I recommend it 10x.
